fields.headline: The best jam scene:   Sweet and Lowdown
fields.trailText: Having performed that evening in a downtown nightclub, jazz guitar genius Emmett Ray (Sean Penn) leaves with a group of new-found acquaintances. Shortly after he arrives at their house, he sits at the kitchen table, putting a handgun down on the table.
fields.body:
Having performed that evening in a downtown nightclub, jazz guitar genius Emmett Ray (Sean Penn) leaves with a group of new-found acquaintances. Shortly after he arrives at their house, he sits at the kitchen table, putting a handgun down on the table.

"Hey, hey!"

"What you got there?"

Emmett beams proudly.

".45."

".45. Hey! Emmett Ray!"

Suddenly, Emmett's eyes light up.

"You wanna go to the dump? Shoot some rats?"

Silence falls over the room.

"Huh?"

"Rats. Come on, I do it all the time. It's a lot of fun."

Silence descends once more.

Cut to Emmett and his companions, jamming in the front room. Emmett's playing is effortlessly brilliant.

Cut to Emmett, back in the kitchen.

"Hey, Emmett. Where d'you learn to play the guitar like that?"

"Yeah, I never heard a guitar sound so good."

"Yeah," Emmett replies, "I'm the greatest in the world. Well, you know - the greatest in the world except Django."

"Django? You know he's coming to America this summer to record?"

Emmett's face falls.

"Oh yeah?"

Cut to Emmett, wandering back through the front room. Casually, he picks up an ashtray and stuffs it inside his jacket pocket. Later, as he walks down the street at dawn, he retrieves it and throws it to the floor.

Cut to the modern-day jazz aficionado Ben Duncan (Himself): "Well, I heard stories that he was a kleptomaniac..."

See also: This Is Spinal Tap, Back To The Future

Don't see also: Still Crazy

Pointless trivia: Sean Penn starred with his brother Chris and his mother Eileen in the 1986 thriller At Close Range.

fields.headline: Failure beckons 'worst team in history'
fields.standfirst: Germany have not been forced out in the opening round since 1984, writes Jon Brodkin in Rotterdam
fields.trailText: Germany have not been forced out in the opening round since 1984, writes Jon Brodkin in Rotterdam.
fields.body:
There could hardly have been more talk of departures if Erich Ribbeck had switched training from Feyenoord to a runway at Rotterdam airport. The coach awoke yesterday to speculation about who will succeed him. The Germans are so pessimistic about making the quarter-finals that their flight home is booked for tomorrow.

Publicly Ribbeck insisted the passports might not be needed for a while yet. Certainly no one will be taking a suitcase to the stadium tonight. But if a reminder was needed of how low things have sunk in the public's mind it came in yesterday's Bild. "The worst team in the history of mankind," screamed the paper, clearly not au fait with some of the Halifax Town sides of the last millennium.

England might find Saturday's 1-0 win somewhat devalued by that assessment. Even accepting that expectations in Germany tend to be higher than at the Shay, such fatalism seems over the top. The scenario that would take Ribbeck's team to the next round is hardly inconceivable: that they manage a more convincing win over Portugal here than Romania record against England in Charleroi.

The Portuguese, after all, are through to the next round and will be resting several key players. And if anyone ought to believe in remarkable late twists it is the Germans. On the final day of the Bundesliga season Bayer Leverkusen needed only a point at tiny Unterhaching to take the title but lost to hand the championship to Bayern Munich. Bayern might also recall an unexpected mishap against Manchester United.

Yet self-belief and spirit have drained. After the negativity and infighting, convincing the players they can succeed could be difficult. Some might even prefer the thought of a barbe cue at home on Saturday to further criticism. "This looks virtually impossible," said the Bayern goalkeeper Oliver Kahn. "But we'll try to win."

Ribbeck, determined to prevent the defending champions from slipping out of a major tournament in the opening round for the first time since 1984, was more optimistic. "Our situation is not as bad and hopeless as many people think," he insisted, though his own fate seems settled.

His contract expires this summer and when he meets the German Football Federation (DFB) it will not be so much a case of "arise Sir Erich" as "kindly depart". Giovanni Trappatoni, once in charge of Italy, has expressed an interest. But the job is more likely to go to the Leverkusen coach Christoph Daum.

With Leverkusen unwilling to release Daum, word is that he will combine the jobs of club and country for a year before taking over full-time. That would mean Germany meeting England in their World Cup qualifier on October 7 with a part-time manager.

The DFB failed to lure Daum before Ribbeck stepped in two years ago because of his contract. But the incoming DFB head Gerhard Mayer-Vorfelder, president of VfB Stuttgart when Daum won the title there, is apparently determined to get his man. A great believer in psychology, Daum forced his players to walk on broken glass before the start of last season to make them believe that if they wanted something enough they could do it.

Franz Beckenbauer has said he does not want the job again and what lies ahead for Ribbeck is unclear. The 63-year-old will be tainted by two unwanted stains of national failure. He was Jupp Derwall's assistant at that European Championship exit of 1984, and although Germany reached a World Cup final two years later, few sense a repeat.

Though in one breath Ribbeck insisted a rebuilding process was just beginning, he also admitted: "There are not many talented young players available in Germany." His loyalty to the ageing Lothar Matthäus has symbolised his struggle to rejuvenate the team.

Tonight Matthäus will win his 150th - and most likely final - cap before riding off into the sunset on his Zimmer frame. "I would prefer that this would be my 27th cap," the 39-year-old said, "because some idiots say I just want to complete the 150 and that's not the case".

Great hope is invested in Sebastian Deisler, the 20-year-old who caused problems down England's left. But Kahn acknowledged: "When it comes to outstanding players we have neither the quantity nor the quality."

Although Ribbeck maintained this was not the worst Germany team for "hundreds and thousands of years" and said his side had played "quite decently" against England, he must be delighted to find that Portugal are resting key men. Luis Figo and Joao Pinto, who were nursing bruised shins after the 1-0 win over Romania, could be among them.

Of course the replacements will seek to prove their worth ahead of the quarter-final and Portugal's coach Humberto Coelho was making the right noises. "This is a top international tournament and Portugal has a responsibility," he said. "That means obviously that we are not that relaxed and we'll try to win the game."

Parma's playmaker Paulo Sousa, Lazio's winger Sergio Conceicao and the Deportivo La Coruna striker Pauleta could all be included. Saturday's goalscorer Costinha is expected to fill in at right-back, where Abel Xavier and Carlos Secretario are injured.

It is a sign of Portugal's confidence that they have booked their hotel until the final day of the tournament. Yet their rapid progress has not come without tensions between Coelho and the press. The normally mild-mannered coach was upset at reports that Saturday's performance was laboured and that players had been negotiating contracts at the hotel. He dismissed claims that English teams were admitted to speak to Joao Pinto.

"We set ourselves an objective and we achieved it," he said. "Normally at this stage we'd be on the beach or watching it on television."

Normally, of course, Germany would be thinking ahead to playing in the final not watching it on the box. But this time they think it's all over. By 10 o'clock tonight they expect to know that it is now.

fields.headline: AOL faces European probe
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: America Online's $130bn (£86bn) merger with Time Warner faces a four-month investigation by Europe's competition commission over concerns that the combined group might have too much influence over online music distribution, the cost of dialing up internet and the information posted in cyberspace.
fields.body:
America Online's $130bn (£86bn) merger with Time Warner faces a four-month investigation by Europe's competition commission over concerns that the combined group might have too much influence over online music distribution, the cost of dialing up internet and the information posted in cyberspace.

Yesterday's announcement by the European commission came as AOL announced a new interactive television service which will allow viewers in three US test cities to email their friends while watching their favourite programmes.

Bob Pittman, president of AOL, said the idea would allow customers to talk about the content of TV. "I can't tell you the number of Americans who talk back to their TV - including me - and now I can talk to other people about the TV."

Viewers will also be able to log on to chat rooms about each programme as they watch it, while an enhanced search engine will make it easier for them to find the programme, out of up to 300 channels available, they want to watch more quickly.

Subscribers will also be able to access their "buddy list", which shows them if their friends are logged on. The move into television is part of AOL's drive to become more than an internet company, and is also driven by its desire to merge with Time Warner. Once that deal is completed, the set-top boxes which the TV service requires could be eliminated by installing them inside Time Warner's cable television boxes.

The European commission's decision means that Time Warner faces its second competition investigation in just four days after the competition body's move last week to look at the impact of its musical joint venture with EMI.

The new investigation about its merger with AOL is based on the premise that AOL will have "preferential access to the leading source of music publishing rights and music repertoire in most member states" as result of the deal. The commission will investigate whether the combined group would become a "gatekeeper" of music on the net if it has the power to dictate the technical standards for distributing music on the net.

"The main competition issue raised by the merger is the vertical integration of Time Warner content with AOL online services," the commission said. AOL, which is still awaiting approval for the merger from the US authorities, was yesterday trying to differentiate its new television venture, AOLTV, from WebTV which has been launched by Microsoft to a slow start.

"WebTV tried to turn your TV into a computer," Mr Pittman told CNBC. "The idea is not to make your TV a computer but rather to enhance the TV experience."

After its launch in the three US cities of Phoenix, Sacramento and Baltimore, AOLTV will go on sale across the US and internationally, including Britain. TV viewers will need to buy a set-top box and pay a monthly fee.

Analysts said that AOL might have a better chance of winning customers for its TV service because it already has 23m customers for its internet service, while WebTV has struggled to attract 1m customers in the three years since its launch. However, it will have to persuade them to buy the box and pay out the additional subscriber fees.

Useful links

AOL

fields.headline: Military and technology
fields.standfirst:
Dance Project
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Even in his relatively public role as artistic director of Meltdown, Scott Walker remains conspicuous by his absence. However, he made his presence felt over the festival's opening weekend with Thimble Rigging, a new score composed by Walker for the Richard Alston Dance Company, with choreography by Martin Lawrance.
fields.body:
Even in his relatively public role as artistic director of Meltdown, Scott Walker remains conspicuous by his absence. However, he made his presence felt over the festival's opening weekend with Thimble Rigging, a new score composed by Walker for the Richard Alston Dance Company, with choreography by Martin Lawrance.

A prefatory caption informed us that medieval sufferers from psoriasis were known as "the silver people", leaving onlookers free to puzzle over how that related to the piece at hand. It seemed that we had been transported to a world of militaristic oppression, since guards were mounted beside the stage while dancers in army-like uniforms marched in front of us. Walker's music alternated between a plaintive minor-key theme assembled from voice samples and drones, and slabs of crushing machine-like noise, driven by a ferocious electronic drumbeat. For what one took to be the silver people, dressed in wispy knitwear that had seen better days, Walker had concocted layers of slow and eerie electronica. There were more questions than answers, but at least you felt they were worth asking.

Then we had to wait outside for an hour while the stage was rebuilt so that all-female dance septet the Cholmondeleys could perform a new score by digital mood-meisters, Orbital. When they let us back in, the hall was swimming in dry ice, while the stage was covered with rows of computer-controlled lighting pods which divided the performing area into a giant grid.

Orbital's score was crisp and pacy, its precise cross-rhythms mirrored in both the Chums's urgent motion and the geometrical patterning of the stage. With the lighting mainly restricted to broody blues and purples, it was difficult to focus on individual dancers, who had rendered themselves extra anonymous by wearing similar hand-painted body suits. But the music grew increasingly tuneful and optimistic as the piece progressed. What you remembered about the piece wasn't the dancing or Lea Anderson's choreography, but the music and the technical expertise behind the production. Fine by me, though dance aficionados may feel differently.

fields.headline: Bored at work
fields.trailText: 20 June: I work for an IT company in a good job, with good pay, but the fact is that I find my job very unfulfilling.
fields.body:
The problem

I work for an IT company in a good job, with good pay, but the fact is that I find my job very unfulfilling. I have often thought about leaving but I have a number of stock options in the company that mature over the next 12 months, and they are definitely worth waiting around for. I will have enough to take a fairly large cut in pay if I wish, or even to start my own business.

I've realised since starting my job just over 3 years ago that I don't want to spend the rest of my life working 9-5 for someone else. I often think that maybe it's just boredom and I would enjoy working in another industry. My educational background is in arts and humanities, rather than IT.

The solution

Maybe expecting to wake up every morning feeling excited about going to work is a bit much to expect, but you should certainly be getting more job satisfaction than your are currently enjoying.

The great thing going for you is that fact that you have a year to choose and embark on a new career direction. This is ideal and prevents all those impulsive mistakes that people in your situation sometimes make (such as packing the job in without having anything to go to, or jumping into the first opportunity that comes their way.)

There are three steps that you should take:

Assess Yourself. This means that you need to find out where your skills lie and what personal qualities you have (do you have leadership potential, decision-making ability, communication skill, problem solving ability, etc.) This takes a great deal of self-analysis and involves looking back to see how you handled incidents previously to pick out the skills you used - and those that are weaker or in need of development. There is no point setting up your own business if you don't have the requisite skills and qualities to make it succeed.

The best way to assess yourself is to either find yourself a good book (the renowned What Colour is Your Parachute? is brilliant) or a careers counsellor (in the Yellow Pages or, if you are a graduate, go to any university careers centre.)

Once you really know yourself, you will need to find a match with careers or professions out there. There are computer programmes or pen and paper tests that will do this for you, which is why consulting a careers advisor can be so helpful (since they will have access to these tests.)

Now that you know what you want to do, the final step involves planning a short- and long-term strategy to get you going. This should involve identifying training you might need, funding, jobs, opportunities, etc., as well as some sort of plan as to how you might progress over the next five years. You should also build in a maternity break if this is in your plans.

Follow this three-step plan, get a good careers guidance book (or seek advice from a good careers advisor) and I am sure you will make a successful transition to a new and exciting future.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

fields.headline: Precious moments
fields.standfirst:
Balanchine's Jewels
Royal Opera House, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: George Balanchine was a product of the old St Petersburg ballet and he never forgot his roots, even after he had settled in New York and reinvented ballet for 20th-century America. When US companies dance his works, St Petersburg feels like an echo refracted through their modern minds and bodies but when the Kirov dance them, the reverse tends to occur. The past becomes the present while contemporary America contracts to a few stylistic mannerisms.
fields.body:
George Balanchine was a product of the old St Petersburg ballet and he never forgot his roots, even after he had settled in New York and reinvented ballet for 20th-century America. When US companies dance his works, St Petersburg feels like an echo refracted through their modern minds and bodies but when the Kirov dance them, the reverse tends to occur. The past becomes the present while contemporary America contracts to a few stylistic mannerisms.

When the Kirov dance Jewels this cultural inversion becomes really interesting. The ballet is created in three distinct, historical sections: Emeralds, which is soft and playful, haunted by the sylphs of Romantic ballet; Diamonds, an evocation of late 19th-century grandeur and Rubies, the centrepiece, strutting the avenues of New York, jazzed up and full of bounce.

Yet even where the choreo-graphy is steeped in the past, it is also unmistakeably Balanchine and for some Kirov dancers the tension between old and new seems hard to achieve. In Emeralds, Balanchine's trademark staccato rhythms and adrenaline surges are sometimes awkward-looking hiccups in the dancers' lyrical flow, while in Rubies the corps de ballet do not always look strong or brazen enough to revel in their pin-up girl poses.

webTitle: VMR may join Durlacher's expansion drive

fields.headline: VMR may join Durlacher's expansion drive
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Durlacher, the internet investment company behind Autonomy and 365 Corporation, has confirmed that it is talking to a German technology firm backed by the Barclay brothers about a merger that could accelerate its expansion plans in Europe.
fields.body:
Durlacher, the internet investment company behind Autonomy and 365 Corporation, has confirmed that it is talking to a German technology firm backed by the Barclay brothers about a merger that could accelerate its expansion plans in Europe.

It is understood that Durlacher's chief executive, Geoffrey Chamberlain, has been talking to Value Management Research for some weeks, although several issues still need to be ironed out.

In a statement to the stock exchange, Durlacher said it was talking to VMR and "a small number of European companies" in line with its aim of expanding across the continent through "best of breed" mergers or acquisitions.

It said that any partners would need to have the same management ethos and share a belief in Durlacher's research-driven business model.

Confirmation of the talks follows a sharp fall in Durlacher's share price from the heights it enjoyed at the start of this year. In March the once ob scure stockbroker carried a market value of almost £2bn, but the sell-off in technology stocks has reduced its worth to around £390m.

However, Durlacher sources insisted the VMR talks were driven by long-term group strategy rather than a desire to boost its capital resources or share price.

"We have said all along that international expansion is our prime objective in the short-term and it was just a question of finding like minded partners with whom to work," said one Durlacher insider.

VMR is run by Florian Homm, a former Merrill Lynch executive, and is very similar to Durlacher in that it is a research-driven internet specialist. It has 23 funds under management and holds stakes in 36 companies that it aims to bring to the market.

Earlier this year VMR attracted the attention of David "Spotty" Rowland, a low-profile and long-term Durlacher client, who was an early investor in Autonomy and Demon Internet.

Mr Rowland took an 18% stake through Jellyworks, the internet incubator fronted by his 24-year-old son Jonathan.

The Barclays, long-term family friends and neighbours in both Monaco and the Channel Islands, bought a 4% stake at the same time. David Barclay's son Howard joined the Jellyworks board.

Durlacher already has a small office in Bonn, Germany and will shortly open a unit in Madrid, but believes it needs local partners if it is to replicate the success it has had in the UK. The shares slipped 2.5p to 78.5p.

fields.headline: ONdigital feud heads for tribunal
fields.trailText: ONdigital faces the embarrassing prospect of fighting legal action against a former director widely regarded as having played a crucial role in the pay television broadcaster's launch.
fields.body:
ONdigital faces the embarrassing prospect of fighting legal action against a former director widely regarded as having played a crucial role in the pay television broadcaster's launch.

John Egan, the former director of operations and strategy, has made a claim for a £100,000 bonus which was tied to the successful launch of the pay television service but which he says was only ever half paid.

Mr Egan, who left the company last September after more than two years of employment, is also seeking damages for unfair dismissal and for a second bonus he claims not to have received last year. He was one of a stream of management departures from ONdigital last autumn.

Mr Egan has subpoenaed the former ONdigital chief executive, Stephen Grabiner, to appear at the industrial tri bunal and has requested subpoenas for Carlton Communications' chief executive, Michael Green, and its executive director and chairman, Nigel Walmsley. The hearing has been set for 10.00am next Monday in east Croydon.

Mr Egan said: "Whether or not the launch of ONdigital was a success is the crux of this issue. At the time all of the shareholders were widely quoted as saying how successful they thought it was. But two months later we were told it hadn't been judged a success and so the bonuses weren't paid. Are they really going to say that the launch wasn't successful?"

Mr Egan claims that half the bonuses were later paid.

ONdigital, which is jointly owned by ITV companies Granada and Carlton Communications, launched in November 1998 and has since signed up around 700,000 customers. The company is expected to pass the 1m mark by the end of this year. "ONdigi tal was a world first and it launched on time and in budget. Of course some shops ran out of set-top boxes but that is because the launch was a success," Mr Egan said.

He has also made a request for access to management accounts for last year showing the take up of subscriptions and revenues earned.

Mr Egan is the second of ONdigital's launch directors to threaten legal action, following a claim for compensation from Mr Grabiner which was settled out of court. Mr Egan's departure was the third senior loss at ONdigital within two months. Mr Grabiner quit to join venture capital firm Apax Partners, while commercial director Jim Ratcliffe also left last summer.

The departures were compounded by the resignation of Ashley Faull, ONdigital's head of programming.

Both ONdigital and Carlton declined to comment on the proceedings.

Analysts have warmed to the current chief executive, Stuart Prebble ,and the company is likely to be floated on the stockmarket within the next year. Valuations of between £1.5bn and £2bn have been put on the business.

Carlton recently appointed investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter to advise on the future strategy of the business. The pay-TV company has successfully exploited the rights to the Uefa Champions League and recently competed in the auction for the Premiership rights where it was outgunned by larger rivals BSkyB and NTL. By way of a consolation prize it picked up the Nationwide Football League, which it plans to screen on a new premium sports channel.

It has recently launched a pay-per-view movie service and email via the television.

Mr Egan has since set up his own business, Sit-up.com, which aims to launch an interactive pay-TV auction channel on satellite later this year.

webTitle: White's hat-trick throws spluttering Spitfires into relegation dogfight

fields.headline: White's hat-trick throws spluttering Spitfires into relegation dogfight
fields.standfirst:
Yorkshire Phoenix 163-9
Kent Spitfires 139
Yorkshire won by 24 runs
fields.trailText:
Yorkshire Phoenix 163-9
Kent Spitfires 139
Yorkshire won by 24 runs
fields.body:
After more than four weeks of anxiety over his health and fitness, Craig White made a stunning return to the county game yesterday with a hat-trick for Yorkshire that propelled them to a 24-run win over Kent.

The victory was Yorkshire's third of the season and plunges the Spitfires, still struggling desperately for batting confidence, deeper into the fight to avoid relegation from the National League First Division. They have only one win from their first seven matches.

White emerged as the star of the show in the 42nd over, in which he broke a threatening partnership between the Kent captain Matthew Fleming and the left-hander Paul Nixon that had yielded 41 runs in nine overs.

White, having just been planted over extra cover for four, had Fleming caught by Michael Vaughan at backward point, the captain having hit 29 from 28 balls with three fours as well as a massive six over midwicket at the expense of Matthew Hoggard.

The wicket effectively ended Kent's hopes of winning, but White was not finished. His next two deliveries were straight and true and brought lbw decisions against Min Patel and David Masters to give the England-contracted all-rounder his hat-trick, the second of his career in all forms of cricket, and final figures of three for 27 from eight overs on his comeback.

His first spell of five overs had been uneventful, steady but lacking in penetration as he conceded 12 runs without breaking through.

Yorkshire's bowling, on a slow pitch that inhibited stroke play, was too venomous for Kent. Chris Silverwood dismissed both openers and then bowled the last man Kristian Adams to claim three for 16 and the off-spinner James Middlebrook took three for 24 to undermine the middle order.

The crucial wicket, however, was taken by Hoggard, who ended a grafting innings of 49 by Rahul Dravid, who reached the boundary only three times but who showed infinite patience on a tricky surface.

Apart from Fleming and Nixon, there was not much else of substance about Kent's batting, which remains fragile in all competitions and is the biggest worry for Fleming and the coach John Wright.

Yorkshire's total was founded on a well-crafted 52 by David Byas, who has been accustomed to opening the innings this season but this time held himself back until No5.

He came in at 38 for three and saw two more wickets fall for the addition of only six runs before he and his fellow left-hander Gavin Hamilton cemented the innings to some extent with a stand of 51 in 18 overs.

They were never on top of the bowling and even the captain managed only five boundaries in his 96-ball innings before he was caught at extra cover to give Mark Ealham his third wicket in the final over.

Hamilton made 21 but White contributed only four runs to Yorkshire's total before he ran himself out when he took on Fleming and was beaten by his swift throw to the wicketkeeper from deep midwicket.

webTitle: Down the England card and out the door for Lord's?

fields.headline: Down the England card and out the door for Lord's?
fields.standfirst: David Hopps rates Hussain's men on first test form and second test prospects
fields.trailText: David Hopps rates Hussain's men on first Test form and second Test prospects
fields.body:
Michael Atherton

Age 32. Tests 98. Runs this match: 20,19

It is not so long ago that all the talk was of phasing Michael Atherton out of the England side. The exhausting combination of injury (pain in the back) and the England captaincy (pain in the neck) seemed to have knocked the edge from his game. Not only county cricket no longer seemed worth getting out of bed for. That impression was entirely banished with a hundred against South Africa in Port Elizabeth last winter, and another against Zimbabwe at Trent Bridge. Atherton resisted with courage and skill at Edgbaston, and he seemed to possess a game plan designed to respond to an uneven pitch, which was more than could be said for some of his team-mates, but his test average has now slipped noticeably below 40 and may never achieve such heights again. He will have to grind on, all the same. Survival rating: Certain.

Mark Ramprakash

Age 30. Tests 41. Runs this match: 18, 0

For England to try to convert Mark Ramprakash into an opening batsman at the age of 30, when most people are past changing, is an ambitious project which, at best, has a 50-50 chance of success. The move was forced by a series of factors: the unimpressive form of Mark Butcher at test level, the failure of Darren Maddy to develop, the wish to nurture Michael Vaughan in the middle order and the perception that Nick Knight's technique is too chancy for a place at the top of the order. Ramprakash's technique and intensity both suggested that opening was an option worth trying. But Courtney Walsh twice dismissed him in Birmingham with moderate deliveries to make one yearn for less style and more substance. Whether opening or at number six, a fine talent remains forever imprisoned. Survival rating: Reasonable.

Nasser Hussain

Age 32. Tests 50. Runs this match: 15, 8

Only Darren Gough received a warmer welcome at Edgbaston than Nasser Hussain, which is a mark of how much Hussain has risen in English affections since he took on the captaincy. It is a task he has approached with commitment, intelligence and shrewdness. Hussain's impatience with the short-termism and emotional extremes of the media is understandable, but England's dressing room sulk on Friday night, when they shunned all requests for interviews, is a worrying indication of a siege mentality that he should have the sense to nip in the bud. What Hussain needs above all is an end to a dreadful run of batting form with some runs for Essex before Lord's. A nonsensical county programme is not about to help; with the days at their longest, the season is now given over to a series of floodlit one-day matches. Survival rating: Certain.

Graeme Hick

Age 34. Tests 57. Runs this match: 0, 0

Before West Indies intervened, Graeme Hick had never had a pair in his entire career. Frankly, who cares? The Hick comeback has become one of the most predictable happenings of an English test summer. However much his fellow professionals are awed by his power, however much Duncan Fletcher believes that he will be the coach who finally unlocks Hick's talent, the fact is that the nation is deeply cynical about his chances of success. It is conceivable that Hick did not touch the ball from which he was adjudged caught at the wicket in England's second innings, and such extenuating circumstances will doubtless be presented in his favour. Hick should be the most vulnerable to a challenge from Yorkshire's fit-again Michael Vaughan, who could and should have played at Edgbaston. Survival rating: Reasonable.

Alec Stewart

Age 37. Tests 98. Runs this match: 6, 8

Those looking for an England scapegoat are unlikely to settle for long upon the figure of Alec Stewart. Such is the vim of England's elder statesman that the prospect is not of a test axing but of a glorious return to the one-day side for next month's triangular series. The dropping of Stewart for the one-day series against South Africa in favour of Nottinghamshire's Chris Read is now spoken of as a dreadful mistake. Stewart's fitness, form and dedication makes his age immaterial, and suggests that he should start marketing health drinks as soon as possible. A technique developed on the true, bouncy pitches of the Oval always made him particularly vulnerable to the crabby, uneven bounce at Edgbaston. Give him some decent surfaces and he can still provide England with some of their most memorable moments this summer. Survival rating: Certain.

Nick Knight

Age 30. Tests 15. Runs this match: 26, 34

Nick Knight presents a problem; a big problem. He was chosen against Zimbabwe as the short-term replacement for the injured Michael Vaughan, kept on for his home ground of Edgbaston even though Vaughan was fit, and sod's law duly intervened as he top-scored in both England innings - albeit only with 26 and 34. That Knight batted pluckily against the West Indies quicks in the second innings cannot be denied. But England's selectors now face a classic dilemma of their own making: do they keep faith with a batsman of exemplary attitude, even though they have limited faith in his ability to cut it at test level? Or do they revert to Vaughan, thank Knight profusely for his sterling efforts and sweet-talk him about being a key element in the one-day side? It is their problem; let them sort it out. Survival rating: Reasonable.

Andrew Flintoff

Age 22. Tests 9. Runs this match: 16, 12. Wickets: 1-48

Andrew Flintoff had his best test of the summer at Edgbaston. Andrew Flintoff had his best test of the summer at Edgbaston. It needs saying twice because Lancashire's man-mountain has attracted increasing criticism in the three tests to date. But he is the only batsman under the age of 30 - whatever happened to the media-fuelled push for youth at the end of last summer? Flintoff is a potentially devastating batsman who needs to play adventurously, but at Edgbaston twice had a platform slightly less stable than the Millennium Bridge. He will launch Courtney into the stands before the summer is out. His clumping fast-medium bowling was also a bonus; in hindsight, it was about as good as things got. Survival rating: Good.

Robert Croft

Age 30. Tests 16. Runs: 18, 1. Wickets: 2-53.

Those who contend that England's sporting failures can be laid largely at the door of a destructive media should carefully consider the story of Robert Croft. The Welshman's recall last week might have brought cries of "Is that what we have come to?" but instead it was greeted with optimistic noises about a new Crofty, awash with adventure, mystery and variety. It was the most riskily upbeat message since Ian Austin was presented as a po tential World Cup star a year ago. In the final analysis, Croft did well enough. He did bowl with more ambition and guile than of old, held England's attack together at times, and the West Indies' plethora of left-handers makes it entirely logical that he retains his place ahead of Lancashire's tyro leg-spinner, Chris Schofield. Survival rating: Good.

Andrew Caddick

Age 31. Tests 33. Runs: 21*, 4. Wickets: 2-94.

Andrew Caddick is another England player whose survival for Lord's will be automatic. He did, after all, return from last winter's tour of South Africa with his reputation enhanced, not least for a seven-wicket haul in Durban which gave England considerable hopes - eventually unrealised - of victory. At Edgbaston, though, Caddick was a disappointment. He is something of a perfectionist, who would like all his test wickets to be dismissed in classical fashion - lift and bounce from a perfect length, causing the batsman to be bowled or caught behind - and he still seems at a loss how to respond when life is not quite so simple. Disputes rage whether Caddick or the Edgbaston pitch went to sleep when the West Indian batsmen grabbed the initiative on the second day, but he is the best practitioner of his art that England possess. Survival rating: Certain.

Darren Gough

Age 29. Tests 39. Runs: 23, 23*. Wickets: 5-109.

What Darren Gough most urgently needs is a pair of blinkers, so that he can no longer see the Freeserve Speedster. Gough has developed a dangerous obsession with the Speedster, which records the pace of every delivery bowled, and in the England dressing room he sometimes talks of little else. Things conceivably could be worse - imagine if he had fallen for the stump-cam instead and gazed longingly into it after every delivery. Blinkers or not, Gough has begun the summer with wonderful ebullience. He was England's best player at Edgbaston, including Brian Lara in a haul of five wickets, bearing a heavy workload uncomplainingly and even batting with a gusto that has not been seen for years. The system of central contracts has been good for him, however much Yorkshire might disagree. Survival rating: Certain.

Ed Giddins

Age 28. Tests 4. Runs: 0, 0. Wickets: 0-73.

Ed Giddins also made a pair at Lord's, although it was certainly not his first and, unlike that of Graeme Hick here, passed with barely a comment. It is Giddins' fast-medium bowling that will particularly concern the selectors. He bowled well at Lord's when the ball swung, and moderately at Edgbaston, his home ground, when it did not. He does not hit the pitch hard enough, quick enough, or from a great enough height, to be hugely assisted by surfaces of uneven bounce. There are sound arguments for retaining Giddins: he bowled well at Lord's against Zimbabwe only a few weeks ago; Steve Harmison, a potential debutant, is now injured; and Ed is a confident soul who is capable of surviving a setback or two. In fact, if they play the loyalty card determinedly enough, England's selectors could just about name an unchanged team. Survival rating: Reasonable.

A nonsensical county programme is not about to help; with the days at their longest, the season is now given over to a series of floodlit one-day matches. Survival rating: Certain. Graeme Hick Age 34. Tests 57. Runs this match: 0, 0 Before West Indies intervened, Graeme Hick had never had a pair in his entire career. Frankly, who cares? The Hick comeback has become one of the most predictable happenings of an English test summer. However much his fellow professionals are awed by his power, however much Duncan Fletcher believes that he will be the coach who finally unlocks Hick's talent, the fact is that the nation is deeply cynical about his chances of success. It is conceivable that Hick did not touch the ball from which he was adjudged caught at the wicket in England's second innings, and such extenuating circumstances will doubtless be presented in his favour. Hick should be the most vulnerable to a challenge from Yorkshire's fit-again Michael Vaughan, who could and should have played at Edgbaston. Survival rating: Reasonable. Alec Stewart Age 37. Tests 98. Runs this match: 6, 8 Those looking for an England scapegoat are unlikely to settle for long upon the figure of Alec Stewart. Such is the vim of England's elder statesman that the prospect is not of a test axing but of a glorious return to the one-day side for next month's triangular series. The dropping of Stewart for the one-day series against South Africa in favour of Nottinghamshire's Chris Read is now spoken of as a dreadful mistake. Stewart's fitness, form and dedication makes his age immaterial, and suggests that he should start marketing health drinks as soon as possible. A technique developed on the true, bouncy pitches of the Oval always made him particularly vulnerable to the crabby, uneven bounce at Edgbaston. Give him some decent surfaces and he can still provide England with some of their most memorable moments this summer. Survival rating: Certain. Nick Knight Age 30. Tests 15. Runs this match: 26, 34 Nick Knight presents a problem; a big problem. He was chosen against Zimbabwe as the short-term replacement for the injured Michael Vaughan, kept on for his home ground of Edgbaston even though Vaughan was fit, and sod's law duly intervened as he top-scored in both England innings - albeit only with 26 and 34. That Knight batted pluckily against the West Indies quicks in the second innings cannot be denied. But England's selectors now face a classic dilemma of their own making: do they keep faith with a batsman of exemplary attitude, even though they have limited faith in his ability to cut it at test level? Or do they revert to Vaughan, thank Knight profusely for his sterling efforts and sweet-talk him about being a key element in the one-day side? It is their problem; let them sort it out. Survival rating: Reasonable. Andrew Flintoff Age 22. Tests 9. Runs this match: 16, 12. Wickets: 1-48 Andrew Flintoff had his best test of the summer at Edgbaston. Andrew Flintoff had his best test of the summer at Edgbaston. It needs saying twice because Lancashire's man-mountain has attracted increasing criticism in the three tests to date. But he is the only batsman under the age of 30 - whatever happened to the media-fuelled push for youth at the end of last summer? Flintoff is a potentially devastating batsman who needs to play adventurously, but at Edgbaston twice had a platform slightly less stable than the Millennium Bridge. He will launch Courtney into the stands before the summer is out. His clumping fast-medium bowling was also a bonus; in hindsight, it was about as good as things got. Survival rating: Good. Robert Croft Age 30. Tests 16. Runs: 18, 1. Wickets: 2-53. Those who contend that England's sporting failures can be laid largely at the door of a destructive media should carefully consider the story of Robert Croft. The Welshman's recall last week might have brought cries of "Is that what we have come to?" but instead it was greeted with optimistic noises about a new Crofty, awash with adventure, mystery and variety. It was the most riskily upbeat message since Ian Austin was presented as a po tential World Cup star a year ago. In the final analysis, Croft did well enough. He did bowl with more ambition and guile than of old, held England's attack together at times, and the West Indies' plethora of left-handers makes it entirely logical that he retains his place ahead of Lancashire's tyro leg-spinner, Chris Schofield. Survival rating: Good. Andrew Caddick Age 31. Tests 33. Runs: 21*, 4. Wickets: 2-94. Andrew Caddick is another England player whose survival for Lord's will be automatic. He did, after all, return from last winter's tour of South Africa with his reputation enhanced, not least for a seven-wicket haul in Durban which gave England considerable hopes - eventually unrealised - of victory. At Edgbaston, though, Caddick was a disappointment. He is something of a perfectionist, who would like all his test wickets to be dismissed in classical fashion - lift and bounce from a perfect length, causing the batsman to be bowled or caught behind - and he still seems at a loss how to respond when life is not quite so simple. Disputes rage whether Caddick or the Edgbaston pitch went to sleep when the West Indian batsmen grabbed the initiative on the second day, but he is the best practitioner of his art that England possess. Survival rating: Certain. Darren Gough Age 29. Tests 39. Runs: 23, 23*. Wickets: 5-109. What Darren Gough most urgently needs is a pair of blinkers, so that he can no longer see the Freeserve Speedster. Gough has developed a dangerous obsession with the Speedster, which records the pace of every delivery bowled, and in the England dressing room he sometimes talks of little else. Things conceivably could be worse - imagine if he had fallen for the stump-cam instead and gazed longingly into it after every delivery. Blinkers or not, Gough has begun the summer with wonderful ebullience. He was England's best player at Edgbaston, including Brian Lara in a haul of five wickets, bearing a heavy workload uncomplainingly and even batting with a gusto that has not been seen for years. The system of central contracts has been good for him, however much Yorkshire might disagree. Survival rating: Certain. Ed Giddins Age 28. Tests 4. Runs: 0, 0. Wickets: 0-73. Ed Giddins also made a pair at Lord's, although it was certainly not his first and, unlike that of Graeme Hick here, passed with barely a comment. It is Giddins' fast-medium bowling that will particularly concern the selectors. He bowled well at Lord's when the ball swung, and moderately at Edgbaston, his home ground, when it did not. He does not hit the pitch hard enough, quick enough, or from a great enough height, to be hugely assisted by surfaces of uneven bounce. There are sound arguments for retaining Giddins: he bowled well at Lord's against Zimbabwe only a few weeks ago; Steve Harmison, a potential debutant, is now injured; and Ed is a confident soul who is capable of surviving a setback or two. In fact, if they play the loyalty card determinedly enough, England's selectors could just about name an unchanged team. Survival rating: Reasonable.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Somerset's unbeaten record, the last in the First Division of the CGU National League, was ended yesterday by Northamptonshire, who had the powerful young David Sales to thank for their 22-run win. By losing at Northampton, Somerset also missed the chance to climb back to the top of the table.
fields.body:
Somerset's unbeaten record, the last in the First Division of the CGU National League, was ended yesterday by Northamptonshire, who had the powerful young David Sales to thank for their 22-run win. By losing at Northampton, Somerset also missed the chance to climb back to the top of the table.

Sales top-scored with 72 as Northants set the imposing total of 251 for eight, with Mal Loye providing able support with 54. Marcus Trescothick - better known for his exploits with the bat - was the most successful Somerset bowler with four for 50 from nine overs.

Having slumped to 153 for eight the game looked up for Somerset, but Peter Bowler (69) and the tail-enders Adrian Pierson (31 not out) and Steffan Jones (27) gave them hope until they were eventually skittled for 229.

In the Second Division, Hampshire's steady improvement continued with an 18-run defeat of Durham at Basingstoke, ending a run of five successive defeats.

After winning the toss, Hampshire made 222 for five, largely down to John Stephenson who hit an unbeaten 83 and the captain Robin Smith who hit 43.

Durham's openers Paul Collingwood (51) and Muazam Ali (36) shared in an opening partnership of 95 but resistance after them was weak and, despite a last-wicket stand of 32 between Jonathan Lewis (55no) and Neil Killeen (21), the visitors' innings ended on 204. Alan Mullally took four for 40 for the hosts.

Derbyshire, who like Hampshire had also previously been without a win in the Second Division, also broke their duck with victory over Middlesex by 15 runs at Lord's.

Batting first after winning the toss, Derbyshire had Dominic Cork (64) and Simon Lacey (40) to thank as they racked up 186 for eight.

Justin Langer hit 56 in Middlesex's reply but the chase ended with the score on 171. Matt Cassar and Paul Aldred took three wickets each for the visitors.

In the county championship, the Second Division's bottom side, Glamorgan , denied Essex the win they needed to take over at the top.

Glamorgan, still without a victory, needed 250 to win, and were 177 for five at the close, with the combined efforts of Matthew Elliott (52), the captain Matthew Maynard (44), Michael Powell (34) and Adrian Dale (24 not out) thwarting unbeaten Essex, who had earlier been bowled out for 102.

fields.headline: Euro 2000 shorts
fields.trailText: • As Kevin Keegan's cavaliers left Charleroi after Saturday's historic win, the van carrying their kit caught fire and had to be abandoned at the roadside. None of the gear was damaged but the kit manager, Martin Grogan, had to phone for a lift and finally arrived at the England base in Spa in a replacement van at dawn yesterday.
fields.body:
 As Kevin Keegan's cavaliers left Charleroi after Saturday's historic win, the van carrying their kit caught fire and had to be abandoned at the roadside. None of the gear was damaged but the kit manager, Martin Grogan, had to phone for a lift and finally arrived at the England base in Spa in a replacement van at dawn yesterday.

 England's final group game, against Romania back in Charleroi tomorrow, will be refereed by the Swiss Urs Meier but the Englishman Graham Poll will be officiating for his future at Wednesday's game between Norway and Slovenia in Arnhem: after the first round the number of referees will be reduced from 13 to eight. The Egyptian Gamal El Ghandour looks likely to be one of the casualties. After a poor first game in Spain v Norway, El Ghandour has been appointed for Denmark v Czech Republic, the only completely dead rubber. "Frankly speaking," said the Spanish coach Jose Antonio Camacho of the unpopular official, "he is not up to this sort of game."

 Peter Schmeichel as vowed to play on until the 2002 World Cup for Denmark. The 36-year-old goalkeeper has 123 caps, 26 fewer than the current world record holder, Lothar Matthäus of Germany, and could overtake him if Den mark reached those finals.

 The French midfielder Patrick Vieira has come to the defence of his beleaguered captain Didier Deschamps. "What has been written about him is a disgrace," he said of the player he would replace if Roger Lemerre, the coach, heeds the critics' advice. "In any case, he is much better than me. He knows how to dictate the pace better than me. If I am not in the team, it is because I do not deserve it."

 Ruud van Nistelrooy, the Dutch striker whose involve ment in Euro 2000, like his transfer to Manchester United, was scuppered by injury, wants to be playing by Christmas. "I hope to be back on the training pitch in a few months," he told Dutch television. "If I look ahead I can see light at the end of the tunnel."

 Liverpool's Dietmar Hamann may be a big fan of his club team-mate Steven Gerrard, but he was less impressed with one of Gerrard's tackles on Saturday: "He caught me with quite a bad challenge, but I knew he would make that tackle so I jumped before he came." That is not Gerrard's view. "He was screaming like a girl," said the English youngster of the challenge, "and you can tell him that as well."

 Norway's Tore Andre Flo has admitted that he dislikes his country's style of play, even if he appreciates the results. "Playing for Norway is another game altogether," he said. "I prefer the way we play at Chelsea, but the most important thing is to get a good result. Our national style works well for us and I am happy to be part of it."

 The former Fiorentina and Bayern Munich manager Giovanni Trapattoni has said that he would be interested in succeeding Erich Ribbeck should the German coach be fired after Euro 2000. "It would be a great honour if the German football federation were to ask me," he said. The 61-year-old, who left Fiorentina at the end of last season, also admitted to being interested in the Italy job, which is less likely to become vacant as Dino Zoff is contracted until 2002. "I am not finished yet. The fire is still within me," he added.

 France's Nicolas Anelka may miss the crunch match against Holland with a swollen knee. "The knee has reacted because Anelka had to play two games in five days and he was not used to that," said the French team doctor Jean Marcel Ferret yesterday. "But it is too early yet to say if he will be able to play on Wednesday." The left-back Bixente Lizarazu and the Arsenal midfielder Emmanuel Petit both missed training yesterday and, while their injuries are not serious, are likely to be rested for Wednesday's game.

webTitle: French without tears but for England it is always a gas

fields.headline: French without tears but for England it is always a gas
fields.standfirst: Thierry Henry, says  Daniel Taylor, has been the leading man so far
fields.trailText: Daniel Taylor reviews the first week and previews the second.
fields.body:
Euro 2000 tiptoes into its second week this morning with the sense of anticipation suffocated by a queasy and unmistakable feeling of trepidation.

With the biggest number of Englishmen repatriated since Dunkirk, a tournament which began at a rate of knots is in danger of being lost at sea.

A downbeat tone, perhaps, but with the stench of tear gas hanging thick in the air the priorities have changed over the past 72 hours throughout Belgium and, in particular, its weary capital. The next few days will be crucial if this competition is to be remembered for its goal, rather than body, count.

In case anyone failed to notice, amid all the fighting a game of football broke out here on Saturday evening. It was not the best game, but what the heck. All England need is a draw against the Romanians tomorrow and Kevin Keegan's men will divert to Brussels for a quarter-final next Saturday with Italy at the King Baudouin stadium.

Should England squeeze through, anything is possible. But for all the tub-thumping, the twinkle-eyed enthusiasm and the watch-this-space bravado, Keegan will remain an innocent abroad until his players have stood toe-to-toe with the heavyweights and not had their noses bloodied.

That is not to undervalue their achievement on Saturday but there is no getting away from the fact that the result against Germany was considerably better than the performance.

The same can be said of Italy, who have beaten Turkey and Belgium to win Group B and still taken a savaging from their own journalists for failing to do so with a greater swagger. Even so, it is hard to contemplate Dino Zoff pulling extra hard on his cigarettes at the prospect of facing an England side who have been spluttering through the gears like a rusty old Fiat leaving the garage on a winter's morning.

Italy have found their winning habit earlier than usual but, from the evidence so far, those who bet on France becoming the first country since Germany to be world and European champions simultaneously are likely to be vindicated come July 2.

The French have produced the most thrilling moments to date and in Arsenal's Thierry Henry they have the current player of the tournament, a striker whose supreme finishing occasionally gets overlooked because of his blistering pace.

On Wednesday France play Holland in Amsterdam for the right to finish as winners of Group D and, even though the Dutch have flattered to deceive thus far, it is tempting to believe it will be a dummy run for the final.

Holland have the bigger incentive to win because it would mean playing a quarter-final in Rotterdam as opposed to Bruges. As France have already won twice in the Belgian city, it would not be such a burden for Roger Lemerre's team.

Elsewhere, Portugal will need to reproduce some of the tantalising stuff they showed against England, rather than the altogether less impressive offerings served up against Romania, if they are to ditch their reputation as perennial bridesmaids. Having topped Group A with back-to-back wins, they are assured of being involved in the first quarter- final in Amsterdam on Saturday, with Turkey and Belgium slugging it out tonight to see who will face them as Group B runners-up.

After an exhilarating first round of matches, most of the second games brought with them the first tell-tale signs of apprehension. Nevertheless the entertainment value remains decidedly higher than most people dared anticipate and, for that, Fifa can congratulate itself. The frequency of its rule changes over recent years may have been widely criticised but the upshot is that the game has never been more attack-orientated.

It must be hoped that the feelgood factor generated by events on the field will outweigh all the negative vibes off it. But, without tempting fate, tonight promises to be another occasion that offers little sanctuary for the people of Brussels. With thousands of Turks rolling into town, and the bulk of the English already here, it is difficult to envisage anything more than another night punctuated by the sound of wailing sirens. Sadly, so far as England are concerned it always ends in tear gas.

With the biggest number of Englishmen repatriated since Dunkirk, a tournament which began at a rate of knots is in danger of being lost at sea. A downbeat tone, perhaps, but with the stench of tear gas hanging thick in the air the priorities have changed over the past 72 hours throughout Belgium and, in particular, its weary capital. webTitle: How the men in red rated

fields.headline: How the men in red rated
fields.trailText: David Seaman
fields.body:
David Seaman

The odd Seaman moment, notably one flap at a corner and a late walkabout near the byline, but otherwise one of his sounder recent displays. 7/10

Gary Neville

His long throws remain important but his passes out of defence were often wayward. Often defends as if he lacks confidence. 5

Martin Keown

Immense. Made tackle after crucial tackle, header after crucial header, his concentration level and drive never wavering, and offered vocal encouragement to others. 9

Sol Campbell

Gave away some dangerous free-kicks early on but settled down to produce one of his better recent performances. 8

Phil Neville

Solid and unfussy, he increasingly looks more at home at left-back. It was his centre - albeit with his right foot - which set up Michael Owen for the header Oliver Kahn tipped against the post. 7

David Beckham

Largely peripheral, but remains uncannily involved when England score and, of course, it was from his free-kick that the winner came. 7

Paul Ince

Ran and ran and ran, made crucial tackles and was inevitably on hand when England needed him. Was left for pace a couple of times but a mainstay of this team. 8

Paul Scholes

Another vital contribution, one minute tackling back in defence, then creating a chance, then firing at goal himself. Proved his versatility when he was moved forward as a second striker late in the game. 8

Dennis Wise

Struggled early on, getting beaten for pace and often caught in possession. He slowly got to grips with his unaccustomed role on the left, but it wasn't one of his best games. 6

Alan Shearer

Still knows how to hold the ball up and drag defenders out of position. He took the goal with the clinical efficiency of a great striker, even if he is no longer that. 7

Michael Owen

England's style of play is not geared to using his pace, but nearly scored with one off-balance header. A second successive substitution will test his character. 7

Substitutes

Steven Gerrard: Settled in impressively, with a combination of energetic running, strong tackling and simple passes. 7

Nick Barmby: Never really got into the game. n/a

fields.headline: The Odds Fellow
fields.standfirst: Italians in mood to make it three out of three
fields.trailText: The latest odds as the tournament hots up.
fields.body:
Italy can record a hat-trick of Group B victories by beating Sweden in Eindhoven tonight at a top-priced 10-11 with Hill's.

With qualification for the quarter-finals assured, the Italian coach Dino Zoff is expected to rest some of his first-choice players. A Swedish win, on offer at 3-1 with Ladbrokes, still looks highly unlikely, though some bookies are suggesting that if the Italians were to ease up, this evening's game might end in a draw (12-5 with Ladbrokes). But the Swedes were disappointing against Belgium and even more so in last Thursday's goalless draw against Turkey.

Italy, confidence growing visibly, will not want to lose their momentum now and whatever team Zoff puts out will be looking to outclass their opponents.

Belgium's limitations were exposed by Italy last Wednesday but Robert Waseige's men should still reach the quarter-finals if they get at least a point against Turkey in Brussels.

The Turks can still theoretically go through if they win tonight's contest. But Mustafa Denizli's team seemed lacking in ambition in the drab match with Sweden and for all their potential they are hard to recommend with confidence. A Turkish victory is a best-priced 4-1 with Heathorns and a draw, a not implausible outcome, is on offer at 12-5 with Ladbrokes. But the Belgians may shade it at 4-5 with the Tote.

Overall, Italy started the tournament as fourth favourites at a top-priced 15-2. After two wins the skilful Azzurri can still be backed at 6-1 with the Tote and they represent far better value than England, whose 1-0 defeat of Germany hardly looked like a championship-winning performance. But Hill's, predictably, has cut England's overall odds from 12-1 to 13-2 and Surrey from 20-1 to 7-1. Ladbrokes is still offering 8-1.

 England's win over Germany left bookmakers with a £1m pay-out . "Punters stayed loyal to England in a big way and bets of up to £10,000 were placed on England to win the match," said the William Hill spokesman Graham Sharpe.

He added: "One punter from Blackburn staked £10,000 on England and has won £24,000. And there were plenty of four-figure bets on them."

fields.headline: Andersson out for Sweden
fields.trailText: Sweden's slim hopes of qualifying for the quarter-finals have suffered a major blow with the loss of their towering striker Kennet Andersson with an ankle injury.
fields.body:
Sweden's slim hopes of qualifying for the quarter-finals have suffered a major blow with the loss of their towering striker Kennet Andersson with an ankle injury.

Tommy Soderberg's side will also be without the defenders Roland Nilsson, who has a foot problem, and Teddy Lucic, who has a back injury, for today's Group B match against Italy in Eindhoven.

To progress Sweden must win and hope that Turkey beat Belgium by a smaller margin. "We have to be very, very lucky," said Soderberg. "We have a small, small chance to go further. It will be a tough game. But it is important that we play well and get a good result."

Italy, who have already won the group to progress to a possible quarter-final against England, are expected to give Alessandro del Piero a first start of the tournament this evening.

The striker has been used as a substitute in Italy's victories over Turkey and Belgium but says he is raring to go. "Certainly in terms of form and maybe also psychologically . . . I've perhaps never been this well prepared before," he said.

"I don't think the fact the coach has chosen the same line-up for the last two matches means that's the end of the story for me."

Del Piero will play alongside either Vincenzo Montella or Marco Delvecchio, while Dino Zoff will rest the Juventus midfielders Antonio Conte and Gianluca Zambrotta, who both picked up yellow cards against Belgium.

The equation for Belgium is simpler, a draw being sufficient for the co-hosts to progress. The coach Robert Waseige may replace the Derby County striker Branko Strupar with Luc Nilis while the left-back Nico van Kerckhoven is doubtful with concussion. Turkey will be missing the midfielder Umit Davala, who has an ankle injury, and the striker Oktay Derelioglu, also injured.

webTitle: Kids ban the Beeb as Big Ron's army rules the roost

fields.headline: Kids ban the Beeb as Big Ron's army rules the roost
fields.standfirst: Euro 2000 special report
fields.trailText: Martin Kelner on how Des and Ron speak for a generation.
fields.body:
I am not able to comment in any great detail on the BBC's coverage of the England-Germany match, because every time I tried to switch over from ITV my 15-year-old son grabbed the remote and switched it back. Not, I grant you, the most scientifically selected focus group, but I know the BBC is keen on this type of research so I pass it on in a spirit of friendship.

When I was finally allowed to monitor the BBC, after the other side had finished, I found a rather poignant scene. There were Gary, Martin, Alan and Johan, still in their jackets and ties against the backdrop of an empty stadium, putting a brave face on it at the end of a desperate week for their side. I half expected Des to come striding into the studio and say: "For you, Johnny, ze var is over."

It is, clearly. There is a whole generation growing up - some in my own home - who feel no particular loyalty to the BBC, having not grown up with Muffin The Mule. They feel no compulsion to share the big national occasion with the national broadcaster, not if it means missing that groovy Edgar Davids ball-juggling ad.

Actually, I must stop using the word groovy if I wish to talk to this generation - and since I am keeping three of them in junk food and ludicrously expensive training shoes, I think I have every right to - as my friends at Radio One tell me it means nothing to young people.

When I was telephoned this week by Radio One's Newsbeat programme and asked to comment on ITV's capture of Premiership football highlights, I propounded the view that it might be welcomed by their adolescent audience, who would probably find Gabby Yorath a little more groovy than Barry Davies. "Could we do that again without using the word 'groovy'?" the reporter asked, ignoring my protestations that I was using it in a post-modern ironic sense.

I explained to him that all the pieces in the newspapers lamenting the loss of Match Of The Day were probably written by sad old guys like me, with fond memories of classic Motty moments, who tend to become moist-eyed at the sound of the famous tune. Now, I said (and this predictably was the entire six seconds they used out of a five-minute interview) we would just have to sit gently humming the tune - di da di di di di di - to ourselves at home. "Or should that be in a home?" the presenter was kind enough to back- announce.

And so to match night and ITV, the station of choice for those to whom Motty is just an old guy in a sheepskin coat. They like Uncle Des, these kids, because they bonded with him during Euro 96 and the last World Cup, but, more than that (and this, I must stress, is based on an informal question-and-answer session with my own small focus group, who really should have been doing his maths homework) they find ITV's presentation, like, way more colourful.

But ITV is not only changing the landscape of televised sport, it is rewriting the English language, courtesy of my colleague Ron Atkinson.

Big Ron's column in these pages, you may have noticed, appears in more or less standard English, which I have always taken as a sign of exceptional versatility on his part because, when you put him in a commentary box with Clive Tyldesley, what he comes out with bears little relation to English as we know it.

Ron, remember, is the man who invented "early doors", since when he has taken it as his sacred duty to coin a neologism for each major tournament. "'E's played a lovely little lollipop there" was one of my favourites from the last World Cup, but on Saturday night - and I cannot be entirely sure of the accuracy of these because my pen travels at double speed when Ron opens his mouth - he excelled himself with two brand new Ron-isms.

"Scholesy should have hit it short, but 'e's tried to play the Hollywood ball," said Ron, which was either his term for an ambitious long pass, or I misheard it and it was some sort of reference to Scholes playing the Hollywood Bowl, in the style of the Beatles or Monty Python.

Big Ron's pièce de résistance, though, came five minutes from time, in the middle of an oration about how England now had to screw their courage to the sticking place and so on, when he appeared to say: "Now it's all about claiming your own onions." That is what it sounded like to me, although my focus group reckons he said: "It's all about clearing your own lungs."

Whatever it was, Stuart Pearce mouthing platitudes on the other side did not come close to matching it for entertainment value. The BBC clearly has some work to do if it wishes to reclaim its onions.

fields.headline: Keown wins his personal battle
fields.standfirst: Victory over the Germans was mission accomplished for the Arsenal defender, writes  Martin Thorpe
fields.trailText: Victory over the Germans was mission accomplished for the Arsenal defender, writes Martin Thorpe.
fields.body:
It has clearly been a sore point with Martin Keown. As he left the pitch after Saturday's historic victory, Kevin Keegan embraced him with a shout of "Well done". But the big defender's first words on this memorable night were not "Thanks, boss" or "What a win". Instead they were, "I should have played against them in Euro 96".

Keown was left out of Terry Venables's squad four years ago and, as Keegan discovered, "against Germany, Martin was a man on a mission".

It showed. In Saturday's match the Arsenal player embarked on a remarkable 90-minute wide-eyed vigil, where danger was the prey and whenever it appeared he was on hand, quick to pounce and ruthless, refusing to let the old foe past; blocking here, heading there while all the time still finding room to urge on his team-mates, cajoling them into position, constantly reminding them of just what this game meant.

England needed a win, not just for history's sake but to stay in the tournament. But for Keown it was personal.

Although he appeared in all England's games in Euro 92 he had not played in a major finals since then. England did not qualify for the 1994 World Cup and he was overlooked in 1996. At the last World Cup he was a substitute for every game but never played.

So Saturday's match gave Keown, a friendly, intelligent and hugely patriotic man, his first chance to do something about beating Germany after years of looking on helpless from the sidelines.

"Like loads of people I had sat and watched in frustration at losing the penalty shoot-outs to the Germans in the past," he said. "I felt that in 1996 I shouldn't have been at home watching that and kicking my heels. I felt that I should have been involved in some way.

"When Gareth Southgate missed, like a lot of people I didn't know what to do. I just felt so strongly that England were going to win that competition. I thought it was our year.

"But to finally get the opportunity in a major competition to play Germany - something I've thought was going to pass me by - was fantastic and to beat them was special.

"As for my performance, well, they kept putting more of the same [sort of] players on and putting the ball into the penalty box and you had to stand up and be counted. I thought Sol did exceptionally well, and I thoroughly enjoyed it."

And yet Keown might not have started at all had his Arsenal team-mate Tony Adams been fit, compounding the sense of deja vu he felt when Adams was given the nod ahead of him for England's first game against Portugal.

"When I was left out of that match I was thinking 'Here we go again'. But the manager told me that I would have a big part to play in the competition. And on Saturday it was nice for my family to see me on the pitch finally because, for the last two tournaments, they thought I was working for the media."

His family may now see him in the England starting line-up more often, especially after he formed such a watertight defensive partnership with Sol Campbell against Germany.

But yesterday Keegan was thinking the unthinkable. "Martin Keown has had a lot of good games for me and that was probably the best because it was the biggest match," he said. "But it wouldn't be hard to bring Tony Adams back in.

"Everyone knows what I think of him, his leadership qualities and the way he has performed for England over the years. He would add something to us."

Keegan believes that Adams will be fit for the quarter-final, if England make it. But it would be an awful blow for Keown if he had to make way. Adams does possess leadership qualities, but on Saturday Keown's own personified the hard-working Team England mentality which dug out the victory.

There will be those who frown upon England turning into Leicester City in order to get a result. But Keown does not see it that way. "Against Portugal we perhaps lost a game trying to win a game," he said. "Against Germany we were a little bit more conservative but we got that 1-0 win.

"The important thing is we're growing as a team." Just as Keown, 34 next month, has grown as a defender.

"When Gareth Southgate missed, like a lot of people I didn't know what to do. I just felt so strongly that England were going to win that competition. I thought it was our year. "But to finally get the opportunity in a major competition to play Germany - something I've thought was going to pass me by - was fantastic and to beat them was special. "As for my performance, well, they kept putting more of the same [sort of] players on and putting the ball into the penalty box and you had to stand up and be counted. I thought Sol did exceptionally well, and I thoroughly enjoyed it." And yet Keown might not have started at all had his Arsenal team-mate Tony Adams been fit, compounding the sense of deja vu he felt when Adams was given the nod ahead of him for England's first game against Portugal. "When I was left out of that match I was thinking 'Here we go again'. But the manager told me that I would have a big part to play in the competition. And on Saturday it was nice for my family to see me on the pitch finally because, for the last two tournaments, they thought I was working for the media." His family may now see him in the England starting line-up more often, especially after he formed such a watertight defensive partnership with Sol Campbell against Germany. But yesterday Keegan was thinking the unthinkable. "Martin Keown has had a lot of good games for me and that was probably the best because it was the biggest match," he said. "But it wouldn't be hard to bring Tony Adams back in. "Everyone knows what I think of him, his leadership qualities and the way he has performed for England over the years. He would add something to us." Keegan believes that Adams will be fit for the quarter-final, if England make it. But it would be an awful blow for Keown if he had to make way. Adams does possess leadership qualities, but on Saturday Keown's own personified the hard-working Team England mentality which dug out the victory. There will be those who frown upon England turning into Leicester City in order to get a result. But Keown does not see it that way. "Against Portugal we perhaps lost a game trying to win a game," he said. "Against Germany we were a little bit more conservative but we got that 1-0 win. "The important thing is we're growing as a team." Just as Keown, 34 next month, has grown as a defender.

webTitle: '0-1! Germany weeps. Is it all over?'

fields.headline: '0-1! Germany weeps. Is it all over?'
fields.trailText: Germany immersed itself in football gloom yesterday and began what promises to be a drawn-out inquest of the national side's Euro 2000 performance after the 1-0 defeat against England, writes Tony Paterson in Berlin.
fields.body:
Germany immersed itself in football gloom yesterday and began what promises to be a drawn-out inquest of the national side's Euro 2000 performance after the 1-0 defeat against England, writes Tony Paterson in Berlin.

"0-1! Germany weeps. Is it all over?" asked the mass circulation Bild newspaper in a front-page banner headline. "Shearer tells us to pack our bags," wrote Berlin's Der Tagesspiegel.

Despite the German coach Erich Ribbeck's protestations that the England victory was an "undeserved defeat that hurts", commentators lambasted the German side for being "bereft of ideas" and incapable of puncturing England's defensive wall.

Pundits were also unanimous in concluding that the match was but a poor shadow of past England-Germany games.

"One could sense that both teams were terrified of making a mistake," said Bild's much-capped Paul Breitner. "What happened to the self-confidence that has been the hallmark of German teams for the last 35 years ?"

Another old international in Günther Netzer, now an analyst for Germany's ARD television channel, predicted a 1-0 victory for Germany at half-time but afterwards remarked: "Our trouble is that we simply haven't developed the right strategy to win against sides like England."

Most commentators agreed that the England victory had all but wrecked Germany's chances of progressing. "The quarter-finals are almost certain to take place without the title holders," wrote Der Tagesspiegel's Michael Rosentritt.

The veteran Lothar Matthäus was singled out for particular criticism, and some commentators declared that Saturday's game ended his international career. "I expected more from a team leader," said Netzer, who blamed Matthäus for failing to fire up his side to go on the attack. "After the game he patiently wrote autographs for his fans. They were his last as a national player, even if he wasn't aware of it," said Bild.

England's victory also increased speculation about the imminent departure of Ribbeck, who had demanded that he be judged solely by his team's performance in Euro 2000.

Misgivings among team members about his performance resurfaced at the weekend in an interview with the German midfielder Jens Jeremies. "The national XI has not progressed. It has not developed at all," he said.

The German Football Association president Egidius Braun was yesterday reported to be already looking for a successor to Ribbeck, whose record reads 10 wins, seven defeats and six draws.
