webTitle: Beckham lives dangerously as the red mist descends again

fields.headline: Beckham lives dangerously as the red mist descends again
fields.trailText: David Beckham's booking on Saturday raised further question marks about his temperament and the assertion that he has matured.
fields.body:
Like him or loath him David Beckham remains fundamental to what England might achieve at Euro 2000. All but one of their past eight goals have stemmed from his crosses, whether at set pieces or in open play.

Yet Saturday's booking, for a reckless body-check on Ulf Kirsten, raised further question marks about his temperament and Keegan's recent assertion that the short-tempered media magnet has matured.

The evidence suggests otherwise. Beckham has found trouble in each of England's past three games in major finals. Another booking against Romania will rule him out of a possible quarter-final tie against Italy .

Concern over Beckham's ability to court suspensions took on graphic form with that retaliatory kick at Argentina's Diego Simeone which led to his exit - and contributed to England's - from the last World Cup.

However, evidence is in short supply to support Keegan's belief that Beckham has turned over a new leaf. After England's opening group game against Portugal the player was photographed making a one-fingered salute to a section of abusive supporters.

Undoubtedly there was provocation. But the subsequent FA warning about his future conduct reinforced the view that he should rise above such taunts. But against Germany the red mist descended again.

fields.headline: Spain stutter to subdue Slovenes
fields.standfirst: The fate of Jose Camacho's unimpressive team is in their own hands, writes  Jon Brodkin in Amsterdam
fields.trailText: The fate of Jose Camacho's unimpressive team is in their own hands after they did just enough in the Amsterdam Arena yesterday to edge towards the next round.
fields.body:
It would be lunacy to cancel the holiday to Marbella and put every last peseta on Spain winning this tournament. But having found no way past Norway, Jose Camacho's stuttering team at least did enough in the Amsterdam Arena yesterday to edge towards the next round. If this is a cunning plan to dampen expectations, it is working a treat.

The wild celebrations among the clutch of Spanish fans and the clenched-fist salute of Abelardo seemed out of proportion with another poor performance. Slovenia - population two million, national sport skiing - are not Brazil. But then Camacho's players had said style was ir relevant; only victory mattered. They take on Yugoslavia on Wednesday with their fate in their own hands.

Asked whether Spain had played well, their striker Raul responded: "Yes. We won." But Slovenia's coach Srecko Katanec was closer to the mark. "They didn't impress me - just as in the first match," he said. "There was no element of the game in which they were better than us."

What made the Spanish display all the more disappointing was that they could hardly have asked Hansie Cronje to organise a better start.

When Raul found the net after 3min 50sec most imagined the Slavs were about to be thrown to hungry Spanish lions. Far from it. It needed Joseba Etxeberria to save his side's blushes a minute after Zlatko Zahovic had equalised in the second half. Slovenia's biggest mistake in this competition has been scoring.

Katanec's side showed guts and skill. But one need only look at the experience and respective clubs of the two sets of players to realise that Spain - shock, horror - underachieved. Lokeren, Maribor and Grazer AK would not send Real Madrid's knees all trembly. It was tempting to feel Slovenia possess a unity and spirit the Spanish lack.

Only in bursts did Camacho's team impress. Yet the coach seems unable or unwilling to see the failings. "It was very hard because it was very hot," he said, which was rather like the Dutch complaining the pitches are too flat.

Last week he insisted his players were not tired. Now he complained that they have had "a very long season". It could be leaves on the pitch next.

If Spain make it to the quarter-finals, they will have to improve markedly to defeat France or Holland. When they played at pace and with width they occasionally sparkled yesterday but all too often it was pedestrian stuff. Their playmaker Pep Guardiola was again below par and, while Slovenia worked to get men behind the ball, they were no Norway. A more creative and clinical side would surely have prospered.

Once Raul had sent a wonderful left-foot shot into the top corner from 18 yards after a Michel Salgado effort had been blocked, the real Spain were expected to surface. But the chances that came before half-time were wasted - Alfonso dragged a shot wide and Raul did likewise with a volley - and Slovenia exposed weaknesses in Camacho's back line and tested Santiago Canizares. After Raul had headed wide at the other end from an Augustin Aranzabal centre, it was no great surprise when Slovenia equalised just before the hour.

The busy Mladen Rudonja was involved, bursting down the left and crossing towards the unmarked Zahovic and Milan Osterc. The Olympiakos forward, keen to play in Spain before long, seemed to mishit his shot but it bobbled in slow motion past Canizares.

As against Yugoslavia, though, inexperience and lack of concentration told. Within 90 seconds Gaizka Mendieta ended a surge upfield by setting up Etxeberria to score at the near post. Even so, Canizares still had to stop a header by Marinko Galic and fine shot by Zahovic to save Spain another embarrassment.

fields.headline: Portugal get priorities right - just
fields.trailText: Major football tournaments tend to yield enduring cameo moments which either place into perspective what has been or set the tone for what is to come.
fields.body:
Major football tournaments tend to yield enduring cameo moments which either place into perspective what has been or set the tone for what is to come.

After explaining, briefly and precisely, why his team had fallen so heavily at a grim afternoon's final fence, Romania's coach Emerich Ienei was asked his opinion on his team's final group fixture against England in Charleroi tomorrow night.

Ienei, moving purposefully towards the sanctuary of an air-conditioned bus, delivered not words but the sort of withering glance that Sir Alex Ferguson unleashes whenever his tactical approach is questioned.

Last-minute defeats are always hard to stomach but Ienei, the colour having long departed his face, had the demeanour of one who knew the game was up.

Portugal, through Costinha's late goal, have qualified for the last eight. Romania could still squeeze into the quarter-finals by returning England to reality but their football was so astoundingly bankrupt of ideas and improvisation in the Gelredome that that seems unlikely.

In short, England are looking at a dream of a final game, against a side who have lost their belief and their most significant player, Gheorghe Hagi, who will be suspended after collecting his second caution of the competition.

"What now? Well, we can still get through if we can overcome the English; that might still prove to be enough for us," said Ienei. "Unfortunately we lost this game in the last second; or perhaps after the last second, because although the referee signalled for four minutes of injury-time the goal came in the 96th minute."

If Romania were poor, Portugal were no better. Yet Humberto Coelho's team has many players of enviable ability. It did not seem that way on Saturday but, after beating England with such elegance last Monday, they were more concerned with not losing, rather than winning, their second game.

The match was unspeakably dull. Portugal's main failing was the limpness of their crossing. With Everton's Abel Xavier omitted despite his impressive contribution against England, they could not even cross for toffee. Luis Figo did everything to ridicule the notion that he is the most accomplished player on the planet, Joao Pinto fell over with Heskeyesque regularity, and Nuno Gomes shredded his reputation for intelligent forward play; it was wretched stuff.

But the weakest link in the Portuguese chain is at the back, in black. Vitor Baia cannot kick, flaps at anything above shin level and instils in those around him knee-trembling panic. As the tournament progresses he may well prove a liability whom Portugal cannot adequately protect.

The game did not deserve a winner but it got one, the substitute Costinha rising magnificently seconds from the end to head home Figo's free-kick.

"We didn't play as we can play. The important thing is that we are definitely into the next phase," said Coelho. "We came here to win games and we have now played twice and won twice. That sounds reasonably good to me."

webTitle: Milosevic breathes life into the group of death

fields.headline: Milosevic breathes life into the group of death
fields.trailText: A goal from Savo Milosevic, which makes him the top scorer with three at Euro 2000, last night breathed welcome life into Group C, in which any two of the four teams can still go through.
fields.body:
People love to talk about groups of death at European Championships, World Cups and even in the Champions League. But a goal from Savo Milosevic, which makes him the top scorer with three at Euro 2000, breathed welcome life into Group C, in which any two of the four teams can still go through.

With the top two finishing positions in the other three groups looking so assured, the organisers will be relieved that the final group games will not contain as many non-events as had been assumed.

Sadly, it was also a match marred by diving, time-wasting and the feigning of injury which led the Scottish referee Hugh Dallas to send off the Yugoslav substitute Mateja Kezman for a bad tackle on Erik Mykland in the 88th minute, just 60 seconds after coming on.

Yugoslavia, thrown out of the 1992 tournament during the Balkan crisis, have never been a team to stir the emotions of those outside their borders. But against a Norway side whose style is so direct that it makes Wimbledon look like Real Madrid, they had a remarkable fan base among the neutrals.

So their opening goal after eight minutes was received with wild acclaim from anyone not dressed in Norwegian red. And what an irony it was that against a side which could easily masquerade as a Premiership XI it should have been scored by Savo Milosevic, who was Stan Collymore's predecessor as a troublesome Aston Villa centre-forward.

Quick off the mark he deflected a free-kick from Ljubinko Drulovic into the far corner of the net to leave Norway's players asking themselves how they had failed to clear the danger with virtually the whole of their team inside the box.

Milosevic also got his head to a Drulovic cross, whipped in with the pace and accuracy of David Beckham, and created a chance for Predrag Mijatovic that Thomas Myhre did well to touch over.

As Yugoslavia's neat football continued to produce chances, Norway's coach Nils Johan Semb was no doubt yelling that well-known phrase from the Graham Taylor hymn book: "Can we not knock it?" When they did, Tore Andre Flo overclubbed a chip from inside of the box which never looked like forcing a save.

The Yugoslavs, who dug themselves out of an enormous hole in the opening game after trailing 3-0 to Slovenia, had clearly decided to get their retaliation, and their goals, in first this time. They were also encouraged by Spain's win over Slovenia which puts progress from Group C up for grabs.

Milosevic did not go cold in the half-time interval, quickly causing more panic in the Norway defence by taking a neat pass from Mijatovic and setting up Vladimir Jugovic in a position from which he might have done better than give Myhre some easy practice.

The Norwegians, perhaps stung by criticism of their style, failed to fire in their usual prodigious crosses, though when Eric Mykland did send one in from the left, it almost brought a goal. Flo's header, though aimed to the top far corner, did not look goal-bound until it took a bizarre deflection off Eirik Bakke's forehead and almost dropped into the opposite corner.

Norway were certainly left cursing their luck when Steffen Iversen collided with the goalkeeper Ivica Kralj while chasing an increasing number of high balls. Half a dozen hard-hatted medics rushed to his attention and though he seemed fit to continue he was immediately replaced by John Carew.

The Yugoslavs in the crowd were by now celebrating in their normal bizarre fashion, turning their backs to the pitch and dancing up and down like Morris men, though thankfully, without the bells. Norway's fans simply felt like looking the other way.

fields.headline: Turkey 2 - 0 Belgium
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Turkey: 1-Rustu Recber; 3-Ogun Temizkanoglu (captain), 8-Tugay Kerimoglu, 4-Fatih Akyel, 5-Alpay Ozalan, 6-Arif Erdem, 7-Okan Buruk, 9-Hakan Sukur, 14-Suat Kaya, 19-Abdullah, 11-Tayfun Korkut. Subs: Osman Ozkoylu, Fevzi Tuncay, Ayhan Akman, Muzzy Izzet, Omer Catkic, Oktay Derelioglu, Umit Davala, Tayfur Havutcu, Hakan Unsal, Sergen Yalcin, Ergun Penbe.

Belgium: 1-Filip De Wilde; 2-Eric Deflandre, 3-Joos Valgaeren, 4-Lorenzo Staelens (captain), 18-Nico Van Kerckhoven; 6-Yves Vanderhaeghe, 7-Marc Wilmots, 8-Bart Goor, 11-Gert Verheyen; 9-Emile Mpenza, 16-Luc Nilis. Subs: Gilles De Bilde, Frederic Herpoel, Philippe Clement, Branko Strupar, Johan Walem, Jacky Peeters, Philippe Leonard, Eric Van Meir, Gert De Vlieger, Marc Hendrikx, Mbo Mpenza.

Referee: Kim Milton Nielsen (Denmark)

1 The game kicks-off with Italy facing Sweden in Eindhoven as Group becomes the first to wind up in Euro 2000.
2 Mpenza has an early strike when he picks up possession 30 yards out, drifts inside slightly and shoots wide of the far post.
3 Mpenza then gets in another shot from the edge of the area when Turkey are again caught napping at the back. It goes a foot wide.
4 Belgium win a corner on the right. Wilmots takes and it is knocked on by Belgian head before Turkey clear.
5 The 33-year-old Nilis races away down the right, enters the area and shoots to the near post but Rustu gets down well. Turkey looking distinctly rocky in the early stages.
7 Turkey corner on the left. Tayfun gets up but De Wilde gets there first.
8 Verheyen and Wilmots create havoc on the right as Turkey continue to get stretched all over the field.
9 Mpenza gets away on the right and scraps his way to a corner with Alpay. The pair shove each other but referee Nielsen keeps the card indoors.

fields.headline: Defeating poverty
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain sets out her vision for improving standards of living in the world's poorest nations
Road the the manifesto: special report
fields.trailText: The Guardian's deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain sets out her vision for improving standards of living in the world's poorest nations
fields.body:
We live in a world of extremes. Prosperity has reached levels that would have been unthinkable to our grandparents, yet one in five people lives in desperate poverty. In an age of breathtaking advances in medical technology, more than 12 million children die each year from easily preventable infectious diseases. In the age of the computer, 800 million adults are unable to read and write.

Poverty can be defeated. But the war against poverty is being lost because of the obscene gaps in opportunity and income that separate rich and poor. We are committed to closing these gaps - and to projecting our commitment to social justice on to the international stage. We will place poverty reduction at the heart of all government policies, pursuing 'joined-up' policies in aid, trade, investment and foreign affairs.

Aid has a vital role to play in projecting our values. Over the past five years we have made a start by reversing the disgraceful cuts in our development co-operation budget made by the last Conservative government. But more needs to be done. In the lifetime of the next parliament we shall increase our aid from the current level of 0.23 of GNP to the UN target of 0.7 - adding £4bn to the aid budget.

British taxpayers have a right to know that aid money is being well spent. We should work to improve the quality of our aid programme so that it makes a real difference to the poor. This means spending more on areas like basic health and girls' education - and less on technical assistance. As part of our commitment to poverty, we should create an independent aid review division to evaluate our impact and make public the findings.

Education is an area at the centre of the government's policy for social regeneration - and not just in Britain. At the World Education Forum in Dakar, governments agreed to develop a global initiative aimed at getting 125 million children into school by 2015. We should demand that this promise is translated into action, using our influence at the G8 to mobilise an additional $4bn a year for education in poor countries. Britain should make an immediate 'down payment' in the first year of the new government through a £500m increase in education spending.

Many of the world's poorest countries, especially in Africa, continue to be crippled by debt problems. Britain has led the way in tackling this problem, but we have to do more. So far, only five countries have benefited from the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative. We must demand more rapid implementation, and work to ensure that debt relief is linked to poverty reduction.

New debt problems are emerging. In East Asia and Latin America debt owed to private creditors such as commercial banks and investment funds are destroying national development efforts. We should demand a new debt relief initiative under which private creditors are required to reduce their demands on countries where debt is undermining basic services such as health and education. Our message to the financial markets; people before profits.

Global markets need global governance .The IMF, the World Bank and the WTO are remote, undemocratic, unaccountable and incapable of responding to the challenge of poverty reduction.

Reform of the IMF should be an immediate priority. Regions such as sub-Saharan Africa, where IMF programmes dominate economic policy, have less than three per cent of voting rights, while rich countries have more than 50 per cent. IMF programmes consistently result in deep cuts in health, education and employment.

International trade is vital to increased prosperity in the poorest nations. Yet world trade rule - and the World Trade Organisation - is rigged against the poor. Protectionism in rich countries costs poor countries $700bn a year - seven times the amount they receive in aid. There should be better market access for all developing countries, and immediate duty-free access for the poorest.

Powerful trans-national companies (TNCs) are benefiting from the patent protection provided by WTO rules on intellectual property. These rules are putting new technologies and essential drugs beyond the means of the poorest countries. A new balance needs to be struck between the rights of investors and the needs of the poor. The period of patent protection should be reduced from 20 years to 10 years.

Foreign investment through trans-national companies is one of the main links between rich and poor countries in today's global economy. British companies are major actors. TNCs have the potential to contribute to poverty reduction through investment and technology transfer. All too often, however, they are guilty of violating human rights and following unacceptable employment practices. A code of conduct for corporate behaviour is needed.

Legislation to prohibit British arms brokers from operating in the poorest countries should be introduced and Britain should work towards an international code of conduct aimed at preventing the sale of weapons to countries that abuse human rights.

Aid pledges

1 Spend £4bn more annually on aid

2 £500m increase in education spending, especially on girls, in the first year of the new government

3 Reform of the IMF

4 Ensure no more use of sanctions which hit the poor, as in Iraq

5 New debt initiative

fields.headline: Brown 'bonanza' goes on essentials
fields.standfirst:
An extra £1bn is now feeding through into school budgets. But what is it buying?
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: It is an unforeseen though welcome consequence of Gordon Brown's £1bn budget bonanza for schools that the children of Yoxford primary are about to get a new box of skipping ropes.
fields.body:
It is an unforeseen though welcome consequence of Gordon Brown's £1bn budget bonanza for schools that the children of Yoxford primary are about to get a new box of skipping ropes.

In common with every state school in the country, a share of the chancellor's billion, announced in March, is just about now finding its way to Yoxford primary, a school in a village of the same name in north Suffolk. The biggest primaries got £9,000. Yoxford, like other small primaries got the smallest slice, £3,000, but, assuming the school governors rubber stamp the head teacher Peter Scuffil's proposals, this will be enough to provide £1,000 worth of reading books, £1,000 in maths equipment, including several sets of good-quality weighing scales, £500 for CD-Roms and £500 for games equipment including skipping ropes, stilts and balls for the playground.

What was unusual about the "Brown money" was that it came with no strings. No bidding, no applications, no competition, no matching funds from the council: heads could spend it on whatever they wanted. The government's approach until then had been to give schools money for essentials, and extra money for its - the government's - priorities, determining when it was spent and what it was spent on. Head teachers welcomed the Brown money, and particularly its method of delivery. But even now, they say, a combination of historic underfunding, new stresses and some bad luck means that often this money is no luxury.

"In many parts of the country it's being used to prop up school budgets where they have been inadequately funded," said John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association. David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "They are certainly not spending it on treats. I'd say they are spending it on essentials."

Though the Tory-introduced local management of schools (LMS) put responsibility for budgets in the hands of head teachers, the national curriculum, national pay awards and a welter of government initiatives limit their freedom to manoeuvre. The standards fund - the government's main channel for targeting funds to national priorities, which is filtered through local education authorities and for which some elements require matching council funds - is alone worth £1.7bn this year.

But head teachers detect that the argument is swinging their way. David Blunkett has floated proposals to give money from central government directly to head teachers, with a separate pot for the LEAs to fulfil LEA functions.

A green paper on local government funding this summer is likely to go some way towards a national funding formula. The comprehensive spending review should unleash at least between £1bn and £2bn in extra education spending.

In his staff room in Yoxford, Mr Scuffil explained: "There is not a lot of the budget you actually have control over." Of the £157,083 due to be spent by Yoxford this year, £141,462 comes under the funding formula through Suffolk county council. Then comes £12,889 from the standards fund: for the literacy and numeracy strategy (£1,098), for "school improvements" - where there is some leeway - £3,421, for teaching assistants (£1,645), for changes to the national curriculum (£315), special educational needs (£250) and a very welcome £6,060 for small schools' administrative support. And with it, paperwork, paperwork, paperwork.

"Initiatives are all very well but there are so many that you can't focus on one properly because there are another four that we are thinking about at the same time. Look back to the days when schools had autonomy over the curriculum, even though we all sort of did the same thing. I don't suppose I would do anything wildly different but somehow the freedom to pursue good ideas is gone." In Mr Blunkett's defence, he has promised a cut in paperwork. And Mr Scuffil concedes: "For some teachers the freedom to pursue bad ideas has gone, which must be good too."

Budget balancing

Mr Scuffil has been head for 22 years of Yoxford primary's 102 year history. Backed by supportive governors and the local education authority, he gets within 2% of his spending target each year. His governors' main aim is to maintain the number of teaching staff and to insure against a fall in pupil numbers. Yoxford tends to bump along with a pupil roll in the mid-50s, although it is up to 62. With much of its income determined on a per-pupil basis (£1,454.57 for every five-year-old, £1,455.91 for every eight-year-old), tiny changes make a big difference and can threaten staff numbers. Helped by printouts from the health authority, the school predicts intake each year. Seventeen are leaving in September; only five are coming in, and another three expected in January, the month the school's role is calculated for the budget. Which is why the governors are keeping £9,000 in reserve in the school's fund.

Bolstered by a glowing Ofsted report, the school is determined to hold on to its teachers. It has only "3.2" - that is, Mr Scuffil, two other full-timers and someone who comes in on a Wednesday, the day Mr Scuffil sets aside for head teacher-related business

For its 3.2, Yoxford pays out £96,000 a year. "Everyone remembers a good teacher - except the person who pays them," rued Mr Scuffil. After other staff costs - including classroom assistants, caretaking, midday supervision - Yoxford has already spent £123,450. Of the re mainder, £16,460 goes on upkeep of the building, much of which is contracted to Suffolk and does not pass in or out of the school's budget.

And then there are a few items where the head does have choices, but it hardly seems indulgence: the school fete and other fundraising through the year ensures that school trips, including one to London every year, are free; County advisory teachers to come in and take the occasional lesson, to give the Yoxford teachers new ideas and input (£1,645). The school pays the county £1,215 to lend it 250 library books, which get changed each term, and £700 to the county paymaster to sort out staff salaries and tax.

Lawnswood school in Leeds got £50,000 in Brown money, the maximum. But then it has 1,496 pupils and its budget is in a different league. It will be spending £4,227,400 this year.

The head teacher Lindsey Wharmby's total staffing bill is £3,119,600. The school will pay energy bills of around £61,800 and £63,000 to the exam boards, both sums more than it will spend on replacing books and equipment. A very cold winter, and the energy bill could be more. And Lawnswood is trying to claw back a deficit which at £120,000 is nearly the size of Yoxford's entire budget.

That deficit is the reason Ms Wharmby's pupils will not be skipping with Gordon Brown's ropes. The money will be the contingency for the general running of the school; if it isn't spent, it will go towards the deficit. "What it did was just give us a little bit of ease all the way through the budget," said Mrs Wharmby.

Into the red

Schools aren't supposed to go into the red. But many do. In a straw poll by John Dunford, about a quarter of his head teachers are spending the Brown money on their school deficit, including heads in Leicester, Manchester and Northumberland. (The remaining 75% were divided roughly equally between materials - textbooks and computers, and staffing.)

Mrs Wharmby expected an £80,000 shortfall last year to cope with a drop in pupil numbers, caused by a very small year 11. With larger year groups (and therefore more money) due in later years she calculated the deficit, covered by the LEA and no more than 2% of the school's budget, could be paid in three years. However, a flu epidemic which hit 16 staff between December and January was compounded by four staff going on long-term sick leave.

It could have been worse. Mrs Wharmby decided at the last minute to continue taking out insurance against sick leave. Even so, the insurance covers only £100 of the £140-150-a-day it costs to bring in a supply teacher; the rest is picked up by the school. She hadn't budgeted enough. "I looked at the pattern over the last two years and put in the same again, and I was wrong."

This year Mrs Wharmby has budgeted cautiously, including £64,000 for insurance and supply teaching costs, to get the deficit back to just under 2%. Some class sizes will have to rise, and teacher numbers fall. Year groups of roughly 270 pupils will be split across nine teachers rather than 10 for some subjects. "You run on a knife-edge all the time."

On Mrs Wharmby's own admission Lawnswood has had a "quite generous" grant this year, with a rise on last year. But again a huge proportion of it is centrally directed, and Mrs Wharmby welcomes it almost in spite of herself.

The Brown money is dwarfed by an extra £362,440 from the standards fund and the excellence in cities programme, mostly provided by central government, some with matching funds from the Leeds. "Excellence in cities is very exciting. But it's changing the whole nature of LMS, because central government is saying 'this is what we want to do in schools'. It just so happens that at the moment I totally approve of everything they are putting their money into."

From excellence in cities comes two learning mentors and a coordinator for work with gifted and talented pupils. The school gets £37,500 for social inclusion, £10,130 in assistant teachers, and £13,300 for the new post-16 qualifications.

"Local management of schools was brought in by an anti-LEA administration," said Mrs Wharmby. "The present administration is bypassing LMS to get their agenda into schools."

Bushey Meads school, near Watford, Hertfordshire, was a winner under the previous government's agenda, because it became a grant maintained school.

But in its new guise as a foundation school it still has the feel of a school doing well, in a well-funded county which benefits from an area cost adjustment that favours the counties ringing London. Bushey Meads is overcrowded - 1,070 pupils in a school built for 636. Its sixth form, which is the most lucrative in terms of funding per pupil, is 250-strong.

And in a budget of £2,969,082 (not including £290,512 direct funding for its centre for 28 children with disabilities), about £120,000 comes from the government grants and the standards fund. It asks parents to contribute £60 a year, not all of whom contribute - some can't, some won't on principle. The school uses £10,000 of that money for the running of the school and the rest for a school "future fund" reserved mainly for IT.

fields.bodyText: It is an unforeseen though welcome consequence of Gordon Brown's £1bn budget bonanza for schools that the children of Yoxford primary are about to get a new box of skipping ropes. In common with every state school in the country, a share of the chancellor's billion, announced in March, is just about now finding its way to Yoxford primary, a school in a village of the same name in north Suffolk. The biggest primaries got £9,000. Yoxford, like other small primaries got the smallest slice, £3,000, but, assuming the school governors rubber stamp the head teacher Peter Scuffil's proposals, this will be enough to provide £1,000 worth of reading books, £1,000 in maths equipment, including several sets of good-quality weighing scales, £500 for CD-Roms and £500 for games equipment including skipping ropes, stilts and balls for the playground. What was unusual about the "Brown money" was that it came with no strings. No bidding, no applications, no competition, no matching funds from the council: heads could spend it on whatever they wanted. The government's approach until then had been to give schools money for essentials, and extra money for its - the government's - priorities, determining when it was spent and what it was spent on. Head teachers welcomed the Brown money, and particularly its method of delivery. But even now, they say, a combination of historic underfunding, new stresses and some bad luck means that often this money is no luxury. "In many parts of the country it's being used to prop up school budgets where they have been inadequately funded," said John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association. David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said: "They are certainly not spending it on treats. I'd say they are spending it on essentials." Though the Tory-introduced local management of schools (LMS) put responsibility for budgets in the hands of head teachers, the national curriculum, national pay awards and a welter of government initiatives limit their freedom to manoeuvre. The standards fund - the government's main channel for targeting funds to national priorities, which is filtered through local education authorities and for which some elements require matching council funds - is alone worth £1.7bn this year. But head teachers detect that the argument is swinging their way. David Blunkett has floated proposals to give money from central government directly to head teachers, with a separate pot for the LEAs to fulfil LEA functions. A green paper on local government funding this summer is likely to go some way towards a national funding formula. The comprehensive spending review should unleash at least between £1bn and £2bn in extra education spending. In his staff room in Yoxford, Mr Scuffil explained: "There is not a lot of the budget you actually have control over." Of the £157,083 due to be spent by Yoxford this year, £141,462 comes under the funding formula through Suffolk county council. Then comes £12,889 from the standards fund: for the literacy and numeracy strategy (£1,098), for "school improvements" - where there is some leeway - £3,421, for teaching assistants (£1,645), for changes to the national curriculum (£315), special educational needs (£250) and a very welcome £6,060 for small schools' administrative support. And with it, paperwork, paperwork, paperwork. "Initiatives are all very well but there are so many that you can't focus on one properly because there are another four that we are thinking about at the same time. Look back to the days when schools had autonomy over the curriculum, even though we all sort of did the same thing. I don't suppose I would do anything wildly different but somehow the freedom to pursue good ideas is gone." In Mr Blunkett's defence, he has promised a cut in paperwork. And Mr Scuffil concedes: "For some teachers the freedom to pursue bad ideas has gone, which must be good too." Budget balancing Mr Scuffil has been head for 22 years of Yoxford primary's 102 year history. Backed by supportive governors and the local education authority, he gets within 2% of his spending target each year. His governors' main aim is to maintain the number of teaching staff and to insure against a fall in pupil numbers. Yoxford tends to bump along with a pupil roll in the mid-50s, although it is up to 62. With much of its income determined on a per-pupil basis (£1,454.57 for every five-year-old, £1,455.91 for every eight-year-old), tiny changes make a big difference and can threaten staff numbers. Helped by printouts from the health authority, the school predicts intake each year. Seventeen are leaving in September; only five are coming in, and another three expected in January, the month the school's role is calculated for the budget. Which is why the governors are keeping £9,000 in reserve in the school's fund. Bolstered by a glowing Ofsted report, the school is determined to hold on to its teachers. It has only "3.2" - that is, Mr Scuffil, two other full-timers and someone who comes in on a Wednesday, the day Mr Scuffil sets aside for head teacher-related business For its 3.2, Yoxford pays out £96,000 a year. "Everyone remembers a good teacher - except the person who pays them," rued Mr Scuffil. After other staff costs - including classroom assistants, caretaking, midday supervision - Yoxford has already spent £123,450. Of the re mainder, £16,460 goes on upkeep of the building, much of which is contracted to Suffolk and does not pass in or out of the school's budget. And then there are a few items where the head does have choices, but it hardly seems indulgence: the school fete and other fundraising through the year ensures that school trips, including one to London every year, are free; County advisory teachers to come in and take the occasional lesson, to give the Yoxford teachers new ideas and input (£1,645). The school pays the county £1,215 to lend it 250 library books, which get changed each term, and £700 to the county paymaster to sort out staff salaries and tax. Lawnswood school in Leeds got £50,000 in Brown money, the maximum. But then it has 1,496 pupils and its budget is in a different league. It will be spending £4,227,400 this year. The head teacher Lindsey Wharmby's total staffing bill is £3,119,600. The school will pay energy bills of around £61,800 and £63,000 to the exam boards, both sums more than it will spend on replacing books and equipment. A very cold winter, and the energy bill could be more. And Lawnswood is trying to claw back a deficit which at £120,000 is nearly the size of Yoxford's entire budget. That deficit is the reason Ms Wharmby's pupils will not be skipping with Gordon Brown's ropes. The money will be the contingency for the general running of the school; if it isn't spent, it will go towards the deficit. "What it did was just give us a little bit of ease all the way through the budget," said Mrs Wharmby. Into the red Schools aren't supposed to go into the red. But many do. In a straw poll by John Dunford, about a quarter of his head teachers are spending the Brown money on their school deficit, including heads in Leicester, Manchester and Northumberland. (The remaining 75% were divided roughly equally between materials - textbooks and computers, and staffing.) Mrs Wharmby expected an £80,000 shortfall last year to cope with a drop in pupil numbers, caused by a very small year 11. With larger year groups (and therefore more money) due in later years she calculated the deficit, covered by the LEA and no more than 2% of the school's budget, could be paid in three years. However, a flu epidemic which hit 16 staff between December and January was compounded by four staff going on long-term sick leave. It could have been worse. Mrs Wharmby decided at the last minute to continue taking out insurance against sick leave. Even so, the insurance covers only £100 of the £140-150-a-day it costs to bring in a supply teacher; the rest is picked up by the school. She hadn't budgeted enough. "I looked at the pattern over the last two years and put in the same again, and I was wrong." This year Mrs Wharmby has budgeted cautiously, including £64,000 for insurance and supply teaching costs, to get the deficit back to just under 2%. Some class sizes will have to rise, and teacher numbers fall. Year groups of roughly 270 pupils will be split across nine teachers rather than 10 for some subjects. "You run on a knife-edge all the time." On Mrs Wharmby's own admission Lawnswood has had a "quite generous" grant this year, with a rise on last year. But again a huge proportion of it is centrally directed, and Mrs Wharmby welcomes it almost in spite of herself. The Brown money is dwarfed by an extra £362,440 from the standards fund and the excellence in cities programme, mostly provided by central government, some with matching funds from the Leeds. "Excellence in cities is very exciting. But it's changing the whole nature of LMS, because central government is saying 'this is what we want to do in schools'. It just so happens that at the moment I totally approve of everything they are putting their money into." From excellence in cities comes two learning mentors and a coordinator for work with gifted and talented pupils. The school gets £37,500 for social inclusion, £10,130 in assistant teachers, and £13,300 for the new post-16 qualifications. "Local management of schools was brought in by an anti-LEA administration," said Mrs Wharmby. "The present administration is bypassing LMS to get their agenda into schools." But in its new guise as a foundation school it still has the feel of a school doing well, in a well-funded county which benefits from an area cost adjustment that favours the counties ringing London. Bushey Meads is overcrowded - 1,070 pupils in a school built for 636. Its sixth form, which is the most lucrative in terms of funding per pupil, is 250-strong. And in a budget of £2,969,082 (not including £290,512 direct funding for its centre for 28 children with disabilities), about £120,000 comes from the government grants and the standards fund. It asks parents to contribute £60 a year, not all of whom contribute - some can't, some won't on principle. This year it is reducing staff levels by 0.8. Throughout Bushey Meads, small classrooms compound the overcrowding problem. Most of the school roofs need repairing. Dr Coleman estimated she needed another £40,000 to cover it. "We welcome the broad curriculum but we want the funding to be put in place." Lots of the extra staffing from the Brown money identified by John Dunford is going into sixth forms. At Bushey Meads, the £40,000 of Brown money will cover a theoretical deficit of £26,000. "Schools went grant maintained originally because they were under-funded. It certainly didn't go on long enough to put right all the things that were needed here. fields.headline: Student outwits the experts
fields.standfirst: Macmillan Press economics site
fields.trailText: It is never an easy task to predict which way the economy will turn, as any analyst will admit. Most of the entrants in the Guardian's economic forecasting competition for 1999 expected it was going to be a rocky year for growth and unemployment. Even the Treasury in its December 1998 preview of the year ahead was expecting growth of around 1.25%, well below the long-run average of 2.25%.
fields.body:
It is never an easy task to predict which way the economy will turn, as any analyst will admit. Most of the entrants in the Guardian's economic forecasting competition for 1999 expected it was going to be a rocky year for growth and unemployment. Even the Treasury in its December 1998 preview of the year ahead was expecting growth of around 1.25%, well below the long-run average of 2.25%.

Instead the economy surprised on the upside - growth was below average but still respectable and unemployment continued to fall. That fooled most of our entrants, but not one first year economics and management science student at De Montfort University. Nana Baiden, the winner of the 1999 Guardian economics competition, correctly guessed that output would expand 2.1% and was just 70,000 off the correct answer for unemployment in December 1999 - 1.17m. Those two results were enough to make Mr Baiden the clear winner out of the more than 200 entries we received.

Mr Baiden, who wants to be an investment analyst when he finishes his degree, managed to outguess the Treasury's forecasters on inflation as well. While they predicted it would be 2.5% - the Bank of England's target - Mr Baiden correctly thought that the Bank would undershoot its goal. He predicted the target measure, which excludes housing costs would be 2.4%, but it was in fact even lower, at just 2.2%. He was, however, too pessimistic about how high the Bank would have to push interest rates in order to achieve its target, expecting base rates to be at 7.75% when in fact they were 5.5%.

Like most of our entrants, Mr Baiden underestimated how far the pound would rise by the end of the year. His guess that sterling would be around DM2.79 was closer than most entries, but in fact it was up at DM3.15 on the last day of 1999. Few people guessed how far the current account would swing into the red either. The Treasury expected it to be £7.5bn in deficit, while Mr Baiden was less pessimistic, pencilling in a £2.5bn shortfall. In the event, trade and investment outflows outstripped inflows by a whopping £12.8bn.

Mr Baiden is delighted with his prize: £500 worth of books from Macmillan publishers. "It's going to be really useful," he says. "I'm still shocked and really happy."

The questions for the 2001 competition will be published on the economics page in December this year. Entries close at the end of January 2001.

webTitle: Racist gang beats man to death at club

fields.headline: Racist gang beats man to death at club
fields.standfirst:
Three soldiers held for questioning after group of eight punched and kicked victim as he lay unconscious and attacked his brother and friend

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A man was beaten to death and two others injured in a race attack outside a nightclub in Westbury, Wiltshire, yesterday.
fields.body:
A man was beaten to death and two others injured in a race attack outside a nightclub in Westbury, Wiltshire, yesterday.

Glyne Agard, who is black, his brother and a friend were attacked by an eight-strong gang as they left the Reflections nightclub.

Detective Superintendent Gary Chatfield of Wiltshire police said that the three men had been racially abused before being beaten as they left the nightspot shortly before 3am.

Mr Agard, 34, from Reading, Berkshire, is understood to have been kicked and punched as he lay unconscious. Paramedics were unable to revive him and he was pronounced dead at the scene. A post mortem examination showed that he died from head injuries.

His brother Stephen, 32, also from Reading, was yesterday in a stable condition in the Royal United hospital, Bath, with head, neck and chest injuries. The third man attacked suffered concussion and was released yesterday.

Glyne and Stephen Agard and their friend had apparently been the subject of racial taunts in the nightclub before the attack happened.

Police arrested four men, three of them soldiers, who were being questioned last night.

An army spokesman said: "There are three serving soldiers under arrest who are helping police with their inquiries." He would not reveal to which unit the soldiers belonged but said they were based in Wiltshire.

Detectives are now studying closed-circuit TV footage from the club. More than 100 officers are working on the case in conjunction with the Wiltshire racial equality council.

Wiltshire police described the attack as "racially-moti vated, brutal and unprovoked". Mr Chatfield said: "We have spoken to his parents and his girlfriend and family. They are clearly distressed by events that have unfolded."

Westbury, with a population of 16,000, is normally a haven for tourists and pensioners with one of the lowest crime rates in Britain. But one Wiltshire police officer, Det Supt Martin Abbott, conceded that number of reported race crimes had doubled in the past year in Wiltshire.

He said: "We don't have a high population of black people in Wiltshire, but whether that's the reason we don't have a great number of incidents, I couldn't say."

The chairman of the commission for racial equality, Gurbux Singh, said recently that the latest figures showed the number of racist incidents in London alone was greater than for the whole of Britain in the previous 12 months.

Scotland Yard said that race hate crimes had doubled in London to an average of 63 a day in the 12 months to April. The total, 23,346, of which 14,699 were violent offences, compared with 23,049 recorded across the entire country in the 12 months to April 1999.

The sharp increase is not confined to the capital, where the bulk of racial crime is committed. West Midlands police said that so far this year there had been 1,500 incidents recorded, compared with a total of 1,000 in 1998-9.

Scotland Yard figures also showed that eight out of 10 racial incidents were unsolved, although this year's clear-up rate of 21% was double that of the previous year.

The rise has come as a disappointment in the wake of Sir William Macpherson's report on police investigation of race crimes, following the botched inquiry into the racist murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence in 1993.

webTitle: Governing, Gardening and Going to Glasgow

fields.headline: Governing, Gardening and Going to Glasgow
fields.trailText: BLAIR AND STRAW RESPOND TO UEFA THREAT
fields.body:
BLAIR AND STRAW RESPOND TO UEFA THREAT

The Government have responded to Uefa's threat to ban England from Euro 2000. Speaking in Portugal earlier today, Tony Blair condemned last weekend's violence, but stressed the "vast majority" of those British thugs arrested were not known to police. "I deeply regret the behaviour of a small group of people who aren't football fans at all, they are hooligans," said Mr Blair. "We have a very, very good intelligence system, we have dealt with this problem in England. We have to make sure we do everything possible to stamp it out abroad as well."

To combat the threat of more violence, Home Secretary Jack Straw has ordered extra police officers to be stationed at ports and airports to identify suspected hooligans before they arrive in Belgium. And the Government have also asked the Belgium authorities not to sell full-strength alcohol before tomorrow's match against Romania. In the longer term, Straw has announced that British clubs will ban for life anyone convicted of football hooliganism.

Meanwhile, a major bookmaker has stopped taking bets on which country will host the 2006 World Cup following Uefa's statement. "England had been well backed 5-2 second favourites, but this affair looks likely to scupper their chances completely," explained William Hill spokesman Graham Sharpe. "It is now impossible to make an accurate assessment of England's chances in the light of the current situation - they certainly haven't been improved, so we have closed the book."

PAUL JEWELL'S DAY OF LEISURE

0800

Wake up. Reflect on yesterday's events, when I offered my resignation as manager of Bradford after "a lot of soul-searching". Rustle myself up a leisurely breakfast. Mm, these cornflakes sure taste good.

0801

Suddenly remember that my resignation hasn't been accepted and that I have been put on "gardening leave" by Bradford's chairman. I will, according to Geoffrey Richmond, "continue to be paid by Bradford City and enjoy full benefits but will not participate in its affairs. This will be the situation until suitable compensation has been sorted out with his next employer." Hold on, this milk tastes sour.

0805

Consider my newly-found status as the Charlie Dimmock of football management. Decide it's not so bad: the garden needs a fair bit of work and it feels good not to wear a bra. Decide to do a spot of pruning until Wigan, Bristol City or Sheffield Wednesday offer me a job.

0806

"Bristol City and Wigan Athletic have both confirmed to the club that they have no interest in Paul Jewell as manager," says Richmond. Hrmph... well, that just leaves the way clear for Wednesday, then, doesn't it? Hear that assistant boss Chris Hutchings has been put in temporary control at Valley Parade and Stuart McCall is the early favourite to replace me. Cah! Knock the head off a rose with a trowel.

0807

The bloke next door pops his head over the fence and asks me why I'm leaving a well-run Premiership club for a team in the Nationwide which is falling to pieces. "I won't say anything else until I'm ready and I will issue a statement in the next couple of days," I scream at him, before hurling a bag of compost after his thick inquisitive skull.

0809

Bored now.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Everything's possible in football. Why shouldn't we get our own slice of luck here at Euro 2000?" - How painful it is to watch Germany goalkeeper Oliver Kahn clutch at straws.

SUTT OFF

Not that they want to get rid of him or anything, but Chelsea have accepted a £6m bid from Celtic for Chris Sutton. Cue dancing in the Kings Road. Should the Fiver's Worst Player of the Season agree terms, he'll become Martin O'Neill's first Parkhead signing (and another player Middlesbrough have failed to land - although just how devastated they'll be on this occasion is another question).

And what a signing he'll be, according to Chelsea assistant manager Gwyn Williams. Not that Williams is trying to push the sale through as quickly as possible, oh no. "Chris has never stopped working hard at his game and I've no doubt he'd be a success in Scotland," Williams said, using his best salesman's patter.

"From what I see Celtic have 75% of the play in most games and Chris is at his best with the ball in the box," the Chelsea man continued, before offering to throw in some free batteries and a couple of cassette tapes. "He's learned from working with players such as Gianfranco Zola, George Weah and Tore Andre Flo," Williams concluded, wisely refraining from pointing out exactly what it is that Sutton has learned - ie: that he's not good enough. Now that's what we call a salesman!

THE RUMOUR MILL

Arsene Wenger has admitted he is interested in bringing Sebastian Deisler to Highbury. "We pursue Deisler very closely with Arsenal," Wenger told the German magazine Kicker. "He is an interesting player for us in the future. Unfortunately, he is still susceptible to mistakes and we are waiting to see how he develops."

Bryan Robson has told Liverpool boss Gerard Houllier to forget about taking Christian Ziege to Merseyside. "Christian Ziege is not for sale," slammed Robson. "Liverpool have not got enough money to buy him. There is no get-out clause in his contract."

Internazionale have reportedly made a £16m offer for Paul Scholes, while AC Milan are lining up a bid for David Beckham.

NEWS IN BRIEF

The BBC is to seek an urgent appeal hearing after a judge ruled that it has no legal protection against Talk Radio broadcasting so-called "live" commentary on sporting events by presenters sitting in front of a TV screen.

Nicolas Anelka could miss France's Group D decider against Holland on Wednesday after an old knee injury flared up last week. The Real Madrid star has been unable to take part in the last two French training sessions and has been forced to stay at the team hotel to rest his left knee.

fields.bodyText: BLAIR AND STRAW RESPOND TO UEFA THREAT The Government have responded to Uefa's threat to ban England from Euro 2000. Speaking in Portugal earlier today, Tony Blair condemned last weekend's violence, but stressed the "vast majority" of those British thugs arrested were not known to police. "I deeply regret the behaviour of a small group of people who aren't football fans at all, they are hooligans," said Mr Blair. "We have a very, very good intelligence system, we have dealt with this problem in England. We have to make sure we do everything possible to stamp it out abroad as well." To combat the threat of more violence, Home Secretary Jack Straw has ordered extra police officers to be stationed at ports and airports to identify suspected hooligans before they arrive in Belgium. And the Government have also asked the Belgium authorities not to sell full-strength alcohol before tomorrow's match against Romania. In the longer term, Straw has announced that British clubs will ban for life anyone convicted of football hooliganism. Meanwhile, a major bookmaker has stopped taking bets on which country will host the 2006 World Cup following Uefa's statement. "England had been well backed 5-2 second favourites, but this affair looks likely to scupper their chances completely," explained William Hill spokesman Graham Sharpe. "It is now impossible to make an accurate assessment of England's chances in the light of the current situation - they certainly haven't been improved, so we have closed the book." PAUL JEWELL'S DAY OF LEISURE 0800 Wake up. Reflect on yesterday's events, when I offered my resignation as manager of Bradford after "a lot of soul-searching". Rustle myself up a leisurely breakfast. Mm, these cornflakes sure taste good. 0801 Suddenly remember that my resignation hasn't been accepted and that I have been put on "gardening leave" by Bradford's chairman. I will, according to Geoffrey Richmond, "continue to be paid by Bradford City and enjoy full benefits but will not participate in its affairs. This will be the situation until suitable compensation has been sorted out with his next employer." Hold on, this milk tastes sour. 0805 Consider my newly-found status as the Charlie Dimmock of football management. Decide it's not so bad: the garden needs a fair bit of work and it feels good not to wear a bra. Decide to do a spot of pruning until Wigan, Bristol City or Sheffield Wednesday offer me a job. 0806 "Bristol City and Wigan Athletic have both confirmed to the club that they have no interest in Paul Jewell as manager," says Richmond. Hrmph... well, that just leaves the way clear for Wednesday, then, doesn't it? Hear that assistant boss Chris Hutchings has been put in temporary control at Valley Parade and Stuart McCall is the early favourite to replace me. Cah! Knock the head off a rose with a trowel. 0807 The bloke next door pops his head over the fence and asks me why I'm leaving a well-run Premiership club for a team in the Nationwide which is falling to pieces. "I won't say anything else until I'm ready and I will issue a statement in the next couple of days," I scream at him, before hurling a bag of compost after his thick inquisitive skull. 0809 Bored now. QUOTE OF THE DAY "Everything's possible in football. Why shouldn't we get our own slice of luck here at Euro 2000?" - How painful it is to watch Germany goalkeeper Oliver Kahn clutch at straws. SUTT OFF Not that they want to get rid of him or anything, but Chelsea have accepted a £6m bid from Celtic for Chris Sutton. Cue dancing in the Kings Road. Should the Fiver's Worst Player of the Season agree terms, he'll become Martin O'Neill's first Parkhead signing (and another player Middlesbrough have failed to land - although just how devastated they'll be on this occasion is another question). And what a signing he'll be, according to Chelsea assistant manager Gwyn Williams. Not that Williams is trying to push the sale through as quickly as possible, oh no. "Chris has never stopped working hard at his game and I've no doubt he'd be a success in Scotland," Williams said, using his best salesman's patter. webTitle: Straw braced for defeat over RIP bill

fields.headline: Straw braced for defeat over RIP bill
fields.standfirst: Opposition to a new bill which allows MI5 access to private emails is mounting. The government will have to think again
fields.trailText: Opposition to a new bill which allows MI5 access to private emails is mounting. The government will have to think again, says chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour.
fields.body:
The beleaguered Home Office, already facing criticism over its handling of asylum seekers and football hooligans, is also bracing itself for the prospect of a swath of defeats over the regulation of the internet.

The regulation of investigatory powers (RIP) bill at first looked like an innocent piece of law-making that would ruffle few feathers. It went through the Commons under the tutelage of the Home Office minister Charles Clarke with hardly a whisper.

But since then a rare alliance of libertarians and businesses are up in arms over the bill.

One thinktank, the Foundation for Information Policy Research, has described the RIP bill as the "endgame of a policy shambles that has lasted four years and is one of the outstanding historical failures of civil service policy machinery of the past several decades".

It has warned that authorities will be able to obtain the vast wealth of communications data on anyone on the internet without need for a ministerial or judicial warrant.

The libertarians see the bill as an extraordinary accretion of new powers for the security services, giving them powers to trawl through the nation's email and internet traffic.

Businesses, meanwhile, see it as a massive burden that could cost them billions of pounds. The Institute of Directors has described the legislation as a classic own-goal. Its figures on the cost of the monitoring on business have led to furious exchanges between ministers and business.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, - who is not directly responsible for the RIP bill - hinted last week that he was willing to listen to representations and see if he could lighten the regulatory burden.

But judging by the opening committee debates on the bill in the Lords, there is little sign that the Home Office wants to backtrack on handing the new powers to the security services. M15 already has powers to intercept mail and telephones, but it needs to catch up with email and other new technologies.

In effect, the RIP bill will criminalise anyone who fails to hand over the key to the encryption. Anyone who forgets the key will be liable to two years' imprisonment.

Lord McNally, the Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, said the Lords should stamp on any bill which gives too much power to the executive. He set out three main objections: "The bill is loosely drafted; it's certainly going to be damaging to e-commerce; and rather than consolidating existing powers, it is an extension of powers which is going to restrict civil liberties considerably," he said.

So far Lord Bassam, the Home Office minister, has tried to deflect the criticisms from the Lords by saying he will write to explain why the government is proceeding as it is. By the time the bill reaches report stage, the bill will either have to be rewritten or face the threat of being thrown out.

webTitle: Lorry deaths a 'stark warning', says Straw

fields.headline: Lorry deaths a 'stark warning', says Straw
fields.trailText: The death by suffocation of 58 suspected illegal immigrants whose bodies were found at Dover must "serve as a stark warning to others", the home secretary said today.
fields.body:
The death by suffocation of 58 suspected illegal immigrants whose bodies were found at Dover must "serve as a stark warning to others", the home secretary said today.

In a statement, Jack Straw told the Commons that the deaths, discovered in a refrigerated lorry last night, were "a most terrible human tragedy."

He said: "This terrible tragedy must serve as a stark warning to others who might be tempted to place their fate in the hands of organised traffickers."

Mr Straw told MPs that the dead were the victims of serious organised criminals who make huge profits from smuggling illegal immigrants. The prime minister would be raising the incident and the need for ever better international co-operation against people traffickers with other European leaders at the EU summit in Portugal.

The bodies were found by a customs officer in the back of a refrigerated truck in the port of Dover yesterday, prompting an international police investigation.

Another two people were found alive in the rear of the Dutch-registered vehicle, which was carrying tomatoes, and crossed the Channel on a ferry from the Belgian port of Zeebrugge. The refrigeration unit was switched off.

The dead - 54 men and four women - and the survivors appeared to be from the Far East, possibly Chinese, the Home Office said.

Police arrested the Dutch driver of the 15m-long truck. The vehicle aroused suspicion because it was registered to a company, Van Der Spek, which had not used the route before, ferry operators P&O Stena Line said.

Government leaders pledged new attempts to crack down on international crime gangs who traffic in illegal immigrants, charging up to £20,000 per person.

The survivors, both men, were hospitalised and were expected to recover, but were too traumatised by their horrific experience to be questioned immediately.

Customs officials said the truck, which arrived just before midnight, was searched because it fitted a "profile" of suspect vehicles.

British police and forces on the continent began trying to track the movements of the truck before it boarded the ferry.

The vehicle left Belgium on Sunday, the hottest day of the year in England and parts of northern Europe, with temperatures reaching 30C (86F).

In April, the government introduced a fine of £2,000 per person on truckers caught smuggling illegal immigrants.

Refugee advocates condemned the immigrant smuggling rings, but Refugee Council chief executive Nick Hardwick said the main problem was that "it is virtually impossible for people feeling persecution to enter Britain legally."

"They are therefore forced to search for such desperate measures in their search for sanctuary," he said.

Smuggling illegal immigrants has become a profitable - and dangerous - business in Europe. At least 173 people drowned last year in the Adriatic attempting to cross from Albania to Italy.

fields.headline: Step on it, my son
fields.standfirst: Gangster chic is spilling out of the movies and on to the road. But what do the  real villains look for in a motor? By  Sophie Radice
fields.trailText: Gangster chic is spilling out of the movies and on to the road. But what do the real villains look for in a motor? By Sophie Radice
fields.body:
If a nice young man wants to drive something really stylish with a naughty edge, he acquires an old Jaguar XJ6 for a couple of grand (or less if it needs work). With its gorgeous swooping lines and stately road presence, he recognises it as being a bit flash in a late-60s, early-70s sort of way. Although his brushes with the law probably amount to a parking fine or two, or a ticking-off from a policeman for stopping on a double yellow line by the cashpoint, when he cruises along with his radio turned up he can imagine that he has a bit of a shady past.

"Gangster chic" - in which completely law-abiding men can indulge in mobster fantasies - has become all the rage since Guy Ritchie's hugely successful Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels. This inspired a rash of lame British gangster films such as Love, Honour and Obey, Honest, and the re-release of The Long Good Friday, as well as the much-panned small screen spin-off of Lock, Stock. The British mobster style has not only taken over the fashion pages of men's magazines - with crombies, well-cut shirts, sharp suits and silk socks - it has also spilled over on to the road, too.

Although the driver of an old Jag may well look like Arthur Daley or EastEnder Phil Mitchell (both XJ6 drivers) to the rest of the world, in his mind's eye it is more likely he is imagining himself as Michael Caine in Get Carter, or any of the 60s criminals in the excellent Gangster Number One, which has extra verisimilitude because of the input of special adviser Bruce Reynolds, mastermind of the Great Train Robbery.

John Wetherhall, who runs a Jaguar restoration garage near Bristol, admits that some of his customers fall in love with the car because it has associations of diamond dealing or multiple night-club owning: "It is a perfectly harmless, though deeply risible game of celluloid British gangster nostalgia, although there are an awful lot of respectable classic Jag owners who simply love the aesthetic of the car. There is very little chance of this 'gangster fashion' kind of driver - who usually seems to work in the media - ever being mistaken for the real thing and pulled over as a suspect for the latest bank heist. If the truth be known, gangsters don't really drive Jags or Daimlers any more."

He's right. Today's gangster is much more likely to drive an SUV (sports utility vehicle) for his loathsome trade of drug-dealing, extortion and general racketeering. Although in the 80s, the gangsters of London, Manchester and Glasgow emulated the company cars of City boys by driving BMWs or Mercedes - giving the spoilt financial and services sector some welcome street cred - the 21st-century gangster seems to have more practical considerations on his mind.

Now Mitsubishi Shoguns, Range Rover Vogues and Discoveries are the cars of choice for the successful criminal. Just as well-heeled mothers like a four-wheel drive so they can protect their hordes of kids from the dangers of city traffic while showing off their wealth, status and procreative ambitions, so the gangster wants a rottweiler of the road to both intimidate and impress his rivals and victims.

Kenneth Noye - who was connected with the money-laundering of the Brinks Mat robbery, the murder of a policeman and was finally arrested for a road rage killing - was the proud owner of an L-reg Land Rover Discovery. In Brent, north London, last February, various SUVs were involved in a terrifying shoot-out in the car park of a leisure complex with hundreds of people caught inside. It all started because the girlfriends of rival criminal gangs got into an argument about parking places. It seems you need at lot of room for an SUV, which gives the driver a feeling of power and strength. You can look down on fellow drivers from patrician heights and feel distanced from the hoi polloi.

The difference in the vehicles driven by the wealthy mum and the gangland leader are in the all- important details. "Bobby", who used to be involved with a notorious north London gang, says: "The glass must be blacked out, the sound system powerful enough to permanently change the rhythm of your heartbeat, and the spare wheel cover has to come from a dealer in Park Lane or Knightsbridge - to show you have the money to go to the best places and pay up front and in full. Basically, it is like a very comfortable tank in a very dirty war: a real fuck-off set of wheels."

Although the SUV offers protection and security, gangsters - be they Yardies, East End boys or Triads - still like a flash car for the evening, or "non-work" assignations. And some people aspire to this gangster fashion. In the estate opposite my house, which is so full of drug dealers there are plans to pull it down, there is one man who owns a four-wheel drive and a BMW Z3 which, unlike my tatty old Peugeot 309, never seems to get vandalised or broken into.

It is obviously much more important for someone in such a world to display their success by the expense and quality of their wheels than to have a comfortable and salubrious home. Pat Goldman, a criminologist undertaking a study of British gangsters, says: "The whole point of being a criminal involved in drugs or prostitution is that it affords you status you otherwise would not have had. The gangster cares less about attracting the attention of the police who, if Jack Straw gets his way, may be given the power to seize cars which they believe to have been bought by ill-gotten gains, than gaining the respect and envy of the local villains."

Dave Courtney - the former gangster who describes himself as a reformed criminal, and who wrote Stop the Ride I Want to Get Off - now drives a white Rolls-Royce with a small England flag down the side: "You only get caught," he says, "if you are making mistakes and drawing attention to yourself."

This is certainly the case with the late playboy robber and gangster Valerio Viccei, who masterminded the Knightsbridge safety deposit job which at £62m is the biggest bank robbery Britain has ever known. The haul was so enormous that Viccei, also known as "the Wolf", filled his bath with banknotes and covered the floor of his flat in north London with jewels. He could have fled, having transferred much of his fortune to safety deposits around the world, but delayed his departure because he was waiting to get his beloved red Ferrari exported. He was arrested at his favourite London hotel, Whites, after his fingerprint was found on one of the safety deposit boxes, and still attempted to escape in his shiny car which he called "the love of his life".

fields.headline: Me and my motor
fields.trailText: Amanda Stretton
fields.body:
What do you drive?
A Seat Ibiza Cupra Sport, orange and bronze.

What do you like or dislike about it?
I hate the colour - and the white wheels. When I first saw it, I refused to get in. Then I was told no one in their right mind would pinch an Orange Seat with white wheels!

Why did you buy it?
I needed a car quick. I looked at a Subaru, but the salesman didn't know how to handle me. I was asking the right questions - but I was a girl . He wondered if I could handle the power. So I gave the car a real white-knuckle test drive. The poor guy was hanging on to his seat.

What kind of driver are you?
Fairly normal on the road. But track driving is different. Then it's OK to be aggressive because everyone is travelling in the same direction.

Any bad habits?
Getting irritated by people who dither at traffic lights and junctions. And I really ought to leave more time for my trips.

Any driving test tales?
I passed my test within days of my 17th birthday. My driving was fine but I got the Highway Code wrong. A motorcyclist came off his bike in front of me and, as well as avoiding running him over, I didn't hit anyone else. My instructor was impressed.

My only crash on the road was the first time I drove abroad, in my father's Jaguar C-type. I have three points for speeding, and am about to get a shed-load more.

I drive to most of the circuits, so do a fair bit of motorway driving. I loathe public transport, so often drive when I go out at night. It stops me drinking.

Normally it's a mess and full of mud. I use it so much I never get round to cleaning it.

What's in the glove compartment and the boot?
The glove compartment is full of music. The boot has baseball hats, a coat and a pen.

Ever had sex in a car?
Yes.

Expand.
No.

If I'm going racing, something loud and dancey. If I am going somewhere grown-up, opera. When I drive home late at night, Radio 4 keeps me awake.

fields.headline: Trafficking in human misery
fields.standfirst: The home secretary's tough line on asylum seekers has little effect on people desperate to enter Britain
fields.trailText: The home secretary's tough line on asylum seekers has little effect on people desperate to enter Britain, argues Derek Brown.
fields.body:
The Home Office's favoured soundbite on illegal immigration is that its latest measures are "fairer, faster and firmer". Human rights groups have strong doubts about the first two claims.

The continuing determination of would-be immigrants to reach Britain was grimly underlined by this morning's ghastly discovery in Dover. Word of Jack Straw's tough new stance has clearly failed to get through to the victims of the people-smuggling trade.

Whatever their motive, they are still desperate to slip past the searchers at Britain's harbours and airports. Those who make it are part of what the rightwing press describe as a "horde" of "bogus" asylum seekers, convinced that the UK is a "soft touch".

The home secretary has done his best to ensure that the last perception is unfounded. Increased surveillance at points of entry, the establishment of spartan secure detention centres, and the removal of asylum seekers from the benefits system are just some of the new measures he has introduced.

For the most part they are heartily approved by those who would reduce all immigration to a trickle. But do they work?

One of the most dramatic initiatives undertaken by the government in its 1999 immigration act was to introduce statutory fines for lorry drivers found to be smuggling people into the country - whether wittingly or otherwise. The penalty, of £2,000 per head plus possible confiscation of the vehicle, has outraged long-distance drivers who say they cannot possibly unseal, open, and check their loads every time they cross a frontier.

It has also failed to deter those who are intent on making a fast, handsome buck from the squalid trade in humanity.

Putting a cash figure on the price of illegal immigration is fraught with conjecture. In some poorer countries, refugees pay only a small deposit, but are made to sign themselves into virtual slavery until they can work off the smugglers' fee, or have it paid by their families.

The going rate is said to be anything up to £20,000 - 10 times more than the minimum fines on lorry drivers. With that kind of money on offer, it is little wonder that criminals are leeching on to the plight of would-be refugees.

But Mr Straw remains convinced that harshness works. In the aftermath of the Dover discovery, he called for a joint European onslaught on the smuggling racket. "The government is determined to crack down on the evil trade in such trafficking, whose perpetrators have no regard for human life," he said.

Neil Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, saw the latest tragedy in quite another light. "It is virtually impossible for people fleeing persecution to enter Britain legally and they are therefore forced to resort to such desperate measures in their search for sanctuary," he said.
