fields.headline: Magazines are us
fields.standfirst: Find out everything you'll ever need to know about magazine and online publishing at Earls Court this week
fields.trailText: Find out everything you'll ever need to know about magazine and online publishing at Earls Court this week
fields.body:
Supported by the Guardian, Total Publishing is the UK's premier event for magazine and online publishing, growing so fast since its debut in 1997 that it has had to move this year to a larger venue in the Earls Court exhibition centre. Alongside the trade fair with 200 exhibitors, the two-day show (which starts on Wednesday) runs training workshops, free seminars and celebrity speaker events.

Headliner speakers include Mike Potter and Christopher Ward of the customer magazine company Redwood, maverick Loaded and GQ editor turned IFG boss James Brown, and Wallpaper's Tyler Brlé, who remains editor of the chic interiors title despite selling it to Time Warner. Among other attractions are sessions on design, subscriptions, sales, brand extensions and "Sex, Chocolate and Magazines", a briefing on "how to make your magazine more desirable".

Also free are sessions to keep industry professionals abreast of changes in production technology, and combining panel discussions (on issues such as digital advertising, colour consistency and pre-press developments) and solo presentations. Puzzled by such buzz-phrases as "digital workflow", "online procurement" and "computer-to-plate"? Here's your chance to get up to speed.

One strand of workshops is devoted to technology, with professional trainers giving coaching on InDesign, HTML, Photoshop, QuarkXPress or Flash, and on turning print documents into web pages and using databases to generate artwork. Another strand focuses on skills, including design, marketing, sales, databases and briefing clients.Workshops are £45 plus VAT (pre-booking is recommended).

The growth in publishing on the web is reflected in two of this year's innovations. Suppliers will give presentations on topics including inter net strategy, digital copyright, advertising and "unleashing the power of content" and Apple will give the UK's first preview of Mac OS X.

Also new for 2000 are online publishing workshops, covering setting-up, writing, design, marketing, sales and driving revenue. David Rowan of Guardian Unlimited is part of a panel discussing online publishing and four cutting-edge agencies set out the rules of good web design.

Judged by 21 experts from the mag world's many sectors and specialisms, the Total Publishing Magazine Design Awards will be presented at the Park Lane Hotel on Wednesday. "Best Designed . . ." prizes for consumer, customer, business magazines are up for grabs, with similar awards for newspaper magazines - with Weekend Guardian among the finalists - and webzines. Equally likely to provoke cheers and boos is the Guardian-sponsored Photographer of the Year award, where the all-male shortlist consists of two snappers from Dazed & Confused (including Rankin, its inspirational publisher), two from Condé Nast Traveller, and one each from the Independent and FT magazines.

Dazed & Confused also makes the shortlist for Front Cover of the Year, where it and the RSPB title Birds face competition from titles from bigger publishers - Esquire (Nat Mags), Wallpaper (Time Warner), MacUser (Dennis) and Weekend Guardian (Guardian Media Group).

 Total Publishing is at Earls Court 2 on June 21-22. Information and booking: www.totalpublishing.co.uk. Hotline for workshop booking: 0870 7511 468

fields.headline: Need to know: Joel Bellenson
fields.trailText:
Age?
35.
fields.body:
Age?
35.

Who is he?
Chief executive and co-founder of DigiScents.com, a US scent communication network and content company. Previously co-ran DoubleTwist, the first company to analyse the human genome.

What's the clever idea?
"That we index a scent according to its chemical composition and place in a scent spectrum. Then we digitise the scent into a small file which can be incorporated with any other media, any kind of web content - interactive games, movies, music, web pages, flash animation, streaming videos, MP3 files, DVD or email. And because our method of digitisation is based on fundamentals of neurobiology, we have a way of describing smell in an objective way which interprets the odour molecules as opposed to just a simple description."

What's the thinking behind it?
"We had been running this biotech and information technology company and wanted to think about ways to apply that to other problems. Vacationing in Florida, struck by the beauty and powerful aromas, the thought hit me that scent is more than the picture and the sound. It adds this extra dimension. There was a twin opportunity for rational design of fragrances and flavours.

How does it work?
"Any media can become scent-enabled. We have a relationship with Real Networks to distribute our ScentStream player to their 100m customers and you can download it from our website. All these PCs then will be able to playback scent through the plug-and-play hardware, which has a cartridge pallete of 128 basic odorants and is controlled by the software from the PC. Then it's up to the creativity of the people using it - commerce or entertainment. Many games and movies make good use of accompanying music for creating a mood, and similarly that can be done with smell - on the PC or eventually TV.

Possible shortcomings?
"We don't claim we can duplicate every scent with 100% accuracy. We can probably hit thousands of smells that people have encountered in their lives very close to the mark, others maybe only 80-90% of the way there, though we can create millions of new smells, smell themes and combinations."

What's next?
"This will be the fastest roll-out of an adoption of new media technology ever, creating the standard for smell. We're targeting the end of the year as our international release date - we're getting approximately 100 new business inquiries per day. We're trying to see if there's a possibility of making a smell camera and also to add something to artificial noses, which don't detect smell the same way."

fields.headline: New media diary
fields.body:
 Another week, another catalogue of cutbacks in the industry. Instead of morbidly dwelling on them (let's leave that to the party poopers), the diary would like to celebrate some of the fantastic recruitment opportunities that have arisen in the past week. For starters, Whittards has just bought the e-tail outfit TheBestOfBritish.com from the Hollinger Telegraph group and plans to turn it into a major luxury goods portal (this might be of interest to some of the 226 Somerfield staff who face redundancy now that the supermaket chain has scrapped its 24-7 internet home shopping service). It's not all doom and gloom in the venture capital world either (despite news that incubator eSouk has just laid off 15 of its 22 staff and is downsizing to "an investor in early stage start-ups" and Incubator has been forced to close due to "overcrowding" in the incubator market): ThinkVentures, which was started by former Freeserve co-founder Mark Danby, is on a major recruitment drive to spearhead its international expansion. So there you go - positive thinking.

 Boo.com will not be forgotten in vain. Not only is the name being resurrected by fashionmall.com, who will be turning it into a billboard for other companies, but ShopSmart.com Sweden, which has just bought boo's überchic Stockholm offices and equipment for the price of a semi in Tottenham, will be remembering the disastrous fashion e-tailing experiment in a unique way. Resourceful staff have decided to turn the abandoned boo-branded paraphernalia - the sweatbands, baseball caps and T-shirts etcetera - into a shrine in the boardroom. Managing director Anders Bergtoft tells the diary, "this to remind ourselves constantly of the dangers of the three Cs: Concorde, champagne and caviar. With ShopSmart we will follow more the three Bs: buses, beer and burgers".

 The mobile internet portal being launched by Carphone Warehouse and AOL in July has unveiled its funky rebranded image as Mviva (formerly mob-e.com), promising more than 50 content partners including Sports.com and Eurobet. Why the sudden name change from mob-e? Could it be that any association with the big doomed whale of Melville's great 19th century novel was just too huge a hostage to fortune? Meanwhile, Orange is catching up, announcing a new ezine, O, to drive subscriptions for its long-awaited Wap services.

 John Brown Publishing launched its new commerce portal BlueSnake.com last week, a spin-off from Bizarre magazine. One of the "best-selling" gadgets on offer is a "squeezie stress willie", perfect for overwrought dot.comers. How thoughtful...

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.body:
 Imitation is the best form of flattery. Today, BBC1 controller Peter Salmon launches The People's Awards - a marvellous new show which will scour Britain for ordinary people of achievement. This innovative idea has nothing whatsoever to do with the Mirror's Pride of Britain awards, now in its third year, which recently pulled in 10m viewers for ITV. Piers Morgan, Mirror editor, says: "There is only one Oscars, as they say, and we're it." The BBC maintains that the Mirror approached it first about televising its event, but was rejected because The People's Awards was already in development. In that case, how has the BBC managed to be more than two years behind? No response. It's all very odd.

 Stand by for conflict. The ITV Network sent in its "final, final" proposals on Friday to the Independent Television Commission over the News at Ten row, but is refusing to make any more concessions. The companies are refusing to move the late night news forward to 10.30pm. The document is barely indistinguishable from the last (rejected) plan. The ITC meets on Thursday. The diary is all a-quiver at the thought of the two sides clashing in court.

 The appointment of the formidable Patricia Hodgson as the next chief executive of the ITC is seen as a hopeful sign by her admirers (though she will not take charge until September, too late to settle the news row). "She's really a politician, and if anyone can save it, she can," says a fan. Hodgson is part of what many expect to become a "Beebification" of the ITC, whose members include her former boss, Sir Michael Checkland. But the diary can report that the news of her new job made her BBC colleagues uncommonly cheerful - and was greeted with gloom by ITC staff. "Shall I open a vein now?" quipped an official.

 While staffers at the Express ponder their fate in the takeovers about to engulf Lord Hollick's United News & Media empire, they at least have this to fall back on. On the Monday after Tony Blair returned from semi-paternity leave, he chose to attend a select lunch with Hollick, Rosie Boycott and several deputies. The subject of conversation? How important the Express was, now that the Mail had lost the plot. It warms the heart to see such co-operative behaviour.

 You can email Maggie Brown on maggiebrown.media@btinternet.com

fields.headline: My media: Peter Snow
fields.trailText:
Newspapers:
The broadsheets on Sundays and during the week the Times, Guardian and Daily Mail. I'd like to take the lot. The wonderful thing about the British press is the huge variety and completely anarchic way one can read about almost anything. I enjoy Simon Jenkins, Andrew Marr, Will Hutton, Andrew Rawnsley and Hugo Young most of all.
fields.body:
Newspapers:
The broadsheets on Sundays and during the week the Times, Guardian and Daily Mail. I'd like to take the lot. The wonderful thing about the British press is the huge variety and completely anarchic way one can read about almost anything. I enjoy Simon Jenkins, Andrew Marr, Will Hutton, Andrew Rawnsley and Hugo Young most of all.

Magazines:
Private Eye, the National Geographic and New Yorker. I'm very influenced by the covers of weeklies - the Spectator, New Statesman, Economist - which of course is very superficial of me.

Books:
Racy novels, good adventure stories, detective novels and books about the sea. I'm an absolute glutton for CS Forester's Hornblower novels. And any political biographies - De Gaulle, Gladstone, even John Major I'm glad to say.

Films:
I do like colossal films, huge films. Braveheart, Titanic, Gladiator. All-time favourite is Lawrence of Arabia.

Television:
I'm completely sold on the recent costume dramas - Wives and Daughters, all the Austens, Copperfield. Ali G is unmissable. Frasier and some of that late night American comedy stuff on Channel 4 is lovely verbal slapstick. I adore good documentaries. The Nine O'Clock News, Question Time and, of course, Newsnight. Alas, News at Ten has gone. I love science programmes. I'm not interested in people doing ordinary things like holidays and decorating houses.

Radio:
I enjoy Andrew Rawnsley's Westminster Hour and File on 4. Current affairs and news are very good and I listen a lot. Today is the master - there's nothing to touch it.

Ads:
I get bored with ads that don't tell me what they're advertising. On television I think ads are becoming extremely sophisticated and actually quite watchable.

Multimedia:
I've got a mobile, an organiser and a palm top.

The wonderful thing about the British press is the huge variety and completely anarchic way one can read about almost anything. I enjoy Simon Jenkins, Andrew Marr, Will Hutton, Andrew Rawnsley and Hugo Young most of all. Magazines: Private Eye, the National Geographic and New Yorker. I'm very influenced by the covers of weeklies - the Spectator, New Statesman, Economist - which of course is very superficial of me. Books: Racy novels, good adventure stories, detective novels and books about the sea. I'm an absolute glutton for CS Forester's Hornblower novels. And any political biographies - De Gaulle, Gladstone, even John Major I'm glad to say. Films: I do like colossal films, huge films. Braveheart, Titanic, Gladiator. All-time favourite is Lawrence of Arabia. Television: I'm completely sold on the recent costume dramas - Wives and Daughters, all the Austens, Copperfield. Ali G is unmissable. Frasier and some of that late night American comedy stuff on Channel 4 is lovely verbal slapstick. I adore good documentaries. The Nine O'Clock News, Question Time and, of course, Newsnight. Alas, News at Ten has gone. I love science programmes. I'm not interested in people doing ordinary things like holidays and decorating houses. Radio: I enjoy Andrew Rawnsley's Westminster Hour and File on 4. Current affairs and news are very good and I listen a lot. Today is the master - there's nothing to touch it. Ads: I get bored with ads that don't tell me what they're advertising. On television I think ads are becoming extremely sophisticated and actually quite watchable. Multimedia: I've got a mobile, an organiser and a palm top. •: Peter Snow presents Mars: A Traveller's Guide (BBC Knowledge, June 27).

webTitle: What's the true cost of BBC3?

fields.headline: What's the true cost of BBC3?
fields.trailText: In Banff last week, 5,000 miles from the Match of the Day furore, Mark Thompson offered his vision of the BBC. Let him have no doubt of the hornets' nest he will stir up.
fields.body:
In Banff last week, 5,000 miles from the Match of the Day furore, Mark Thompson offered his vision of the BBC. His radical response to the rising number of multi-channel homes, and the growing ease of surfing that electronic programme guides and Tivo devices offer, is the future segmentation of BBC television output by genre, akin to the radio realignments the BBC introduced 30 years ago. Let him have no doubt of the hornets' nest he will stir up.

First, we need to examine the parallel with BBC radio. There, the mixed schedule disappeared soon after the war, with the introduction of the Third Programme to accompany the Home Service and the Light Programme. These three channels later became Radios 2, 3 and 4, and were joined by Radios 1 and 5 Live, as commercial radio - clearly segmented, to reflect how people listened - pushed the BBC further down the same route.

Yet the rise of multi-channel commercial TV - as segmented an offering as commercial radio - has barely affected the balanced nature of terrestrial TV services: even Channel 5 has pursued a mixed schedule. People watch a wide range of programme genres, and like to find them in their preferred channel environments.

There is programme content that people will search out, whatever channel it's on. But the first inevitable consequence of reshuffling all BBC content by genre, as Thompson proposes, will be a sharp fall in the level of viewing for serious material if it is evicted from the mass audience channels.

This may be the BBC's strategic objective. Dislodging all serious material except the news from BBC1 (and moving the news back an hour) will improve its viewing share. Will the dislodged material transfer to BBC2? And will ratings successes such as Have I Got News For You? and The Simpsons follow Ground Force and The Royle Family to BBC1? If there is a straight swap, BBC2's loss of viewing share will simply counterbalance BBC1's gain.

But this two-dimensional exchange is an unlikely outcome. There is more serious material on BBC1 than mass audience material on BBC2. The cascade effect will see the most serious material on BBC2 dislodged to BBC Knowledge, BBC Parliament and BBC Choice, with children's programmes on BBC1 perhaps shuffled onto BBC Children's.

That way, total BBC audience share might be enhanced, or at least protected against further multi-channel erosion. But simply providing serious and minority-appeal programming, and then effectively hiding it from public view, is a curious redefinition of public service broadcasting.

There is another major difference between radio and TV. In radio, the BBC's biggest spend is on its most visibly public service channels - 3 and 4. Radios 1 and 2 would be far more controversial than they are as public service offerings if they cost the licence fee payer more than £3 a year. But BBC1 costs the licence-fee payer £40 a year, as a forced tax. If it becomes simply an entertainment channel without ads, what is the political justification for poor and rich alike paying such a sum, with no choice as to whether they want it?

Perhaps Thompson assumes it would indeed be funded by advertising - but there is resistance in Brussels to public service broadcasters, funded by licence fees, also seeking advertising in competition with commercial operators.

If the BBC were subscription-funded, the Thompson plan would be far less controversial. It could charge different fees for different services, and the consumer would quickly tell the corporation whether it was on to a winner. But the licence fee - rightly or wrongly - subjects the BBC to a far stronger public perception of obligations than, say, ITV, or even Channel 4, as the Match of the Day row illustrated. A mixed schedule on BBC1 reflects the fact that it is funded by all and therefore should offer programming of many types.

Funding of £900m a year for an entertainment service is an impossible burden to place on the already strained justification for the licence fee. After all, in entertainment more than any other area of activity, the BBC depends on outside talent - writers, performers, directors, producers - rather than staff: the creative pool that all broadcasters can tap, rather than being the exclusive preserve of a BBC culture or policy.

Thompson's digital vision may be well-suited to the future realities of broadcasting: but not to the licence-fee mechanism. His radicalism needs to be at least as much directed to the funding question as to the content and packaging issues. That really would be radical.

 David Elstein is chief executive of Channel 5

webTitle: Dundee to take third outing to the outback

fields.headline: Dundee to take third outing to the outback
fields.trailText: The Queensland government has confirmed that Paul Hogan will be returning to Australia to make a third movie on the Crocodile Dundee series
fields.body:
The Queensland government yesterday confirmed that Paul Hogan will be returning to Australia to make a third movie in the Crocodile Dundee series, as we reported several months ago.

Crocodile Dundee III will be filmed from August at the Movie World Studios on the Gold Coast in Queensland and at other locations in the state before moving to Los Angeles.

It is 14 years since Hogan achieved international stardom with his first portrayal of the laconic bush legend Mick Dundee.

Produced and co-written by Hogan, Crocodile Dundee III will star his wife Linda Kozlowski (pictured, with Hogan), whom he met while filming the original. The the new comedy will see Mick Dundee taking a trip to Hollywood.

The Dundee character was based on Northern Territory bushman Rodney Ansell, who died last year in a shootout with police near Darwin.

webTitle: Jackson honoured on Hollywood's Walk of Fame

fields.headline: Jackson honoured on Hollywood's Walk of Fame
fields.trailText: Off the cinema screens this weekend, attention remained firmly on Samuel L. Jackson as the 51-year-old actor was immortalised with his own star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame
fields.body:
Off the cinema screens this weekend, attention remained firmly on Samuel L Jackson, with the 51-year-old actor's immortalisation on Hollywood's Walk of Fame.

The inauguration of the star on Friday coincided with the release of Shaft, a remake of the 1971 film sensation in which Jackson plays the leading role.

"When I came here in 1969, I looked at all the names on Hollywood Boulevard and it never came across my mind that I would be a part of this, even once I got in this business," said Jackson

The Walk of Fame, where more than 2,000 names appear on stars on Hollywood Boulevard, is a coveted tribute to entertainment personalities. The first star was laid on February 9, 1960 in honour of actress Joanne Woodward.

fields.headline: Transcript: Linda Grant live online
fields.standfirst: The journalist and Orange winning author of When I lived in Modern Times thinks that book prizes are just a marketing exercise, loves e-books and deliberately didn't read Zadie Smith. Read the full debate here
fields.trailText: The journalist and Orange winning author of When I lived in Modern Times thinks that book prizes are just a marketing exercise, loves e-books and deliberately didn't read Zadie Smith. Read the full debate here
fields.body:
LindaGrant1
Hi. I'm here. People seem to want to know about the difference between writing journalism and writing fiction. I don't think there's such a big wall. Both of them ought to be about good writing and telling stories.

blackbird21
Did you ever really expect to win the Orange Prize? Considering Zadie Smith was supposedly the favourite and her publishers were already putting stickers on White Teeth with 'Orange Prize winner' on?

LindaGrant1
Blackbird: Did I expect to win the Orange Prize? Well, not myself, no. In fact friends can testify that up to being in the car on the way to the ceremony I was adamantly saying that I wasn't. But I have to say that starting around a week before, people started telling me that they thought I was going to win. And some of those were fairly close to the process. However I just thought that they were being nice. I found out later that someone bet on me and won £400. I did think that the field was more open than others thought. I wouldn't have been surprised if Judy Budnitz or Elizabeth Strout won.

shem32
What's your attitude to a woman-only prize? Would you appear in a woman-only anthology?

LindaGrant1
shem32: My attitude to a women only prize? Well, every prize has some kind of restriction on it. The Booker excludes American writers (and it would be a very different shortlist if it didn't.) There are prizes I'm not eligible for - first novel by a writer under 35 for example. In the end, however, prizes shouldn't really be judged as the "best" book but rather as a marketing exercise to sell books. Every shortlisted writer on any prize finds their sales rocketing. As for appearing in an all-women anthology - of course, the same as if it were an all-UK anthology or all Jewish.

Mrudu
Is writing for journalism any different from writing for fiction? Are you working on anything now? How much research did your book involve? Have you read Zadie Smith's book. If yes, your opinion?

LindaGrant1
Mrudu:I read a few books for the research but principally, I would say that the two most important pieces of research I did were with an elderly lady living in Jerusalem who talked to me for hours about her own life during that period, and walking the streets of Tel Aviv for days on end. As for Zadie Smith's book, no I haven't read it, quite deliberately. I decided not to read any of the books on the shortlist before the prize was announced because I didn't want to get depressed, thinking, well, I can't possibly win. Finally, I'm going off tomorrow to Cornwall to start work on another novel, this one set in Liverpool, in the present

sgcc2
Do you see obvious parallels between the Israel of When I Lived... and Britain under New Labour: a people hoping to put a dark past behind them, then experiencing the dream fading, the fudge setting in, even the buildings gradually losing their gloss? Was it deliberate?

LindaGrant1
sgcc2: I have to say that I never gave New Labour a thought when I was writing this, but the metaphor of Tel Aviv (and indeed the whole book) is about idealism and its failures. What I really was thinking about was the war in Kosovo which was going on at the time. I couldn't make my mind up what I thought about it and it occurred to me that in the end it didn't actually matter as I wasn't affected one way or the other. The characters in my book, however, are in a very different situation. Whatever they decide will determine their future. I think this isn't understood about the contemporary situation in the Middle East.

CCole
Who would you cite as your literary influences?

LindaGrant1
Ccole: My literary influences - Dickens (another journalist turned novelist), the Jewish American big hitters like Roth and Bellow, and women writers like Nancy Mitford and Jean Rhys who are fantastic on how women construct their identity through clothes.

tamara
Would you call yourself a journalistic novelist bearing in mind your other career?

LindaGrant1
tamara: I'm not sure what a journalistic novelist is, but I don't think I like the sound of it.

mmreed
You've written about your mother's experiences with Alzheimer's... Family memoir seems to be an increasingly popular genre (I'm thinking of Dave Eggars at the moment with his story of bringing up his younger brother). Is it hard to write 'truthfully' about family? Did you feel intrusive? Did you feel you were producing a piece of writing for all or a helpful text for others with the same problems and issues?

LindaGrant1
mmreed: Writing Remind Me was a difficult decision to make and I wouldn't have done so if my sister hadn't srtongly supported me. The point is that the two of us felt very very alone when we were going through our problems and the whole discourse on the subject was dominated by people saying, well, of course, I love my mother I could never put her in a home. Someone had to break out of this. But I think that the book has a much broader message, which is that none of us really know our parents.

tamara
And have you read any of the Catherine Sayler mysteries by American crime writer Linda Grant...? (Or are you leading a double literary life?)

LindaGrant1
tamara: The funny thing about Catherine Sayler is that she's about the same age as me and has the same hairstyle, only blonde. I looked at her website. But no, I haven't read them, mainly because I'm not much of a one for crime fiction. I notice on Amazon (all writers are obsessed with the Amazon sales figures) that her rankings have shot up since I won the Orange.

rgsharp
What do you think of Andrea Dworkin's take on Israel (and her ultra-emotive journalism, for that matter)?

LindaGrant1
rgsharp: I think Andrea Dworkin's take on Israel is extremely interesting (more so than her absurd idea that there should be a country for women.) She's trying to address something people find hard to get to grips with, that maybe there is more than one victim here and that victims are capable of victimising each other. I think this makes many people fairly annoyed because it's much easier to find a set of good guys and a set of bad guys. She's trying to assess how the experience of anti-semitism affected the Jews and in particular what happened when they tried to fight back. I think this is well worth listening to. BUT I also believe that her view of contemporary Israel is fairly out of date, like the fact that she'd never heard of Dana International.

dan314
Did you find that your experience as a journalist helped or hindered you in writing When I lived in Modern Times?

LindaGrant1
dan314: Being a journalist means that I'm more interested in what goes on outside my own front door than in my own psyche. One way in which it hinders is that I think I'm too much of a stickler for factual accuracy. I should liberate my imagination a bit more. I'm amazed to find that friends of mine who have written memoir type books have not always told the strict truth.

Tally43
Has winning the prize given you any more confidence in your skills as a writer - or do you think that the whole idea of literary prizes is bogus? Has it changed things for you at all?

LindaGrant1
tally 43: Well, I've been accused of being arrogant. I was actually fairly confident of my skills as a writer. It was a damned sight harder to get other people to take them seriously. Every review referred to the fact that I was a journalist, as if this was a kind of warning. I have worked very hard to develop a deceptively transparent style and never more so than in Modern Times where the writing was supposed to mimic the architecture, very simple and very unadorned. I don't want the reader to have their attention drawn to the language. I want the language to be supple and simple and to contain a punch because you don't notice that it's creeping up on you. Has the prize made a difference? Absolutely. I feel that I no longer have to struggle to be taken seriously.

naomi2
Do you think the printed novel is becoming an outmoded form? Do you think traditional publishing has a future? Obviously the computer screen cannot replace the portability of a book, but what about WAP phones and palm pilots etc? Do you have any particular interest in new technologies? Also as a print journalist, all these new developments in publishing must also impact on you?

LindaGrant1
Naomi: I think that the printed book will definitely become an outmoded form. In fact I was saying to a friend on Friday, one day people will be judged on their age as "she's the sort of person who still has bookshelves", like I'm the sort of person who is old enough to still have some vinyl hanging about the house. I LOVE new technology. I love living in modern times. The book will continue to exist, though not in the same form. It will be downloaded from the internet onto some book-sized reader. This exists already but there are problems about the weight because of the battery. But it will be fixed.

shem32
Did you like the Ya Ya Sisterhood book? I ask because there was much snobbish sneering when it made the shortlist... Should the orange shortlist be different from the Booker? - or is it just about 'the best' books? (pretty subjective, anyway...)

LindaGrant1
I haven't read Divine Scretes, as I haven't read any of the others on the shortlist. I think that if the judges put it on the shortlist, there will have been a reason. I'm a big fan of well-written non-literary fiction. The trouble is finding the stuff that IS well-written.

CCole
Do you ever play the Desert Island Disc game? What would be the book you'd take?

LindaGrant1
Ccole: I have fantasising about my desert island book since I was about 15. I think it would have to be Proust - I've been trying to finish it since I was in my twenties. I'm about halfway through and I love it but finding the time 

trapeze
Congratulations Linda - it must be wonderful to have been given such a strong vote of confidence. You bring a strong Jewish identity to most of your writing. Do your publishers ever worry that this will ghettoise your work? Does this affect your American sales - and are you known in Israel?

LindaGrant1
Trapeze: The Jewish question is a really interesting one. Up till now I've not had a US publisher (Modern Times was turned down by everybody - then the morning after the announcement my agent's phone was ringing off the hook.) I think that part of the reason for this is that Americans think that British Jews aren't real Jews. Someone said to me that the British talk with la-di-dah accents and drink their tea with their fingers crooked. To be a Jew is to very much the opposite of being British - reserved, laconic, ritualised in behaviour, and this one of the themes the boom deals with - a British Jew in mandate Palestine. I think the Americans feel that they have the UK pigeonholed as heritage and Jews aren't part of that. I suppose they think, we have our own Jews, we don't need any from anywhere else. And as Britain wasn't affected by the Holocaust, we don't have that either. So we're kind of invisible. As for Israel, the book is available there, though not as yet translated. On the other hand, most Israelis who read literary fiction speak excellent English and it's more likely that Archer would be translated than me.

shem32
What made you decide not to write about the Kosovo war directly?

LindaGrant1
shem: Because I haven't been to Kosovo. And I'm not sure that I wanted to.

mmreed
Did you talk to your mother about the book, if you don't mind my asking?

LindaGrant1
mmreed My mother was not capable of following a sentence as long as this one. Her short-term memory was only a few seconds long.

LindaGrant1
Well, thanks to everyone who for some reason is sitting indoors on this horrible hot sticky day instead of being outside in the sun.

I don't want the reader to have their attention drawn to the language. I want the language to be supple and simple and to contain a punch because you don't notice that it's creeping up on you. Has the prize made a difference? Absolutely. I feel that I no longer have to struggle to be taken seriously. naomi2 Do you think the printed novel is becoming an outmoded form? Do you think traditional publishing has a future? Obviously the computer screen cannot replace the portability of a book, but what about WAP phones and palm pilots etc? Do you have any particular interest in new technologies? Also as a print journalist, all these new developments in publishing must also impact on you? LindaGrant1 Naomi: I think that the printed book will definitely become an outmoded form. In fact I was saying to a friend on Friday, one day people will be judged on their age as "she's the sort of person who still has bookshelves", like I'm the sort of person who is old enough to still have some vinyl hanging about the house. I LOVE new technology. I love living in modern times. The book will continue to exist, though not in the same form. It will be downloaded from the internet onto some book-sized reader. This exists already but there are problems about the weight because of the battery. But it will be fixed. shem32 Did you like the Ya Ya Sisterhood book? I ask because there was much snobbish sneering when it made the shortlist... Should the orange shortlist be different from the Booker? - or is it just about 'the best' books? (pretty subjective, anyway...) LindaGrant1 I haven't read Divine Scretes, as I haven't read any of the others on the shortlist. I think that if the judges put it on the shortlist, there will have been a reason. I'm a big fan of well-written non-literary fiction. The trouble is finding the stuff that IS well-written. CCole Do you ever play the Desert Island Disc game? What would be the book you'd take? LindaGrant1 Ccole: I have fantasising about my desert island book since I was about 15. I think it would have to be Proust - I've been trying to finish it since I was in my twenties. I'm about halfway through and I love it but finding the time  trapeze Congratulations Linda - it must be wonderful to have been given such a strong vote of confidence. You bring a strong Jewish identity to most of your writing. Do your publishers ever worry that this will ghettoise your work? Does this affect your American sales - and are you known in Israel? LindaGrant1 Trapeze: The Jewish question is a really interesting one. Up till now I've not had a US publisher (Modern Times was turned down by everybody - then the morning after the announcement my agent's phone was ringing off the hook.) I think that part of the reason for this is that Americans think that British Jews aren't real Jews. Someone said to me that the British talk with la-di-dah accents and drink their tea with their fingers crooked. To be a Jew is to very much the opposite of being British - reserved, laconic, ritualised in behaviour, and this one of the themes the boom deals with - a British Jew in mandate Palestine. I think the Americans feel that they have the UK pigeonholed as heritage and Jews aren't part of that. I suppose they think, we have our own Jews, we don't need any from anywhere else. And as Britain wasn't affected by the Holocaust, we don't have that either. So we're kind of invisible. As for Israel, the book is available there, though not as yet translated. On the other hand, most Israelis who read literary fiction speak excellent English and it's more likely that Archer would be translated than me. shem32 What made you decide not to write about the Kosovo war directly? LindaGrant1 shem: Because I haven't been to Kosovo. And I'm not sure that I wanted to. mmreed Did you talk to your mother about the book, if you don't mind my asking? LindaGrant1 mmreed My mother was not capable of following a sentence as long as this one. Her short-term memory was only a few seconds long. LindaGrant1 Well, thanks to everyone who for some reason is sitting indoors on this horrible hot sticky day instead of being outside in the sun.

webTitle: June 19: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: June 19: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Harry Potter race hots up, Spielberg fails to rescue Dieter, and Michael Clarke Duncan set for canine caper
fields.body:
 Sixth Sense Oscar-nominee Haley Joel Osment (pictured) has joined the list of Harry Potter hopefuls (see our news story, April 11). Undeterred by director Chris Columbus's avowal that the film is to have a British actor playing the lead, the child-star told reporters he would love to play the role: "You can put the word out, and I'll start working on my accent." It seems unlikely that the production team would let the small matter of his nationality stand in the way of casting such a huge name. After all, Osment has plenty of experience of movies that deal with the more arcane side of life.

 Even Spielberg's eleventh-hour intervention (see our news story) couldn't help save Dieter, the dispute-ridden picture from Universal Pictures and Mike Myers. Preproduction on the project was shut down at the close of business on Friday.

 Oscar-nominated actor Michael Clarke Duncan (The Green Mile) is in negotiations to join David Arquette in See Spot Run, the story of a mailman who takes care of a dog that, unbeknownst to him, is an FBI drug-sniffing superdog.

webTitle: You have a scoop. So what do you do?

fields.headline: You have a scoop. So what do you do?
fields.trailText: Yet another great idea for becoming a millionaire that I never did anything about. First, get a job working in the internet division of a national newspaper. Next, charge £10 every time you get asked: "So, will you actually scoop the newspaper?".
fields.body:
Yet another great idea for becoming a millionaire that I never did anything about. First, get a job working in the internet division of a national newspaper. Next, charge £10 every time you get asked: "So, will you actually scoop the newspaper?".

I don't remember exactly how many times I've been asked this question, but I'm pretty certain that at £10 a pop, I'd be well on my way to buying my first Caribbean island by now. Ah well, such is life.

My answer, incidentally, has always been a long and waffly explanation of the nature of a scoop and the role the net can play in supporting a big story as well as breaking it. Although we have been covering breaking news now for two years, and although we regularly run copy before it appears in the paper, and have even had our own exclusives, we have never broken one of the paper's big stories on the net.

However, were I working at the News of the World, I would now be saved such waffle and I could simply reply: "We have done. Don't you remember the way we broke the story of the Queen meeting Camilla Parker Bowles back in the hazy summer of 2000?"

Yes, they did it, and congratulations to them. True there were clearly some factors that led them to it - the threat of rivals breaking the story the next day, and a new editor eager to make her mark. But neither of those is particularly special. The result was not only a bit of UK newspaper history, but a gloriously gushing splash to cover the event in the trade magazine Press Gazette.

Of course, it has all happened before in the United States. The first example of a paper letting its website scoop it happened three years ago, when the Dallas Morning News published its scoop about a confession by the Oklahoma bomber, Timothy McVeigh, 15 hours before the story was due to hit the streets. At the time it was called "the biggest change in American papers in 25 years", by one commentator.

In both cases the simple fact that the story was broken on the net was an event in itself, and was reported as such; the merits of the actual story almost took second place to the mechanics of its delivery. Both editors could bask in the deserved glory of their positive PR - good, both for the paper and its web operation.

This is all well and good for now. But, once the novelty of net scooping has fallen away, we are left trying to work out a whole new set of rules about how and when to use the net to break a story.

It is not just newspapers who have the problem; weekly magazines are faced with the problem on an even larger scale. You publish on a Wednesday, but you get that brilliant exclusive on a Monday. Dare you wait? Once it was no problem - you had only print-based rivals, but now there are now so many websites offering up to date information on everything

There is never going to be an easy answer to this - but the guidelines are pretty simple. The net exists, it is not going to go away. If you have a website, you have the option to use it to break stories. However, if you do it, you have to make sure you get credit for it. Which means that once you put the story up on the site, you simultaneously have to tell the world you've done it.

Let's consider another couple of examples of stories which show the right and the wrong way to do it.

Last month, the New York Times, Washington Post and Wall Street Journal were handed the story of the proposed merger between United Airlines and US Airways. The arrangement was very simple: they could have the story for their papers, but they could not contact sources for background or comment, and they could not break it on their websites in advance of the papers being printed.

Unfortunately for them, and the airlines' PR people, the Financial Times got hold of the story, and broke it on its site six hours ahead of the US papers' self-imposed embargo. Not only that, but it also sent out an email to subscribers, informing them of the big story. A great result for the FT, in a market where minutes can literally mean millions, and (hurrah!) a potentially crushing blow for cushy deals between journalists and PR types.

Next, a rumour that may or may not be true, but that anyone involved with net publishing will recognise as all too believable.

Sunday Newspaper X had a rather juicy exclusive. As is standard practice in such cases, it planned to break the story in its final edition to avoid other papers stealing the story. However, no one remembered to tell the internet editor, and somehow the story was inadvertently put onto their website with the first edition, and was immediately picked up by their rivals.

As with most things on the net, if you get it right, you are destined for glory. The consequences of mistakes, however, are normally too miserable to even think about.

 Simon Waldman is head of Guardian Unlimited

fields.headline: Shaft shifts despite sexual shortcomings
fields.trailText: Shaft, John Singleton's gritty remake of the 1971 blaxploitation classic opened in the US this weekend, and went straight to the top of the box office, taking $21.1m
fields.body:
John Singleton's gritty remake of the 1971 blaxploitation classic, Shaft, opened in the US this weekend and went straight to the top of the box office, taking $21.1m.

Dressed top to toe in Armani, Samuel L Jackson plays NYPD detective John Shaft, the namesake nephew of the original Shaft, Richard Roundtree. Roundtree makes a cameo appearance, along with the film's original director, Gordon Parks.

Shaft grossed more than the combined total of the three other new movies opening this weekend: animated sci-fi adventure Titan A.E, teen romance Boys and Girls and the reissue of Fantasia 2000.

Critical response to Shaft has been mixed, although all agree that this is a very different film from the one that caused such a sensation 30 years ago. The Washington Post described it as "a movie without spirit, stuck with a hero (Samuel L Jackson) without heart and a villain without teeth," and virtually every critic has complained the hero's lack of love interest. The black New York Times' critic, Elvis Mitchell writes: "The one area in which the original Shaft succeeded is that it explicitly portrayed black men as sexual beings in a way they had never been on-screen before. Though an outrageous flirt, the nouveau Shaft has more affection for his wardrobe than anything else." Roger Ebert in the Chicago Sun Times agrees: "One thing modern about the movie is its low sexual quotient. Blaxploitation came along at a time when American movies were sexy, with lots of nudity and bedroom time. Modern action pictures seem prudish by comparison."

The reason behind Shaft's lack of (sexual) action is open debate. Director John Singleton told Entertainment Weekly that the producer Scott Rudin and Studios executives refused to grant Shaft more than two sexual encounters.

"The only battle I lost with the producers was over how much sex there was going to be," said Singleton. "They said they didn't want to offend any women. They didn't want to offend anybody."

Jackson, who also pushed for an increase in his character's off-duty action, believes that producer Scott Rudin and screenwriter Richard Price (both white) didn't understand the African-American perspective on sexuality. "These guys had their own ideas about what a Shaft movie is, but they happened to be ethnically incorrect," he said.

This is not the first time that on-set rifts have been revealed. As we reported last week, Jackson has criticised both Singleton and Price for their take on the film, commenting, "Richard Price tried to put certain words in my mouth. I told John point-blank that I refused to say that white man's lines."

 The official site

webTitle: Shayler given bail promise by CPS

fields.headline: Shayler given bail promise by CPS
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Prosecution lawyers have opened the way for David Shayler's return to Britain by saying they would not oppose bail when the former MI5 officer is charged under the Official Secrets Act.
fields.body:
Prosecution lawyers have opened the way for David Shayler's return to Britain by saying they would not oppose bail when the former MI5 officer is charged under the Official Secrets Act.

Sue Taylor, the head of the crown prosecution service London division casework directorate, has said, provided "satisfactory conditions were agreed", the CPS "would not object" to any bail application.

She also said it would be "fair and appropriate" to take into account the three months Mr Shayler spent in a Paris jail in 1998 before the government's attempt to extradite him failed.

The CPS concessions were made in a letter to John Wadham, Mr Shayler's lawyer and the director of the civil rights group Liberty. However, the CPS has rejected his suggestion that secrets charges against Mr Shayler should be limited to information that has been published. This includes evidence of MI6 involvement in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.

fields.headline: China and refugees
fields.trailText: Would-be refugees fleeing the repressive Chinese regime  account for many of   those seeking asylum in Britain.
fields.body:
Would-be refugees fleeing the repressive Chinese regime account for many of those seeking asylum in Britain.

Chinese immigrants were the second largest group applying to remain in the UK in April, the last month figures are available for.

They made up 455 of the 5,890 applications received, only outnumbered by the 535 people applying for asylum from Sri Lanka.

Between seven and 10 criminal gangs are thought to control the lucrative trade smuggling those desperate to escape overland and into Britain in the backs of lorries.

Chinese immigrants are often locked in safe houses until fees of around £18,000 are paid.

webTitle: Britney Spears and her transatlantic jet dash

fields.headline: Britney Spears and her transatlantic jet dash
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan is advised of his best move; David Davies faces a difficult task; and Karel Poborsky's bad luck continues.
fields.body:
* * * * * * * * * * * * *

ADVERTISEMENT

Play football, see football, talk football, breathe football. The Euro is brought to you in association with www.breathe.com It's amazing what happens when you breathe.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

EUROTALK

"In the second half Dietmar Hamann was going around crying and squealing like a cat, and you can tell him that" - Steven Gerrard, whose assured display against Germany threatens Michael Owen's place in the England starting line-up, stakes a further claim on next season's 'most popular man in the Anfield dressing-room' title.

THE EURO-TORIAL

Last week they were hapless no-hopers. Now they're all-conquering heroes. Isn't it amazing what a victory against the worst Germany side in 40 years can do for your reputation?

And nobody knows this better than Kevin Keegan. After defeat against Portugal he was derided as a footballing General Haig, ordering his men forward in the face of an overwhelming barrage from the enemy. Now he finds himself praised for his tactical acumen, while his the team are lauded for their lionheart spirit. "Heroes 1 Janckers 0," claims today's Sun. Beating the Germans was "better than sex", proclaims the Star. And - surprise, surprise - several of the World Cup heroes from 1966 are trotted out, as per usual, to proclaim that this time England can win it.

But can they? Let's be realistic. All that has happened is that one ageing, painfully average side has beaten another one. It was like watching two proud pensioners in a nursing home go at it, rather than two prize-fighters in their prime. As ex-German international Paul Breitner put it: "It was a mediocre match that didn't come close to the level of earlier Germany-England classics. As I watched it I kept wondering which side had soiled their underpants more with the fear of making a mistake."

It's clear that England - on the evidence of their last two games - still have a long way to go. But Keegan can draw on some positives. His side did show considerable spirit to bounce back from the 3-2 defeat by Portugal, and displayed some dogged resilience late on. But that won't be enough to win Euro 2000. Some brain must be added to the traditional English brawn.

Gerrard was insightful and incisive when he came on and should start against Romania. England also need McManaman - someone who can hold up the ball, take it past people and pass accurately - qualities we lacked on Saturday. To his credit, Keegan knows this. "We must improve on that," he admitted. "We must pass it better. If we give it away as we did against Germany we are not going to last the trip." Let's hope he'll back his words up with positive action.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM

Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. Win a £200 tab behind the bar at Yates's Pubs all around the country....go to www.breathe.com, click on the Euro 2000 link and enter the draw.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

DAVIES TO MEET UEFA

FA executive director David Davies hopes to meet with Uefa chief executive Gerhard Aigner today in the wake of Uefa's announcement that further outbreaks of English violence in the lowlands could lead to Kevin Keegan's team being expelled from Euro 2000.

Uefa's executive committee said they would "have to determine whether the presence of the England team at this tournament may be maintained should there be a repetition of similar incidents". But Davies insisted: "There are procedures and processes that must be taken before a country is excluded."

However, although Davies is primarily working to ensure England's further participation in the tournament and to limit the damage to England's 2006 World Cup bid, he was nevertheless quick to condemn the actions of the English hooligans. "There is pressure that the team and we can put on," he said, "and all I can ask is that we all act in a way to make these people realise the damage they are doing. We hope and believe that they will understand the seriousness of the situation."

EURONEWS

Muzzy Izzet is struggling to be fit for Turkey's crucial Euro 2000 game against co-hosts Belgium in Brussels tonight. The Leicester midfielder admitted: "There is a lot of bruising around the ankle. I am just trying to rest up and keep it elevated."

Norway coach Nils Johan Semb has accused Scottish referee Hugh Dallas of allowing himself to be "tricked" after Yugoslavia won a bad-tempered match 1-0 in Liege. "We couldn't find our rhythm because of the antics of the Yugoslavs," said Semb.

EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY

Hi there! I'm Britney Spears. I've been following your soccer tournament on US television, and I just had to jet over from the land of the free and the home of the brave to meet up with that sexy Czech guy called Karel who had such a good game against France last Friday. I was told this is where I'd find him, but there doesn't seem to be anybody here.

I suppose I may as well while away the hours reading out these rumours, although I'll be surprised if you can hear a word I say over the noise coming from that cupboard, which sounds not dissimilar to the desperate cries of a bound-and-gagged international footballer about to miss his one and only chance to date a pop star.

Chelsea and, surprisingly, Arsenal are interested in £3.5m Nick Barmby. Everton are not prepared to meet Barmby's increased wage demands and will sell before the player becomes available on a Bosman free next summer.

Liverpool have offered Middlesbrough £5m for Germany's left-back Christian Ziege.

Arsenal and Lazio representatives have met in Brussels to broker the £18m transfer of Marc Overmars.

Sunderland want to sign Czech Republic midfielder Radek Bejbl. The 27-year-old is not guaranteed a place in Atletico Madrid's starting eleven and would be available for £3m.

Middlesbrough boss Bryan Robson has made a £16m bid for Christina Aguilera.

Tore Andre Flo is rumoured to be a £14m target for Rangers. But chairman David Murray has played down the suggestion: "There is no chance of Flo joining Rangers at the moment but we are confident of signing a striker before the start of the season."

Well, that's the lot. I suppose I'll have to go. I was kinda hoping Karel would ask me to the prom. Ah well, do you have Jiri Nemec's phone number?

TV AND RADI(EUR)O

ITV: Euro 2000 Live (7.30pm)
Turkey v Belgium or Italy v Sweden? We think it might be Turkey v Belgium. Although it could be Italy v Sweden.

BBC1: MOTD @ Euro 2000 (11.30pm)
Definitely Turkey v Belgium and Italy v Sweden.

ITV: Euro 2000 - The Big Match (12.30am)
Probably Italy v Sweden if they showed Turkey v Belgium earlier on.

BBC1: Euro 2000 Replay (12.35am)
Although if ITV threw in a curveball and showed Italy v Sweden it might be Turkey v Belgium instead.

British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Football - Live (7pm)
This is likely to be Belgium v Turkey, so if you get Eurosport you'll want Italy v Sweden on ITV in order to flick between both matches with your remote. But what if you don't get Eurosport and you're Belgian?

Euro 2000 Football (10pm to 7.15am)
Turkey v Belgium and Italy v Sweden will be on this, surely. Look at the amount of time they've got to fill!

Radio 5 Live: Euro 2000 Live (7pm)
Both matches. At once. We reckon.

THE EURO-TORIAL Last week they were hapless no-hopers. Now they're all-conquering heroes. Isn't it amazing what a victory against the worst Germany side in 40 years can do for your reputation? And nobody knows this better than Kevin Keegan. After defeat against Portugal he was derided as a footballing General Haig, ordering his men forward in the face of an overwhelming barrage from the enemy. Now he finds himself praised for his tactical acumen, while his the team are lauded for their lionheart spirit. "Heroes 1 Janckers 0," claims today's Sun. Beating the Germans was "better than sex", proclaims the Star. And - surprise, surprise - several of the World Cup heroes from 1966 are trotted out, as per usual, to proclaim that this time England can win it. But can they? Let's be realistic. All that has happened is that one ageing, painfully average side has beaten another one. It was like watching two proud pensioners in a nursing home go at it, rather than two prize-fighters in their prime. As ex-German international Paul Breitner put it: "It was a mediocre match that didn't come close to the level of earlier Germany-England classics. As I watched it I kept wondering which side had soiled their underpants more with the fear of making a mistake." It's clear that England - on the evidence of their last two games - still have a long way to go. But Keegan can draw on some positives. His side did show considerable spirit to bounce back from the 3-2 defeat by Portugal, and displayed some dogged resilience late on. But that won't be enough to win Euro 2000. Some brain must be added to the traditional English brawn. Gerrard was insightful and incisive when he came on and should start against Romania. England also need McManaman - someone who can hold up the ball, take it past people and pass accurately - qualities we lacked on Saturday. To his credit, Keegan knows this. "We must improve on that," he admitted. "We must pass it better. If we give it away as we did against Germany we are not going to last the trip." Let's hope he'll back his words up with positive action. * * * * * * * * * * * * * A MESSAGE FROM BREATHE.COM Euro 2000. Big screen sport action. In a pub. With your mates. Win a £200 tab behind the bar at Yates's Pubs all around the country....go to www.breathe.com, click on the Euro 2000 link and enter the draw. * * * * * * * * * * * * * DAVIES TO MEET UEFA FA executive director David Davies hopes to meet with Uefa chief executive Gerhard Aigner today in the wake of Uefa's announcement that further outbreaks of English violence in the lowlands could lead to Kevin Keegan's team being expelled from Euro 2000. Uefa's executive committee said they would "have to determine whether the presence of the England team at this tournament may be maintained should there be a repetition of similar incidents". But Davies insisted: "There are procedures and processes that must be taken before a country is excluded." However, although Davies is primarily working to ensure England's further participation in the tournament and to limit the damage to England's 2006 World Cup bid, he was nevertheless quick to condemn the actions of the English hooligans. "There is pressure that the team and we can put on," he said, "and all I can ask is that we all act in a way to make these people realise the damage they are doing. We hope and believe that they will understand the seriousness of the situation." EURONEWS Muzzy Izzet is struggling to be fit for Turkey's crucial Euro 2000 game against co-hosts Belgium in Brussels tonight. The Leicester midfielder admitted: "There is a lot of bruising around the ankle. I am just trying to rest up and keep it elevated." Norway coach Nils Johan Semb has accused Scottish referee Hugh Dallas of allowing himself to be "tricked" after Yugoslavia won a bad-tempered match 1-0 in Liege. "We couldn't find our rhythm because of the antics of the Yugoslavs," said Semb. EURORUMOUR with KAREL POBORSKY Hi there! I'm Britney Spears. I've been following your soccer tournament on US television, and I just had to jet over from the land of the free and the home of the brave to meet up with that sexy Czech guy called Karel who had such a good game against France last Friday. I was told this is where I'd find him, but there doesn't seem to be anybody here. I suppose I may as well while away the hours reading out these rumours, although I'll be surprised if you can hear a word I say over the noise coming from that cupboard, which sounds not dissimilar to the desperate cries of a bound-and-gagged international footballer about to miss his one and only chance to date a pop star. Chelsea and, surprisingly, Arsenal are interested in £3.5m Nick Barmby. Everton are not prepared to meet Barmby's increased wage demands and will sell before the player becomes available on a Bosman free next summer. Liverpool have offered Middlesbrough £5m for Germany's left-back Christian Ziege. Arsenal and Lazio representatives have met in Brussels to broker the £18m transfer of Marc Overmars. Sunderland want to sign Czech Republic midfielder Radek Bejbl. The 27-year-old is not guaranteed a place in Atletico Madrid's starting eleven and would be available for £3m. Middlesbrough boss Bryan Robson has made a £16m bid for Christina Aguilera. Tore Andre Flo is rumoured to be a £14m target for Rangers. But chairman David Murray has played down the suggestion: "There is no chance of Flo joining Rangers at the moment but we are confident of signing a striker before the start of the season." Well, that's the lot. I suppose I'll have to go. I was kinda hoping Karel would ask me to the prom. Ah well, do you have Jiri Nemec's phone number? TV AND RADI(EUR)O ITV: Euro 2000 Live (7.30pm) Turkey v Belgium or Italy v Sweden? We think it might be Turkey v Belgium. Although it could be Italy v Sweden. BBC1: MOTD @ Euro 2000 (11.30pm) Definitely Turkey v Belgium and Italy v Sweden. ITV: Euro 2000 - The Big Match (12.30am) Probably Italy v Sweden if they showed Turkey v Belgium earlier on. BBC1: Euro 2000 Replay (12.35am) Although if ITV threw in a curveball and showed Italy v Sweden it might be Turkey v Belgium instead. British Eurosport: Euro 2000 Football - Live (7pm) This is likely to be Belgium v Turkey, so if you get Eurosport you'll want Italy v Sweden on ITV in order to flick between both matches with your remote. But what if you don't get Eurosport and you're Belgian? Euro 2000 Football (10pm to 7.15am) Turkey v Belgium and Italy v Sweden will be on this, surely. Look at the amount of time they've got to fill! Radio 5 Live: Euro 2000 Live (7pm) Both matches. At once. We reckon.

fields.headline: Blazing around like never before
fields.standfirst: Every Monday wisden.com goes behind the scenes to get the lowdown on one of the performances of the week. Today we talk to England's forgotten man (well, one of them), Aftab Habib, who blasted 164 for Leicestershire against Derbyshire
fields.trailText: Aftab Habib, 28, is a middle-order strokemaker for Leicestershire. He made his debut for Leicester in 1995 and last year played two Tests for England against New Zealand, but was dropped after making 26 runs in three innings. This season he averages over 60 in the Championship, and on June 15 he passed 500 runs for the season when he made 164 (225 balls, 21x4, 2x6) against Derbyshire at Grace Road. In a low-scoring match he was the only batsman to pass 50 and The Times said he batted with "unrelenting authority". He takes up the story.
fields.body:
Aftab Habib, 28, is a middle-order strokemaker for Leicestershire. He made his debut for Leicester in 1995 and last year played two Tests for England against New Zealand, but was dropped after making 26 runs in three innings. This season he averages over 60 in the Championship, and on June 15 he passed 500 runs for the season when he made 164 (225 balls, 21x4, 2x6) against Derbyshire at Grace Road. In a low-scoring match he was the only batsman to pass 50 and The Times said he batted with "unrelenting authority". He takes up the story.

"It's been a weird season because of the weather and it's been really hard at times to get a rhythm, but I'm pretty happy with my form.

"The game against Derbyshire was an important one - we have played more games than the other first-division sides and needed a win under our belts. I have never played the way I played against Derby before. I have always been capable of hitting big shots over the top and blazing around but not quite like that. The wicket was very slow and I played in a real attacking way. It was probably on a par with my 215 against Worcester in 1996.

"I've always done quite well against Derby and I felt good that morning. It was nice to get out there and the sun was on my back which always helps. I was hoping to get a good score. I came in at 30-3 and we were in trouble but everything went my way. I don't think I gave any chances that I can remember.

"I went to my hundred with a boundary. I got a full-toss from Kevin Dean which was very generous.

"My most memorable shots? Well I got off the mark with a four, second ball, which the boys were talking about. I hit Tim Munton through mid-on and it is always a nice feeling to hit it back past the bowler. And then I hit Kevin Dean for six off my legs over midwicket. I don't really hit many sixes in the Championship, though against a spin bowler I might have a dart, so the fact that it was against a seamer shows what a positive frame of mind I was in. I just wanted to hit it over the fence.

"I think that my game has changed considerably over the last couple of years. I used to be quite a loose player but now my shot selection is a lot better, I'm a lot more confident and relaxed and my game has improved a lot. Mentally I've got a lot tougher too. And I'm enjoying my cricket, I'm loving playing for Leicester.

"I think there was something in The Times the other day saying that Habib should forget his Test misery. Playing at that level was a big shock to me and a great honour. Like a lot of people I would love to get back in the team but I have to keep scoring runs and let the bat do the talking. It is entirely up to the selectors. I think that Jack Birkenshaw [Leicestershire's cricket manager] has been pleased with the way I've been playing this season and so have I."

Aftab Habib was talking to Tanya Aldred. For his previous interview with wisden.com, talking about his winter with England A in Bangladesh and New Zealand, click here.

webTitle: EU finance ministers fail to agree on savings tax

fields.headline: EU finance ministers fail to agree on savings tax
fields.standfirst:
EU summit agenda
European council at Feira, Portugal
fields.trailText: European Union leaders began their twice-yearly European council meeting today with an unexpected failure to agree details of an EU-wide tax on savings.
fields.body:
European Union leaders began their twice-yearly European council meeting today with an unexpected failure to agree details of an EU-wide tax on savings.

Austria has blocked an expected deal between EU finance ministers which would have ended a two-year dispute over an EU-wide tax on savings. The issue will now be put on hold for up to two years.

Plans by the EU to impose a withholding tax on savings across the EU have been supported by 13 of the 15 member states, but strongly opposed by Austria and Luxembourg, which reject any commitment to automatically introducing information exchange.

"I'd like to see an agreement on the tax issue, but I'm not sure we'll succeed," the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder said at a breakfast with the French president, Jacques Chirac.

The deadlock appears to be good news for Britain, which argues that the proposed tax would damage business in the City. But Tony Blair has already expressed his confidence that Britain will not be forced to accept the taxing of savings at source, which was initially proposed.

Over lunch, Austria's prime minister, Wolfgang Schuessel, was expected to protest about his country's political isolation over the presence of the far-right Freedom party in the coalition government. Portugal, which is hosting the meeting as the holder of the rotating EU presidency, has stressed that the sanctions were not a matter for the summit.

Restrictions on political interaction imposed when the Freedom party entered Austria's government were introduced individually by each of the other 14 EU member states, rather than through the EU. This means that technically they cannot be included on the agenda of a summit intended to discuss EU affairs.

There is no sign that other member states are prepared to relax their approach to Austria while the Freedom party remains in government.

Other issues not on the formal agenda but likely to be raised during the two-day meeting in Sanata Maria da Feira, Portugal, include the behaviour of English football fans in Belgium over the weekend. Tony Blair was expected to express regrets for the violence to the Belgian prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt.

Asylum seekers will also be under the spotlight, following calls by the home secretary, Jack Straw, for a revision of the 1951 United Nations convention on refugees and the discovery of 58 bodies of suspected illegal immigrants at Dover today.

The official summit programme will focus on reform of the EU's institutions and the accession of countries in central and eastern Europe. Some states hoping to achieve EU membership have protested at the slow pace of their applications.

Member states were expected to endorse Greece's membership of the euro, planned for January 1, 2001.

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: Day ten

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: Day ten
fields.standfirst: Four men, armed with £50, aim to be the last man standing after 23 days of daily football betting. It's You Bet Your Life, brought to you in association with BlueSq
fields.trailText: Raul gave Sean Ingle something to smile about yesterday - by whipping an early goal in against Slovenia, he won our tipster £30.
fields.body:
Raul gave Sean Ingle something to smile about yesterday - by whipping an early goal in against Slovenia, he won our tipster £30.

The standings now look like this:

Scott Murray £91.67
Sean Ingle £74.56

Mike Hodgkinson £38.75

Paul MacInnes £30.50

Now for the selections for today's matches.

Scott Murray

Belgium v Turkey: Correct score 3-1 14/1 (£5)

Belgium didn't embarrass themselves against Italy, and were patently superior to a comparatively star-studded Swedish team. So I don't expect them to slip up against Turkey, especially with the crowd behind them. The Turks will be desperate not to leave the party early, of course, so I expect their last-ditch efforts to produce a goal - but it won't be enough to stem the flow of a Belgian side brimming with confidence.

Sean Ingle

Belgium v Turkey: Draw 2/1 (£5)

You would need to be Captain Jean Luc Picard to steer a safe path through all the ifs, buts and maybes regarding tonight's matches. Will Italy, who've already qualified, bother against Sweden? And if they don't, can Freddie Ljungberg and co take advantage at a generous 13/5 against? Meanwhile, are Belgium really as good as they seem? And are Turkey really as bad? I really don't know. But for some irrational reason a draw between Belgium and Turkey appeals.

Mike Hodgkinson

Belgium v Turkey: Turkey to win 10-3 (£10)

The price against Turkey is way too big, considering the improved performance of their goalie in the Sweden match and the way they got it together for short spells against Italy. If Sergen Yaldan starts and Hakan Sukur starts to look more lively, this could be the steal of the tournament. Give them another chance to show the class that lurks within.

Paul MacInnes

Italy v Sweden: Goals scored 0 - 1 9/4 (£5)

After putting all my credentials as a rubbish gambler on the line by winning a bet at the weekend (come on Eng-er-land!) I now hope to rectify the situation by betting on Italy and Sweden playing out a boring game. Surely, in fact, Sweden will turn it on to give themselves a chance of qualifying. But my inept instincts tell me that Italy's defence is too strong to be breached and, having already qualified themselves, the Azzuri won't be too bothered about the three points.

fields.headline: Cruyff escapes the British inquisition
fields.trailText: There was an Englishman, an Irishman, a Scotsman and a Dutch man, sitting in a television studio, when the Englishman turned to the other three and said: "Unless we stop arguing amongst ourselves they're all going to be switching over to old smoothie-chops on the other side."
fields.body:
There was an Englishman, an Irishman, a Scotsman and a Dutch man, sitting in a television studio, when the Englishman turned to the other three and said: "Unless we stop arguing amongst ourselves they're all going to be switching over to old smoothie-chops on the other side."

The Scotsman replied "sure!" and the Irishman chirped "I agree with that but..." when the Dutchman interrupted: "Yes, but technically they are no good. They only have one tactic, the tired formula of old men in suits, whereas we, we have great technique and we wear no ties."

In the way that constructing a dome to celebrate the millennium probably seemed a really good idea at the time, so the idea of recruiting Johan Cruyff looked a guaranteed vote-winner for the BBC. Acknowledged as the best European footballer of all time, respected for his managerial achievements, Cruyff is a person without peer in the European game. And doesn't he know it?

The rest of the panel - even the egotistical Hansen - were in awe of Cruyff's impressive footballing CV. Consequently, no one had the courage to interrupt him mid-ramble and pose the question on everyone's lips, namely: "What are you talking about?!"

Meanwhile, over in ad-land, ITV, clearly worried that they could be sued under the Trade Descriptions Act, sensibly omitted Glenn Hoddle from their panel of 'three wise men'. Earlier in the day, describing Romania's Adrian Ilie as "having a deception of pace", the deceptively-dumb Hoddle picked up his second yellow card and was banished to the sidelines.

Yesterday, Yugoslavia, an enigma wrapped within a riddle of a team and Norway, a less flamboyant (would you believe?) but better-organised version of England, met in the Sclessin Stadium, Liege. However, given Mark Lawrenson's ominous warning about "the dark side of Yugoslavian football", and the brutality of some of the challenges, the Hell Mouth, Sunnydale seems a far more likely location.

With no sign of Buffy, it was left to Scottish referee Hugh Dallas to save the day. Fortunately, with ample experience of refereeing Celtic-Rangers games and a steady supply of red and yellow cards at his disposal, Dallas coped admirably with the carnage.

webTitle: Tragic results of trade in despair

fields.headline: Tragic results of trade in despair
fields.standfirst: The Observer's Burhan Wazir, who experienced a clandestine cross-Channel truck ride, says it is time to rethink the asylum policies that today drove 58 desperate people to their deaths
fields.trailText: The Observer's Burhan Wazir, who experienced a clandestine cross-Channel truck ride, says it is time to rethink the asylum policies that today drove 58 desperate people to their deaths
fields.body:
58 bodies - thought to be illegal immigrants - were discovered in the back of a lorry that arrived at Dover last night. Two people found alive in the rear of the Dutch-registered vehicle are currently in hospital.

The grim discovery further highlights the need for harsher penalties for offending drivers. Earlier this summer, I boarded a truck in Calais ending up in Dover after paying a fixed fee. It was a hateful experience: the conditions were cramped and the journey filled with fear. On landing, I swore I would never willingly undertake a similar assignment. Others, however, have no choice.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, today said: "This is a most terrible event. I am appalled by this loss of human life." But Straw's myopic methods of cracking down on asylum seekers account for a large part of the problem. Had the 58 asylum seekers survived, the immigration authorities would only have sought to hold them in a detention centre anyway, soon to be dispersed around the country.

To describe the trafficking of passengers into this country as an "evil trade" doesn't quite sum up the abhorrent exchange. The truck drivers - many of them poorly paid by their Eastern European masters - understandably fall privy to the demands of asylum seekers they meet on their journey. It is a mutually beneficial undertaking, and civil penalties have yet to make an impression on the truck drivers. Further, it is impossible to search all the vehicles trundling in and out of mainland Britain's ferry ports.

Yesterday's deaths are a tragedy. The 58 will probably remain nameless; their epitaphs written by the truck driver who tried to smuggle them into the country. We could do worse than remember them over the next few days, and try to imagine the sheer desperation - political or economic - that drove them to climb into their carriage. And tonight, as he makes further comments to the media, Jack Straw could do worse than rethink his asylum policy.
