webTitle: Farmer wins first round of murder appeal

fields.headline: Farmer wins first round of murder appeal
fields.trailText: Farmer Tony Martin, who was jailed for life for the murder of a teenage burglar, has won the first round of his appeal battle.
fields.body:
Farmer Tony Martin, who was jailed for life for the murder of a teenage burglar, has won the first round of his appeal battle.

Jurors in the case of can be questioned over whether they were intimidated, three Court of Appeal judges ruled today.

Lord Justice Rose, Mr Justice Harrison and Mr Justice Tomlinson gave the go-ahead for the jury to be written to and asked to answer certain questions "as soon as possible".

The judges, sitting in London, ordered that the terms of the questions addressed to the jury should not be disclosed by the press.

Today's brief preliminary hearing saw the beginning of Martin's bid for freedom. He was not at court today. The full appeal is expected to be heard later this year.

Martin, 55, was found guilty of murdering teenage burglar Fred Barras, 16, and wounding his accomplice Brendan Fearon, 30, with a shotgun.

Before Martin's counsel Anthony Scrivener QC began to make his application to the court concerning the questioning of jurors, Lord Justice Rose told him that the court was "sympathetic, subject to anything the Crown want to say, to the idea that the jury should be asked one or two questions".

He added: "We are not sympathetic to them being set an exam paper." At the full appeal Martin's defence team is expected to argue that a fair trial was not possible because there was an atmosphere of intimidation for jurors and witnesses.

But their main ground for appeal is the claim that the judge "substantially misdirected" the jury during his summing-up. Martin, of Bleak House, Emneth Hungate, near Emneth, Norfolk, was found guilty of murdering Barras, of Newark, Notts, and was sentenced to life imprisonment after being convicted by a 10-2 majority at the end of an eight-day trial at Norwich Crown Court in April.

He was also convicted of wounding Fearon, also of Newark, with intent to cause grievous bodily harm. The farmer was cleared of attempting to murder Fearon and of possessing a pump-action shotgun with intent to endanger life.

Jurors heard the burglars had been shot after breaking into Martin's isolated home late at night in August. Barras had been shot in the back and Fearon in the groin.

The farmer, who claims he fired in self-defence, has described the death of Barras as "regrettable" and says he did not intend to kill him.

webTitle: Blair quells cabinet splits on euro

fields.headline: Blair quells cabinet splits on euro
fields.trailText: Tony Blair said today that ministers must make "interchangeable" speeches on the single currency to demonstrate that they are following the same line.
fields.body:
Tony Blair said today that ministers must make "interchangeable" speeches on the single currency to demonstrate that they are following the same line.

The prime minister, who is attending an EU summit in Portugal, reaffirmed that he and his government are in favour of joining the euro when the economic conditions are right.

Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Today programme, Mr Blair shrugged off comparisons between his government's alleged divisions and the Tory party's wrangles over Europe under John Major. Reports of a government split on the issue focused on differences between the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

"The position of the government - and this is in complete contradiction to the last government - is clear. In principle, we are in favour of Britain's membership of a successful single currency. In practice, however, the economic conditions have got to be met," Mr Blair said.

"And that's for a very simple reason - if the economics of monetary union are not right for Britain it would not be the right thing for us to do. But in principle, membership of the successful single currency, with a single market - which would be the largest single market in the world, a world into which we have over 50% of our trade and of which millions of British jobs are engaged - is in principle the right thing for Britain to do."

Mr Blair claimed his comments on the euro were always portrayed as a shift in one direction or another. "People either say you are warming up or you are cooling down when in fact you are repeating the self-same policy we have had since October 1997," he said.

In the interview, the prime minister also expressed his horror at the discovery of 58 bodies in the back of a lorry at Dover. The dead were believed to have been trying to enter Britain illegally. "It underlines the importance of stamping out this trade in people," he said.

Mr Blair condemned the English football hooligans responsible for riots in Belgium.

He also rejected claims that his speech to the Women's Institute earlier this month was the low-point of his time in office. "You've got to distinguish between what is important and what is a load of  media hype and drivel," he said. "What is truly important is not my getting a bit of heckling during a WI speech, it's delivering a strong economy, decent public services and a fairer society."

webTitle: Now North Korea invites the Pope

fields.headline: Now North Korea invites the Pope
fields.trailText: A visit to Pyongyang which could well upstage last week's summit between the Koreas is under serious consideration, with the news that North Korea has extended an official invitation to Pope John Paul II.
fields.body:
A visit to Pyongyang which could well upstage last week's summit between the Koreas is under serious consideration, with the news that North Korea has extended an official invitation to Pope John Paul II.

The Vatican has confirmed that the invitation was handed over by South Korea's ambassador in Rome, on behalf of the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il.

The prospect was first raised by the South Korean president, Kim Dae-jung, at last week's summit. Kim Jong-il reportedly responded: "OK, then tell the Pope to come."

If it takes place, a papal visit will not be greeted by countless thousands of the faithful. The Catholic church in North Korea is believed to number no more than 3,000 members. Its priests were expelled from the country long ago.

However, contacts between the Catholic world and Pyongyang are increasing. The Holy See has quietly sent four delegations to North Korea since 1995 for humanitarian purposes, most recently in December last year.

"Mass is not celebrated and the faithful can only pray together," according to Kathi Zelloweger of the Catholic aid organisation Caritas in Hong Kong. "But there is contact, and contact and dialogue is fundamental."

The Vatican's mission, led by Archbishop Celestino Migliore, "had permission to visit freely the whole country", said Ms Zelloweger. "We travelled along the west coast and were able to see how the people live outside the capital."

The relations between Pyongyang and the Vatican may be assisted by the recent establishment of diplomatic relations between Italy and North Korea. Italy's foreign minister, Lamberto Dini, said on Saturday that the Pope was "available for a visit to North Korea as well as to China", and suggested that the prospects of a visit were high.

But the Vatican insists that a papal visit to Pyongyang will only be possible if the country accepts Catholic priests again.

webTitle: Jobs boost from new Ikea stores

fields.headline: Jobs boost from new Ikea stores
fields.trailText: Ikea is to create 10,000 new jobs in the UK by opening 20 new stores, the Swedish furniture company announced today.
fields.body:
Ikea is to create 10,000 new jobs in the UK by opening 20 new stores, the Swedish furniture company announced today.

The firm hopes its 10-year expansion programme will double sales and cut prices by 20%.

Managing director of Ikea UK, Goran Nilsson, said: "As UK jobs in the manufacturing industry continue to decline, the importance of companies who commit to the service sector in the long-term and on a large scale is critical." Mr Nilsson said the expansion would bring "real economic benefits in areas of regeneration", and he pledged that Ikea would build on brownfield sites "where possible".

The company, the world's largest furniture retailer, will invest over £300m in the next five years by building eight new stores and two new distribution centres, creating over 4,500 new jobs in addition to the 5,000 already employed at its existing 10 stores.

A further 12 stores will be opened in the second stage of the expansion, creating at least 6,000 new jobs.

Areas being considered for the new shops include Manchester, Coventry, Glasgow, South Wales, the south coast and London.

Since the first Ikea store opened in 1987 the group has grown to become the third biggest furniture retailer in Britain after MFI and DFS.

The UK is Ikea's second biggest market after Germany, accounting for 11.5% of the company's total £5bn turnover. It employs 5,000 people in the UK and 50,000 around the world.

Turnover in the UK reached £584m last year, and is expected to grow to over £700m this year.

fields.headline: Personal services
fields.standfirst: Revenues are off the scale and global domination is on the agenda. While the rest of the industry is wringing its hands, online advertisering companies are blooming. Imogen O'Rorke reports.
fields.trailText: Revenues are off the scale and global domination is on the agenda. While the rest of the industry is wringing its hands, online advertisering companies are blooming. Imogen O'Rorke reports.
fields.body:
At a time when the death knell sounds for another dot.com every week and the new economy is undergoing paranoid self-examination, there is one sector that is healthier than ever before: online advertising and digital marketing. When theInternet Advertising Bureau's next report comes out next month, it will show exponential growth and diversification in this area.

For evidence of this putative "renaissance" just look at all the mergers and acquisitions in recent weeks. First the online planning and buying agency Media21 was acquired by the US giant Grey Global, becoming Beyond Interactive Europe; and then Primedia-owned digital communications company Pres.co and marketing company Foresight were paired of in a merger which they claim will make the new company the biggest revenue-generating group in the UK new media industry, with a projected revenue of £27m.

The message for agencies and marketing consultancies is clear: consolidate and rule. In all these cases, global expansion was the primary motive. "There is a great opportunity but a limited timescale to establish a presence in Europe and we don't have the resources to do it ourselves separately," Tim Smith, chairman of Foresight, told Revolution this week.

Rick Sareen, who takes over as MD of Beyond in a couple of weeks, suggests the decision to go with the big guys was inevitable: "The internet is a global medium and you are almost forced down that route. If we didn't go global we would lose clients and probably staff because we could not afford to pay them enough." In the past year Media21, along with competitors i-level and Profero, has been approached by "numerous" agencies wanting to buy-out, but Sareen waited for the right opportunity: "We were looking for a truly international partnership."

As demand, not to mention the size of the projects, increases (PricewaterhouseCoopers reports a 122% increase in advertising revenue in the first half of 1999), specialists such as Media21, and end-to-end solutions agencies such as Razor fish, DeepEnd or the Hub are finding they simply have neither the space or the resources to keep up with clients' demands. "We have effectively upgraded from a planning/buying agency into a full service," says Sareen.

i-level, on the other hand, turned the Grey deal down in December because it wished to stay independent. Instead, it has just announced partnerships in the Benelux countries. "You can either cling onto the tail-end of this bandwagon or you can lead it. This way we feel we are leading," says CEO Charlie Dobres.

Dobres compares the market at the moment to the advent of television in the middle of the century. "Of the old print-based companies of the 40s, which survived beyond the 50s?" he asks.

Creative agencies such as the Hub, which developed Genie's mobile internet service and Woolworths' interactive Open service, now offer everything from consulting through to advertising and software integration. "To service the fully converged technologies you have to be fully converged yourself," says MD Sam Rudder.

While there can be no doubt of the growth spurt in this area of the new economy (the recent market correction did nothing to dampen online advertising companies' share prices - in some cases it boosted them), compared to the US, where yearly advertising revenues are worth around $4.6bn, it is still early days for the UK. Last year's market was worth only £100m.

Behind all the mergers and acquisitions lies a much more complex picture of an industry learning how to exploit the new digital media commercially experiencing the first wave of what analysts are calling a renaissance. The first requirement is the need to adapt to client demand. Traditionally, clients would have gone to one agency for their offline marketing requirements and to another for their web marketing and design; now they expect a US-style fully integrated "one stop shop" service.

Media sales houses such as Doubleclick and 24/7 (which now has offices in over 28 countries) started consolidating months ago and are reaping the benefits. 24/7 recently acquired Sabela Media, Imake, Award Track and Exactis, companies which focus on market sales, technology and loyalty across email, wireless, digital and broadband. Doubleclick recently bought Flashbase, a company which specialises in sweepstake technology. 24/7 UK, which was started in 1999 with a staff of seven, now employs 40 and reports 1,000% revenue growth on last year.

It is clear that the very nature of online marketing is changing. "Our business is increasingly focused on direct marketing," says Karl White, MD of 24/7. The surfer's journey can now be tracked through websites - if they've been to a finance site and then to a motoring site, the database will assume they are looking to buy a car and tailor the adverts accordingly and instantly. The US company has just unveiled new technology which will enable a unified advertising campaign to be served up on any platform.

On the front line, the focus is shifting from acquiring customers to developing sophisticated relationships with existing ones. "Converging media is changing the very nature of marketing communications," says Danny Meadows-Klue, a veteran internet publisher and chairman of Internet Advertising Bureau. "Markets started fragmenting a long time ago, with more newspaper supplements and programming segmenting. The journey eventually ends in one-to-one high-value customer relationships."

Online advertising began with a few hopeful banners stuck out in cyberspace. In the near future a 25-year-old woman will be presented with an entirely different set of adverts to a man in his 40s. "Where database marketing was once restricted by cost of mailing, call centres and face to face, all these things have become really simple," says Meadows-Klue. "And what we have is a one-to-one relationship with a million consumers through a website, and a situation where consumers in a way can interrogate their own data. After all, what is the internet other than an absolutely vast database of databases?"

All this bodes particularly well for people entering the industry at ground level and for entrepreneurs focused on innovative forms of marketing. "This is the most exciting time to be getting into this industry" says Meadows-Klue, with a burst of optimism sweetly reminiscent of the halycon pre-crash days. "We're looking at the dawn of a new era for advertising."

fields.headline: Feeding frenzy
fields.standfirst: First take someone else's work, then charge others to read it... As pure content sites collapse,  David Rowan looks at the rise of news aggregators.
fields.trailText: First steal someone else's work, then charge others to read it... As pure content sites collapse, David Rowan looks at the rise of news aggregators.
fields.body:
Here's a neat economic model for the new economy. First, wait for a leading media company to invest in high-quality journalism - an (ahem) incisive piece of analysis like this, for instance - and to give it away on its website. Then steal that rather excellent headline above it, which you make available on your own website, something that copyright law allows. Next, charge leading companies £1,700 a month each to get access to that headline, if it leads to the sort of piece they want to read. Finally - and this will crack you up - tell the Guardian it must pay you £20 each time 1,000 people look up its own story from your site.

Oh, and then collect $21m from investors who think your site is so cool it is worth between $60-$100m.

Far-fetched? Not if you are Moreover.com, one of the growing number of "news aggregators" building up market valuations as fast as "pure content" websites are collapsing. Last week, Moreover.com completed a funding round from Reuters and Atlas Venture, among others, that it hopes will let it feed other people's headlines to 400,000 websites by the start of next year. At present, Moreover.com is harvesting headlines from 1,500 sources, headlines that it gives away in category-based feeds to 50,000 sites - which can choose, say, to offer a feed about biotech news or space-science news. Users click on headlines to read the full stories on the originating sites - which can sell advertisements against those page views. The company is now working on providing auction feeds and last-minute flight feeds.

The timing of the funding will not have gone unnoticed at Salon.com, TheStreet.co.uk, and other editorial-content sites that have recently been forced to examine their own business models. Last week, as staff at crime-news site APBnews.com were working for free in the hope of salvation, thebullet.co.uk, a UK media site, announced it had "shut down day-to-day operations" while it considered its future.

Nick Denton, a former FT journalist who is Moreover.com's chief executive, believes his low-cost, high-value service has a business model that content sites cannot match. It makes money at both ends of the content-transfer process: banks and private companies pay for custom feeds that serve their own needs; at the other end, it charges content sites for the traffic it delivers to them - which can be far greater than advertising or search-engine positioning would bring.

Typically, a news aggregator such as Yahoo! charges 1-3 cents to a publisher's site every time a headline is clicked through from Yahoo!'s news pages. Some publications will pay up to 10 cents a click; and a financial site such as E-Trade might pay a dollar a click. Moreover.com charges in the range of 2-6 cents - which Denton says is "about a hundredth of the cost of the clickthrough from banner ads". "There's an incentive for content sites to pay to promote," he explains. "We've 1,500 sources. No one publisher is an absolute must-have." (Guardian Unlimited, which runs its own free content-distribution service to other websites, does not pay Moreover.com or other aggregators for referrals.)

The challenge for content-based websites is finding a way to pay for all that expensive original journalism. Consumers have rarely been happy to pay to read articles online, unless, as with the Wall Street Journal, it might help them make more money. Banner advertising is rarely the answer even for the larger sites. Denton sees only three options for pure-content websites. First, pretend to be an aggregator by linking users to relevant pages on other people's websites.

Second, syndicate everything - taking a cue from the ubiquitous Reuters, or mapping companies such as Mapquest. "If it costs too much to get visitors to your site, get your content out where the viewers are," advises Denton.

Third, go offline as well as online. Tech-news bible the Industry Standard subsidises its loss-making website with a hugely profitable weekly print magazine, whose ad revenue is more than $100m.

It's clear who the real winner will be in online media, says Denton: "Yahoo!, the world's most rapidly growing media company ever, doesn't produce an ounce of original content. The Yahoo! effect is immensely powerful. Add up the market valuation of all the information aggregators out there, and they've got 100 times the combined market value of every pure original content site."

But you don't need to be a media giant to be a successful aggregator. Take Jim Romenesko, an Illinois journalist whose fascination with industry snippets led him last May to rise before dawn to compile his daily mediagossip.com digest of online papers' must-reads. The popularity of his one-man site, not just among hacks, led to an approach from the Poynter Institute, a journalism school where he now runs its site, MediaNews. Some big players would envy his traffic and "brand recognition". "I ran mediagossip.com for several months before Poynter came to me," Romenesko says. "If I knew anything about ad sales, I could have probably made a living on my own. The sites that will succeed will be lean and not beholden to Wall Street."

Inside.com, a new media-industry site established by top US magazine journalists including Kurt Andersen, could hardly be seen as lean. Having raised $25m, it has hired writers from Vanity Fair, Rolling Stone and the Wall Street Journal to offer the inside scoop on the publishing, film, broadcast and music industries. Subscribers are asked to pay $199 a year to catch the buzz - a controversial business model, given recent re-valuations of content sites. But Andersen, who has edited Spy and New York magazine, dismisses this year's depression in content-sites' values, which he feels is "as extreme and unthinking as 1999 mania".

Yet he, too, admires the aggregators' strategy. "The brilliance of Yahoo! is that it's national and it's local, it's cheap to produce and it gives its audience real depth. The big problem facing Salon, which is essentially a national alternative newspaper produced every day, is that it's national, and has no local advertisers to whom it can deliver futon buyers or concert-goers."

Critics of Andersen's site, however, raise questions about its own business model. Journalists are expensive and troublesome to employ. Moreover.com, which employs 33 staff, claims its 10,000 daily headlines could be handled by four people. Romenesko doubts whether users will pay money upfront: "Web users simply demand that content be free. Porn they'll pay for, but news and features they won't."

Nick Denton sees Inside.com as doomed. "I'm gobsmacked," he says. "After this incredible catalogue of failures in subscription-based content, to set up a site like that in 2000 is quite an amazing venture whose timing could not be worse."

Andrew Ross, executive vice- president of Salon.com, argues that content providers and content aggregators need each other. "There is no question that when, say, AOL or Yahoo! - the pioneers of content aggregation - turn on the hose, a content provider's traffic can go through the roof. At the same time, content aggregators need content - and, as more websites emerge and grow, so, presumably, will the demand for both of our services."

Ross's fear is that those who control the portals to content will merely rely, lazily, on the "usual suspects - the traditional wire services, the branded old media that do little more than shovel up their pre-existing content in 'digital' form - at the expense of those who are delivering original, web-based content. fields.headline: New blooms at the BBC
fields.standfirst: Greg Dyke is applying a green-fingered touch to his reorganisation of the BBC.  Maggie Brown  reports on petals, pot-plants, daisies and their place in the digital age.
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke is applying a green-fingered touch to his reorganisation of the BBC. Maggie Brown reports on petals, pot-plants, daisies and their place in the digital age.
fields.body:
The BBC kicked off an urgent debate about the future of BBC1 and BBC2 last week, which could dwarf the fuss over Match of the Day. Director of television Mark Thompson - the brainy young Turk once rash enough to kill off One Man and His Dog - has gone public with Greg Dyke's approval, floating the idea of saying goodbye to "mixed schedules". Dyke's regime would phase out BBC1 as we know it, and reconfigure it as a populist entertainment network more in tune with the digital times, a family of channels - BBC1, 2, 3 and 4 - rather along the lines of BBC Radio. First changes are pencilled in for late 2001.

Since Dyke took over in February and produced a manifesto called One BBC, envisaging happy teams of producers working in a creative powerhouse, the headlines have been grabbed by his plans to cut bureaucrats and potted plants as he introduced departments constructed as petals in a daisy. But alongside the cuts now being finalised, the more exciting part of the Dyke strategy has been overlooked: working out how to crank up the machine so that in two or three years' time the BBC has acquired the programmes to fit the changed channels while discarding John Birt's technologically driven legacy - two bungled digital networks, BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge, and the unloved News 24.

"The focus now is on programmes and audiences, really that's all the BBC is about, not mobile phones," says a key architect of the re-think. And the shift has meant talking in public about the unthinkable. How programmes are organised in schedules in an era when the electronic programme guide is king and the Tivo box, allowing you to personalise schedules, makes advances into homes.

The Reithian belief that the BBC is there to inform, educate and entertain - counting on viewers, seen as passive, stumbling into an uplifting arts programme after watching a sitcom - has meant that BBC1 currently offers 14 different programme genres within its schedule, including religion, music and current affairs. Thompson is the first to say publicly that he doubts that this lofty ideal will still make sense when digital households eventually become the majority.

His speech sounded the death knell of that traditional public service device of "hammocking". Putting a serious current affairs programme between a top drama and comedy no longer works. People simply zap away. A documentary or a Panorama on BBC1 will attract a BBC2-sized audience.

At the very least, Thompson is clear that all BBC services, above all BBC1, have to become more predictable in the short to medium term (up to five years), using "zones" grouping the same kind of programmes together. So BBC1 will begin replacing documentaries - and probably Panorama and Omnibus - with top-class drama and entertainment. In fact, drama production is going up by as much as 40% in the coming year. BBC2 will be the home for serious documentaries, but will still incubate new comedy series, such as The Royle Family and Coupling, for the next few years.

"It's either an incredibly bold move or terribly wrong," says one executive - a not untypical reaction in a BBC where many remain gobsmacked doubters. But the speech is all part of a calculated process. Thompson flew to a remote television festival in Banff, Canada to deliver it. What he said was being minutely checked by Dyke until just before he spoke. Insiders know Thompson is the warm-up act for Dyke's MacTaggart Lecture at August's Guardian International Edinburgh Television Festival.

The proposals for reorganising the BBC's TV services into an integrated family of channels will then be put up for consultation in the autumn. The plans were discussed with the governors last month. But it's highly significant that the first public airing of the new strategy has come from Thompson - the most pukka of "old" BBC figures, widely seen as Dyke's likely heir. "If Greg had said it, he'd be accused of being Roland Rat getting his oar in," explains an insider.

Singling out John Tusa - former head of the World Service, now boss of the Barbican - the Oxford-educated Thompson also raised eyebrows by taking on Britain's cultural elite, dubbing them "just one more niche" not necessarily in touch with the wider public. He said that live broadcasts of classical music, including eventually most Proms concerts, might perhaps be best suited to a separate arts and ideas cultural channel.

Reaction so far is pretty divided. All the rival terrestrial networks sat up smartly. The rethink has great relevance to ITV, still fighting a battle with the regulator over news. Its director of programmes, David Liddiment, remains committed to a mixed, diverse schedule. Dawn Airey, Channel 5's director of programmes, said: "It sounds like a good idea. I'm not surprised. It's logical."

Inside the BBC, the speed of change stunned many outside the very top echelon. "I've never seen a change-around occur so quickly," said one respected figure. A senior BBC broadcaster said: "I find it deeply worrying. It's a different tone completely from what was being said even a year ago." As recently as November, ratifying the Alan Yentob-headed review of the channel, the BBC governors declared that BBC1 should offer the "broadest range and richest genre mix" of any British "broad-appeal" network.

Politicians have yet to formulate detailed responses, but the BBC will clearly have a fight on its hands. Gerald Kaufman's sceptical culture, media and sports select committee will tackle it when the BBC's chairman, Sir Christopher Bland, goes to a hearing next month. At the Department of Culture, culture secretary Chris Smith's office expressed surprise, and repeated his belief in the value of a mixed schedule for BBC1.

It seems that the BBC, in a preemptive strike, is redefining its public service broadcasting offering before legislation which might introduce stricter controls. Awkwardly, this is happening at a time when key areas, such as news and current affairs, are, as one executive says, "in a totally prone position", run by managers not confident in their jobs.

But the move is also driven by fear: research into viewing in digital homes shows startling declines in BBC ratings. For example, in multi-channel homes in Wales audiences for the Six O'Clock News and the Nine O'Clock News have fallen by more than 40%. Men and children are heading straight for the genre selections on the EPG, ignoring channel schedules. "Nickelodeon is the first thing children come across [on the EPG], Blue Peter isn't even up there," gasped one department head after a recent BBC briefing.

Will Wyatt - until December Birt's deputy as BBC Broadcast chief executive - says the new approach makes sense. "This is what the BBC will need to become at some stage. But the question is when - how soon? And it's important not to betray the people who are sticking with only terrestrial channels."

Meanwhile, however tempting the prospect of raising audience share by making BBC1 more populist, the reality is that the internal reorganisation - the exact make-up of those infamous petals - to deliver the goodies is going far from smoothly. Many of the BBC's key hits, such as Teletubbies and Have I Got News For You?, are delivered by independent contractors supplying the BBC with ideas and talent - altogether contributing nearly half of drama and entertainment output. Indies are furious about a major muddle in the revamping of the BBC's commissioning process, which saw the Independent Commissioning Group they dealt with dismantled, but nothing put in its place.

Pact, the body representing more than 1,000 producers, last week briefed competition lawyers, making plain it is prepared to sue. "It's outrageous, scandalous," says chief executive Shaun Williams. "Still, four months on, there's a gaping hole. We see controllers saying 'no' when they would have said 'yes' before."

The crucial difference now is that genre commissioners sit alongside TV channel controllers, handling and picking proposals together. But there's a big flaw in that system. Commissioners have got to deliver a substantial chunk of work to their own producers. So they are not neutral. They know the BBC's task is to build up in-house production.

Why the delay in sorting things out? Why so many unfilled top jobs? Because the new system puts Dyke and Thompson at the centre. Their judgments are the ones that count. The drawbacks were painfully apparent during last week's sports rights debacle, where the need for a experienced specialist pounding the sports beat (rather than an acting head of sport) was all too glaringly obvious.

webTitle: Time to grasp a few nettles

fields.headline: Time to grasp a few nettles
fields.standfirst: The barrack-room lawyers of the television industry (there's no shortage of them) have three days to get their ideas in to the Department of Culture, Media and Sport on communications reform.
fields.trailText: The barrack-room lawyers of the television industry (there's no shortage of them) have three days to get their ideas in to the Department of Culture, Media and Sport on communications reform.
fields.body:
The barrack-room lawyers of the television industry (there's no shortage of them) have three days to get their ideas in to the Department of Culture, Media and Sport on communications reform. A single regulator is virtually a given. So too is the BBC being subject to the new authority - the governors, although a perfectly good board of management, are no longer credible regulators.

A white paper has been promised for the autumn, though I suspect its appearance before Christmas is no more likely than Jerry Springer getting the Order of Merit. It is indeed a complex task. But please, please DCMS, put forward some firm proposals. The July 1998 green paper merely tabled a long list of questions. The government now needs to move on from its consultation culture. Technology is changing our industry at a punishing pace. The white paper has to grasp some nettles firmly and come up with radical approaches. Here are a few thoughts:

 Nettle one: ITV's regional remit. It makes perfect sense to allow the creation of a single ITV company covering the whole of England. But it is increasingly paradoxical for one company to supply the premier entertainment channel while purporting to be a producer of regional programmes.

ITV's current offerings are crudely divided between areas defined by nothing more sophisticated than where the transmitters happened to be in 1953. Digital technology offers infinite possibilities. But genuinely local television remains a pipe dream.

In return for the privilege of the national entertainment channel, ITV should be asked to support the new restrictive service licences being issued. ITV should give them promotional time and sell advertising for them (as it used to for Channel 4). Without this, the licences will struggle and Britain will never have local television with which real communities can identify.

 Nettle two: Channel 4's status. Channel 4's info-warriors are winning the argument against privatisation. It would serve little purpose and would reduce the amount of money it invests in programming. But Channel 4 needs a new remit. It should not be based on "innovative programmes" per se. This is a typically unenforceable requirement vulnerable to the subjective whims of regulators.

Channel 4's role should be redefined as an incubator fund for the creative economy. One senior member of the channel described it to me as being UK television's equivalent of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But Channel 4 will need to be protected by fair-trading rules to allow it to run digital channels and online services at a loss while building their capital value. There should also be a policy for eventually realising that capital value.

 Nettle three: BBC commercial activities. I have argued before in this column for BBC Worldwide to be privatised and for the BBC to set up an intellectual property licensing division. For the first time, the BBC's assets would be properly valued in the marketplace and fair-trading arguments silenced.

The BBC should also be able to take minority equity stakes in businesses built on its intellectual property. In this way, a clear line would be drawn between activities funded by the licence fee and commercial ones. It would also give scope to Greg Dyke's entrepreneurial ideas.

And as a twist to the "mutuality" debate, why not return some of the proceeds directly to licence fee payers? This could be the elusive driver for digital take-up. The dividend would be paid to those viewers who had subscribed to a digital service and held in trust for the rest.

 Nettle four: electronic programme guides (EPGs). The means of entry to the digital world must be truly flexible. Our creative economy will grow if we are all given the maximum opportunity to consume as many goods and services as possible. Whether via an ADSL service, a cable supplier, a satellite company or a terrestrial company, we should be able to gain access to material with maximum freedom. The existing EPGs are clunky, mostly channel-based and, at their worst, anti-competitive.

 Nettle five: content supply. "Content" covers everything from conventional television programmes to online data. To have a healthy creative economy, Britain needs a truly competitive content market.

Television has never had one because the distributors (the broadcasters) control access to the audience and fund nearly all the content. Meanwhile, Oftel is forcing BT to open up its networks to a range of providers. The white paper should affirm this principle so content suppliers have access to all the distribution platforms.

 Peter Bazalgette is creative director of GMG Endermol Entertainment, an independent production company part-owned by the Guardian Media Group

Technology is changing our industry at a punishing pace. The white paper has to grasp some nettles firmly and come up with radical approaches. Here are a few thoughts:  Nettle one: ITV's regional remit. It makes perfect sense to allow the creation of a single ITV company covering the whole of England. But it is increasingly paradoxical for one company to supply the premier entertainment channel while purporting to be a producer of regional programmes. ITV's current offerings are crudely divided between areas defined by nothing more sophisticated than where the transmitters happened to be in 1953. Digital technology offers infinite possibilities. But genuinely local television remains a pipe dream. In return for the privilege of the national entertainment channel, ITV should be asked to support the new restrictive service licences being issued. ITV should give them promotional time and sell advertising for them (as it used to for Channel 4). Without this, the licences will struggle and Britain will never have local television with which real communities can identify.  Nettle two: Channel 4's status. Channel 4's info-warriors are winning the argument against privatisation. It would serve little purpose and would reduce the amount of money it invests in programming. But Channel 4 needs a new remit. It should not be based on "innovative programmes" per se. This is a typically unenforceable requirement vulnerable to the subjective whims of regulators. Channel 4's role should be redefined as an incubator fund for the creative economy. One senior member of the channel described it to me as being UK television's equivalent of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But Channel 4 will need to be protected by fair-trading rules to allow it to run digital channels and online services at a loss while building their capital value. There should also be a policy for eventually realising that capital value.  Nettle three: BBC commercial activities. I have argued before in this column for BBC Worldwide to be privatised and for the BBC to set up an intellectual property licensing division. For the first time, the BBC's assets would be properly valued in the marketplace and fair-trading arguments silenced. The BBC should also be able to take minority equity stakes in businesses built on its intellectual property. In this way, a clear line would be drawn between activities funded by the licence fee and commercial ones. It would also give scope to Greg Dyke's entrepreneurial ideas. And as a twist to the "mutuality" debate, why not return some of the proceeds directly to licence fee payers? This could be the elusive driver for digital take-up. The dividend would be paid to those viewers who had subscribed to a digital service and held in trust for the rest.  Nettle four: electronic programme guides (EPGs). The means of entry to the digital world must be truly flexible. Our creative economy will grow if we are all given the maximum opportunity to consume as many goods and services as possible. Whether via an ADSL service, a cable supplier, a satellite company or a terrestrial company, we should be able to gain access to material with maximum freedom. The existing EPGs are clunky, mostly channel-based and, at their worst, anti-competitive.  Nettle five: content supply. "Content" covers everything from conventional television programmes to online data. To have a healthy creative economy, Britain needs a truly competitive content market. Television has never had one because the distributors (the broadcasters) control access to the audience and fund nearly all the content. Meanwhile, Oftel is forcing BT to open up its networks to a range of providers. The white paper should affirm this principle so content suppliers have access to all the distribution platforms.  Peter Bazalgette is creative director of GMG Endermol Entertainment, an independent production company part-owned by the Guardian Media Group

fields.headline: Give it up, Alastair
fields.standfirst: After a fortnight of terrible press coverage for Labour, Alastair Campbell is going to lie low. Quite right, says  Roy Greenslade, the spin doctor is redundant.
fields.trailText: After a fortnight of terrible press coverage for Labour, Alastair Campbell is going to lie low. Quite right, says Roy Greenslade, the spin doctor is redundant.
fields.body:
I am not a mouthpiece for Alastair Campbell. We have been colleagues, we are friends, and we talk quite often. We also happen to agree on the fundamental point about the role of the press in political life. We both regard editors and journalists - whether working directly to their owners' agenda or to their own - as society's prime spin doctors.

Where we have tended to disagree is over how to combat this fact of media life. From the moment he became Tony Blair's press secretary, he adopted a strategy about which I have long been sceptical. Not least because it is, in some ways, at odds with his combative personality and takes little account of his fiercely partisan viewpoint.

Before the election, I understood the benefits that would accrue from wooing the Sun and neutralising the Tory bias of other titles. But, given the treatment they had handed out to John Major in his final years in office, I didn't expect them to endorse the Conservatives anyway.

Once Blair became prime minister he enjoyed a lengthy honeymoon, though there were early hiccups (the Ecclestone affair, the Cook marriage saga) which suggested that the antagonistic relationship between press and government would eventually kick in once more.

Within months, the central line of newspaper attack emerged: the target was to be Campbell himself. Spin must be turned into a sin. The supposed strength of the Blair government, its presentation, was to be transformed into its weakness.

Beaverbrook - echoing Hitler, incidentally - was fond of telling his editors: "Repetition is the key to propaganda." Indeed it is.

"The drip-drip-drip of poison", to borrow Peter Mandelson's apt description of the process, soon became a daily phenomenon. "Spin-doctor" became a term of abuse. Spinners were "exposed" as dabblers in the "black arts". Readers were encouraged to see Campbell and his ilk as a sinister group.

A Guardian library check of computer records for 10 national papers over the past three years shows that "spin" has appeared in more than 2,500 headlines, let alone stories.

Meanwhile, Blair was cast as a hostage to the "art of spin". His government's policy statements and ministerial speeches were reported not in terms of their content but with a nod towards what we might call the mechanics behind them. Why and how they came about was considered more important than the fact of their existence.

Naturally, a Tory party in disarray, with a new, untried leader finding his way, latched on quickly to the press agenda. The cries of "spin" in the Commons became as regular as those in the papers.

It didn't take long for the simplistic single-syllable word to take hold of the public imagination. Blair had become synonymous with spin. Ask a random selection of people now what they think of the government and, whether they support it or not, most are sure to mention spin in a pejorative way.

I wasn't in the least surprised by the revelation in the leaked memo written by Blair's private pollster, Philip Gould, that the prime minister is widely considered to be "all spin and presentation".

But I was astonished that it has taken Gould so long to discover it. What use are these focus groups if they are so slow to catch on? A surprising number of people I bump into even know who Campbell is.

The man in the background has taken centre stage, not because he has sought it but because newspapers have thrust him into the limelight. Part of the reason for this is undoubtedly Campbell's relationship with the journalists he meets every day. They resent his power, dislike his sarcasm and, on many occasions, have been intimidated by his rage.

Even those papers sympathetic to Labour have been upset by the tactics he employs. Why does he feed stories to the true-blue Daily Mail rather than the red-tinged Daily Express?

Why should the Sun, which remains as reactionary as ever, be treated sweetly, while the Mirror is too often left to swing in the wind (and get so angry it even dared to urge readers to vote Tory in the London mayoral election)?

If the Campbell approach made sense two years ago, it surely doesn't any longer. The press has resolutely set its face against Blair - and no amount of spin doctoring will make much difference now.

I kept a record of political coverage in the four most popular daily papers (Sun, Daily Mail, Mirror and Daily Express) from May 29 until Friday. Over those 17 days, the headlines and stories were overwhelmingly negative, in spite of the fact that three of those titles are supposed to be supporting Blair.

The Daily Mail, as one might expect, has been relentless in its criticism. It also devotes more space to politics than the other three put together. Several pages in most issues are dominated by heavily angled "news" stories pouring scorn on Blair.

On most days there were three page leads critical of Labour. On May 31, for example, the sequence of headlines ran: "60,000 have deserted New Labour" (page 2); "Labour reels as a million vote to keep clause 28" (page 6); "This archaic class war on middle England" (above an attack on John Prescott on pages 18 and 19); "'Shame' of Robin Cook" (over an article on Sierra Leone on page 26); and "Blair ignores calls to cull army of spin doctors" (page 29).

Next day, the Mail splashed on "Fiasco of Labour's health service survey", and its page 2 was headlined "Labour 'has become paranoid under Blair'". This story wasn't carried by any other paper - which isn't too surprising, since it was based on the views of a wife of a former junior minister writing in Tribune.

When the story of Baroness Jay's schooling broke, the Mail splashed on it. The following day it was the subject of a leader and of comment by two columnists, with all three pieces making the same point.

By the end of that week, when Blair made his speech to the Women's Institute conference, the paper was in its element, with headlines about "humiliation", "Blair's Waterloo" and "Wembley backlash." Significantly, its main leading article was about "the perils of spin".

But what of the Blair-friendly Sun? Here are a selection of its headlines over the period: "You've lost touch, Tony"; "2 Jags, 9 baths and a butler" (about the refit of Prescott's grace-and-favour residence); "Blair's thrown it all away"; and "Labour council tax shake-up could put bills up 25%".

Sun columnist Richard Littlejohn never lets a chance of hammering Blair pass him by. The paper carried an article assaulting Blair's policies by Tony Benn. A variety of stories about the euro were explicit attacks on Blair and chancellor Brown. Leading arti cles, which, admittedly, few Sun readers bother with, contained innumerable gripes about the government.

OK, then, what about the Mirror? There was certainly more sympathy for Blair in its leaders, and it did its best to counter the WI fiasco by revealing the eccentric views of one of the hecklers. It was also harsh on William Hague.

But some headlines were strangely reminiscent of the Sun. One - "You've lost touch, Tony" - was exactly the same. Among others were "Labour fudges fox hunt vote", "Derry's £150,000 Dorchester bash" and "Jack's open door" (to asylum seekers).

Also notable was the casual abuse of government figures in other columns by Paul Routledge and even by Sue Carroll, who referred to Baroness Jay as a pompous peer. She may well be right. The point is that, along with stories about splits on the euro, the overall picture painted of Blair in the Mirror is little different from that in other papers.

The Daily Express seemed to be in two minds. Its famed right-wing columnist Peter Hitchens apart, there were plenty of anti-government headlines - "Ageist Labour has forgotten elderly", "How we were betrayed by Brown", "Prescott blunder...", "Blair gimmicks won't cure the ills of the NHS" and many more.

Does anyone believe that this litany of loathing for the government is the result of successful spin-doctoring by Campbell? What it illustrates instead is the failure of spin, that the papers have reverted to type, that the press cannot be beaten into obeisance by the kind of public relations initiatives adopted by Campbell and his team.

These four papers are together read by about 25m Britons every day. They have gradually built up in the minds of their readers the idea that Blair is a man of no substance who has not fulfilled his promises. I regard that as an untrue picture - but trying to obliterate newspaper spin is impossible. No wonder Campbell is going to take a back seat for a while. What's the point of doing anything else?

fields.headline: Feuds with the famous
fields.standfirst: After four years of stirring it with the celebs on the Mirror, showbiz columnist Matthew Wright is taking the plunge into the dot.com world. He explains why to Matt Wells.
fields.trailText: After four years of stirring it with the celebs on the Mirror, showbiz columnist Matthew Wright is taking the plunge into the dot.com world. He explains why to Matt Wells.
fields.body:
For some journalists, career highs might include penetrating a remote war zone, interviewing a world leader or unveiling a major scientific breakthrough. But given the opportunity, most of those hacks - this one included - would happily swap their battered pocket notebooks for an access-all-areas pass at a Madonna gig. Yet for some reason, Matthew Wright wants to hang up his tiara.

"There's only a certain amount of time you can do this sort of thing for before it starts to take a toll on you," says Wright, whose last column in the Mirror will appear tomorrow. It seems that the relentless round of showbiz parties, press launches and daily deadlines has taken its toll on Wright, who at 35 is taking the dot.com plunge and joining an entertainment website aimed at teenage girls.

So no more cheesy polaroids of Matthew with Maddy, Matthew with Barrymore, and Matthew with Hugh and Liz; no more tales of the size of Robbie Williams's manhood. It's the end of an era. How will we cope with life without Matthew? And more to the point, how will Matthew cope with life without us?

For he is the archetypal showbiz hack. The cheeky grin, flirtatious blue eyes and slightly camp manner (he's married, before you ask) cover a steely determination to be the best at his job, to get the top stories, the biggest exclusives. And, it seems, a genuine understanding of the nature of celebrity. "What I have learned is that they might be extremely rich and extremely famous but, apart from the fact that certain aspects of their lives have been changed by their status, they are still essentially human and normal. If you can talk to a celebrity like they are a normal person, you'll get a normal conversation back."

Wright's rise as a showbiz hack has been harder than most. When he started at the Mirror a little more than four years ago, he was a bit of a nobody. He had worked for his current boss Piers Morgan at the Sun, when Morgan was editor of the Bizarre column, followed by a spell on the Richard Littlejohn show at Sky. But he was far from being a household name.

Joining the Mirror wasn't much help either - most of the PR circuit which controls the flow of stories from the big-name celebrities was firmly plugged in to News International. If you didn't work for the Sun, your name wasn't on the list. So there was only one way to get noticed: shout very loudly. "I started very aggressively, the idea being that the only way we would win the battle against other long-established columns would be to go and make ourselves unforgettable, poke fun at them and tease celebrities quite mercilessly. And it worked - we started to get recognised as a newspaper column and as a face in our own right."

The relentless pursuit of celebrity became Wright's stock-in-trade. While other columns depended upon the drip-feed from public relations teams, Wright battled from outside. And while the strategy was hard work, it was also immense fun. "In the early days I was just viciously cruel about people."

Cruel is not the word. There was the singer Darren Day: "We pursued him for his inability to remain faithful to people for more than about 10 minutes."

And the EastEnders star Sid Owen: "I think Sid suffered from Darren Day-itis - the same inability to remain faithful. He threw a pint of beer over me - I think that was about us saying what a useless piece of pondlife he was."

Then there was Robbie "Hamster" Williams: "That was about the size of his manhood, which was the result of some pictures we were offered but didn't buy."

And the Spice Girls: "I stand by all of what I said about them. I'm amazed that it became the phenomenon that it did, because I don't consider them to be a particularly talented bunch of women. The 'girl power' thing irritated me - everybody I could see around them was a man. The songwriters were men, their manager was a man, their record company people were men."

There comes a time, though, when some of these people have to be confronted. So how did Day feel about all his ex-girlfriends spilling the beans about what a rat he was? "He was very pleasant about it, and held his hand up and we went out for lunch."

Robbie Williams? "I had to apologise in the paper, which was quite tongue-in-cheek. It was just before the Brit Awards, when he had been nominated in every category. There didn't seem to be much point in continuing to say he was a useless no-hoper, because obviously the public loved him. And, God bless him, he was really sweet about it. I saw him about a month later and we shook hands - it was the handshake that meant more to pop fans than the one between Gorbachev and Reagan. It had a high-camp, send-up feel to it.

"Again I was very impressed by his personality, that he could forgive what was a fairly relentless campaign of mickey-taking against him. Every time I see him it's all very civilised. I wonder whether, if the roles had been reversed, I would have forgiven and forgotten. I'm not sure I would have done. I would probably have had a swing at me like Sid Owen tried to."

But the Mirror column was not just about send-ups: celebrities were not the only ones to set up publicity-seeking stunts. Wright once presented a baby's sleepsuit to Madonna, shortly after she had become a mother, at a press conference for Evita. "I was shaking like a leaf, I was so nervous - I walked down to the front, said 'Hello Maddy, I've bought you this' - and she said: 'I don't think it'll fit me.' Adrenalin took over and it was high camp all the way."

Then there was the time when he sneaked in with a false beard to a Smash Hits poll-winners party after being banned following the Spice Girls feud, and hid in a toilet before barging down to the front when the group came on stage: "I jumped up onto the orchestra pit and unfurled a Mirror banner. Geri Halliwell said 'There's Matthew Wright!' and all of a sudden the BBC cameras got this Mirror banner and a silly man in a beard. It's a huge buzz. I was literally shaking like a leaf, as much with the humiliation of it as anything else. I'm no tough guy, but I've no shame. . ."

Clearly not. But if the party was such fun, why wimp out now? Why is a man at the top of his profession, on the second-biggest daily newspaper in the country, taking the plunge in uncharted waters? "Lots of things really, lots of things coming together at the same time in my life. I've done 10 years in Fleet Street, I'm almost 35 and I looked around and asked myself what other jobs would I like to do on Fleet Street. There's only a certain amount of time you can do this or you just lose interest in it and become not so good at it. Four years is just about the right time, I think."

Wright is passionate about the new venture - mykindaplace.com - and while he is aware of the risks, he believes there is a market to be exploited. "The research shows that teenage girls were heavily and increasingly reliant on the internet. That was the direction that age group was going. It just seemed like the obvious thing to do." (And if the website fails, there's always the book he's writing, and "other projects".)

Wright has been brought in to oversee the editorial direction of the new website, which will be the usual teen mix of showbiz and lifestyle features. He will take charge of a team of journalists, mostly recruited from monthly magazines, and bring them up to speed with the disciplines of daily deadlines - it is anticipated that about 60% of the site will be updated daily.

It is a risky venture for Wright. It is not going to be easy to persuade stars who see the tabloid press as the best vehicle to push their personalities to come around to the web way of thinking. And he doesn't believe that his name will help. "It's easy to assume that because you have a high-profile job on a successful newspaper that automatically opens doors for you. But from the start, when I was working with Piers here, it was very obvious that the PR strategy was single-minded and pointed towards Wapping. We decided that the best way to do it was independently of the PRs - to go out and self-generate, and that's what we've done for the past four and a half years. It's something that I'm used to doing, starting from scratch."

The timing, too, is questionable: mykindaplace launches just as some high-profile content-heavy sites are just discovering that their revenue doesn't begin to justify their overheads. "I don't see that fear as pertinent to what we're doing. One of the most reassuring figures I've seen was that the teen magazine market is rapidly falling apart in terms of circulation, and I can't think of any other reason for that other than teenage girls are diversifying their interests. Why should they pay £1 or £2 for a magazine when they can get exactly the same information for free on the internet, and with a stronger interactive element?"

After 10 years relentlessly pursuing the famous and infamous, Wright has a pretty good idea of who's doing what to whom. And he has formulated a pretty good idea of which celebrities he likes. "All the camp ones: Elton, Barrymore, Winton. Why is it that gay people are so in tune with showbiz? I know it's a generalisation, but they seem to have a lot more fun, they send themselves up more." That's what it's all about. "I've used the word 'camp' a lot here - but it's all just a bit of a send-up, a bit of a joke, isn't it?"

Then there was Robbie "Hamster" Williams: "That was about the size of his manhood, which was the result of some pictures we were offered but didn't buy." And the Spice Girls: "I stand by all of what I said about them. I'm amazed that it became the phenomenon that it did, because I don't consider them to be a particularly talented bunch of women. The 'girl power' thing irritated me - everybody I could see around them was a man. The songwriters were men, their manager was a man, their record company people were men." There comes a time, though, when some of these people have to be confronted. So how did Day feel about all his ex-girlfriends spilling the beans about what a rat he was? "He was very pleasant about it, and held his hand up and we went out for lunch." Robbie Williams? "I had to apologise in the paper, which was quite tongue-in-cheek. It was just before the Brit Awards, when he had been nominated in every category. There didn't seem to be much point in continuing to say he was a useless no-hoper, because obviously the public loved him. And, God bless him, he was really sweet about it. I saw him about a month later and we shook hands - it was the handshake that meant more to pop fans than the one between Gorbachev and Reagan. It had a high-camp, send-up feel to it. "Again I was very impressed by his personality, that he could forgive what was a fairly relentless campaign of mickey-taking against him. Every time I see him it's all very civilised. I wonder whether, if the roles had been reversed, I would have forgiven and forgotten. I'm not sure I would have done. I would probably have had a swing at me like Sid Owen tried to." But the Mirror column was not just about send-ups: celebrities were not the only ones to set up publicity-seeking stunts. Wright once presented a baby's sleepsuit to Madonna, shortly after she had become a mother, at a press conference for Evita. "I was shaking like a leaf, I was so nervous - I walked down to the front, said 'Hello Maddy, I've bought you this' - and she said: 'I don't think it'll fit me.' Adrenalin took over and it was high camp all the way." Then there was the time when he sneaked in with a false beard to a Smash Hits poll-winners party after being banned following the Spice Girls feud, and hid in a toilet before barging down to the front when the group came on stage: "I jumped up onto the orchestra pit and unfurled a Mirror banner. Geri Halliwell said 'There's Matthew Wright!' and all of a sudden the BBC cameras got this Mirror banner and a silly man in a beard. It's a huge buzz. I was literally shaking like a leaf, as much with the humiliation of it as anything else. I'm no tough guy, but I've no shame. . ." Clearly not. But if the party was such fun, why wimp out now? Why is a man at the top of his profession, on the second-biggest daily newspaper in the country, taking the plunge in uncharted waters? "Lots of things really, lots of things coming together at the same time in my life. I've done 10 years in Fleet Street, I'm almost 35 and I looked around and asked myself what other jobs would I like to do on Fleet Street. There's only a certain amount of time you can do this or you just lose interest in it and become not so good at it. Four years is just about the right time, I think." Wright is passionate about the new venture - mykindaplace.com - and while he is aware of the risks, he believes there is a market to be exploited. "The research shows that teenage girls were heavily and increasingly reliant on the internet. That was the direction that age group was going. It just seemed like the obvious thing to do." (And if the website fails, there's always the book he's writing, and "other projects".) Wright has been brought in to oversee the editorial direction of the new website, which will be the usual teen mix of showbiz and lifestyle features. He will take charge of a team of journalists, mostly recruited from monthly magazines, and bring them up to speed with the disciplines of daily deadlines - it is anticipated that about 60% of the site will be updated daily. It is a risky venture for Wright. It is not going to be easy to persuade stars who see the tabloid press as the best vehicle to push their personalities to come around to the web way of thinking. And he doesn't believe that his name will help. "It's easy to assume that because you have a high-profile job on a successful newspaper that automatically opens doors for you. But from the start, when I was working with Piers here, it was very obvious that the PR strategy was single-minded and pointed towards Wapping. We decided that the best way to do it was independently of the PRs - to go out and self-generate, and that's what we've done for the past four and a half years. It's something that I'm used to doing, starting from scratch." The timing, too, is questionable: mykindaplace launches just as some high-profile content-heavy sites are just discovering that their revenue doesn't begin to justify their overheads. "I don't see that fear as pertinent to what we're doing. One of the most reassuring figures I've seen was that the teen magazine market is rapidly falling apart in terms of circulation, and I can't think of any other reason for that other than teenage girls are diversifying their interests. Why should they pay £1 or £2 for a magazine when they can get exactly the same information for free on the internet, and with a stronger interactive element?" After 10 years relentlessly pursuing the famous and infamous, Wright has a pretty good idea of who's doing what to whom. And he has formulated a pretty good idea of which celebrities he likes. "All the camp ones: Elton, Barrymore, Winton. Why is it that gay people are so in tune with showbiz? I know it's a generalisation, but they seem to have a lot more fun, they send themselves up more." That's what it's all about. "I've used the word 'camp' a lot here - but it's all just a bit of a send-up, a bit of a joke, isn't it?"

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst:
All today's rumours
Put into a haiku so
You don't waste your time
fields.trailText: Chelsea and Arsenal are after Nick Barmby. Everton are not prepared to meet Barmby's increased wage demands and will sell before the player becomes available on a Bosman free next summer.
fields.body:
Chelsea and Arsenal are after Nick Barmby. Everton are not prepared to meet Barmby's increased wage demands and will sell before the player becomes available on a Bosman free next summer.

Celtic are close to signing two strikers to replace Leeds-bound Mark Viduka. Martin O'Neill is poised to snatch Chris Sutton from under the noses of Middlesbrough with a £6m bid. Apparently Bryan Robson can offer the Chelsea misfit more money but the ex-Blackburn forward favours Parkhead. And the new Bhoys boss also wants West Ham's Paulo Wanchope.

Liverpool have offered Middlesbrough £5m for Christian Ziege.

Sunderland want to sign Czech Republic midfielder Radek Bejbl. The 27-year-old is not guaranteed a place in Atletico Madrid's starting eleven and would be available for £3m.

Rangers have denied making a £14m bid for Chelsea striker Tore Andre Flo. Chairman David Murray said: "There is no chance of Flo joining Rangers at the moment but we are confident of signing a striker before the start of the season."

Arsenal target Athirson, a wing-back for Brazilian club Flamengo, has tested positive for drugs. A potential move to Highbury is now off.

Australian right-back Andy McDermott, released on a free transfer by West Bromwich Albion, is close to completing a move to Juventus.

Derby striker Esteban Fuertes has joined Lens in a £4m deal. The 27-year-old Argentinian has been on loan at Colon Santa Fe since being refused re-entry to Britain because of problems with his passport and work permit. Fifa have decided that Derby will get the transfer fee - there had been a wrangle with Colon over who owned the player's contract.

fields.headline: Carve-up or cock-up?
fields.standfirst: Mathew Horsman  on a frenzy of misplaced greed, bad advice, complicated rules and dithering Premier League chairmen which turned a rights auction into a right farce.
fields.trailText: Mathew Horsman on a frenzy of misplaced greed, bad advice, complicated rules and dithering Premier League chairmen which turned a rights auction into a right farce.
fields.body:
The moment the Premier League decided, ill advisedly, to ask for sealed bids for the next round of television rights to broadcast top football, the die was cast. Far from the £2bn over three years promised in the incessant leaks to the national press in recent months, the 20 Premier League clubs will share just £1.6bn, barely above the most conservative of market expectations.

And talk about prune juice! Just how long would you expect the £1.6bn to stay with the clubs? Do I hear £15m to win the transfer rights to the next "big thing" from continental Europe?

Worse, BSkyB, the holders of the core pay-TV rights to top football since 1992, was expected to pay up big time, and did not. How much did Sky bid? A former senior Sky executive, asked to speculate as to the outcome, believed that the rights to the pay-TV live window would go for £1.7bn. When told the actual figure, he was astonished. "They [the Premier League] have given it away!" he said.

BSkyB, the winner of the key live rights to 66 matches, saw its shares soar by nearly 15% over two days, first on speculation that it would have to spend just £1.1bn over three years, a far cry from the Premier League's hopeful expectations, and then on the confirmation that, indeed, that is precisely what BSkyB would be paying for the biggest prize in UK sport. Yet again, Sky had got it right.

What went wrong? A mix of misplaced greed, bad external advice, complicated bidding rules and an overly sensitive board of Premier League chairmen worried about the potential for regulatory intervention combined to provide the biggest disappointment in sports rights since the bad old days of ITV-BBC duopoly control of major sport.

The bid for the renewal of Premier League rights was meant to be mega - fuelled by the value of content in the new media age. Football, everybody knows, drove the take-up of dishes and cable connections in the 1990s, and helped make multi-channel television a success. And there is no doubt that football is increasingly valuable.

In 1992, BSkyB bid £304m for five years' worth of live TV rights. "They will lose their shirts", thought one Greg Dyke, now director-general of the BBC and then on the losing side of the bidding war for top football at ITV. By 1996, the stakes had risen. Sky had to bid an amazing £670m, payable over four years, to secure an extension to its pay-TV rights, seeing off Carlton, Mirror Group and United News & Media.

This time, with the prospect of multiple platform revenues (enhanced TV, mobile, digital subscriber line, and the rest), the expectation was for a major uplift in the money flowing to top football. The auction attracted various bids from the great and good of British media: Sky, of course, and NTL, naturally. But also digital terrestrial broadcaster ONdigital (owned by Granada and Carlton), Telewest, Pearson, the BBC and ITV. An uplift there certainly was, but nothing like on the scale that the League chairmen had hoped.

The process looked flawed as soon as it was announced. The league chairmen decided to entertain sealed bids for each of three categories of rights - live, pay-per-view (PPV) and highlights. It was further decided that no single broadcaster would be allowed to win more than one category of rights. From the start, this created a problem.

The only reason to bid high for any content is to secure exclusivity. There is no point paying a premium for content if others can have access along with you, and so devalue your proposition. A bit of free advice for the Premier League on these matters: one, you always make more money if you put an exclusive offer on the table; two, you always make more money if you allow bidders to come back a second time; three, you always make more money if you hire advisers who understand points one and two.

There are reasons why the league and its advisers behaved the way they did. For a start, both ONdigital and NTL threatened to go to the regulators (here and in Brussels) in the event that BSkyB was able to extend its dominance of televised sport. As a consequence, the league wanted the process to be as fair, and as transparent, as possible.

At the same time, a string of media companies, including BSkyB and NTL, had been busy taking stakes in Premier League clubs, and there was a concern that undue pressure might be brought to bear on the bidding process. Better, therefore, to seal the bids.

It all played into BSkyB's hands. Sky was never going to bid over the odds, knowing, as it did, that only the dominant Premier League broadcaster (Sky, itself, of course) had already spent the money to create studios, hire staff, and develop a brand to bring top football to the nation. Any new entrant would start well back from the starting line.

More to the point, why pay huge amounts for the live rights, if someone else would get the pay-per-view matches, and possibly cannibalise your market? If PPV proved popular, wasn't there a chance that Sky Sports subscribers would simply cancel their accounts, knowing they could watch the odd match on PPV?

The approach of dividing up the rights gave Sky an edge, because it knew that no one else could steal all the matches on offer. The result? BSkyB low-balled the "live" rights, knowing that someone else - as it turns out cable company NTL - would get the PPV window.

Sky knew, too, that satellite homes, inevitably, would be offered the PPV service. There are only two commercial rules about PPV. It is all about the number of potential customers, and the number of these who buy the service. No PPV operator would risk losing access to the 4m homes in the UK currently receiving their digital television via Sky dishes. A PPV operator needs as many potential customers as possible, since so few, traditionally, actually purchase. (We won't even speculate as to whether the parties actually held discussions about tactics before tabling their bids. Yes, it is true, executives from NTL were seen entering the forbidding doors of Sky's headquarters in Isleworth in recent weeks. Don't go there.)

Perversely, the real loser here, other than the short-changed Premier League, is NTL (so any carve-up scenario looks distinctly ropey - unless, of course, you subscribe to the "double cross" school of history). The hapless cable operator, struggling to introduce a digital service when its rival Telewest is already well advanced, bid a whopping £328m in guaranteed revenues for pay-per- view football. This is a market that has no pedigree in this country. It is a market that requires the widest possible distribution. It is a market that would benefit hugely from cross-promotion from a terrestrial broadcaster. BSkyB got its 66 live games at a level at least 45% below the top expectation of £2bn. NTL, by contrast, has paid £328m - upward of 30% over the odds (the top forecast for PPV was £300m) for an unproven market.

Assuming NTL charges £4.99 per match, for each of 40 matches a year, it has to persuade fully 6% of all multi-channel homes in the country to buy all the matches (or 12% to buy half the matches, or 24% to buy a quarter of the matches, etc.) to break even. On the basis of the US experience, this a tall order. I, for one, think they have over-paid.

And what of the BBC? No more Match of the Day? Scandal! No Football League either? (That went to ITV and ONdigital, for a huge £315m). Atrocious!

In fact, the BBC did precisely the right thing by letting ITV win the highlight rights and letting ITV and ONdigital pay over the odds for the Nationwide matches. The idea of paying £183m over three years for highlights and a share of £315m for Football League rights would never have been acceptable in the context of a BBC already worried about its sources of funding. This is a corporation aware of its tenuous position, as one director-general exits, and another takes his place.

Talk about a rock and a hard place! Had the BBC beaten ITV, there would have been whingeing editorials in the better national newspapers about the profligacy of the stewards of public service television. (As it is, the BBC is instead pilloried for having lost yet another sport fixture.) Well done, BBC, for securing instead rights to the FA Cup matches.

The Premier League and Nationwide rights arrangement is now set for another three years. Sky, yet again, is in the driving seat, and NTL has bitten off (probably) far more than it can chew. ITV is back into top league football. Does it all matter? Yes.

The future of multi-channel TV is probably as much about home shopping, online information and computer games as it is about Coronation Street or EastEnders. About 20% of us are logging on to the internet every day. Another significant minority never watch network television. But whatever else you say, football still rules. OK.

 Mathew Horsman is a media analyst at the City firm of Investec Henderson Crosthwaite. The firm has done work for many of the companies mentioned in this article but did not work on any of the football bids.
