fields.headline: Jules Roy
fields.standfirst: The historian of France's adventures in Algeria, critic of the French establishment and of the bombing of the Ruhr
fields.trailText: The life of Jules Roy, who has died aged 92, was full of contradictions. Though he studied for the priesthood for five years, he became a soldier, and then a pilot.
fields.body:
The life of Jules Roy, who has died aged 92, was full of contradictions. Though he studied for the priesthood for five years, he became a soldier, and then a pilot.

He adored the voluptuousness of being swept away and absorbed by events: in 1940 he was a Pétainist, and hated the English, who had attacked the French fleet. Then in 1942, he came to England and joined the RAF. After taking part in the bombing raids on the Ruhr, he concluded that such raids were wrong. And he collaborated with those who produced a Free French publication in London that was critical of General De Gaulle.

After the war he volunteered to serve with the French army in Indo-China, where he held the rank of colonel. But after the French defeat at Dien Bien Phu, he angrily blamed the French generals and administration.

However, Roy was not famous for his military life, but as a writer: the author of some 60 volumes - novels, essays, plays, pamphlets, film and television scripts. In 1989 he published his Mémoires barbares (Harsh Recollections) and most recently three volumes of his Journal, covering the years 1925 to 1996.

The last of these volumes concludes on February 21 1996, with the old soldier in his retirement at Vézelay, in Burgundy. Earlier volumes explained how he had deliberately taken himself away from the literary murmurs of Paris and sought to find somewhere to live, ending up either with farms that were too big or with chateaux that he found depressing. He was helped by Sonia (whom he married in 1965; with his divorced first wife, Mirande, he had had a son and daughter), but they grew desperate as his income from published work declined. Eventually they settled for Vézelay and its beautiful abbey.

Here he was at his best as a writer. In Paris he was far too preoccupied with complaining about his own literary reputation. He tried very hard to get elected to the Academy (although as a young man he had stood by the Quai de Conti with his fellow Algerian Albert Camus, and had sworn he would never seek admission to that place); invited to dinner at the Elysée Palace, he sat next to an author who had just sold 500,000 copies of her latest work. But in Vézelay he looked after an old donkey, called Ulysses, fed upon bread and carrots.

In the Algerian war - and Jules Roy was one of those writers who popularised the term (the officials not wishing to accept that it was a war) - he was on the side of the Algerians. Born in the village of Rovigo in Algeria, where the plain of the Mitidja encounters the Atlas Mountains, he did not go to Algiers until he was 11, first to the lycée , and then at the age of 20 to the seminary.

When he looked back on his youth, he saw how few Algerians attended the lycée , and how little preoccupation the seminarists had with the religion of Islam. His mother spoke of the beauty of the country, but said how much more beautiful it would be if there were no Arabs present. A distant cousin married a young Algerian in 1930. For the next 10 years she ceased to exist as far as Roy's family were concerned. He did not admire the French in Algeria, remembering them as ignorant and too given to consuming anisette .

The smaller settlers were more sympathetic, but although they talked about France and the French Revolution, they never thought of applying the principles of liberty, equality and fraternity in the world around them. Although his mother spoke a sort of Arabic, no one was obliged to do so. It was for the Arabs to learn French.

So Jules Roy welcomed the independence of the country where he was born. But, since he was Jules Roy, that was far from being the end of the story. He returned to Algeria and went to visit his mother's grave. He could not find it. Someone had raided the cemetery. The tomb of his mother had disappeared, like the trees in the plain of the Mitidja.

His most successful novel, La Vallée heureuse (Happy Valley), describes his experiences in the Halifax bomber attacking the Ruhr in 39 raids. For publishing this work, he was punished by the French air force authorities, who gave him 14 days' detention. But in 1946 the novel won the Renaudot Prize.

Another book that aroused a scandal dealt with the profession of carrying arms - Le Métier des armes (1948). He insisted that soldiers would continue to fight for a cause, such as liberty, but would no longer fight for a general, for a politician, or for an arms manufacturer. In 1968 he published the first volume of a long series describing the history of France in Algeria which was successfully adapted for television.

He was a man of great charm, and it was natural that in old age he should be referred to by the imperial name of Julius.

He was always somebody who asked questions - among the last of those questions was whether he had been a good Christian. Perhaps not, was his answer. But, came the next question, was St Peter a good Christian?

 Jules Roy, soldier, pilot, author, born October 22 1907; died June 15 2000

He adored the voluptuousness of being swept away and absorbed by events: in 1940 he was a Pétainist, and hated the English, who had attacked the French fleet. Then in 1942, he came to England and joined the RAF. After taking part in the bombing raids on the Ruhr, he concluded that such raids were wrong. And he collaborated with those who produced a Free French publication in London that was critical of General De Gaulle. After the war he volunteered to serve with the French army in Indo-China, where he held the rank of colonel. But after the French defeat at Dien Bien Phu, he angrily blamed the French generals and administration. However, Roy was not famous for his military life, but as a writer: the author of some 60 volumes - novels, essays, plays, pamphlets, film and television scripts. In 1989 he published his Mémoires barbares (Harsh Recollections) and most recently three volumes of his Journal, covering the years 1925 to 1996. The last of these volumes concludes on February 21 1996, with the old soldier in his retirement at Vézelay, in Burgundy. Earlier volumes explained how he had deliberately taken himself away from the literary murmurs of Paris and sought to find somewhere to live, ending up either with farms that were too big or with chateaux that he found depressing. He was helped by Sonia (whom he married in 1965; with his divorced first wife, Mirande, he had had a son and daughter), but they grew desperate as his income from published work declined. Eventually they settled for Vézelay and its beautiful abbey. Here he was at his best as a writer. In Paris he was far too preoccupied with complaining about his own literary reputation. He tried very hard to get elected to the Academy (although as a young man he had stood by the Quai de Conti with his fellow Algerian Albert Camus, and had sworn he would never seek admission to that place); invited to dinner at the Elysée Palace, he sat next to an author who had just sold 500,000 copies of her latest work. But in Vézelay he looked after an old donkey, called Ulysses, fed upon bread and carrots. In the Algerian war - and Jules Roy was one of those writers who popularised the term (the officials not wishing to accept that it was a war) - he was on the side of the Algerians. Born in the village of Rovigo in Algeria, where the plain of the Mitidja encounters the Atlas Mountains, he did not go to Algiers until he was 11, first to the lycée , and then at the age of 20 to the seminary. When he looked back on his youth, he saw how few Algerians attended the lycée , and how little preoccupation the seminarists had with the religion of Islam. His mother spoke of the beauty of the country, but said how much more beautiful it would be if there were no Arabs present. A distant cousin married a young Algerian in 1930. For the next 10 years she ceased to exist as far as Roy's family were concerned. He did not admire the French in Algeria, remembering them as ignorant and too given to consuming anisette . The smaller settlers were more sympathetic, but although they talked about France and the French Revolution, they never thought of applying the principles of liberty, equality and fraternity in the world around them. Although his mother spoke a sort of Arabic, no one was obliged to do so. It was for the Arabs to learn French. So Jules Roy welcomed the independence of the country where he was born. But, since he was Jules Roy, that was far from being the end of the story. He returned to Algeria and went to visit his mother's grave. He could not find it. Someone had raided the cemetery. The tomb of his mother had disappeared, like the trees in the plain of the Mitidja. His most successful novel, La Vallée heureuse (Happy Valley), describes his experiences in the Halifax bomber attacking the Ruhr in 39 raids. For publishing this work, he was punished by the French air force authorities, who gave him 14 days' detention. But in 1946 the novel won the Renaudot Prize. Another book that aroused a scandal dealt with the profession of carrying arms - Le Métier des armes (1948). He insisted that soldiers would continue to fight for a cause, such as liberty, but would no longer fight for a general, for a politician, or for an arms manufacturer. In 1968 he published the first volume of a long series describing the history of France in Algeria which was successfully adapted for television. He was a man of great charm, and it was natural that in old age he should be referred to by the imperial name of Julius. He was always somebody who asked questions - among the last of those questions was whether he had been a good Christian. Perhaps not, was his answer. But, came the next question, was St Peter a good Christian?  Jules Roy, soldier, pilot, author, born October 22 1907; died June 15 2000

fields.headline: Diana Ross
fields.standfirst: From the Little Red Engine chuffing out of Taddlecombe junction to Candlewick Green: a life of writing and illustrating for children
fields.trailText: Diana Ross, who has died aged 89, was a children's writer and illustrator best known for her stories about the Little Red Engine.
fields.body:
Diana Ross, who has died aged 89, was a children's writer and illustrator best known for her stories about the Little Red Engine.

She was born in Valletta, Malta, where her father was in command of HMS Diana. She attended schools in Stratford-on-Avon, Oxford, Paris and then Kensington High School for Girls, and read history at Girton College, Cambridge.

In 1932, she went to Newfoundland - her paternal great-grandfather had been a Canadian prime minister, while her mother's cousin, Sir Wilfrid Grenfell, had been a missionary in Labrador. In Sir Wilfrid's footsteps, she worked for six months as a volunteer with the children of the Grenfell Mission Orphanage. On her return home, she went to the Central School of Art in London, then spent five years teaching art. At this time her writing began to develop, and provided her with connections with the publishing world.

While her husband, the designer and photographer Anthony Denney (they married in 1940 and were divorced 10 years later), was in India early in the second world war, Diana lived with her sister Elizabeth's family at Speen, near Newbury.

While working out stories to entertain a nephew, she began to combine the nearby Lambourne branch railway line with a little, already old-fashioned, tin toy engine. The Little Red Engine Gets a Name was published by Faber in 1942 with illustrations by Polish artists Jan Lewitt and George Him. The tale begins with the engine forlornly yearning for a chance to venture further afield than the Taddlecombe junction line and to be known by a name instead of merely as a number.

In the same year, Ross wrote a delightful story in which a variety of garments are wind-whisked into a tumult and chased by a number of eccentric characters into a twisted tumbling climax. A marvellous match of pictures (the illustrator was Leslie Wood) and words, the book, Whoo, Whoo The Wind Blew, was not published until 1946 because of paper shortages.

The second engine book, The Story of the Little Red Engine, also had a delayed publication; the original illustrators declined an invitation to provide the pictures, so Leslie Wood was the obvious alternative choice. That perfect author-illustrator partnership was to continue for a further eight books until 1971, and The Little Red Engine Goes Carolling. Last year, three of the series appeared in splendid, vibrant, new editions published by André Deutsch.

The skill in her writing for young children lies in devices that incorporate repetition and also generate a sense of anticipation. She understood that her readers, and those who listened to her stories, loved the possibility of danger - if seen from a safe place.

There was also a far more complex sequence of stories, over five books, featuring an impish human-ape, Jackanapes, akin to a folklore character, and Miss Pussy, who metamorphoses from a feline original. The best of the stories are a triumph, with a precise montage of incidental detail to draw in the reader. The illustrators for these books included Ross herself, using the pseudonym Gri, for the first, The Golden Hen (1942), and Shirley Hughes in the last of the series, the Merry Go Round (1963).

A number of her stories were commissioned by the BBC for Listen with Mother and other radio broadcasts, from the wartime years onwards. Some then found their way into print in anthologies or as picture books. This fruitful connection continued until the late 60s, when she contributed stories for the BBC's Playschool, and was a consultant during the development of Candlewick Green for children's television.

After the war, she became an admirer of Bertrand Russell and an active marching CND supporter. She was also an early campaigner against the increasing use of pesticides, and wrote letters expressing concerns about probable long-term effects on the environment.

Ross loved animals, and in a talk for children on Australian radio in 1956, the family's current five cats and one elderly dog were described. For 40 years, she made a home at Melksham, Wiltshire, where painting, sculpture and pottery were constant occupations.

Whistling is a sure sign of inner contentment, and Diana was a virtuoso whistler capable of challenging the garden blackbirds. Echoes of all of her attributes can be found throughout her stories: naturally, the Little Red Engine can whistle, and it does so both knowingly and with joy.

She is survived by the children of her marriage, twin daughters and a son.

webTitle: Keegan and Shearer go on the attack

fields.headline: Keegan and Shearer go on the attack
fields.standfirst:
Euro 2000 special report
David Lacey: England near lift-off
fields.trailText: Shearer's strike ratio is one reason Keegan loves him, but there are surely others, and not all of them can be put into words.
fields.body:
As Kevin Keegan said yesterday, it looked a simple finish. But when David Beckham's free-kick bounced near the German penalty spot and sat up in front of Alan Shearer, there was still work to be done.

"An inexperienced forward might have snatched at it," Keegan said. "He might not have been able to get the timing and the power on it that it needed, because there was very little pace on the ball when it came to him." But Shearer launched himself into a flying leap, flexed his neck muscles and used his forehead to drive the ball across Oliver Kahn and into the net to deliver England their first senior tournament victory over Germany since 1966.

It was enough to win Shearer the headlines, too, and the official man-of-the-match award, and Keegan came into the after-match press conference practically bursting with told-you-so pleasure in the performance of his talismanic centre-forward.

"Alan Shearer has answered his critics again," the coach proclaimed, "so just give him two or three days' rest before you start back at him. He's never given me anything other than a hundred per cent when he's put on that shirt. He's a man among men, and that's why he's the captain of my England side."

Shearer, too, felt he had rebutted the criticism of recent weeks, including an internet poll purporting to prove that three-quarters of the nation's football fans wanted him out.

"Tonight the fans gave me the same reception that they've given me in every England game," he said. "It's only certain people in the press who want me out, but I can handle that. I don't really care, to be honest."

And yet Shearer's performance during the first half of the match in the Stade Communale on Saturday night had provided nothing but further ammunition for those who believe that, despite the unassailable achievements of his career, at 29 he is no longer a deserving candidate for automatic selection. While England were struggling to get the ball away from the Germans, Shearer looked a sluggish and peripheral figure. It was his fellow striker, Michael Owen, with whom he has yet to forge even the faintest semblance of a true partnership, who ignited the fires of English resistance 10 minutes before half-time, when his header forced Kahn to tip the ball on to a post.

But it was Shearer who scored the goal and Owen who was subsequently taken off when the team's resistance needed stiffening. Shearer has now started and finished every one of the 12 matches of Keegan's Euro 2000 campaign, and this was his seventh goal. His strike ratio is one reason Keegan loves him, but there are surely others, and not all of them can be put into words.

When Keegan tried to explain it yesterday, he ended up describing his regret at Shearer's decision, announced in February, to leave the international scene at the end of the present tournament. The coach blames the media. "You can't keep picking him up and throwing him down," he said. "I think that's what you've done. You put him up there and the minute he's gone just a little bit below par, because he hasn't scored a goal, you've kicked him around. It's taken its toll on him. But I've never discussed it with him, and please don't say that I have because it would make him sound like a whinger, and I don't think he's that. I think he's a real man, and he's a leader, and he showed it again last night. I don't think there's another Alan Shearer in England at the moment."

And yet, despite expressing his sorrow in the clearest terms, Keegan declined in somewhat mystifying terms an invitation to say that he would do the obvious by asking Shearer to change his mind. "Alan is his own man," he declared. "I've never discussed it with him. I've not talked to him [about it] today and I won't talk to him tomorrow. He knows without me talking to him. I was very disappointed when he announced it. I said to him, 'Think about it long and hard.' He said, 'I've been thinking about it for six or seven months.' So I don't think he'll change his mind. He's the sort of guy who makes up his mind and that's it. But if he did, I for one would be delighted. And so would the players."

Naturally enough, Keegan doesn't like being told by any player that he is not available for international duty. "I don't want anyone to say that they don't want to play for England again, and that includes some of the players, like Paul Merson, who have. I'm very disappointed with that. I still think Alan's got something to offer. If you're honest with yourself, despite some of the fantastic alternatives we've got, if you were in my position, then you'd probably plump for him just like I do, because you know what you're going to get from him. It's for the others to force their way in."

It was Keegan who paid £15m to take Shearer from Blackburn Rovers to Newcastle United in 1996. "I don't care what people think as long as the people around me believe in me," Shearer said, as calm as ever in the euphoric aftermath of victory, and few can ever have believed in him with as much fervour as the England coach. Nevertheless Keegan sounded resigned to entering the 2002 World Cup campaign with a different player in the No9 shirt that Shearer has occupied on 60 occasions.

"He made his decision and he announced it in the way he wanted," Keegan said. "I don't know what he's thinking. I suppose the best way for him to finish would be to pick up that Euro 2000 trophy. That's a dream at the moment, and it's our job to make it a reality for him. It's his job, too, and he can have a major part in it, as he showed last night.

"It would be going out in style for him. It's what he wants, the players and the staff desperately want it to happen, and certainly it's what the fans want. And then I guess he'll close the book, and that will be a nice way to end it."

webTitle: Football's coming home, whatever that may be

fields.headline: Football's coming home, whatever that may be
fields.standfirst:
If our team defines our national identity, we're in trouble
Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: If our team defines our national identity, we're in trouble
fields.body:
As we turned out of a dark, obscure side street on Saturday evening, Islington Green was suddenly a blaze of carnival. Hundreds upon hundreds milling in raucous hilarity: dancing and singing as though at some giant open-air disco. Blue lighting effects and siren wails by the Metropolitan police. A night to remember through a haze of booze? Of course. England had - just - beaten Germany. It was another of those "national events" that Islington's most famous ex-resident thinks defines us as a community.

"I don't usually watch football, but - " said the girl at the party. That "but" is archetypal. It signals one of those very occasional moments when all our citizens feel summoned by hype and conditioning to express a common emotion. Millennium eve at the dome didn't manage that. The death of Diana probably did. But soccer knows where the magic button is hidden. An amazing power, if not an amazing grace.

Consider the dominating crisis of the last few days - which had nothing to do with Brown, Cook and euro mysticism. The BBC lost Match of the Day. Where, rationally, was the story there? It wasn't much of a crowd-puller any longer, just a tired old highlights show shunted back and forth in the schedules. Now we, the punters, would get it much earlier on ITV, fronted by Des Lynam (who quit Wood Lane in boredom and disgust). Good deal: bad deal? Who cares?

Yet the potency of the symbolism abruptly shifts other levers. National broadcaster abandons national game in Greg Dyke's greatest humiliation. The portent quite outweighs the reality - or, rather, reveals that football has developed a reality of its own, a weird blend of legend, patriotism and brute cash. It lives and burgeons now as a substitute for war.

No coincidences. As the cold war ended and the wall came down, Rupert Murdoch shrewdly made football the panzer division of satellite TV and every newspaper in the land began to add pages of sports coverage by the tonne as foreign news retreated. If you look back to the supposed glory days of World Cup victory, you'd be surprised by the vestigiality of the coverage. We may have been interested before: but never - inexhaustibly, irredeemably - so interested.

Of course there were echoes of war about 1966. How could there not be? But even then the heroes mostly had to make do with cheers and petty pay packets. It was Tony Blair, only a few months back, who set about giving all the old team their gongs, their battle medals for gallantry. Retrospective deification.

The new warfare, moreover, oozes historical resonance. It is a matter of country, to be sure: but country is not enough week after week. We're back through centuries to the old Europe of city states where Milan, Florence and Rome fought for regional dominance and - crucially - paid mercenary armies to help them achieve it. Hire some Prussians or some Poles? Look at football.

Italy, home of the city state, began it for us (hiring Greaves, Charles and Platt). The greatest and would-be greatest sides in Europe now depend on it. When you see Holland play in this tournament, you effectively watch Barcelona. The Dutch, for the past couple of years, have mouthed their praises and their excuses in a lumpen Catalan. The big teams of Spain - a country of ancient kingdoms - are mercenary to their core, a collection of Argentinians and Brazilians come for their pay days, purchased for something more than mere success.

And Britain? What are we, but belated leaders of this pack? The managers are French, Italian, Norwegian. Chelsea is Saturday afternoon at the Berlitz school. Man U doesn't like the Australian goalkeeper it bought to replace its towering Dane and tries a bald Frenchmen instead. (I can remember the time when French goalkeepers used to be a joke like Scottish goalkeepers: but now the joke's on us). Watch Euro 2000 and, intrinsically, you watch how the Premier League's passing the summer.

There are two ironies here. One is crude and political. For what do we Brits see afternoon upon afternoon, as the locker-room door opens, but lines of economic migrants - Romanians, Africans, Yugoslavs - come to take our money and our grateful applause? The other tugs in the opposite direction. Put on a national shirt and our everyday heroes are suddenly enemies again. The north-east fan who claps Ziege when he runs down David Beckham in a league match is supposed to jeer him when he does the same in German colours. Adulation and vilification only a change of shirt apart.

This, in sum, is a deeply confusing war. The game of symbolism deals inexorably in symbols. The players on the park are pawns, performing to fit our preconceptions. Defeated managers are disgraced generals. (Exit Van Gaal at Barca). Defeated teams are sold back to where they came from or dispatched to the knacker's yard. And yet we also look to it as some kind of definition of our nationhood.

That, in footballing logic, must be crazy. The millions which television already heaps upon the Premier League - plus the millions more of Dyke's debacle - go and will keep going as wages to the established stars, not to our own grassroots. Those lie untended as the trickle-down effect floods overseas - guaranteeing, if you will, an ultimate lack of success. Two midfield ex-dynamos heading into their middle 30s are all we have left. But there is also a malign lack of wider logic.

The other headlines from Charleroi yesterday were, as dismally expected, about riots, arrests by the hundred, foul brutality as usual. Our lately departed minister of sport, a former scion of the left, could be heard telling David Frost how much he admired the German police's new tactic of knocking doors at night and taking passports away. Civil liberties wilt before the wonder of the game. Justice is winning the World Cup in 2006.

I couldn't help, as I heard him, thinking about a film I saw the other day. It is called Brothers and it will, the posters say, be at "cinemas everywhere" this week. Five laddish lads go to Paros for a week and, in the spirit of Ibiza/Greece Uncovered, drink and dope and defecate and shag their time away. Kevin and Perry gone larger. And they could all of them - every one - have jetted straight in from Brussels. Not isolated cuckoos in their generational nest, not a supposed few for pious vilification, but the general stuff of mass entertainment.

Football's coming home: but what is home? Football is the instant definer of national identity: but what's the definition? Football, with its cash and cynicism and melee of glib loyalties and paper allegiances, is Us. But what, as the crates of lager are readied for tomorrow, does it say about us?

Millennium eve at the dome didn't manage that. The death of Diana probably did. But soccer knows where the magic button is hidden. An amazing power, if not an amazing grace. Consider the dominating crisis of the last few days - which had nothing to do with Brown, Cook and euro mysticism. The BBC lost Match of the Day. Where, rationally, was the story there? It wasn't much of a crowd-puller any longer, just a tired old highlights show shunted back and forth in the schedules. Now we, the punters, would get it much earlier on ITV, fronted by Des Lynam (who quit Wood Lane in boredom and disgust). Good deal: bad deal? Who cares? Yet the potency of the symbolism abruptly shifts other levers. National broadcaster abandons national game in Greg Dyke's greatest humiliation. The portent quite outweighs the reality - or, rather, reveals that football has developed a reality of its own, a weird blend of legend, patriotism and brute cash. It lives and burgeons now as a substitute for war. No coincidences. As the cold war ended and the wall came down, Rupert Murdoch shrewdly made football the panzer division of satellite TV and every newspaper in the land began to add pages of sports coverage by the tonne as foreign news retreated. If you look back to the supposed glory days of World Cup victory, you'd be surprised by the vestigiality of the coverage. We may have been interested before: but never - inexhaustibly, irredeemably - so interested. Of course there were echoes of war about 1966. How could there not be? But even then the heroes mostly had to make do with cheers and petty pay packets. It was Tony Blair, only a few months back, who set about giving all the old team their gongs, their battle medals for gallantry. Retrospective deification. The new warfare, moreover, oozes historical resonance. It is a matter of country, to be sure: but country is not enough week after week. We're back through centuries to the old Europe of city states where Milan, Florence and Rome fought for regional dominance and - crucially - paid mercenary armies to help them achieve it. Hire some Prussians or some Poles? Look at football. Italy, home of the city state, began it for us (hiring Greaves, Charles and Platt). The greatest and would-be greatest sides in Europe now depend on it. When you see Holland play in this tournament, you effectively watch Barcelona. The Dutch, for the past couple of years, have mouthed their praises and their excuses in a lumpen Catalan. The big teams of Spain - a country of ancient kingdoms - are mercenary to their core, a collection of Argentinians and Brazilians come for their pay days, purchased for something more than mere success. And Britain? What are we, but belated leaders of this pack? The managers are French, Italian, Norwegian. Chelsea is Saturday afternoon at the Berlitz school. Man U doesn't like the Australian goalkeeper it bought to replace its towering Dane and tries a bald Frenchmen instead. (I can remember the time when French goalkeepers used to be a joke like Scottish goalkeepers: but now the joke's on us). Watch Euro 2000 and, intrinsically, you watch how the Premier League's passing the summer. There are two ironies here. One is crude and political. For what do we Brits see afternoon upon afternoon, as the locker-room door opens, but lines of economic migrants - Romanians, Africans, Yugoslavs - come to take our money and our grateful applause? The other tugs in the opposite direction. Put on a national shirt and our everyday heroes are suddenly enemies again. The north-east fan who claps Ziege when he runs down David Beckham in a league match is supposed to jeer him when he does the same in German colours. Adulation and vilification only a change of shirt apart. This, in sum, is a deeply confusing war. The game of symbolism deals inexorably in symbols. The players on the park are pawns, performing to fit our preconceptions. Defeated managers are disgraced generals. (Exit Van Gaal at Barca). Defeated teams are sold back to where they came from or dispatched to the knacker's yard. And yet we also look to it as some kind of definition of our nationhood. That, in footballing logic, must be crazy. The millions which television already heaps upon the Premier League - plus the millions more of Dyke's debacle - go and will keep going as wages to the established stars, not to our own grassroots. Those lie untended as the trickle-down effect floods overseas - guaranteeing, if you will, an ultimate lack of success. Two midfield ex-dynamos heading into their middle 30s are all we have left. But there is also a malign lack of wider logic. The other headlines from Charleroi yesterday were, as dismally expected, about riots, arrests by the hundred, foul brutality as usual. Our lately departed minister of sport, a former scion of the left, could be heard telling David Frost how much he admired the German police's new tactic of knocking doors at night and taking passports away. Civil liberties wilt before the wonder of the game. Justice is winning the World Cup in 2006. I couldn't help, as I heard him, thinking about a film I saw the other day. It is called Brothers and it will, the posters say, be at "cinemas everywhere" this week. Five laddish lads go to Paros for a week and, in the spirit of Ibiza/Greece Uncovered, drink and dope and defecate and shag their time away. Kevin and Perry gone larger. And they could all of them - every one - have jetted straight in from Brussels. Not isolated cuckoos in their generational nest, not a supposed few for pious vilification, but the general stuff of mass entertainment. Football's coming home: but what is home? Football is the instant definer of national identity: but what's the definition? Football, with its cash and cynicism and melee of glib loyalties and paper allegiances, is Us. But what, as the crates of lager are readied for tomorrow, does it say about us? peter.preston@theguardian.com Useful links Euro 2000 Official site Football violence: special report Football Association National Criminal Intelligence Service

webTitle: Post Office makes first loss for 24 years

fields.headline: Post Office makes first loss for 24 years
fields.trailText: The Post Office has made its first after-tax loss for 24 years, it was announced today.
fields.body:
The Post Office has made its first after-tax loss for 24 years, it was announced today.

The organisation reported post-tax losses of £264m for the last financial year, almost exclusively because of government plans to pay benefits directly into bank accounts from 2003.

It has "written down" £571m of assets as part of a project to computerise its network of more than 18,500 post offices.

It said it could not see how it could justify such a large investment because sufficient new earnings could not be generated to replace the lost income.

Benefit payments account for around one third of income for post offices and many sub-post masters have warned of a wave of closures, especially in rural areas, because of the loss of benefit payments business.

Profit before tax was £474m - down by 13% on the previous year. This was mainly because the Post Office froze or reduced postage prices over the last financial year.

The Post Office said its turnover was up by 7% last year to £7,522m, which its chairman, Neville Bain, said was a "creditable performance" in difficult trading conditions and with increasing competition.

He said the reduction in underlying profits was not unexpected and was reflected in government targets for the year.

The Post Office chief executive, John Roberts, said the loss was a "blow", but predicted that the organisation would be back in profit next year.

He described today's loss as a "blip" but expected profits of between £200m and £300m next year.

Mr Roberts stressed that the losses would be covered by the Post Office and would not lead to stamp price increases, office closures or job cuts.

"It is a one-off. We are trading very profitably but we have to write down these assets."

Almost 8,000 post offices have already been automated under the so-called Horizon project and 300 more are being equipped each week.

webTitle: Warring ministers forced into show of unity by Blair

fields.headline: Warring ministers forced into show of unity by Blair
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair last night reasserted his authority over feuding cabinet colleagues when he insisted that they were all behind the government's wait-and-see policy on the European single currency - and will remain so until the next general election.
fields.byline: Michael White  and  Ian Black  in Santa Maria  da Feira and Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Tony Blair last night reasserted his authority over feuding cabinet colleagues when he insisted that they were all behind the government's wait-and-see policy on the European single currency - and will remain so until the next general election.

In a determined display of unity after a week of near-public feuding over tactics for the promised referendum on British euro-membership, the prime minister insisted that the chancellor, Gordon Brown, join him and Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, on last night's flight to the EU's summer summit in Portugal. Mr Brown had intended to fly out on a later flight.

The trio used the opportunity to discuss the summit agenda, the Downing Street spokesman said in Feira last night, not what he dismissed as "a total spin fest" by the British media about cabinet feuds.

But he did implicitly concede that Labour MPs and advisers may have fuelled the flames of disagreement over Mr Cook's "edited" speech to the Commons.

Accusing hostile newspapers of trying to recreate the same divisions which tore John Major's cabinet apart, Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, insisted that there was not a word you could point to uttered by a senior minister that contravened the policy set out by Mr Brown in October 1997. "The people who matter in this government are the ministers and they do share the policy and they do speak with one voice about it." Mr Campbell dismissed press coverage as "more suited to the coverage of a soap opera".

Despite Downing Street's denials, there was little doubt about the mutual personal bitterness between senior ministers on the chancellor's refusal to countenance wider discussion of the merits of the euro.

But John Prescott yesterday insisted the prime minister should allow a debate to flow within government. The deputy prime minister said the entire cabinet, and not just the chancellor, must decide if Britain is ready to join the single currency. Mr Prescott insisted he was supportive of the chancellor's stance on the euro, but added "there will be a debate about some of these conditions as they change".

He added: "You have got to have debate and discussions within the cabinet," stressing repeatedly that it would be the cabinet that would make the decision on whether to recom mend British entry into the euro, prior to putting the decision to a referendum.

Mr Prescott's intervention on BBC TV's On The Record, is designed to warn the chancellor not to try and suppress debate within cabinet over divisions over tactics.

In his Mansion House speech last week, Mr Brown appeared to take sole charge of the policy insisting the Treasury was the guardian of the policy. Prior to the chancellor's speech the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, at the behest of Downing Street and the chancellor was forced to strike out passages from his Commons speech on Europe deemed to be too favourable to the Euro.

There is also concern among some pro-European Labour MPs that the chancellor intends to contract out the decision on whether the economic tests have been met to the Bank of England. The proposal was made at the weekend by Bill Morris, the Transport and General Workers Union general secretary and an ally of Mr Brown's.

The proposal would have the merit of depoliticising the judgment on whether the British and European economies were enjoying sustained or temporary convergence, a judgment a second term Labour government would have to take within a year of its re-election if Britain was to have any chance of completing sterling's link-up with the euro in time for the following election. However, Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England is a known sceptic on the single currency.

If the judgment on the economic tests was passed to the Bank of England, pro-Europeans fear Britain would never join the currency since the caution of the Bank would always lead to the conclusion that insufficient evidence is available as to whether the convergence is sustained or temporary. As Mr Blair and Mr Cook joined EU socialist leaders for their ritual pre-summit dinner, Mr Brown was locked into negotiations on the "withholding tax" on savings with the Portuguese hosts seeking to break the impasse.

Downing Street also believes it can head off a controversial new charter of rights - but sees no need yet to change tack on another controversial policy, the sanctions against Austria over the far-right Freedom party.

Mr Blair and Mr Cook will also be seeing their Greek counterparts to "maintain momentum of the police investigation" of the murder in Athens of British diplomat, Stephen Saunders.

webTitle: Tolkien epic is lord of the net

fields.headline: Tolkien epic is lord of the net
fields.trailText: The film version of JRR Tolkien's fantasy trilogy the Lord of the Rings may still be more than a year and a half away but the $200m (£137m) epic has already caused a storm on the internet, with a promotional trailer breaking download records.
fields.body:
The film version of JRR Tolkien's fantasy trilogy the Lord of the Rings may still be more than a year and a half away but the $200m (£137m) epic has already caused a storm on the internet, with a promotional trailer breaking download records.

More than 1.7m web users worldwide down loaded the trailer for the trilogy of films on the first day it was available, doubling the amount of hits for Star Wars Episode 1: The Phantom Menance, which previously held the record.

The Fellowship of the Ring is due to be released in December 2001, with the second instalment, The Twin Towers, arriving in cinemas in 2002, to be followed 12 months later by the final part, The Return of the King.

The cast includes the American Elijah Wood, who plays Frodo Baggins, Sir Ian McKellen as the wizard Gandalf, Sean Bean as Boromir and Ian Holm as Bilbo Baggins.

The films, which are in production in New Zealand, have also spawned a plethora of fan related sites, many of them containing photos and reports from the set. Local papers have also carried numerous interviews with residents who have been employed on the films, while the Wellington Knitting Club has provided armour for 15,000 extras.

But while many Tolkien fans are gobbling up every nugget of information about the adaptation, not all are happy with the direction in which the films appear to be going.

Peter Jackson, the director, has brought in Liv Tyler and Cate Blanchett to play Arwen and Galadriel, minor roles in the book but enlarged in the screenplay, to add a bit of love interest to the story. The decision to increase female participation in the movie has been defended by the film's executives, who claim it is the best way to heighten and simplify the drama.

It is not the first time film makers have tried to bring the Lord of the Rings to the screen. The Beatles were desperate to do a movie of the book, with Paul playing Frodo, Ringo as Sam, John as Gollum and George as Gandalf, but the rights were bought up for what became Ralph Bakshi's disastrous 70s cartoon version, which ended halfway through the story when the producers ran out of money.

webTitle: Death threats sent to Nick Brown over badger cull

fields.headline: Death threats sent to Nick Brown over badger cull
fields.trailText: Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has received death threats from animal rights activists in protest at the government's controversial badger culling trials.
fields.body:
Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has received death threats from animal rights activists in protest at the government's controversial badger culling trials.

The Ministry of Agriculture has set up the cull to try to establish whether there is a link between badgers and tuberculosis in cattle.

A Maff spokesman last night said that Mr Brown had been targeted along with the farmers and scientists involved with the experiments.

He said: "Mr Brown has received death threats from people on the fringes of the badger movement. We have heard reports that the children of farmers and members of Maff staff engaged in the trial have been followed. We condemn this utterly."

The spokesman, who would not comment on the exact circumstances of the death threats, added: "Mr Brown has called on Jack Straw to ensure that mechanisms are brought in to make sure that Maff staff and the farmers are given the full protection of the law."

Maff said that Mr Brown was not the first agriculture minister to be targeted by animal rights activists. The spokesman said that Douglas Hogg also received death threats on the same issue while William Waldegrave received threats over live animal exports.

Maff has estimated that 12,500 badgers will be culled at 10 sites over a five-year period. The trials started two years ago.

Animal rights groups, who say the experiments are unscientific and cruel, believe the money should be spent on developing a vaccine and promoting better animal husbandry. The National Federation of Badger Groups has protested that badgers have been killed during the breeding season, leaving their starving cubs to die.

The National Farmers' Union believes that 40,000 farmers will have been financially ruined by bovine TB by the time the experiments are completed. Many farmers believe there should be a full-scale badger cull.

Ben Gill, the NFU president, called on the activists who are responsible for the death threats to be treated under the law as terrorists. "I am concerned about the badger and also GM crop trials. These activists are in a different bracket and are guilty of clear, absolute terrorism."

Badger trials have so far been conducted on the Gloucester-Hereford border, Devon and Cornwall border, east Cornwall, east Hereford, north Wiltshire, west Cornwall and the Staffordshire-Derbyshire and Devon-Somerset borders.

fields.headline: Adult humour
fields.trailText: Contempt for American television should be tempered by the fact that the system which created Who Wants To Marry A Millionaire? also made The Simpsons.
fields.body:
Contempt for American television should be tempered by the fact that the system which created Who Wants To Marry A Millionaire? also made The Simpsons. Indeed, the same network - Rupert Murdoch's Fox - presided over both.

Simpsons Night (Friday, 6pm, BBC2) - including famous episodes and documentaries going back to the drawing board - celebrates a landmark television show which, in reaching its tenth anniversary, has now remained in top position eight years longer than President George Bush who, in a miscalculated campaign speech, once pledged to build an America "less like The Simpsons and more like The Waltons".

Bush's remark was disastrous, solidifying his image as someone out of touch. Matt Groening, creator of The Simpsons, understood much better the way the country was going. Watching the anniversary video pack The Simpsons: Year 2, two aspects of Groening's achievement become apparent. The first is the range of references. Some plots (Homer uses hair restorer, Bart gets bad grades at school) are classic sitcom, but the cartoon format allows an ease with fantasy sequences (conversations with the Devil, pacts with God) which human action comedies would never risk.

Political satire (when gruesome power plant boss Mr Burns is spun into an almost successful run for governor) and literary allusion (an episode based on Poe's The Raven) are other signs of Groening's daring.

A recent episode discussed the nature of fiction itself. It's revealing that - unusually for a TV series - certificates on The Simpsons videos vary: some U, some PG. It's a measure of the different levels going on.

Most impressive is way that The Simpsons corrected American TV's tendency to flatter the audience by exaggerating the glamour of characters' lives. The Simpsons are precisely and defiantly blue collar. A show always alert to ironies embodies one: that a series ostensibly for kids should be one of television's most grown-up.

fields.headline: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: This is a wretched time for Fielding. His daughter is taking A-levels and the mood in his house is so delicate that he and his wife absolutely must be polite to one another.
fields.body:
This is a wretched time for Fielding. His daughter is taking A-levels and the mood in his house is so delicate that he and his wife absolutely must be polite to one another. They dare not express bad temper for fear of ruffling the Daughter, who is a blue touch-paper. They tippy-toe about, trying not to say anything inflammatory, such as "How are you?" or "Fancy some breakfast?" Everyone must address Daughter in a positive way, saying "Your room's nice and tidy/Your hair looks terrific today" and suchlike.

And Daughter isn't the only person Fielding has had to kowtow to lately. He has further abased himself at school by finally filling in the hated Threshold Form in a horribly licky-bottom way and is deeply ashamed of himself.

Meanwhile, his family continue to live life on the edge. They hold their breath and provide nourishing meals for their pallid, revising child. It is a mark of Daughter's desperation that she has asked Fielding to give her an English tutorial. This is something of a breakthrough. It is eight years since she last spoke to her father voluntarily, let alone asked for guidance. And all this when Fielding and his wife are already weakened by the coursework. Coursework is tough on parents. They worry for two years: "When will my child stop watching soaps/start working?" Fielding's daughter waited until the very last, then dashed off an impressive film noir about Ladbroke Grove in the final 12 hours.

I remember this ghastly ordeal myself, as the Treasure sweated into the small hours, trying to finish her art coursework. It had no end. However much she did, there was always more she should have done, and a parent cannot rest while his/her child is up all night on the edge of breakdown.

Naturally Fielding's nerves are in shreds. It is fearfully difficult to control oneself when one is busting with anxiety. At night he lies sleepless, his brain buzzing with hideous possibilities. He knows them from experience with his own pupils: Daughter could explode first thing on exam morning, fall off the bus, be late, go blank or storm out of the exam. She could even get three As and not get into Oxford.
fields.bodyText: This is a wretched time for Fielding. His daughter is taking A-levels and the mood in his house is so delicate that he and his wife absolutely must be polite to one another. They dare not express bad temper for fear of ruffling the Daughter, who is a blue touch-paper. They tippy-toe about, trying not to say anything inflammatory, such as "How are you?" or "Fancy some breakfast?" Everyone must address Daughter in a positive way, saying "Your room's nice and tidy/Your hair looks terrific today" and suchlike. And Daughter isn't the only person Fielding has had to kowtow to lately. He has further abased himself at school by finally filling in the hated Threshold Form in a horribly licky-bottom way and is deeply ashamed of himself. Meanwhile, his family continue to live life on the edge. They hold their breath and provide nourishing meals for their pallid, revising child. fields.headline: Standing guard for Canada
fields.standfirst: Beverley McLachlin is Canada's first woman chief justice. But thanks to the impending Human Rights Act, her court could have a significant influence on English law.  Clare Dyer  reports
fields.trailText: Beverley McLachlin is Canada's first woman chief justice. But thanks to the impending Human Rights Act, her court could have a significant influence on English law.  Clare Dyer  reports
fields.body:
The chances are you've never heard of Beverley McLachlin. But her pronouncements and those of her colleagues are about to have a profound influence on the way our law develops.

McLachlin is the newly installed Chief Justice of Canada, the first woman to hold this powerful and influential post. She heads the nine-judge supreme court of Canada, the country's highest court. But why should the rulings of a court thousands of miles away in a foreign country affect what happens here?

For the answer, see Margaret Brown v Procurator Fiscal. That was the Scottish case that caused a furore last February when the appeal court ruled that 30-year-old Brown's admission that she was driving while over the alcohol limit could not be used against her. Since that was a key piece of evidence, the case had to be dropped.

The Human Rights Act, which comes into force in October, will bring the European Convention on Human Rights into English law. The convention has been part of Scottish law for more than a year as a result of the act which brought in devolution. Since 1982, Canada has had a charter of rights and freedoms modelled on the European convention. As the judgments in Brown's case and others in the last year show, Canada's 18 years of case law are certain to be mined heavily by our judges when cases with human rights points come before our courts.

The judgment in Brown's case is peppered with dicta from McLachlin and other Canadian supreme court judges. Our courts will have to take account of judgments from the European court in Strasbourg in deciding cases that come before them, but the Brown judgment draws even more more extensively on case law from Canada, where the laws and values are similar to Britain's.

The Scottish judges quote McLachlin's pronouncement in a 1990 case: "The protection conferred by a legal system which grants the accused immunity from incriminating himself at trial but offers no protection with respect to pre-trial statements would be illusory." And: "A person in the power of the state in the course of the criminal process has the right to choose whether to speak to the police or remain silent."

Interpreted by a generation of activist judges, the Canadian charter has had a revolutionary effect, little anticipated back in 1982. The supreme court's rulings have been controversial, much criticised in academic journals, newspaper leaders and news magazines. The judges, critics say, have usurped the role of parliament. Constitutional experts and court watchers predict that the Human Rights Act will similarly politicise British judges.

So when Lord Woolf met the press this month for the first time in his new role as Lord Chief Justice of England, I was in Ottawa, following a Mountie through the corridors of Canada's supreme court building to the chief justice's wood-panelled office. I was greeted not by a 67-year-old man but by a young-looking woman of 56. However similar the two countries' laws and institutions, Canada's senior judges are much more representative of the people they serve.

Even the titles in Britain assume that women will never hold them: Lord Chief Justice, Lords of Appeal in Ordinary (the full title of the law lords). No woman in Britain has ever held one of the two highest posts, Lord Chief Justice or Master of the Rolls, or sat in our highest court, the House of Lords. (In Britain the Lord Chief Justice is the senior judge but does not sit in the highest court - he heads the court of appeal's criminal division; in Canada the chief justice heads the supreme court, a role more akin to the that of the senior law lord in Britain - a post just taken up by Lord Bingham, who was till this month Lord Chief Justice.)

While McLachlin is the first woman to occupy Canada's highest judicial office, the supreme court has had women members for nearly 20 years. Of the nine judges, three are currently women - including Louise Arbour, formerly chief prosecutor at the UN war crimes tribunal for the former Yugoslavia and Rwanda.

Unlike Britain's senior judiciary, dominated by the products of elite public schools, McLachlin, like most Canadian judges, was state- educated. She grew up as one of five children in the small farming community of Pincher Creek, Alberta. "We didn't have much money. We struggled," she told guests at her swearing-in ceremony. "What you could do mattered more than where you came from."

Her parents both had German roots. The Scottish surname came from her first husband, Rory, who died young, when their son was 12. Rory encouraged her to go to law school: "Without his infusions of confidence I would never have believed I could have succeeded in the male-dominated legal profession."

Eleven years ago, after seven years as a judge in British Columbia, she got the call to the nation's supreme court in Ottawa. Her son, Angus, who had to leave his friends in Vancouver, told her: "Go for it, Mom." She married her second husband, a lawyer, eight years ago.

Thirty years ago, women were as scarce in the law schools of Canada as they were in Britain's law faculties. Yet in Canada they have made it to the top of the system as they have not here. "I do think that because women sometimes have had different experiences in life they may bring perspectives that are important to the discussion table," says McLachlin. "You can have a richer, fuller discussion and one that better reflects the real values and concerns of society."

Critics of the court's activism counter that it is for the people's elected representatives in parliament to fashion the law to reflect the values and concerns of society, and not for the judges. The view that the judges have grown too powerful is a widespread theme in the Canadian media. Typical is a leader in the Montreal Gazette: "The supreme court has become a political institution. Its power should be checked."

The court, indeed, has the power to strike down statutes passed by parliament and provincial legislatures, and it is a power it uses freely. In Britain, judges will not be able to strike down a statute; there will be a fast-track procedure for parliament to amend any law found to breach human rights. McLachlin believes, however, that the difference may be more apparent than real.

Between 1982 and 1998 the Canadian supreme court struck down 58 statutes. Last year, in a controversial ruling hailed as a victory for gay rights, it outlawed any provisions in a statute which define a spouse as "a member of the opposite sex". That one judgment will mean rewriting up to 1,000 federal and provincial statutes. Conrad Black's National Post took issue with the ruling, claiming "public opinion is too divided on gay rights for judges to take sides". But McLachlin points to a survey last month showing strong public support for the charter.

In 1991 she delivered the majority judgment striking down rape shield laws protecting alleged rape victims from questioning about their sexual history. In a powerfully reasoned judgment, she argued that the accused's right to a fair trial should not be sacrificed. Citing the Birmingham Six and other cases of wrongful conviction, she insisted: "The price is too great."

Another woman judge, Claire l'Heureux-Dubé, delivered an equally eloquent dissent. The rape shield laws were rewritten but have come before the court again in a case awaiting judgment. Other current issues concern gun-control laws, child pornography and whether Canadians charged with murder in the US should be extradited to face the death penalty, which is outlawed in Canada.

A new book, The Charter Revolution and the Court Party, by political scientists FL Morton and Rainer Knopf, accuses the court of allowing itself to be hijacked by women's organisations, civil liberties bodies and other interest groups permitted to intervene in cases. Even the Italian senate, campaigning globally against the death penalty, was allowed to intervene in the extradition case. British courts, which have so far been sparing in allowing interveners - Amnesty International's role in the Pinochet case was an example - will have to hear more when the Human Rights Act comes into force, according to Robert Hazell, professor of government and the constitution at University College London. McLachlin insists: "This court is not hijacked by any interest groups or anyone else. We listen to all the arguments and make our decisions accordingly, I think, in a very independent way."

Most Canadians were unprepared for the revolution the charter has brought. But, she says, the supreme court signalled from the outset "that they were going to take these rights and freedoms very seriously, that they were going to give a generous, purposive approach to them, that they were going to interpret them in the world context of human rights issues and human rights law". There's little doubt that British judges will do the same.

fields.headline: The odd couple
fields.standfirst: When Who Wants To Marry a Millionaire was broadcast earlier this year, it made headlines around the world. Now a new documentary tells the whole story.  Mark Lawson is transfixed
fields.trailText: When Who Wants To Marry a Millionaire was broadcast earlier this year, it made headlines around the world. Now a new documentary tells the whole story. Mark Lawson is transfixed
fields.body:
When American journalist Kurt Andersen wrote his impressive first novel, the millennial comedy Turn Of The Century, his satirical inventions included several spoofs of US television shows. He calculated these as savage exaggerations of trends in the medium towards stupidity and prurience. So Andersen was surprised when friends in TV seriously suggested he could maximise the book's profits by selling the formats for these potential ratings winners to the industry.

The impossibility of any send-up of American TV surpassing what is already sent out is emphasised by a documentary - Who Would Want To Marry A Millionaire? (Wednesday, Channel 4) - which brings a welcome sardonic edge to the soccer-sclerotic schedules.

Combining archive with hindsight interviews, David Schiff's film examines the programme which has come to be regarded as popular TV's Suez: the two-hour Fox special earlier this year called Who Wants To Marry A Millionaire? in which 50 women competed to marry a man with $2m in his wallet. The prize guy was hidden behind a screen and exposed only at the moment of proposal. Just before the credits rolled at the Las Vegas Hilton, rich bachelor Rick Rockwell married Darva Conger, a forceful blonde whose closing soliloquy - "If you choose me, I will be your friend, lover and partner" - had shown a Clintonian grasp of small-screen technique.

Regrettably, Conger soon proved to resemble her President in terms of both verbal and romantic reliability. Declaring on the first day of the honeymoon cruise that she had no feelings for her human jackpot, she was back in Las Vegas within seven days filing for divorce. She claimed that, on the programme, she had been "playing a role".

If so, she may have been entirely compatible with her brief husband, whose most intense courtship in the course of the show was probably with publicity, although he continues to deny this in the film. Rockwell was a stand-up comic whose main humour derived from staging public stunts. He'd also been accused of violence to women and, though rich by blue-collar standards, was a pauper by wing-collar ones.

The narrative is compelling, and there will surely be a movie one day, like Robert Redford's Quiz Show which recreated a previous loss of ethics. But the documentary's strength is to isolate tiny, telling details. Rockwell's bald spot was electronically filled in on screen. He hired a psychologist to help him frame his questions.

People selected from a line on American TV hug the person next to them because producers tell them to do it: the camera needs time to find them. The sequence in which suitors paraded in swimsuits was justified by producers because the millionaire had a beach house. One woman knew that she'd lost when she confirmed that she'd like to keep her job. During a commercial break, twice-divorced host Jay Thomas ran backstage and urged Rockwell not to select Conger because he recognised the type.

The documentary's closing update section captures perfectly a culture in which shame is just another kind of fame and the losers merely cash in differently coloured chips at the showbiz casino. Rick Rockwell's previously unknown comedy show is now a sell-out hit, with a new routine based on his experiences as TV's instant jilted husband. He now believes that God put him through public humiliation for a reason. Darva Conger is preparing to pose naked for a six-figure fee from a magazine. Minor participants maintain their own celebrity. Two of the failed would-be brides stripped for $5,000 on the Howard Stern Show.

The programme's most shaming revelation is probably that this apparently classic American fiasco was inspired by British broadcasting. The producer (previous hit: The World's Scariest Police Chases) was consciously merging Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? with a documentary on the British strangers who met and married on a radio show.

It's important that we take our share of the blame. Ten years ago, an America-is-hell piece like this would have encouraged a warm smugness in viewers here, sustaining our superiority complex as we switched over to our high-class costume dramas and late-night philosophy debates. Screened just after the Channel 5 naked gameshow hosted by a nude Keith Chegwin, Who Would Want To Marry A Millionaire? has the unexpected effect of creating feelings of inferiority. At least opportunistic American trash has higher production values and the host keeps his clothes on.

And any remaining temptation to regard Rick and Darva's television wedding as a vision from a distant hell is removed by inspection of this week's documentaries on the main commercial channel. The Streakers (Wednesday, ITV) is a shameless compilation of sportsground show-it-alls. And in Celebrity Heartbreak (Friday, ITV) - thankfully, only 20 minutes was available for preview - Trisha Goddard meets C-list stars involved in love-splits written up by the tabloids. Coleen from the Nolan Sisters discusses her love-rat ex-husband. George Best is asked whether sex is better than scoring goals.

British TV may not yet have made marriage the prize in a gameshow, but its divorce from previous standards becomes more absolute every day.

 Who Would Want To Marry A Millionaire? (Wednesday, 9pm, Channel 4) The Streakers (Wednesday, 10.30pm, ITV) Celebrity Heartbreak (Friday, 10pm, ITV)

webTitle: When the Bard came to the bar

fields.headline: When the Bard came to the bar
fields.trailText: Anthony Arlidge QC is a sort of impresario, responsible for putting on shows in that inn of court. He's also, a historian-detective with a mission - to try to prove that the first ever performance of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night was in the Middle Temple Hall, on February 2 1602.
fields.body:
Anthony Arlidge QC also bears the splendid title of Master of the Entertainments in the Middle Temple. He's a sort of impresario, responsible for putting on shows in that inn of court. He's also, it turns out, a historian-detective with a mission - to try to prove that the first ever performance of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night was in the Middle Temple Hall, on February 2 1602. And despite a paucity of hard evidence, his book Shakespeare and the Feast of Love (Giles de la Mare) is pretty persuasive. He's found a diary entry by a student of the inn: "last night wee had a play called Twelve Night or What You Will".

Arlidge has also discovered that a cousin of the Bard's, Thomas Greene, was at the inn at the time, possibly involved in choosing the entertainments. Further, Shakespeare was not popular at the competing inn, Gray's, because some of its members had objected to the abdication scene in his Richard II when it was staged there; so he might have needed a new venue. Arlidge has uncovered lots of other circumstantial evidence, all of which points to the existence of an extraordinary night when Shakespeare tried out his new play on a bunch of judges, lawyers and students. We can be sure that the event, like all such entertainments at the inns, was a rowdy, rumbustious affair, not at all respectful. Alas, there's no evidence of the audience's reaction.

 Chambers, that extremely funny radio comedy series about barristers, has transferred to television (BBC1, Thursday, 10pm). The transition doesn't always succeed, but Chambers, I think, gets away with it, although its radio roots clearly show. It's a sort of surreal Rumpole, with its best moments coming when it's at its most absurd. John Bird is splendidly pompous as the head of a second-rate chambers, the other members of which are all suitably eccentric or feeble-minded. The first episode contained a scene in which, for a bet, Bird's opponent in a tedious court case inserted into his speech the names of all the EastEnders characters ; Bird's task was to mention cunnilingus without the judge noticing. Very funny, and I hope that every episode (there are five more to come) has similarly excessive verbal pyrotechnics. Some of the jokes may be lost on non-lawyers, but there are still enough left to make for enjoyable watching.

It is one of the truths of legal life that the more outrageous, unreal and ridiculous the portrayal of lawyers is, the more people believe it to be the real thing. I expect Chambers to set back the image of barristers by several decades. Poor bar, trying to project itself as a lithe 21st-century profession; and now this television programme showing barristers, to a man and woman, as buffoons.

There have, sadly, been a number of examples of women suing over breast implants that have gone wrong. Mary Gale, a former exotic dancer from New York, has introduced a variation on the theme. The trouble in her case is that the breast implants were inserted - I am trying to find a delicate way of putting this - into her buttocks. Ms Gale, suing the plastic surgeon responsible, told the jury that she had asked him to enhance the shape of her behind, in order to be able to dance even more exotically and earn even more money . He's a sort of impresario, responsible for putting on shows in that inn of court. He's also, it turns out, a historian-detective with a mission - to try to prove that the first ever performance of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night was in the Middle Temple Hall, on February 2 1602. And despite a paucity of hard evidence, his book Shakespeare and the Feast of Love (Giles de la Mare) is pretty persuasive.
