fields.headline: My body and me
fields.standfirst: Do skinny models make young girls obsessed with their looks? This week, the government's so-called super-waif summit will talk about just that.  Terri Apter  reports, while four teenagers  reveal how they feel. Interviews by Amy Fleming
fields.trailText: Do skinny models make young girls obsessed with their looks? This week, the government's so-called super-waif summit will talk about just that.  Terri Apter  reports, while four teenagers  reveal how they feel.
fields.body:
Since the early 70s, women have broken through every career barrier and transformed traditional assumptions about female social roles. But 30 years on, the pace of change freezes as they look in the mirror. Teenage girls are stuck in the glaring lights of the catwalk. Blind to realistic and healthy physiques, they measure themselves against the ideal female images captured on camera. Some girls, particularly those who are perfectionists, pursue this ideal in defiance of common sense. Dieting to the point of starvation, they are literally dying for a model figure.

On Wednesday, the women's unit in the cabinet office is holding what is widely but unofficially referred to as "the super-waif summit" - a meeting with health experts and designers, stylists and magazine editors. Minister for women Tessa Jowell is expected to chair a debate on the causes and possible remedies of girls' constant dieting and obsession with their appearance. In particular, the women's unit is expected to confront fashion industry leaders over the prevalence of skinny models and their effect on girls' wellbeing.

This meeting was planned in the wake of the Listen Up report released in April, in which teenage girls were described as dissatisfied with their physique and oppressed by fashionable female icons. While some journalists have argued that a young girl's disappointment at realising she is not and never will be as thin and pretty as her ideal is the stuff of soap opera rather than politics, the report asserted that "the government takes these concerns seriously and is considering what action might be feasible".

This position has strong support in well-documented findings that a girl's sense of self-esteem and emotional wellbeing are closely related to how she feels about her body. It is government business, then, to bring to account an industry that is generating a public health hazard. But how effective can it be to target fashion industry leaders over girls' (and women's) skewed physical ideals? After all, girls learn the language of bodily dissatisfaction in many contexts. Among friends, they endorse the ideal: "Doesn't she have a perfect figure?" they ask. "Don't you wish you could look like her?" They then bond as sisters by promising to diet together.

Most teenage girls are daughters of dieters. They see their mothers refuse dessert and complain about their thighs, stomach, arms, chin, rear. Many mothers, feeling responsible for a daughter's appearance, give as many warnings to "be careful what you eat" as to take care with sex. A girl can be hurt, too, by a father's appraising looks, kidding quips and snide remarks about her physique. All this from people who care for her and love her: think what's in store for her from her enemies if her figure doesn't match the norm.

Is the fashion industry, then, just a scapegoat? Magazine editors are already airing their defence. Vogue's Alexandra Shulman is reported as saying you don't catch anorexia from opening the pages of her magazine. So is this one more example of ministers patronising women?

Though there is far more to girls' persistent self-denigration than media imagery, it is impossible to argue away the link between dieting, eating disorders and bodily dissatisfaction on the one hand, and idealised images of skinny beauties on the other. The British Medical Association reviewed a range of research from international sources and while it admitted this did not prove outright a causal link between thin models and rates of eating disorders, the correlation was sufficiently high to argue that anorexia is powerfully fuelled by media images.

While less than 3% of young women suffer from anorexia or bulimia, 90% of British women are said to diet sometimes and bad body fever - that sense of our bodies being aesthetically under par - is as common as dust. So it does make sense, after all, to force the powerful fashion industry to be accountable for its impact on the nation's health.

There are, however, other tacks to explore. Ideals are not passively imposed on young minds. Some groups of girls and women move comfortably in their own bodies, even in a culture replete with fashion and diet industries. To date, few cases of anorexia and bulimia have been reported among British black and Asian girls. They see the same images of thin women the white girls do, but do not internalise them as models they should aspire to.

Perhaps we could learn what safety mechanism is triggered here. These girls may look to the real women they rub shoulders with to identify what's attractive and appealing. Habits of family eating, too, may prevent bizarre calorific self-denial.

When the intelligence and imagination of most teenage girls sticks on the pages of a sickly culture, we need not only to attack its causes but also to uncover the secrets of resistance.

Joanna Rothenberg, 13

Today we went on a school trip, so we didn't have to wear uniform. Getting dressed is hard because I'm really conscious of how I look and there's always competition about who's wearing the most expensive, stylish clothes. We only went to a farm but people were wearing designer tops and some even had make-up on - I didn't as I only wear a bit on special occasions. I wore a Little Miss Naughty T-shirt and some Nike running trousers and a jumper. I'm quite slim so I didn't worry about how my figure looked.

I didn't have breakfast because I don't like eating in the morning but throughout the day I ate whatever I wanted to without thinking about it. Sometimes if I'm eating excessive amounts I worry but it's not really a problem for me. Friends at school are often dieting and worrying about eating too much. There is this idea that prettier girls will be more popular but in reality I don't think people judge totally on appearance.

During lunch break, we looked at some magazines. The models make you feel bad sometimes because you're not as skinny as them, but then you look past it and in a couple of days it doesn't really matter.

When we were walking home, some guys were looking at my friends - not because of the way they were dressed but because of the way they're formed, because they've already got boobs and stuff. The girls are really aware of who's the thinnest and sexiest.

After school, I watched TV. The girls in pop videos wear such revealing clothes. Sometimes I think they look really good and I'll want to dress like that and go to those kinds of places. But in real life you'd just feel weird. When I'm out on the street, I feel really self-conscious and I compare myself to the people around me, but when I'm at home or with my friends, I feel comfortable.

Lorna Hankin, 17

I've eaten healthily all day, starting with cereal, yoghurt and fruit for breakfast. This isn't to lose weight - I don't think I need to - but because I was living on tea and toast before and had no energy. I had a sandwich, crisps and fruit for lunch, and later had to fight the urge to eat chocolate. I sometimes overcome it by drinking water. If you do indulge and people comment, it makes you feel guilty and self-conscious. Men can eat what they like but people tend to comment on what girls eat.

I'm in the sixth form and we don't have to wear uniform, so I'm very conscious of what I put on every day. I'm happy with my body and I'm size 10, so I don't really have to worry, but I avoid clothes I think make me look big. I don't like my stomach when I bend over, so I won't wear belly-tops and I don't like going without tights because I don't tan easily.

I spend about 15 minutes on my make-up - I'm always aware of covering up spots and things. As a brunette, I'm conscious that I don't live up to the ideal of a woman with long blonde hair and blue eyes. I also sometimes wish I was taller.

My friends and I look at models in magazines and say things like "Oh, she's so thin" or "She's got a horrible mouth". If boys think a girl is attractive, then you take more notice. Sometimes the models are too thin - I wouldn't want to look ill like them. My main aim is to feel good and mostly I do because I think I look OK. As a young woman, you do get noticed - and you do find often the most popular girls are the prettiest ones rather than the nicest.

I don't know anyone who's got anorexia or bulimia, and I think it comes from the individual rather than the media. A lot of the time, girls my age are looking for reassurance, so they may say they're looking fat when they know they're not because they just want to hear that they're not.

Roma Norriss, 16

I would be lying if I said I wasn't conscious of how I look. I always try to wear clothes that don't make me look fat or unattractive. I usually wear something around my waist, like a sarong over trousers.

I didn't have any breakfast this morning because I don't like eating first thing and don't have time anyway. It's got nothing to do with losing weight and I don't have an unhealthy view of food. It's strange because I'm actually quite huge, but I rarely get hungry and rarely eat during the day. I go through phases when I don't eat anything at all, but then other times I eat everything I see.

Today a group of us were talking about how ridiculous it is that the modern ideal is for women to be really skinny and boyish when for centuries it's been larger women who've been seen as attractive. It's difficult for girls to feel happy and confident about how they look when the media has created an environment that encourages girls to be skinny.

We are given Barbies as children, which must have had an influence, yet apparently you'd die if you had the equivalent of Barbie's vital statistics. I don't feel self-conscious about my body in front of my friends - it's not an issue for me. I do have friends who have eating disorders and have done horrific things to themselves, but all the boys say they like chunky women, so I don't feel like I have to lose weight for them.

I buy men's magazines and don't mind the women in them. Models are nice to look at but I don't compare myself with them and I don't find it hard to accept that there are many more beautiful women in the world than me. I think it's bad that models are so thin, but more because of the effect it has on other people than on me personally. I do suffer from slight body dysmorphia - I think everyone does to some extent.

Nina Fagon, 18

I don't worry about my body shape as I don't follow models and fashion and things like that. It doesn't interest me. I was watching this catwalk show on TV the other day and the models looked really malnourished. It was quite scary - I hadn't realised it was that bad.

I've got a typical Afro-Caribbean figure in that I'm bottom-heavy with thick thighs, but I don't have any problems with the way I look. I watch a lot of films but I don't want to be like the women I see in them. They're them and I'm me. A lot of my friends have got a complex about their bodies but I don't see the point of it - there's nothing you can do to change your basic body shape, unless you drastically over-eat or under-eat. They associate being big with being unfit, which is not true, and they complain about their size without doing any exercise.

I eat three meals a day because that's when I'm hungry - I don't feel the need to snack. Getting dressed in the morning, it's a case of what goes together out of what's clean. I don't wear make-up, apart from a bit of lipstick when I'm going out, and I dress the same wherever I go, though if I'm going out I may put on a little top. I don't feel the need to hide anything - I've been dancing since I was two or three, so I've always had to be in front of people in leotards. I'm only conscious about my body in terms of flexibility and strength, not shape.

Last night we went to a Barbie party wearing short, tight, pink dresses and this old man just shook his head in disgust. It was weird - I don't usually wear dresses because I feel self-conscious. I don't mind what people think but I don't like wearing clothes that shout "Look at me". If a man whistles at me in the street, I feel shocked that I've been unaware of being watched.

fields.headline: UN backs Annan on Lebanon
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The UN security council agreed yesterday to endorse secretary general Kofi Annan's verification that Israeli troops had pulled out of Lebanon.
fields.body:
The UN security council agreed yesterday to endorse secretary general Kofi Annan's verification that Israeli troops had pulled out of Lebanon.

But in a nod to Russia, the council acknowledged that there may have been violations of the border, as Lebanon insists, since Mr Annan made his certification last Friday.

Russia had delayed the council's statement since Saturday because Lebanon insisted that Israelis were still on its soil. Mr Annan had threatened to cancel a trip to Beirut today if the council did not support his position.

Mr Annan said UN troops were responsible for verifying any violations on the border, not the countries involved.

"I would not describe what is between the UN and Lebanon as a dispute. It is more of a hiccup which will be overcome," he said in Cairo. "Verification of violations is the responsibility of the United Nations and not either party. If we hand over the verification to either party, then we are entering dangerous ground."

webTitle: The Des factor falters as ITV and BBC go head to head

fields.headline: The Des factor falters as ITV and BBC go head to head
fields.standfirst: Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: ITV lost out to the BBC in the battle to win viewers for the England v Germany game.
fields.body:
He may have twinkled his eyes and smouldered his little heart out, but Des Lynam failed to help ITV beat BBC1 in the battle to win viewers for the England v Germany game, writes Vikram Dodd .

The BBC was yesterday crowing after pulling in 11.8m viewers, nearly twice as many as the 6.1m who watched the match on its commercial rival.

But ITV last night said its new star sports presenter, Des Lynam, poached from the BBC, had helped to reduce the size of the corporation's traditional lead over it when the two channels go head to head.

The BBC's margin of victory for Saturday night's England win was less than the England v Germany game during Euro 96 when it beat ITV by three to one.

Then just 26.5% of viewers chose ITV's coverage over the BBC's, while on Saturday it was 34.1%.

The ratings victory will come as balm for the corporation's wounds after ITV last week wrestled away the rights for highlights of Premier League football from 2001.

BBC1 scheduled the hit movie Babe and a special episode of EastEnders to lure viewers to its coverage, presented by the former England striker Gary Lineker.

A BBC spokesman, Mike Hales, pointed out that a greater proportion of ITV viewers, over one-sixth, had switched off its post-match analysis. The BBC lost just 400,000 viewers.

Mr Hales said: "The Des factor doesn't seem to exist. When you look at the post-match figures, that indicates the relative popularity of the two teams of pundits and the presenters similarly."

An ITV spokesman, Paul Tyrrell, said: "It's not a trouncing. It's the closest we've ever been to the BBC when we've gone head to head. We're very pleased."

The two channels will next go head to head if England qualify for the quarter finals.

A BBC spokesman, Mike Hales, pointed out that a greater proportion of ITV viewers, over one-sixth, had switched off its post-match analysis. The BBC lost just 400,000 viewers. Mr Hales said: "The Des factor doesn't seem to exist. When you look at the post-match figures, that indicates the relative popularity of the two teams of pundits and the presenters similarly." webTitle: England told: more rioting and you're out

fields.headline: England told: more rioting and you're out
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: English football has been left facing the most crucial days in its entire history after Uefa, the game's European governing body, threatened the team with expulsion from Euro 2000 if its fans caused any further problems during the remainder of the tournament.
fields.body:
English football has been left facing the most crucial days in its entire history after Uefa, the game's European governing body, threatened the team with expulsion from Euro 2000 if its fans caused any further problems during the remainder of the tournament.

The unprecedented ultimatum and the behaviour of English fans has severely embarrassed the British government which came under fire from Uefa president Lennart Johannson for not doing enough to prevent hooligans from travelling abroad.

After a weekend of violence in Charleroi and Brussels, Mr Johannson said: "Fans cannot be allowed to behave like this again and create havoc. The UK government owes it to everyone concerned to take similar steps to those taken in other countries to stop those troublesome fans from travelling abroad.

"Other governments have shown that it can be done. The UEFA executive committee called on the government of the UK and the Football Association of London to take the necessary steps to stop English hooligans from travelling abroad."

With fears increasing that there could be further violence in the run-up to tomorrow's game against Romania, Mr Johannson warned: "Uefa will have to determine whether the presence of the English team in the tournament should be maintained should there be a repetition of similar incidents. We cannot afford a repeat of the fans' behaviour of recent days."

It is believed to be the first time that a major footballing nation has been threatened with expulsion from a high profile tournament.

Prime minister Tony Blair, responding to Uefa's ultimatum, said: "Hopefully this threat will bring to their senses anyone tempted to continue the mindless thuggery that has brought such shame to the country." Uefa took the decision to deliver the ultimatum to the England team following an emergency meeting of its executive committee.

Mr Johannson said that the behaviour of the English had scarred the tournament and that he was afraid that one day, innocent people could be killed in the violence which has blighted Euro 2000.

Mr Johannson added: "We cannot forget what happened in Heysel. We cannot ignore the incidents in Istanbul and Copenhagen and what has happened in Charleroi and Brussels."

Kevin Miles, co-ordinator of the Football Supporters Association Fans' Embassies, at the tournament, said: "While all genuine supporters deplore any trouble caused by anyone following the English team, Uefa's proposal would seem to punish the innocent to an extent that even the Belgian police have not yet managed."

Prior to the Uefa announcement, an embarrassed home secretary Jack Straw acknowledged that he had allowed Britain to enter the Euro 2000 football championship with major loopholes in its anti-hooligan laws, including excessive discretion for magistrates to permit troublemakers to travel abroad.

Conservatives rounded on Mr Straw saying the Home Office had backtracked on a commitment to introduce a bill in this session giving magistrates powers to impound passports of anyone liable to commit a football related-offence abroad, even if they had not been convicted in British courts.

The then Home Office minister Kate Hoey had given the undertaking in parliament in May 1999. She later withdrew the idea, saying it would be better to wait to see if magistrates used new duties contained in a private members bill sponsored by Tory MPs to impound passports of convicted hooligans.

Mr Straw said yesterday that he planned to make it mandatory on magistrates to remove a passport automatically from anyone convicted of a domestic football-related offence. Magistrates will be required to demand the convicted hooligan surrenders his passport for the duration of a tournament.

Now magistrates have a statutory duty to impose such travelling bans only if they believe it will prevent violence. But since this new tightened power came into force last September only 23 of the 203 hooligans convicted of domestic offences have been made subject to international banning orders.

It is also likely that magistrates will be asked to ban fans from travelling abroad, even if they have not been convicted of an offence, if the police can persuade a magistrate they are likely to commit an offence. One likely criteria is expected to be if the suspected hooligan has a criminal record.

Latest chapter in long history of havoc

1974 Tottenham banned from playing two European games at White Hart Lane after fans riot in Uefa Cup final at Feyenoord

1975 Leeds banned from Europe for four seasons, later cut to two, after riots during European Cup final in Paris

1977 Manchester United expelled from European Cup Winners' Cup after crowd trouble against St Etienne. Later reinstated

1980 England fined £8,000 after riots in Turin during European championship game v Belgium

1981 England fans cause £60,000 damage in Basle after World Cup defeat by Switzerland

1983 Tottenham fans riot in Rotterdam. England fans rampage in Luxembourg

1984 Tottenham supporter shot dead in Brussels and police hold 200 fans after riot before Uefa Cup final against Anderlecht

1985 39 people die at Heysel stadium, Brussels, before Liverpool's European Cup final against Juventus. All English clubs banned indefinitely from European competition

1986 Five stabbed in riot between followers of Everton, Manchester United and West Ham on a cross-channel ferry

1988 English soccer officials withdraw request to allow clubs back in Europe after violence during European championship finals in West Germany

1990 England fans clash with Italian fans and police in Rimini before a World Cup match in Bologna. English clubs readmitted into European competitions

1992 Violence by English hooligans in Malmo and Stockholm at European championship finals raise doubts whether England should host 1996 tournament

1993 England fans clash with Dutch police in Amsterdam on eve of World Cup qualifying game against Holland

1995 Friendly international against Republic of Ireland in Dublin abandoned after 27 minutes when England fans riot

1996 Hooligans riot in Trafalgar Square after England lose to Germany on penalties in Euro 96 semi-final

1997 Italian police baton-charge England fans at Rome's Olympic stadium after supporters cause trouble

1998 England fans cause trouble during England's opening match of World Cup 98 against Tunisia in Marseille

2000 Two Leeds United fans stabbed to death in Istanbul ahead of Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray. English hooligans arrested by Danish police after riots before Arsenal v Galatasaray Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen

webTitle: How a farcical wrangle in parliament allowed hooligans to cause mayhem

fields.headline: How a farcical wrangle in parliament allowed hooligans to cause mayhem
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: As soon as last December's draw for the group stage of Euro 2000 was posted, pitting England against Germany, fears were voiced that violence would mar the match.
fields.byline: Patrick Wintour, Vivek Chaudhary  and Vikram Dodd
fields.body:
As soon as last December's draw for the group stage of Euro 2000 was posted, pitting England against Germany, fears were voiced that violence would mar the match.

British police and ministers knew Europe's flagship soccer championship would provide a stage for English hooligans to display their savagery. The fixture against the Germans would be a focal point for their efforts.

But a parliamentary wrangle verging on farce meant that Britain failed to put enough new legislation on the statute books to stop convicted or suspected hooligans travelling abroad. The tournament started with English soccer thugs able to leave the country - and thus with the chance to get to games in Holland and Belgium where they could cause mayhem.

In Germany, the authorities' operations to control hooligans were far more robust, with people merely suspected of involvement in soccer violence being banned from leaving the country. The anti-hooligan drive was founded on one of Germany's biggest surveillance operations of known football thugs, which began two years before a ball was kicked in Euro 2000. Officers monitored gangs' activities, compiling a dossier of their movements and political affiliations.

A similar operation was carried out by British police, spearheaded by the National Criminal Intelligence Service (NCIS), which liaised with Belgian, Dutch and French forces.

But at this point the two countries' approaches diverged. In Germany police efforts were bolstered by special legislation enabling them to confiscate the passports of hooligans they suspected would travel to Euro 2000. The fact it was feared that an individual could cause trouble was enough to take his passport away. Empowered by this law, German officers raiding the homes of several hundred hooligans. As many as 500 had their passports seized.

In Britain the power magistrates had to stop thugs from travelling abroad was withering through underuse. By the start of the tournament just 23 international banning orders were in force.

In the long leadup to the tournament, the government did not provide any of its own parliamentary time for soccer violence legislation, instead leaving it to be tabled as a private member's bill.

The Conservative MP Simon Burns had introduced a bill in the spring of 1999 that would have given British authorities German-style powers to stop hooligans leaving Britain for Euro 2000. The bill tightened the requirements on magistrates courts to impose international banning orders on anyone convicted of a football-related offences. Previous laws passed in 1989 merely asked magistrates to issue restriction orders if they knew it "would help to prevent violence or disorder". The Burns bill changed this to "reasonable grounds to believe that making the order would help to prevent violence or disorder".

In addition, instead of simply being required to report to police stations, hooligans would also be required to hand over their passports at named police stations for five days surrounding overseas matches.

Ministers realised new powers were needed when figures showed that by December 1997 there were just nine restriction orders in force, prompting the home secretary, Jack Straw, to write to the courts reminding them of their powers.

Mr Burns also planned to widen the scope of his bill, to allow banning orders against people without soccer violence convictions where there were reasonable grounds to suspect they would cause trouble. This plan, supported by the Home Office and NCIS, was spurred by the fact that English hooligans involved in violence during the 1998 World Cup in France had not been put on trial there but were deported. They arrived back in Britain not covered by the terms of the existing banning orders.

Though the Tory frontbench supported this tough measure, in the vanguard of opposition were the rightwing Tories Edward Leigh, Eric Forth, Roger Gale and Michael Fabricant. Mr Forth called the idea worthy of the old Soviet Union. "One of the most fundamental rights of our citizenry over many centuries is that a person who has not been convicted of an offence is regarded as innocent until proven guilty by due process of law," he said.

The Labour MPs Tom Pendry, Joan Whalley and Peter Pike also raised doubts about the plan, but less vociferously.

By May 1999 Mr Burns had decided against tabling the new clause, after it became clear that opponents were willing to kill his whole bill. He thought the government would then pick up the part of his bill that had been scuppered.

The then Home Office minister, Kate Hoey, said the government in principle supported the measure. But she later told MPs the idea was premature. "We clearly have to monitor the effectiveness of the bill - if it is passed - in terms of offences committed and the number of orders," she said. "We need to be in possession of that information before we can further consider the significant new powers proposed in the new clause."

Weeks before the start of Euro 2000, the fear that not enough had been done to combat English soccer thugs was voiced by Detective Superintendent Brian Drew, head of NCIS's football unit. He accused magistrates of failing to act on their new legal duties.

Last month the threat of violence was again brought home when the Uefa Cup final in Copenhagen between Arsenal and Galatasaray was marred by clashes.

Uefa, organiser of Euro 2000, grew more and more exasperated by Britain's apparent lack of action. Gerhard Aigner, Uefa's chief executive said: "It is regrettable that the government in the United Kingdom has not introduced legislation which would make it possible to stop registered hooligans from travelling."

Yesterday, after being attacked by the Conservatives for doing too little, Mr Straw said none of the first 200 people sent back to Britain had convictions for football-related violence or was known to the NCIS's hooligan spotters.

England was suffering a "cultural" problem which had seen the appeal of drunken thuggery apparently extending beyond the hardcore hooligans to attract people who otherwise led respectable and law-abiding lives, he said.

"We can target those who we know about, but it is much more difficult to target those who have never come to the attention of police in the UK."

webTitle: Charleroi police deliver short sharp shocks to quell clashes

fields.headline: Charleroi police deliver short sharp shocks to quell clashes
fields.standfirst: Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: Charleroi and Brussels woke up yesterday bruised from a weekend of unrest and bracing themselves for another round of confrontations when England fans return for tomorrow's match against Romania.
fields.byline: Vivek Chaudhary  in Charleroi and  Sarah Hall
fields.body:
Charleroi and Brussels woke up yesterday bruised from a weekend of unrest and bracing themselves for another round of confrontations when England fans return for tomorrow's match against Romania.

Already the talk is of violence and security operations rather than football.

The shabby former mining town of Charleroi returned to normal after the brief moments of mayhem that threatened to overshadow England's victory. The water cannon and armoured vans had cleared out along with the fans and only a handful of residents sat quietly in Place Charles II enjoying the sunshine.

On Saturday afternoon the square was host to depressingly familiar clashes. The violence may have looked vicious on TV screens in Britain but in truth it was brief, well contained by police and not as serious as other clashes involving England fans over the past few years.

Rival fans had started drinking in the city's main square at 8am but as the day wore on and the strong beer began to take effect, skirmishes broke out. Around 3pm fans drinking in adjoining bars started hurling abuse, then plastic chairs and tables.

Police moved in with water cannons, causing the fans, the majority of them English, to disperse. Offi cers then moved in on horseback to separate the rival factions. It was all over within 10 minutes, with many innocent fans caught up in the mayhem.

Later, once the match had started, squads of police moved back into the square for mass roundups of England fans, particularly the ticketless ones who had come to the city to watch the match in bars. Around 300 fans were detained after kick-off in preventative arrests; they were not charged but held for 12 hours and then deported.

It was firm, sharp and effective policing that quelled what could have become a full-scale riot.

Belgian police insisted yesterday that they would continue with their policy of mass roundups and zero tolerance towards suspected troublemakers. Whenever there has been the merest whiff of trouble, either in Charleroi or Brussels, police have been quick to respond.

Major Michel Rompen of the Belgian police, who coordinated the security operation in Charleroi, said: "We always said that we would be tough with hooligans, some predicted a catastrophe but in the end it was just a few incidents. It will be the same on Tuesday."

After Saturday's match the majority of England fans returned to Brussels, where there were more clashes, this time with local north African youths.

But many fans complained they had been treated unfairly by police and the media. "Everyone is making out that it was a major riot and although it looked bad there was only a minority of people involved," said Adrian Woodward from Essex.

Terry Walker, another England fan who witnessed police baton charge an English mob in central Brussels on Saturday, said: "They were trying to crack heads open and were pepper spraying anybody who came in their way. Not everyone is out here to cause problems."

Meanwhile, deported fans were returning home, protesting their innocence. Matt Jones, one of 215 fans deported, said he had been in Brussels less than two hours on Friday when riot police threw teargas into the pub where he and two friends were drinking.

"We deliberately chose a little pub down a side street to get out of the way of any trouble and I'd just got my second pint," he said. "All we were doing is singing - and the national anthem of all things.

"The next thing we knew, the windows were smashed and coppers were throwing in tear gas. They were beating us down and I got a crack with a truncheon."

The fans were held in crammed cells for 36 hours.

"Eight hundred and fifty of us were arrested and I reckon around 20 of them were hardcore," Mr Jones said. "I went to all the games in the last World Cup and never had a sniff of trouble. But I tell you what, I'll never follow England abroad again."

fields.headline: Mugabe's rivals scent poll victory
fields.standfirst:
Mugabe's opponents scent election victory

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The unthinkable may be about to happen in Zimbabwe: President Robert Mugabe could be facing humiliation and defeat for his Zanu-PF party in the coming weekend's parliamentary election.
fields.body:
The unthinkable may be about to happen in Zimbabwe: President Robert Mugabe could be facing humiliation and defeat for his Zanu-PF party in the coming weekend's parliamentary election.

A new opinion poll suggests that the opposition Movement for Democratic Change is poised to win 70 of the 120 contested parliamentary seats.

Under the constitution, Mr Mugabe - who has led Zimbabwe ever since his massive victory in the former British colony's first majority-rule elections in 1980 - appoints another 30 members to parliament. But yesterday the leader of the MDC challengers, Morgan Tsvangirai, said he would try to limit the president's ability to do so.

The president's term lasts until 2002 but the MDC is trusting that if it wins Mr Mugabe will be pressed into going early. The thought of an opposition victory this weekend, if not of an immediate Mugabe resignation, no longer seems fanciful.

Six weeks ago when Zanu-PF launched its election campaign with a wave of intimidation against supporters of the Movement for Democratic Change some opposition leaders considered calling for a boycott of an election they believed could not be free or fair.

Now against all the earlier odds they sense victory, and yesterday 15,000 of their supporters sang, danced and cheered in Harare's Rufaro stadium in lethal anticipation.

"We showed Robert Mugabe the yellow card," the MDC president, Morgan Tsvangirai, told them - referring to February's nationwide vote that rejected Mugabe attempts to change the constitution. "Now we show him the red one!" A roar of triumphant laughter engulfed the stands and, on cue, hundreds of people waved little red cards.

It was an evocative moment at the stadium where Prince Charles lowered the Union flag two decades ago in the independence ceremonies that saw Rhodesia give way to Zimbabwe

"We have enough of poverty, enough of racism, enough of Zanu-PF," Mr Tsvangirai said after beginning his speech by asking the crowd to stand in memory of the roughly 30 candidates and supporters who have been killed since the election campaign began.

"Robert Mugabe is a violent president who does not love the people of this country. He only loves power. We are not for retribution but those who have done the killing must answer for it."

But there was also violence at the MDC rally itself, youths attacked three men suspected of being Zanu-PF supporters, one of whom had to be rescued by police with dogs.

In spirit and in turnout, however, the contrast with Mr Mugabe's rally the day before was painful. Even though it was held at Highfield, close to Harare's biggest black township, the president's gathering mustered little more than 5,000 people. Loudspeakers were heard calling on bus drivers to bring more people.

Tony Gara, the Zanu-PF chairman for Harare province, apologised: "Your Excellency, you should know that your people work on Saturday and we also had very little time to arrange the rally."

Mr Gara sounded almost like an MDC supporter when he rubbed in one of the main factors in the economic slump which has seen Mr Mugabe's popularity plummet: "Some people also could not get here because of the fuel crisis," he told the president.

The small number who did come were treated to a history lesson about Zimbabwe's colonial past and accusations that the British were some of the most racist people on earth.

"Zimbabwe is a black man's land and therefore a black man has the right to determine its future. We must remember the problems we went through when they ruled this country" Mr Mugabe declared.

But his rhetoric - and his favourite slogan, "Zimbabwe will never be a colony again" - seemed out of touch: most people are more concerned that the country's economy began to turn down in the 1990s and that they now face an unemployment rate said to be as high as 55%, and annual inflation of around 74%.

"Jobs are the main question, not land," Nelson Chamisa, the MDC's national youth secretary, told yesterday's opposition rally.

The magnitude of Mr Mugabe's crisis today is hard to absorb. The MDC is a broader coalition even than the rainbow alliance forged by Nelson Mandela in South Africa.

It includes whites who fought in the army in support of Rhodesia's white-rule leader, Ian Smith, as well as liberals who fought against him. It has thousands of blacks who used to be with the Zanu-PF guerrillas in the fight that began in 1967 for majority rule, as well as others who were rivals or kept their heads down in the war.

There is room for caution. Urban areas produced the biggest No vote in February's referendum, and MDC supporters say a general election will not necessarily be a carbon copy of the referendum.

"Turnout was highest in the towns and if you break the result down regionally, 63 constituencies voted Yes for Mugabe and 57 voted No," said Brian Raftopoulos, the editor of the National Constitutional Assembly's journal, Agenda.

Heavy intimidation in the rural areas in the past month is designed to keep the MDC's vote down there, the party's officials say. What began as an effort by Zanu-PF to frighten black workers on white-owned farms through land invasion by squatters claiming to be veterans of the liberation war has moved into the so called communal areas where most rural blacks live.

But even there the mood seems to be changing. In Zimbabwe urban and rural life are intertwined. People talk of "the place where I stay" meaning their residence in town and of "home" meaning the village where their families come from and where parents or grandparents still live.

So the word gets out and is brought home to the countryside by bus and communal taxi every weekend.

webTitle: Summer of air traffic chaos looms

fields.headline: Summer of air traffic chaos looms
fields.standfirst: Four-hour computer breakdown at Heathrow control centre forces flight cancellations and long delays
fields.trailText: Air authorities were last night bracing themselves for the possibility of a summer of severe disruption to passengers due to an overload on the national air traffic control system.
fields.body:
Air authorities were last night bracing themselves for the possibility of a summer of severe disruption to passengers due to an overload on the national air traffic control system.

Senior managers at Britain's biggest air traffic control centre were last night trying to find the reason for the second breakdown of the computer in only eight days. Airlines were still struggling yesterday to return to normal, and some flights were up to eight hours late.

A spokesperson for National Air Traffic Services (Nats) said the system at West Drayton, near Heathrow, had been out for four hours on Saturday. An immediate investigation had been mounted but the fault had not been identified.

Passenger traffic into and out of Britain is increasing by 5% a year and the strain on the system grows inexorably, stretched to the limits during the summer holiday period. The computer that prints out information strips for air traffic control staff is nine years old, but is still considered to be up to date and safe.

The strips provide information to controllers on the position of all aircraft, including those flying over Britain from Europe and the Atlantic. On Saturday staff were forced to write out strips manually, resulting in controls being placed on the number of aircraft taking off and landing at British airports. The overall capacity of Britain's air traffic control system was cut by three quarters.

An industry source said the problem was computer overload. West Drayton controls not only the number of fights taking off and landing in London and the south-east, but the planes that fly over the UK.

The source said the number of flights rose considerably at this time of the year because of the sudden increase in holidays. "We have to face the fact that under some circumstances the computer cannot cope," the source said.

Nats said: "The safety of aircraft has at no time been threatened. We imposed the flow controls in order to guarantee safety."

The disruption highlights the need for the much-delayed £600m Swanwick control centre, in Hampshire, to start operating. The centre has been bedevilled by computer glitches and is still two years away from completion.

It should have opened in 1996 but problems with software have held it up. When it is fully commissioned it will take over all the work from West Drayton, which is to be shut down. But the handover will take several years and will not be completed until Nats is confident about the safety of each part of the plan and the training of staff.

Thousands of passengers were still stranded yesterday, more than 24 hours after the computer collapsed. One of those who had to turn back was William Hague, the Conservative leader, who had intended to fly to Portugal for a meeting with leaders of European centre-right parties.

All the big airlines, including British Airways and British Midlands, had to cancel flights, partly because aircraft were in the wrong place.

A spokeswoman at Heathrow said 316 flights - one in four - had been cancelled at the weekend. The low-cost airline, EasyJet, scrapped its entire operations on Saturday.

Electronic warning signs on all the approach roads to Heathrow flashed out the bad news yesterday: "Severe delays arrivals and departures."

Although the backlog was slowly cleared throughout the day, the entire departures floor of terminal one, the worst affected, was snarled up in huge check-in queues, snaking across the building and leading to baffled arguments where the lines crossed.

There were signs of tempers fraying among exhausted staff and travellers. The most fortunate had lived near enough to the airport to go home on Saturday night and return, but some had spent all night in the airport. They got away on the earliest flights, causing a knock-on build-up of people waiting for later flights.

The cafe repeatedly had to send for new supplies of mineral water, and several people fainted. By lunchtime on the hottest day of the year security staff were discreetly advising elderly passengers to take refuge in the comparative coolness of the room usually reserved for children travelling alone.

webTitle: Joseph, 8, in line to make online fortune

fields.headline: Joseph, 8, in line to make online fortune
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: An eight-year-old boy who gets just £1 a week pocket money could become e-commerce's first mini-millionaire, according to his father, Chris, 41.
fields.body:
An eight-year-old boy who gets just £1 a week pocket money could become e-commerce's first mini-millionaire, according to his father, Chris, 41.

Joseph Allen helped conceive the online betting operation betachance.com, which opened for business two weeks ago. The youngster, who lives in Trowbridge, Wiltshire, came up with the idea of putting the firm online while his father was giving him a bath.

Now, with punters already flooding in, there are plans to float the company on the stock market. And because Joseph was awarded shares for his part in the firm's foundation, he could soon see his pocket money rise to well over £1m if it becomes a plc.

Betachance.com is based offshore on the island of Mauritius, and transactions are tax free.

The venture was drawn up by Mr Allen and his brother Godfrey, who is a racing expert, but it was only after Joseph's suggestion that it was turned into an e-commerce project.

The shares awarded to Joseph have been put it a trust fund and he will be unable to touch the money until he is 18.

He already knows what he wants to spend the money on.

He said: "I'd like to buy Manchester United and a motorbike. I'd also like to get some Lego for my brother."

fields.headline: Heat wave
fields.standfirst:
High temperatures bring out sunseekers
The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands of people headed for seaside resorts yesterday as parts of Britain enjoyed their hottest June day since 1996.
fields.body:
Thousands of people headed for seaside resorts yesterday as parts of Britain enjoyed their hottest June day since 1996.

"It was a very wide area of extremely hot weather," said a Met Office spokesman. He added that the high temperatures would last until tomorrow, followed by rain and showers bringing temperatures back to normal levels.

Parks were packed as temperatures reached 30.8C (87F) in London. Leeds had its hottest June day for five years with 30.7C and temperatures reached 29C (84F) in the Midlands and northern England and Wales.

An estimated 27,000 cyclists - many in fancy dress - battled the heat during the annual 58-mile journey between London and Brighton in aid of the British Heart Foundation. In Brighton itself, thousands flocked to the beach to make the most of the weather. There were similar scenes all along the south coast and in the north, sunseekers packed the sands at Blackpool.

The AA said roads heading to seaside resorts were very busy compared to Saturday where most people stayed at home to watch the football.

The London Eye was closed for several hours after it developed a technical problem around midday. "We would normally leave passengers on the Eye while engineers investigated the problem but because of the intense heat, we decided to get them down," said a spokeswoman.

fields.headline: Worm's eye
fields.trailText: Cynics had long held that the name of each government department marks a point of surrender, so agriculture presides over the collapse of farming, defence over the shrinkage of Britain's military potency, education over the spread of illiteracy and so forth. All very flip, no doubt, and not very helpful.
fields.body:
Cynics had long held that the name of each government department marks a point of surrender, so agriculture presides over the collapse of farming, defence over the shrinkage of Britain's military potency, education over the spread of illiteracy and so forth. All very flip, no doubt, and not very helpful.

But even the staunchest big government idealist must shudder at: Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions. Of the four main constituents, "department" just about passes muster, but "environment, transport and the regions" represent three giant tombstones to hopes buried by money power and corporate rapacity.

By rights, the DETR ought to have blazed a trail in taking care of what Schumacher called the meta-economy, dealing with the questions people ask after they've had answers to "am I safe?" (Home Office) and "is my money safe?" (Treasury). One can be safe-ish and rich (in a sense) with ribbon development, gridlocked roads and bombed-out industrial areas, but that is scarcely a future worth striving for.

As it is, the fate of the DETR recalls Coral Bell's recessional in New Society in November 1980 for the Carter presidency: "Why did so plentiful a sowing of good intentions produce so slight a harvest of beneficent results - and so bothersome a crop of incidental weeds?"

Well, quite. In the DETR's case, the answer is relatively straightforward and oddly comforting for those terrified by the alleged might of "the huge bureaucratic government machine". The department remit put it up against the greediest and most powerful industrial lobbies in Britain (with the possible exception of the bloated Billy Bunters in defence and civil aviation): property development, civil engineering, road transport and the privatised "railway" companies.

In addition, these enemies had huge passive support from that amorphous "civilian population" of companies, large and small, that - oblivious to all the flim-flam about "the death of distance" - insist on the vital need to base themselves in the south-east.

This is roughly the equivalent of facing in battle the Paras, the foreign legion and the Russian army, all on the same side and all enjoying the backing of a faceless guerrilla movement of the calibre of the Vietcong. No one in public life ought even to think of taking on this mob unless they have unflinching backing from the top, and this has been all too obviously lacking in the DETR's case.

Just as the City is making it plain to the Treasury that - regulation bill or no bill - it is not prepared to be regulated, so the concrete kings and lorry barons have swatted the DETR's well-meaning but ineffectual attempts to bring them under control.

Thus there is no mystery to the 860,000 homes being dumped on the home counties, nor to the U-turns on road building and traffic congestion. That nothing much seems to emerge from "national rail summits" ought to fall short of shocking.

The DETR was outgunned and outfought at every turn, as it was bound to be. It lost. More to the point, so did we.

webTitle: Blair switches trusted advisers to Millbank to prevent feuds

fields.headline: Blair switches trusted advisers to Millbank to prevent feuds
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour has stepped up its reorganisation of its much criticised communications empire ahead of the general election with two trusted Downing Street aides moving to party headquarters at Millbank.
fields.body:
Labour has stepped up its reorganisation of its much criticised communications empire ahead of the general election with two trusted Downing Street aides moving to party headquarters at Millbank.

The move is designed to prevent personality feuds at Millbank, improve communication between party and government, and protect Alastair Campbell from Tory claims that he intends to put most energy towards re-election, though his £96,000 salary will still be paid by the taxpayer.

Mr Campbell, as the prime minister's chief spokesman, announced last week that he would pull back from daily lobby briefing of journalists. Yesterday Andrew Lansley, the shadow cabinet minister, claimed the taxpayer would now fund Mr Campbell's effort to secure Labour's re-election.

Charlie Whelan, the former press secretary to Gordon Brown, the chancellor, yesterday echoed the view. "Since Alastair will now be spending most of his time working on the general election strategy he ought to be paid by the Labour party, not the taxpayer."

Mr Campbell says he will be spending more time on strategic government plans, covering the spending review, transport, and the NHS.

The two special advisers moving to Millbank are the former BBC journalist, Lance Price, and Pat MacFadden, who was recently appointed deputy chief of staff at Downing Street; he is a veteran union fixer. Phil Murphy, director of communications at Millbank, switches to Downing Street. Mr Price will take over Mr Murphy's job.

Mr MacFadden, a former adviser to Donald Dewar, the Scottish first minister, is seen as one of the few who can overcome the rivalries in the relationship between Mr Brown and Peter Mandelson. Mr Brown is overseeing strategy in the election campaign and Mandelson implementation, but in practice the distinction does not work.

It is known that some Blairites are worried about lack of support at Millbank. Mr Brown has installed his widely liked lieutenant, Douglas Alexander, in the team; and Mr Price is seen as a possible counterbalance.

The dual appointment is also a sign that Downing Street is concerned about the recent local and European election setbacks, as well as the decision to prevent Ken Livingstone standing as Labour nominee for London mayor.

The shift in personnel came as John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, urged cabinet colleagues to drop some of the "spin" culture that has included phrases such as "boom and bust" and "for the many, not the few" - soundbites often used by Tony Blair.

Mr Brown is overseeing strategy in the election campaign and Mandelson implementation, but in practice the distinction does not work. It is known that some Blairites are worried about lack of support at Millbank. Mr Brown has installed his widely liked lieutenant, Douglas Alexander, in the team; and Mr Price is seen as a possible counterbalance. The dual appointment is also a sign that Downing Street is concerned about the recent local and European election setbacks, as well as the decision to prevent Ken Livingstone standing as Labour nominee for London mayor. The shift in personnel came as John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, urged cabinet colleagues to drop some of the "spin" culture that has included phrases such as "boom and bust" and "for the many, not the few" - soundbites often used by Tony Blair.

fields.headline: Defeating poverty
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain sets out her vision for improving standards of living in the world's poorest nations
Road the the manifesto: special report
fields.trailText: The Guardian's deputy foreign editor Victoria Brittain sets out her vision for improving standards of living in the world's poorest nations
fields.body:
We live in a world of extremes. Prosperity has reached levels that would have been unthinkable to our grandparents, yet one in five people lives in desperate poverty. In an age of breathtaking advances in medical technology, more than 12 million children die each year from easily preventable infectious diseases. In the age of the computer, 800 million adults are unable to read and write.

Poverty can be defeated. But the war against poverty is being lost because of the obscene gaps in opportunity and income that separate rich and poor. We are committed to closing these gaps - and to projecting our commitment to social justice on to the international stage. We will place poverty reduction at the heart of all government policies, pursuing 'joined-up' policies in aid, trade, investment and foreign affairs.

Aid has a vital role to play in projecting our values. Over the past five years we have made a start by reversing the disgraceful cuts in our development co-operation budget made by the last Conservative government. But more needs to be done. In the lifetime of the next parliament we shall increase our aid from the current level of 0.23 of GNP to the UN target of 0.7 - adding £4bn to the aid budget.

British taxpayers have a right to know that aid money is being well spent. We should work to improve the quality of our aid programme so that it makes a real difference to the poor. This means spending more on areas like basic health and girls' education - and less on technical assistance. As part of our commitment to poverty, we should create an independent aid review division to evaluate our impact and make public the findings.

Education is an area at the centre of the government's policy for social regeneration - and not just in Britain. At the World Education Forum in Dakar, governments agreed to develop a global initiative aimed at getting 125 million children into school by 2015. We should demand that this promise is translated into action, using our influence at the G8 to mobilise an additional $4bn a year for education in poor countries. Britain should make an immediate 'down payment' in the first year of the new government through a £500m increase in education spending.

Many of the world's poorest countries, especially in Africa, continue to be crippled by debt problems. Britain has led the way in tackling this problem, but we have to do more. So far, only five countries have benefited from the Heavily Indebted Poor Countries Initiative. We must demand more rapid implementation, and work to ensure that debt relief is linked to poverty reduction.

New debt problems are emerging. In East Asia and Latin America debt owed to private creditors such as commercial banks and investment funds are destroying national development efforts. We should demand a new debt relief initiative under which private creditors are required to reduce their demands on countries where debt is undermining basic services such as health and education. Our message to the financial markets; people before profits.

Global markets need global governance .The IMF, the World Bank and the WTO are remote, undemocratic, unaccountable and incapable of responding to the challenge of poverty reduction.

Reform of the IMF should be an immediate priority. Regions such as sub-Saharan Africa, where IMF programmes dominate economic policy, have less than three per cent of voting rights, while rich countries have more than 50 per cent. IMF programmes consistently result in deep cuts in health, education and employment.

International trade is vital to increased prosperity in the poorest nations. Yet world trade rule - and the World Trade Organisation - is rigged against the poor. Protectionism in rich countries costs poor countries $700bn a year - seven times the amount they receive in aid. There should be better market access for all developing countries, and immediate duty-free access for the poorest.

Powerful trans-national companies (TNCs) are benefiting from the patent protection provided by WTO rules on intellectual property. These rules are putting new technologies and essential drugs beyond the means of the poorest countries. A new balance needs to be struck between the rights of investors and the needs of the poor. The period of patent protection should be reduced from 20 years to 10 years.

Foreign investment through trans-national companies is one of the main links between rich and poor countries in today's global economy. British companies are major actors. TNCs have the potential to contribute to poverty reduction through investment and technology transfer. All too often, however, they are guilty of violating human rights and following unacceptable employment practices. A code of conduct for corporate behaviour is needed.

Legislation to prohibit British arms brokers from operating in the poorest countries should be introduced and Britain should work towards an international code of conduct aimed at preventing the sale of weapons to countries that abuse human rights.

Aid pledges

1 Spend £4bn more annually on aid

2 £500m increase in education spending, especially on girls, in the first year of the new government

3 Reform of the IMF

4 Ensure no more use of sanctions which hit the poor, as in Iraq

5 New debt initiative

webTitle: UN urged to try leader of rebels

fields.headline: UN urged to try leader of rebels
fields.standfirst:
Sierra Leone wants Sankoh in dock of international court, as more fighting exposes deteriorating security situation

Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: Sierra Leone has asked the UN to set up an international tribunal to try the captured rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, for crimes against humanity. But the plan faces obstacles, including uncertainty about the legal standing of an amnesty granted to the Revolutionary United Front leader last year.
fields.body:
Sierra Leone has asked the UN to set up an international tribunal to try the captured rebel leader, Foday Sankoh, for crimes against humanity. But the plan faces obstacles, including uncertainty about the legal standing of an amnesty granted to the Revolutionary United Front leader last year.

President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah has written a confidential letter to the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, requesting the creation of a tribunal with foreign judges in Freetown. The government has declined to discuss the contents of the letter publicly. Sierra Leone's justice minister and attorney general, Solomon Berewa, said an announcement will probably be made later this week.

Among the options being considered by the government is a joint tribunal of Sierra Leonean and international judges. This might lead to other charges against Mr Sankoh.

A UN tribunal would be limited to trying breaches of international law, principally crimes against humanity. The maximum penalty it can impose is life imprisonment.

A Sierra Leonean court could hear other accusations, including diamond smuggling, illegal weapons purchases and an alleged coup. It could also impose the death penalty. The rebel leader has already escaped the hangman once after being sentenced to death two years ago but reprieved by peace negotiations.

Among the issues to be resolved is whether the amnesty granted Mr Sankoh under the peace accords signed in Lomé a year ago still stands. Some lawyers and human rights activists argue that the RUF's repeated breaches of the peace agreement - including continued killings and rapes even before the resumption of war last month, the illegal importation of tens of millions of dollars worth of weapons, and their failure to disarm and demobilise - negates their leader's amnesty.

That would leave Mr Sankoh open to charges of crimes against humanity for the RUF's strategy of murder, hacking the arms and legs off civilians, mass rape and the abduction of children for use as sex slaves and soldiers.

Other lawyers say that the amnesty has no validity in international law, and merely protects Mr Sankoh from prosecution in his own country. But some argue that the issue is too complex and that the rebel leader should be tried for crimes committed since the peace deal. The RUF continued to murder and rape long after the agreement was signed.

From judgements at the Rwanda tribunal, prosecutors would not have to prove that Mr Sankoh ordered his rebels to commit atrocities, merely that he knew of them and failed to try to stop them.

The siting of the court will also be contentious. Some UN officials favour locating it outside Sierra Leone but the experience of the Rwanda tribunal, in Tanzania, has not been good. The court has been isolated from Rwanda and the victims of the genocide, diminishing its impact on the society where the crimes occurred.

The Rwanda tribunal has been painfully slow and riddled with incompetence and corruption. It took three years to bring the first accused to trial and has yet to try any leading organisers in its custody, six years after the genocide.

If Mr Sankoh ends up before a local court, the Sierra Leone police say they have a solid case for prosecuting him for illegal diamond and weapons deals. The government says it has evidence proving that he was plotting a coup last month. There is also the matter of 20 people shot dead by his guards during a demonstration outside his house in May.

The government also has to decide what to do with 121 RUF soldiers and officials being held under presidential emergency powers. Amnesty International and other human rights groups have called for all RUF leaders responsible for atrocities to be put on trial, not just Mr Sankoh.

The government has yet to state its position but it is keen to keep open the option of negotiating with some rebel commanders as part of its twin strategies - military and political - to end the war.

fields.headline: US joins row on Lebanon
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The United States has stepped in to resolve a dispute between Lebanon and the UN over Israel's troop withdrawal from southern Lebanon, the government said yesterday.
fields.body:
The United States has stepped in to resolve a dispute between Lebanon and the UN over Israel's troop withdrawal from southern Lebanon, the government said yesterday.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, called the Lebanese president, Emile Lahoud, several times to discuss his refusal to accept a UN verification that Israel has completed its withdrawal.

Lebanon says Israel still occupies pockets of its territory. Yesterday Lebanese and UN cartographers set out to inspect disputed points on the border.

Mr Lahoud denied reports that his government had accepted the UN certification following his conversations with Ms Albright. "These reports are totally untrue. Lebanon insisted that it will not give its consent before the [Israeli] withdrawal is first verified by its team and the UN team."

Lebanon's rejection of the verification is a setback for the UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, who is in the Middle East to discuss the next steps to achieve regional peace.

webTitle: Milburn unveils drive to cut infant mortality

fields.headline: Milburn unveils drive to cut infant mortality
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: A target to cut health inequality by reducing infant mortalty both by region and health authority is likely to form a central part of the national plan for the NHS due to be unveiled shortly by the health secretary Alan Milburn.
fields.body:
A target to cut health inequality by reducing infant mortalty both by region and health authority is likely to form a central part of the national plan for the NHS due to be unveiled shortly by the health secretary Alan Milburn.

The plan was revealed as Peter Lilley, the former Conservative minister, prepared to publish today an alternative blueprint for NHS reform giv ing individual patients an unfettered right to choose their hospital and consultant.

Mr Lilley's proposals, in a pamphlet from the normally left-of-centre Demos think tank, also call for tables of hospital performance similar to those which have helped to create competition among state schools.

Mr Milburn already has targets to cut coronory and heart disease as well as the number of deaths caused by mental illness. He is said to have been struck by evidence that infant mortality varies enormously across the country, with class a major contributor.

The figures, from April last year, show the 10 health authorities with the worst infant mortality rates per 100,000 births: Coventry 9.4, Bradford 9.0, Sandwell 8.8, Barnsley 8.6, Lambeth 8.2, Kensington and North Westminster 8.1, Walsall 8.1, Birmingham 8.0, Rotherham 8.0 and Leeds 7.7.

The lowest rates are in relatively affluent areas: Solihull 2.7, Cornwall and Isles of Scilly 2.8, Isle of Wight 3.3, South Staffordshire 3.6, Kingston and Richmond 3.6, North Hertfordshire 3.7, East Surrey, 3.7, North and Mid-Hampshire 3.7, West Kent 4, West Sussex 4. The national average is 5.9%, above the EU figure of 5.7%.

Studies seen by Mr Milburn suggest that Sweden -with similar class inequalities - does not suffer the same inequalities in infant mortality, suggesting poverty need not inevitably lead to higher infant mortality. Major contributory factors are the child's birth weight, the mother's diet and her propensity to smoke.

Ministers believe they may need to offer more than advice to pregnant women, and may broach a major extension of pre-natal care, possibly in the context of sure start, the scheme to make children ready for school by the age of four.

Sure start already has a target to increase average birthweights in each area. Ministers are looking at grants to im prove diet, as well as extending visiting periods of midwives from the current three weeks.

Mr Lilley said he had left the Tory front bench last year after a "high octane row" over his scepticism about expanding private provision in healthcare. His pamphlet opposes privatisation of the NHS, but calls for real competition between hospitals, giving patients and their GPs enough information about performance and waiting times to make a sensible choice.

NHS patients would continue to be funded by the taxpayer and public money would follow them to whichever hospital they chose. GPs would become advocates to secure the best treatment for their patients. Better hospitals would expand, putting pressure on the rest to raise standards.

Mr Lilley contrasts his approach to the "command and control" approach of Tory and Labour. The Conservative reforms of 1991 gave GPs little scope to choose treatment.

Mr Lilley was supported by 24 neurosurgeons in a "statement of concern" to the department of health. They said many patients suffering from movement disorders, spinal injuries and severe chronic pain could no longer obtain treatment outside their local area.

"We have gone backwards since last year and the year before," said the neurosurgeons, backed by the Parkinson's Disease Society.

webTitle: Granada takes a Chance to beef up float

fields.headline: Granada takes a Chance to beef up float
fields.trailText: Granada yesterday announced the appointment of former BSkyB executive David Chance to the board of its media division in the lead-up to a £7bn stock market listing.
fields.body:
Granada yesterday announced the appointment of former BSkyB executive David Chance to the board of its media division in the lead-up to a £7bn stock market listing.

Mr Chance, a former deputy managing director of BSkyB, was credited alongside his then boss Sam Chisholm with turning round the fortunes of Rupert Murdoch's pay-television business in the mid-1990s. The appointment as a non-executive director will add weight to the board ahead of the float.

Granada Media will include the ITV franchises for Granada, Yorkshire, London Weekend and Tyne Tees as well a half share in OnDigital, stakes in ITN, Scottish Media Group and Australia's Seven Network. It will also produce 6,000 hours of programming a year including Coronation Street, Blind Date and Cold Feet.

In addition, Granada has announced that Nigel Rich, the former Trafalgar House chief executive who now chairs property group Hamptons, is also to join as a non-executive director. "We have very ambitious plans to grow Granada Media as it becomes an independent media group and both David and Nigel have a wide range of skills and experience to help us," said Charles Allen, who will be executive chairman of Granada Media.

Granada expects to float 20% of the media division by mid-July in time for trade secretary Stephen Byers' judgment on the consolidation of ITV.

The spin-off will allow Granada to raise cash for an attempted takeover of either United News & Media or Carlton Communications and will also provide paper currency in the form of Granada Media shares.

The competition commission delivered its report to Mr Byers on Friday and he is expected to give his verdict in around three weeks.

The flotation of Granada Media follows the merger of the company with Compass Hospitality to beef up its catering and leisure business. The merger with Compass met with a hostile reception from investors but shares in both Granada and Compass have been steadily recovering.

Mr Chance and Mr Chisholm are also renowned for pocketing £12m after their contracts to advise football's Premiership on the sale of broadcasting rights were cancelled without doing a day's work.

fields.headline: Vivendi seals merger
fields.standfirst: Old and new media join forces as Seagram falls to the French
fields.trailText: The creation of a $100bn (£66bn) media powerhouse will move toward its end game today as a trio of board meetings at Vivendi, Canal Plus and Seagram are held to approve the terms of their agreed merger.
fields.body:
The creation of a $100bn (£66bn) media powerhouse will move toward its end game today as a trio of board meetings at Vivendi, Canal Plus and Seagram are held to approve the terms of their agreed merger.

A statement issued by French media and utility group Vivendi yesterday said that the negotiations "have now entered their final stage". Meetings between the companies went on all weekend and the aim is to make a formal announcement tomorrow.

The agreement is in the mould of the AOL-Time Warner merger at the beginning of the year in which the old and new media worlds collided. Seagram's Universal music publishing business is the largest in the world and includes artists Boyzone, Elton John and Shania Twain, while its film business has scored hits with The Mummy, Gladiator and U-571.

Its television arm produces shows including Xena Warrior Princess and has a library of programmes such as Kojak, Murder She Wrote and Miami Vice.

The business will provide a wealth of content for Vivendi's pay-TV distribution networks, including Canal Plus in France in which it already holds a 49% stake. The content though will also underpin the development of Vivendi's new media interests including its Vizzavi internet portal which is a joint venture with Vodafone-AirTouch.

Vivendi also owns a number of mobile phone networks, including SFR through Cegetel in France which could be used to carry music and entertainment.

The agreement is likely to see Vivendi paying around $33bn for Seagram in shares with the combined group expected to be renamed Vivendi Universal.

Jean-Marie Messier, the chief executive of Vivendi, said last week that Seagram would sell its $9bn drinks business as part of the deal. Front runners for the drinks division are expected to be Allied Domecq, Bacardi and Pernod Ricard.

Since he took the helm of what was then known as Générale des Eaux in 1996, Mr Messier has reshaped the former utility as a media and communications business. The company is preparing to float 40% of the water arm and analysts expect it eventually to exit the business entirely.

webTitle: A lot of interest, but not all of it welcome

fields.headline: A lot of interest, but not all of it welcome
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: "Good morning, Mr Hamdy. My name's Debbie and I'm calling from Another Sales Company. I recently read about Rools and thought that our recruitment/ advertising/ marketing/ body-piercing services would be ideal for your business."
fields.body:
"Good morning, Mr Hamdy. My name's Debbie and I'm calling from Another Sales Company. I recently read about Rools and thought that our recruitment/ advertising/ marketing/ body-piercing services would be ideal for your business."

Yes, there is a downside to developing a business profile. Since securing our investment and going public with our intention to launch, we have had plenty of direct experience of unsolicited callers - both the welcome and unwelcome.

The most dramatic twist is that we appear to have picked up a corporate cyber-stalker along the way. For the past three weeks, a shadowy individual (yes, we think we know his identity) has been trying to get us to hand over sensitive commercial documentation relating to the business, including our business plan and marketing strategy.

The stalker's tactics would be almost amusing if they were not so obviously aimed at harming our business. To date, the individual has tried impersonating a personal friend of a high-profile investor, an employee of another one of our investors and, just last week, even one of us, in an attempt to get the relevant information - in the latest case from one of our marketing agencies.

Of course, the stalker only ever communicates by email and asks for all replies to be directed to a second anonymous email address or fax number. Thankfully, all the attempts have been relatively clumsy and we have been able to alert our various business partners - including our lawyers - to this piece of skulduggery.

Odd interest in Rools does not stop there. We were called by a businessman last week who claimed he had a new and unique marketing tool that was perfectly suited to the youth market.

It would boost our customer numbers by hundreds of thousands. It could not fail. But that was all he would tell us.

No more information would be made available. We were expected to buy into the idea there and then.

The idea of doing a bit of digging into the businessman's past proved irresistible. It threw up some vague and thoroughly dubious story about his supposed past career in international business development in the defence industry.

Maybe one day we'll get round to the arms trade, but there are other markets to crack first.

The upside of all the interest in Rools is that we have received valuable inquiries from companies that we are now looking to work with.

For example, the whole team is now learning an additional foreign language after the manager of a language school had the initiative to write to us subsequent to an article on the business.

We have become rather adept at filtering interest from outside to ensure that we focus on the things that have the potential to add real value to Rools. It is a natural learning process, but it still eats time.

Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are the co-founders of Rools.com, a service that enables teenagers to buy online without a credit card
