fields.headline: Alternative guide to 21st century prosperity
fields.trailText: The alternative Mansion House speech does not have quite the same cachet as the real thing. The City's elite was not hanging on my every word, no avid interest from the financial wire services, no loving cup being passed round.
fields.body:
The alternative Mansion House speech does not have quite the same cachet as the real thing. The City's elite was not hanging on my every word, no avid interest from the financial wire services, no loving cup being passed round.

But like a certain brand of lager, my address to the New Economics Foundation tried to reach the parts that Gordon Brown's failed to touch. Although stability, productivity and monetary policy are important, so are more basic questions such as sharing the value of common resources as a basis for public revenue.

My speech began with the manifold threats to the existing tax base, including:

In a globalised economy, taxes on incomes and business profits are being reduced to attract mobile capital and people.

In ageing societies, a shrinking working-age population will resist levels of direct taxes necessary to support a growing population of the economically inactive.

Sales of products and services downloaded directly from the internet - music, films, pictures, games, information of all kinds - will reduce governments' ability to collect revenue from customs duties, VAT and other sales taxes. The internet will make it easier to shift personal earnings and business profits to low-tax regimes and tax havens.

Already the Exchequer loses tax of at least £20bn a year from the £400bn invested in tax havens like the Channel Islands and Isle of Man. More than $6 trillion is held in tax havens worldwide. This - and the huge amount of tax evasion and criminal money laundering that goes with it - can only be tackled by shifting the tax base to things like land that cannot be transferred to tax havens. There are also positive arguments for a "tax shift". The idea, attracting support in many countries, is to tax bads, not goods, and to tax waste, not work.

In practice this means increasing taxes on the ownership and use of common resources, including land, energy and the capacity of the environment to absorb pollution, and reducing taxes on useful enterprise and work. For example, the EU's proposed carbon-energy tax would have yielded the double dividend of reducing CO 2 emissions and reducing taxes on employment.

The fact is that today's tax system is perverse. By bearing heavily on employment and on rewards for work and enterprise, and lightly on the use of common resources, it encourages overuse of natural resources and under-employment of human resources.

This is damaging - economically, socially, and environmentally. It seems nonsensical to tax the rewards people earn from the value they add by helping to meet society's needs and wants, and not to make people pay for the value they subtract by using or monopolising common resources.

And a system which makes it easier for people and businesses, the richer they are, to minimise their tax obligations is clearly unjust. Using tax havens and setting up "mixer companies" in Luxembourg, to enable leading British companies to save £4bn a year from UK tax on their foreign earnings, are just two examples.

The value of common resources provides urgently needed new sources of public revenue. These are resources whose value is due to nature and the activities and decisions of society as a whole, and not to the efforts or skill of particular individuals or organisations.

One example is the radio spectrum. A recent auction of licences to use it for mobile phone services over the next 20 years raised £22.5bn. Another is the value of land. When the route of the Jubilee line in London was published, the prospect of improved access raised the value of properties near it and the owners received a windfall.

They had done nothing and paid nothing for it. Society had given them a free lunch. A site-value tax on land could replace existing taxes to the tune of £50bn to £90bn a year. Similarly, the New Economics Foundation report Creating New Money, published last week, proposes that the value of new non-cash money - now printed and put into circulation by commercial banks as profit-making loans - should be collected as public revenue. It calculates that this would raise about £45bn a year, equivalent to a reduction of 12p on income tax, and that today's arrangements give the banks supernormal profits of about £21bn a year - a nice free lunch.

The aggregate annual value of these common resources is very great. Sharing it among all citizens as public revenue, rather than leaving it enclosed as private profit, could replace many existing taxes. Think of it as predistribution, not redistribution.

And think of predistribution as a recipe for an economically prosperous, socially inclusive, ecologically sustainable 21st century world.

ames Robertson was a co-founder of the New Economics Foundation in the mid-1980s.

The text of the alternative Mansion House speech is at: New Economics Foundation

fields.headline: On the warpath
fields.standfirst:
Assad's heir pledges to continue Syrian anti-corruption drive
Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Syrian government warned yesterday that it will pursue its campaign against the corruption endemic in its society when the 40-day period of mourning for the late president, Hafez al-Assad, ends.
fields.body:
The Syrian government warned yesterday that it will pursue its campaign against the corruption endemic in its society when the 40-day period of mourning for the late president, Hafez al-Assad, ends.

The warning came as the president in waiting, Bashar al-Assad, consolidated his hold on power at the first meeting of the ruling Ba'ath party congress for 15 years. He was elected party general secretary yesterday - a post his father held for 30 years - and is expected to see his key supporters elected to strategic party jobs.

The congress, which is charged with finding a way to revitalise the country's stagnant economy, discussed a report yesterday on the massive corruption problems and their subsequent drain on public resources.

The anti-corruption drive being led by Bashar had been gathering momentum until the death of the president nine days ago; it had netted many senior politicians, the most prominent being Mahmoud Zoubi, who had been prime minis ter for 13 years until he retired in March.

Politicians and officials distort the economy by taking cuts from business contracts, and from extensive smuggling between Syria and the Lebanon. The amounts siphoned off run into millions of pounds; one unusually outspoken member of the Syrian parliament, Riad Seif, estimated yesterday that the "commission" taken on some public projects amounted to 30% of the projects' worth.

"It starts from the top," he said, though stressing he did not include the late president or Bashar, a view grudgingly shared on the street. Mr Riad blamed corruption at the top on greed and at the lower levels - among judges, policeman and other officials - on the very low salary scales.

The former prime minister, Zoubi, died last month while under investigation. The public view was that he was killed, but the Syrian government insisted he had committed suicide.

"The commander of police went to his house in the Dumor suburb where he was playing cards," a Syrian official said. "He was presented with a charge sheet saying that he had to present himself the next day for investigation. He went upstairs to his bedroom and shot himself. He was dead when he arrived in hospital."

The official claimed he had creamed off millions of pounds during his time in office. Others accused of corruption include Bashir al-Najar, the former head of Syrian intelligence; Mohammed Haider, the former deputy prime minister; and the former transport minister, Mufid Abdul Kerim.

For Bashar to engage in anything more than a token drive against corrupt officials will be risky. A confrontation with ministers, police and army commanders taking paybacks could spark a rival power bid, or even a coup attempt.

A serious anti-corruption programme may only be possible when, or if, he entrenches himself in power.

But, according to one well-placed source in Syria, Bashar has already won the all-important backing of Asif Shauket, the commander of the military secret police, who is one of the main powers in the land and is married to the heir apparent's sister.

fields.headline: The low down
fields.standfirst: Electromagnetic radiation
fields.trailText: Electromagnetic radiation
fields.body:
The practice of wearing a pendant around the neck as a protection against malign influences has yet to gain widespread acceptance in the office. So when a product comes on to the market promising protection from low-level electromagnetic radiation, staff might be inclined to be sceptical. When told that its active agent is a small coil of copper wire, they might even be inclined to laugh. Indeed one of the directors of the company developing the device, the Q-Link, admits that "our theories are not accepted by a wide section of the scientific community".

But what support the device does have appears impressive. Professor William Tiller of Stanford University and Professor Norman Shealy, a leading US neurosurgeon, are due to publish favourable research on the effects of the anti-radiation charm.

Certainly the effects of electromagnetic radiation emitted by computers and other office machinery is something that troubles many environmental scientists. There is evidence that it has an adverse effect on the immune system, making users more prone to colds, headaches and stress.

As a discipline, environmental science is reluctant to draw its conclusions from simple cause and effect. But it is often the case that one simple action will have an enormously wide impact. An office building in Glasgow halved absenteeism by altering its windows so that they could be opened and shut by individual employees. Similar results have been obtained by screening out magnetic fields.

The technology of the Q-Link is slightly more contentious than that of the screening devices used in such experiments. Commercial secrecy also inhibits scientific discussion. Nevertheless, it is worth noting that controversial scientific innovations often take some time to be accepted by the mainstream.

fields.headline: Desktop icons
fields.standfirst: No 24: the hole punch
fields.trailText: No 24: the hole punch
fields.body:
Never underestimate the power of the hole-punch. Reputations have depended on them - at least in the classroom. Those who carefully hole-punched geography handouts to fit perfectly into spotless folders were invariably on the fast-track to becoming head prefect. (Their peers who preferred holes in maths textbooks and school blazers, it's safe to say, were not.)

Fast forward a few years to the office, and we are still obeying those same primaeval laws of the "punch". The world will forever divide, after all, into those who file religiously, and those who prefer their paper by the mountain. The former are particularly fond of ring reinforcers, little stickers attached to each side of the paper to reinforce the hole. The latter prefer opening the back of the hole-punch and scattering tiny circles of paper to the four winds.

Hole-punching is highly technical. Should you opt for the Continental four-hole, or the British two? Do you require a guide arm to measure where to put the hole? And when filing, do you opt for the purist's ring binder, or the serious filer's lever arch? Not content with punching five or so sheets at a time? You need a heavy-duty hole-punch, a modern industrial marvel that can take up to 24 sheets at once. One manufacturer alone lists 16 different types of hole-punch.

Whatever your requirements, the puncher people have thought of them. The less robust of wrist may want to opt for levers, and for the particularly deskproud, a range of colours is available. It is the humble hole- punch you have to thank for the fact that papers can be kept in order; without it, filing anarchy is only a step away.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Observer
fields.body:
Observer

Britain can afford to join the euro now that the pound is nearing the psychologically important three German mark barrier, according to one of Britain's most influential industrialists. Nick Reilly, chief of car maker Vauxhall and head of the economics committee of the Confederation of British Industry said Britain should prepare to adopt the single currency and the British government should send out a clear message that it intends to join. His call echoed the verdict of the monetary policy committee's DeAnne Julius that "economically it could go in".

Sunday Times

The fund management group Phillips & Drew has told Greg Hutchings, chairman of the buns-to-guns group, Tomkins , that he should resign. But Hutchings is refusing to go and in response P&D is organising a near £2.5bn hostile buy-in led by Bob Mackenzie, former chief executive of National Car Parks. Hutchings is ready for a showdown with P&D, which has cut its Tomkins stake from 6m shares to 4m shares.

Durlacher is in merger talks with a Germany company backed by the Barclay brothers to create a pan-European technology group worth £550m. Geoffrey Chamberlain, Durlacher's chairman is understood to be holding talks with Value Management Research , a fund manager and online broker.

Corus , the steelmaker, has warned ministers further big job cuts are on the way, following its announcement of nearly 1,500 redundancies on Friday. One option being studied by the former British Steel is the partial closure of its giant Llanwern plant, which employs 3,000 people in South Wales. The associated tinplate works at Ebbw Vale, with 2,000 staff, could also be hit.

Sunday Telegraph

Trevor Hemmings, the reclusive multi-millionaire businessman who own the Blackpool Tower, is poised to buy Littlewoods Pools from the Moores family for up to £170m. Hemway , one of Hemmings' private firms, is in exclusive negotiations to acquire the business after beating off a series of competitors.

More than 50,000 British private investors applied for shares in Deutsche Telekom in the third tranche of the big German telecommunication company's global share sale. The shares were priced on Saturday night at €66.50 (£42.30), valuing the offer at €15bn - well above the value originally anticipated.

Sunday Business

Liberty International chairman Donald Gordon has staged a dramatic attempt to prevent rival property group British Land taking control of the company. Gordon has contacted Standard Bank , the South African company which agreed to sell its 29.9% share in Liberty to British Land for £541m two weeks ago, offering to better its terms.

fields.headline: Wanted: economical economists
fields.trailText: The cash-strapped Treasury has become the victim of its own iron control on public spending by being forced to recruit economists from Australia, New Zealand, Spain and Ethiopia to meet the rising demand for number crunchers across Whitehall.
fields.body:
The cash-strapped Treasury has become the victim of its own iron control on public spending by being forced to recruit economists from Australia, New Zealand, Spain and Ethiopia to meet the rising demand for number crunchers across Whitehall.

Faced with a shrinking pool of qualified graduates from British universities and stiff competition from the better-paid private sector, the Treasury said it had just appointed its first Ethiopian recruit, following a worldwide trawl for expert advisers.

The Treasury said it was using publications such as the Economist and the Guardian to find economists, and was concentrating on countries with lower salaries than Britain to compensate for the increasing attraction to UK graduates of higher-paid jobs in the private sector. "We don't get many Germans applying," said one senior official, "because of the relative wage levels."

Problems have become more acute over the past decade with the demand for economists in Whitehall up by 40% since 1989 but the supply has been shrinking as a result of the increased popularity of university business studies courses.

Treasury sources admitted that the government is facing a classic economic problem of demand exceeding supply, but that they are prevented from solving it in the traditional way - by offering the salaries that will tempt sufficient graduates to work for the public sector. "We are trying to push the price we are offering up," said one. "We have increased salaries quite a bit, but we are still subject to the public spending envelope."

A newly qualified economics graduate can expect to earn £19,000 in Whitehall, with an additional £2,500 for someone with a post-graduate qualification. Salaries at the Bank of England - which has expanded its contingent of economists since the formation of the monetary policy committee are around £5,000 a year higher, because the Bank is not subject to the same constraints on public sector pay.

Until recently, civil service rules prevented the employment of non-UK nationals in Whitehall, but the government economic service - headed by the Treasury's chief economist, Gus O'Donnell - has spearheaded the drive for a more cosmopolitan approach. Overseas entrants are being offered three-year contracts.

Mr O'Donnell said that there had been a rapid increase in the demand for microeconomists in government because departments were under pressure to meet quantified targets.

He said the appeal of a job in the civil service for British graduates was not the pay but that of an interesting job and the acquisition of a highly marketable skill.

fields.headline: Railtrack scraps appeal
fields.trailText: Railtrack has backed down from the threat of legal action against the rail regulator over the burgeoning costs of Britain's most important rail artery, which have doubled to £5.8bn, the company confirmed last night.
fields.body:
Railtrack has backed down from the threat of legal action against the rail regulator over the burgeoning costs of Britain's most important rail artery, which have doubled to £5.8bn, the company confirmed last night.

It said it had decided not to appeal against an enforcement order, imposed by the regulator, Tom Winsor, for information about its huge infrastructure project to upgrade the west coast mainline between London and Glasgow.

Railtrack had been given until last Thursday to lodge its appeal. Under Gerald Corbett, the company's chief executive, its policy has been to challenge decisions from the regulator where commercial interests are at stake.

No official reason was offered for the decision. But senior managers within the company are well aware that a high-profile confrontation with the regulator - at a time when Railtrack is attempting to get more money from the government to support its new projects - would not be well received by ministers.

The rail regulator's office welcomed Railtrack's decision. It said that it was "still examining material sent to us by the company" and hoped to make an announcement soon.

Railtrack faces considerable problems with the west coast mainline project. Ministers are aghast that the cost of the scheme has escalated so quickly without any apparent good reason. They are looking to Mr Winsor for a professional judgment on what has gone wrong and what can be done.

Under the project, the company is contracted to complete the first phase by 2002, allowing Sir Richard Branson's new tilting trains to operate between London and Manchester at speeds of up to 125 mph.

The second, more difficult part of the contract, is the modernisation of signalling. This will allow Sir Richard's trains to reach speeds of up to 140mph, and for a service to operate between London and the north-west every half-hour, making it a more attractive proposition than air.

But Railtrack says that it is unlikely to be able to complete the project as it originally planned. This is why it needs more money from the government, including the provision of more freight paths on the route. It has not set an absolute figure but has been hinting that it will need an extra £1bn a year.

Railtrack could face a legal challenge on its own account from Sir Richard's company, Virgin Trains, if it fails to meet the terms of a tightly drawn-up contract on the west coast mainline. Virgin can claim up to £250m from Railtrack if it cannot deliver on the deal.

Urgent talks are expected to be held between the government, the regulator and the shadow strategic rail authority on how the west coast project can be saved.

The SSRA's chairman, Sir Alastair Morton, may be given the task of policing the project, and of bringing it in under Railtrack's budget of £5.8bn. It was described last night by one industry source as "grossly overpriced".

Industry sources are pessimistic that even the first part of the project will be finished in two years. They say that Railtrack started the project too late and has too much ground to make up. The joint supervision of the regulator and the SSRA may therefore produce a more realistic timetable.

The government is due to announce its plans for investment in transport next month as part of the chancellor's public sector spending round.

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, has told Sir Alastair that he is prepared to give the SSRA at least £2bn, so long as Sir Alastair can show quick results.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: The Hit | Walker | The Idiots | Love And Death On Long Island
fields.body:
The Hit
(Stephen Frears, 1984)
10pm, FilmFour

A classy Brit gangster film crossed with a touch of Bunuel. Two hitmen - John Hurt's Braddock and Tim Roth's Myron - are in Spain to kill Terence Stamp's Willie Parker (pictured), the grass whose singing sent a gang of hoods down a decade before. It's the perfect Stamp role: part cockney hardnut, part zen philosopher, he's been expecting the hit for years, and his utter lack of fear unsettles his killers in the Spanish heat.

Walker
(Alex Cox, 1987)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Alex Cox's South American odyssey boasts some original touches and interestingly idiosyncratic flourishes. Ed Harris stars as a Victorian adventurer who travels deep into the Nicaraguan forest, gets sidetracked from his mission, and becomes a dictator. The soundtrack is provided by Joe Strummer

The Idiots
(Lars Von Trier, 1998)
11.45pm, FilmFour

Von Trier's satire caused uproar at the Cannes festival two years ago, not so much because it was made under the purist Dogme regulations (natural lighting, hand-held cameras, etc), but because of the content: it concerns a small group of people who have fun pretending to be disabled. Moving beyond the limits of acceptable behaviour, they test society's values, and the patience of the audience, for whom their actions remain puzzling. Demanding, funny and explicit, it's flawed, but also more than just a sick joke.

Love And Death On Long Island
(Richard Kwietniowski, 1997)
3.45am, Sky Premier

An impressive debut from Kwietniowski, this is the story of crusty widowed author Giles De'Ath, who, wandering into the wrong screening at the cinema, conceives a sudden, mystifying infatuation with its star, Ronnie Bostock (Jason Priestley). Soon he's on a flight from London to New York and Long Island, and engineering a meeting with the shallow lad. Quiet, very funny, delicately nuanced, with a wonderful performance from John Hurt.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: You And Yours | An Inspector Calls
fields.body:
Starting with You And Yours (12.04pm, Radio 4), the BBC is trying to introduce listeners with spare time and handy skills to charitable organisations which may be able to employ them. The TimeBank project is highlighted throughout the week in various radio and television programmes. Participants are asked to commit themselves to a specified number of hours' work, for which the BBC will find appropriate recipients. Details are available on 0870-608-4422 or www.bbc.co.uk/timebank

The decision that job- seeking football fans will have money docked for attending Euro 2000 games conjures up a picture of Benefits Agency staff scanning endless match tapes to unmask offenders. In reality, as Jenny Cuffe reveals in An Inspector Calls (8.0pm, Radio 4), most fraudsters are shopped by colleagues or neighbours. In the first of three programmes she follows investigators Stella and Steve as they pursue tips, hoping to stop some £5,000m going to false claimants.

fields.headline: A match made in hell
fields.trailText: Seoul Mates | True Stories | The South Bank Show
fields.body:
The apostle Paul tells us that it is better to marry than to burn, but judging on the evidence of the weekend's television, all I can say is - pass the matches. Seldom has so much misery been endured and inflicted in the name of wedlock, as subjects across the channels rushed towards matrimony like lemmings towards a cliff, only to express surprise on finding themselves hurtling in a downward direction.

Hee-Jung was a gorgeous young Korean woman who could, presumably, have her pick of the local boys in Seoul. But no - she must marry an American soldier, the equally gorgeous Will, despite the fact neither spoke the other's language and both had violently different expectations of marriage. The atrociously titled Seoul Mates (Saturday, BBC2) followed her enthusiastic attempts to bridge the gulf between them and to make a go of it, undaunted by the fact that eight out of ten marriages between Korean women and US servicemen end in divorce. While Hee-Jung enrolled in the USO's Brides School and learned how to cook a Thanksgiving dinner, Will revealed himself as a hard-headed pragmatist with conservative views on just about everything. He returned to the US to pursue his career, leaving Hee-Jung to pine, at which point we all recognised the plot of Madam Butterfly and fully expected caddish Will to marry his hometown honey. Happily for all, he eventually summoned Hee-Jung to join him and they were married. No immolation, but an uncertain future to say the least. The newlyweds seemed mismatched to an almost comic degree - and yet it was impossible not to believe Hee-Jung's heartfelt declarations of love.

Meanwhile on Channel 4, film-maker Nina Davenport plumbed new depths of humiliation in her True Stories film, Always A Bridesmaid. Unmarried Nina felt, at 30, that time was running out for her, and spent 90 minutes obsessing over her 24-year-old boyfriend Nick, who, to nobody's surprise but hers, was in no hurry to tie the knot. She fed her desperation by interviewing a handful of doughty spinsters who all claimed that their lives had been enriched by their single status. This should have calmed her down, but seemed to have the opposite effect, as Davenport returned to muse further on her plight like a child picking at a scab. In between these orgies of self-regard, Davenport pursued her day job as a wedding videographer, a career path as appropriate as putting an anorexic in charge of a pie shop. Good sense almost prevailed when Nina and Nick split up but, this being New York, it was only a "six-month break", after which they got back together again to discuss how their relationship had grown and changed. On film, of course.

We were left hoping that Nick might propose, if only to put an end to Davenport's navel-gazing. Tempted by the website address flashed up at the end of the film, one discovers only that www.bridesmaidthemovie.com is under construction. Hopefully Nick and Nina's wedding snaps will be posted there one day.

Worst of all advertisements for marriage were the Amises, père et fils, who were the subjects of The South Bank Show (Sunday ITV). This was a shameless puff for Martin Amis's Experience, but there was enough footage of father and son doing their contrasting thing to make it enjoyable. Melvyn Bragg interviewed Martin with cheerful sycophancy, treating every utterance as sybilline. Amis seemed to enjoy the attention, peppered his answers with words like "animus" and "recrudesce" and was, as ever, charismatic and charming. Kingsley was much more fun, though - both in archive footage and in readings from his correspondence. "Annoying people is part of one's life's work," he said, with a twinkle in his eye, and what a great job he did of it. Even Martin was riled.

It was on the subject of marriage, though, that the sourest notes were sounded. Kingsley left his first wife, Hilary Bardwell, to marry novelist Elizabeth Jane Howard. Then, deciding that she was Satan in skirts, he went running back to a remarried Hilary, and ended his days in a companionable ménage-à-trois. Martin has repeated some of the trick, and waxed rueful over the effect his divorce had on his own children. But for all Martin's elegance, it was Kingsley who rightfully stole the show, trotting out his ever-more absurd opinions ("Women and queers and children cry when things go wrong") and carrying on outrageously to the bitter end.

Amis seemed to enjoy the attention, peppered his answers with words like "animus" and "recrudesce" and was, as ever, charismatic and charming. Kingsley was much more fun, though - both in archive footage and in readings from his correspondence. "Annoying people is part of one's life's work," he said, with a twinkle in his eye, and what a great job he did of it. Even Martin was riled. It was on the subject of marriage, though, that the sourest notes were sounded. Kingsley left his first wife, Hilary Bardwell, to marry novelist Elizabeth Jane Howard. Then, deciding that she was Satan in skirts, he went running back to a remarried Hilary, and ended his days in a companionable ménage-à-trois. Martin has repeated some of the trick, and waxed rueful over the effect his divorce had on his own children. But for all Martin's elegance, it was Kingsley who rightfully stole the show, trotting out his ever-more absurd opinions ("Women and queers and children cry when things go wrong") and carrying on outrageously to the bitter end.

webTitle: Gun battle sparks panic in Freetown

fields.headline: Gun battle sparks panic in Freetown
fields.standfirst: Sierra Leone: special report
fields.trailText: A minor dispute over stolen cassette tapes degenerated into a gun battle in the heart of Freetown on Saturday, leaving at least one passer-by dead in clashes between rival factions among government forces.
fields.body:
A minor dispute over stolen cassette tapes degenerated into a gun battle in the heart of Freetown on Saturday, leaving at least one passer-by dead in clashes between rival factions among government forces.

Yesterday, Sierra Leone state radio insisted that the clash was a minor incident. "The government wishes to assure the public that the incident was no threat to the security of the country," the station said.

But many Sierra Leoneans saw the fighting as evidence of the instability of the government's military alliance and the worsening security situation since the British pulled out most of its combat force last week.

UN peacekeepers stepped up patrols around Freetown yesterday amid reports of fresh clashes between pro-government factions close to the front line in the war against Revolutionary United Front rebels.

Saturday's shooting apparently broke out after a soldier in the new Sierra Leone army tried to stop a member of the pro-government Kamajor militia from stealing tapes from a car. Within minutes dozens of fighters from both factions were firing, sending civilians in the street running for their lives.

A driver was shot dead when his car was hit by bullets. Four other people were injured in the fighting. Two of them were Kamajor fighters who said they had been stabbed with bayonets. Thousands of people fled restaurants and bars for their homes, fearing that rebels had infiltrated the city.

The government is relying heavily on a disparate collection of militias, private armies and fresh recruits to press the war against the RUF. The new Sierra Leone army, born of last year's peace accords, is still in its infancy. The British are training 1,000 new recruits but many of its officers are either inexperienced or tainted by a history of human rights abuses.

The army has been recruiting heavily among members of the old military force which seized power twice during the 1990s until it was ousted by Nigerian troops who restored the elected government.

Many of the soldiers loyal to the overthrown regime switched sides to fight with the RUF, committing atrocities by adopting the rebels' tactics of mutilations and rape to terrorise the civilian population.

Some of those same troops are now fighting for the government under the command of the former military ruler, Johnny Paul Koroma. But while he has pledged his backing for President Ahmad Tejan Kabbah for now, Mr Koroma is known to be ambitious for greater power.

The government is also relying on the Kamajor militia whose young fighters see copious quantities of gin and magic as more important to their success than training and tactics. The Kamajor leader, Samuel Hinga Norman, is also Sierra Leone's deputy defence minister. His loyalties are as questionable as Mr Koroma's.

Saturday night's clash was followed by reports that two soldiers were killed and three injured when fighting between pro-government factions flared in the strategic town of Lunsar. The RUF has launched regular raids against Lunsar, the staging ground for the government's assault on the rebel headquarters at Mak eni. But the latest fighting was between troops of the new Sierra Leone army and soldiers loyal to Mr Koroma.

A British aid worker who went missing in Sierra Leone six weeks ago has been found alive after escaping from the RUF. Alan Smith, 55, walked into the town of Mile 91 and was met by British soldiers who took him to Freetown. The British high commission declined to discuss his condition or how he had escaped. Mr Smith, from Birmingham, worked for an organisation donating computers to schools.

fields.headline: The city - the final frontier
fields.trailText: The theme of the seventh Venice Biennale of Architecture is, according to its director, the Roman architect Massimiliano Fuksas, "cities: less aesthetics, more ethics". Its aim is "to pick up the thread that was broken at the end of the 70s, the great heritage of research, ideas and utopias produced by the 60s".
fields.body:
The theme of the seventh Venice Biennale of Architecture is, according to its director, the Roman architect Massimiliano Fuksas, "cities: less aesthetics, more ethics". Its aim is "to pick up the thread that was broken at the end of the 70s, the great heritage of research, ideas and utopias produced by the 60s". That's a particularly tall order in Venice: the city has been in decline since the 18th century, and hasn't been a real, workaday place since the great flood of November 1966, which marked the beginning of a major international effort to conserve Venice and the end of the everyday life that "la Serenissima" once knew. From then on Venice was pickled in aspic, becoming a tourist ghetto and a place known equally for its aesthetics and its lack of ethics when it came to dealing with the millions of visitors who flooded into St Mark's Square every year.

Yet when was Venice ever ethical? At the height of its power, it ruled an empire built on wily trade, commercial cunning and arcane banking. Not that any of this troubles you when you arrive in the dusty public gardens bordering the lagoon, and explore the delightfully eccentric Biennale pavilions. It's not so much a case of ethics be damned, or ignored; the Venice Biennale has long been a showcase of ideas far more than of buildings, and the real point of the exhibitions in the rival national pavilions is to outdo one another.

The British Pavilion, organised by the British Council, is an enjoyable snapshot of one generation of British architects: born in the late 40s and early 50s, they have reached their stride and are undoubtedly good ambassadors for British architecture. They are Zaha Hadid, David Chipperfield, Will Alsop, and Nigel Coates and Doug Branson. The entire gang are graduates of the Architectural Association, London, and their range of work - ideas, provocations, models of work in progress - shows how talent nurtured in Britain has developed into the best kind of "zuppa inglese".

While there is nothing trifling about the display in the British pavilion, it is immensely colourful, highly engaging and serious at the same time. At least some architects have learned to communicate, not through marketing and PR, but by creating images, making models and expressing ideas that are as involving as much contemporary installation art. If these are not as provocative as those of the Hirsts and Lucases of this world, it's because what's on show here are ideas for real buildings.

The main room of the British pavilion is given over to a cartoon-like model of Will Alsop's design for C/plex, a public arts centre for West Bromwich. Alsop is the architect of the spirited new public library in Peckham, south-east London, a big character who likes to make a splash with challenging buildings that seem part amoeba, part mechanism. The C/plex model, a great burst of party balloon-like colours, is installed in a room painted by Alsop and slashed across with architect's slogans. It must have made culture secretary Chris Smith happy when he came for lunch, for rarely has the message of accessibility and art for all in the regions been more clearly spelt out - yet in a way that also appeals to those who believe that architecture should be more than just polite.

Alsop's explosive style is echoed in the Ecstacity installation next door, a gloriously dynamic vision of what a city might be if only we stretched our imagination the Doug Branson and Nigel Coates way. In a beautifully installed wall of their own architectural models - miniatures blown in glass, buildings and the body zone from the Millennium Dome reduced to clever parodies of the kitsch souvenirs sold in Venetian tourist shops - Branson and Coates have plotted their spirited view of architecture on a giant city map. Theirs is an architecture of fantasy as well as reality, and here they have created a city that Italo Calvino would surely include in his book Invisible Cities, in which a fictional Marco Polo entertains the mighty Khan with tales of the fabulous and utterly unlikely cities he has visited. As Calvino says at one point in these imaginative narratives, he is always talking of Venice, a city that not even Coates and Branson could have invented. And Ecstacity, with its six related urban "narratives" - tuning in, locking on, undressing, letting go, cranking up and flipping out - is as much about Venice as it is about the city of the imagination that most of us long to live in.

Zaha Hadid's contribution is a serpentine weaving and folding of recent projects. Again, this display reflects the labyrinthine nature of Venice, where the only thing expected is the unexpected. Hadid, Alsop, and Branson and Coates prove to be the very sort of architectural talent that Venice would do well by, should the city finally learn to reinvent itself and interrupt its long decline.

David Chipperfield, whose clear-cut Modernism is as different from his co-biennalists' architecture as parmesan is from cheddar, is the only one of the gang with a live project in Venice. Well, dead, to be more accurate: Chipperfield is creating a new quarter in San Michele, the cemetery island whose bones and mathematical alleys haunt the Venetian lagoon, unknown in the living city close by. In a cool, white sepulchre of a room, Chipperfield, architect of the praised River and Rowing Museum in Henley-on-Thames, shows fine models of the grand new buildings he's designing worldwide, including the ambitious Palace of Justice, Salerno. It seems strange that Chipperfield is the only one of the British biennalists designing for Venice. And yet Venice is as much the city of the geometric purity of Andrea Palladio as it is of the Baroque voluptuousness of Baldessare Longhena, architect of the sensuous Salute church, or of the tangle of alleyways from which not even a Greek hero with a ball of string could find his way out.

The British Pavilion was put together quite late in the day. Whether serendipity or a cunning plan has won the day for the architectural ragazzi in Venice, it's impossible to say. Yet together Branson and Coates, Hadid and Alsop have brought a life to Venice that possibly only Venice truly understands, while Chipperfield brings life to the culture of death that has long shaped our dreams of this ineffable city.

fields.headline: The girls from Brazil
fields.standfirst: There's a lot more to the Brazil 500 festivities than sexy dancing, writes  Suzie Mackenzie  , while  Mark Espiner  sees musical icon Caetano Veloso wow them at the Barbican
fields.trailText: To be in Brazil is to witness the present: Rio's brilliant white beaches flanked by skyscraper hotels, the traffic jams that snake along the big bay of Guanabara. But everywhere you hear, resoundingly, the voice of the past: in Salvador the demands of street-children whose faces are those of a people that has been robbed.
fields.body:
To be in Brazil is to witness the present: Rio's brilliant white beaches flanked by skyscraper hotels, the traffic jams that snake along the big bay of Guanabara. But everywhere you hear, resoundingly, the voice of the past: in Salvador the demands of street-children whose faces are those of a people that has been robbed.

And wherever you travel it is reiterated that Brazil is a nation of contrasts; not one single culture but an accretion of cultures. An old culture, forged from an unholy alliance between middle-class Portuguese gentlemen, indigenous Indians and Muslim slaves. And it has at its heart a strange tension - a stern loyalty to the past plus a need to tear up its histories.

It is 500 years since Brazil was "discovered" by the Portuguese explorer Pedro Alvares Cabral, who was blown off course on his way to the Orient. It is also just over 100 years since it abolished slavery, in 1888, the last nation in the western hemisphere to do so. More than an error of navigation this, it continues to mark the country deeply.

Still, this year has been designated Brazil's cultural coming of age, and this summer begins a conscientious drive to reinterpret Brazil to the world through its major artists in all fields of the performing and visual arts. To bring us not the travel brochure Brazil, all football and carnival fan fare, but a Brazil in the words of dance artist Deborah Colker "more expressive of the people's spirit".

Not a homogenised Brazil either. For as Colker points out, "Brazilians take an almost tribal pride in being not only unlike the rest of Latin America but as unlike one another as it is possible to be." Take, for example, Dr Edemar Cid Ferreira, a short, stocky extremely wealthy banker who raised the $20m investment necessary to fund the Brazil 500 Rediscovery Exhibition of which he is president.

This massive historical and cultural exhibition with over 15,000 exhibits is situated in Ibirapuera Park in Sao Paolo. All around the park are knots of impassioned kids skateboarding or playing music, whose cracked smiles reveal cracked teeth. Ferreira arrives stealthily, in a blacked-out Mercedes. One of the guides whispers that he is so rich he has been buying up the houses surrounding his mansion in Sao Paulo and now owns every one on the block. He doesn't want neighbours.

His aim with the exhibition, Ferreira says, "is to change the image of Brazil abroad and to give ourselves self-vision. To make a bridge between people here and a bridge with the world. It's a project." He doesn't care about the criticism that this is art as spectacle, as carnival. (Ferreira has "dressed" many of the exhibition spaces. There are fake fields of purple paper poppies.)

It doesn't bear thinking about how many street kids could have been dressed with the money wasted on this paraphernalia designed to satisfy a rich man's vanity. Different aspects of the exhibition will find their way to Cambridge's Fitzwilliam, Oxford's Ashmolean and to the British Museum, plus museums in the US and Paris.

But not, unfortunately, the part of the exhibition entitled Black in Body and Soul, which attempts to understand "the struggles" and the contribution of Africans to Brazilian culture, and to dispel what it calls "the whitening" of history. So, there is nothing blacker than the room full of instruments forged to torture slaves, or William Blake's 1793 engraving Negro Hanged Alive by a Rib. The exhibition anticipates receiving 600,000 schoolchildren as it travels around Brazil. From this Ferreira hopes they will understand the multiplicity of their origins, Brazil's "transculturalism" which is not "multiculturalism". And that they then will take a pride in their heritage.

But this dry, arid strategy evoked by Ferreira, all to do with the grim imperatives of money, is eradicated by the freewheeling, bright, individual talents of the performing artists. For pure eccentricity, Grupo Giramundo, a family of third-generation puppeteers will bring their folk tale Cobra Narato to Riverside Studios in August. No money here - just an unadulterated love of the artform, a sense of the amazing that is conveyed to the audience who respond with amazement.

Giramundo's theatre is a rundown warehouse in Belo Horizonte where they have been making their puppet art for 30 years. In their collection they have 800 puppets. The company originator and director, Alvaro Apocalypse, takes on a small number of young puppeteers each season and trains them in gaiety as much as in technique. Their work is a reminder that you can achieve every nuance of seriousness through lightheartedness - and, perhaps nothing without it.

Cobra Narato experiments with every type of puppet from glove to marionettes moved by string to Chinese-inspired puppets moved by sticks or slides from the back, and is simply delightful. It works both with and against a myth of Brazil as a heritage of superstition and animistic beliefs. Its subject is nothing less than to try to discover the best means by which people can live together.

Which is also the subject of Grupo Corpo's work, who, along with Companhia de Danca Deborah Colker, remain Brazil's leading contemporary dance company and who return to Britain for their second visit with two recent dance pieces, Benguele and Parabelo. Corpo's work is supple, a physical technique responsive to percussive influences, and based on traditional Brazilian movements to original music by Joao Bosco. Parabelo - which director Fernando Velloso translates as: "If you want peace prepare for war" - refers to the beneficent and destructive impulses alive in his contradictory country. As Velloso says: "Here, the sun is so strong it can kill people like a gun. People die of the heat, they have no water. And yet the sun is beauty."

The company has existed for 25 years and has reached the point where it can look outside Brazil for interpretations. Recently Corpo worked with the composer Philip Glass. "We now have our own very strong character. It's a good time for us to show our work abroad. In terms of Brazil, the country is in transition. It may not be the perfect moment to celebrate and 500 years may not be the perfect anniversary. But we are not claiming Brazil is perfect. Just that there are positive things, wonderful things, and these should be celebrated."

Vacuum-packed salsa

Those banished from their country often become its voice. So with the 58-year-old Brazilian singer-songwriter, Caetano Veloso. He was imprisoned in the late 60s for writing songs that expressed the counter-cultural spirit of the time, then spent a couple of years in exile in London before returning to a more politically relaxed Brazil. He has since become the bulwark of Brazilian music and culture, reflecting its past and working with new artists.

An audience of enthusiastic expatriates and a smattering of Brits filled the Barbican for his show, which opened the Brasil: Brazil 500 festival. Caetano, in a stylish suit, swinging his acoustic guitar, walked on stage with elegant poise and an inviting smile. He looked 28 not 58, and supported this illusion with an energetic performance of full-on percussive pieces, glittering electric pop, samba, bossa nova and soft acoustic solos. His band - "They are so talented and so sexy," he smiled - were so tight, the sound was almost vacuum-packed.

Among the songs from his latest releases, Livro and the live recording Prenda Minha, were some wonderful interpretations of Brazilian classics. The band segued from a yearning performance of Jorge Ben's Jorge da Capadocia into the traditional Prenda Minha, where Caetano's falsetto warble twisted into Jobim's Meditacao.

Terra, Caetano's own ballad of exile and love, saw the audience provide a spontaneous backing vocal, which he applauded. He then turned his mesmeric voice to London London, another song of exile, but written in English when he was here in 1970. Its chorus - "while my eyes go looking for flying saucers in the skies" - is glaring. He's a great lyricist, but something got lost in translation there.

Throughout, Caetano held his audience with his eyes, smiles and theatrical gestures; in return, they greedily demanded encore after encore and danced in the aisles. Above it all his distinctive voice shone through clear, pure, poetic. A voice of freedom.

 Grupo Corpo perform at Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020 7863 8000), June 29-July 1. Grupo Giramundo will appear at Riverside Studios, London W6 (020 8237 1111), August 23-26. They will also present Peter and the Wolf at the Ross on Wye international festival (01989 563330), August 19-20. Companhia de Danca Deborah Colker appear at the Barbican, London EC2 (020 7638 8891), July 18-22 as part of the Brasil: Brazil festival. Brazil 500 information line: 020 7399 9265.

Giramundo's theatre is a rundown warehouse in Belo Horizonte where they have been making their puppet art for 30 years. In their collection they have 800 puppets. The company originator and director, Alvaro Apocalypse, takes on a small number of young puppeteers each season and trains them in gaiety as much as in technique. Their work is a reminder that you can achieve every nuance of seriousness through lightheartedness - and, perhaps nothing without it. Cobra Narato experiments with every type of puppet from glove to marionettes moved by string to Chinese-inspired puppets moved by sticks or slides from the back, and is simply delightful. It works both with and against a myth of Brazil as a heritage of superstition and animistic beliefs. Its subject is nothing less than to try to discover the best means by which people can live together. Which is also the subject of Grupo Corpo's work, who, along with Companhia de Danca Deborah Colker, remain Brazil's leading contemporary dance company and who return to Britain for their second visit with two recent dance pieces, Benguele and Parabelo. Corpo's work is supple, a physical technique responsive to percussive influences, and based on traditional Brazilian movements to original music by Joao Bosco. Parabelo - which director Fernando Velloso translates as: "If you want peace prepare for war" - refers to the beneficent and destructive impulses alive in his contradictory country. As Velloso says: "Here, the sun is so strong it can kill people like a gun. People die of the heat, they have no water. And yet the sun is beauty." The company has existed for 25 years and has reached the point where it can look outside Brazil for interpretations. Recently Corpo worked with the composer Philip Glass. "We now have our own very strong character. It's a good time for us to show our work abroad. In terms of Brazil, the country is in transition. It may not be the perfect moment to celebrate and 500 years may not be the perfect anniversary. But we are not claiming Brazil is perfect. Just that there are positive things, wonderful things, and these should be celebrated." Vacuum-packed salsa Those banished from their country often become its voice. So with the 58-year-old Brazilian singer-songwriter, Caetano Veloso. He was imprisoned in the late 60s for writing songs that expressed the counter-cultural spirit of the time, then spent a couple of years in exile in London before returning to a more politically relaxed Brazil. He has since become the bulwark of Brazilian music and culture, reflecting its past and working with new artists. An audience of enthusiastic expatriates and a smattering of Brits filled the Barbican for his show, which opened the Brasil: Brazil 500 festival. Caetano, in a stylish suit, swinging his acoustic guitar, walked on stage with elegant poise and an inviting smile. He looked 28 not 58, and supported this illusion with an energetic performance of full-on percussive pieces, glittering electric pop, samba, bossa nova and soft acoustic solos. His band - "They are so talented and so sexy," he smiled - were so tight, the sound was almost vacuum-packed. Among the songs from his latest releases, Livro and the live recording Prenda Minha, were some wonderful interpretations of Brazilian classics. The band segued from a yearning performance of Jorge Ben's Jorge da Capadocia into the traditional Prenda Minha, where Caetano's falsetto warble twisted into Jobim's Meditacao. Terra, Caetano's own ballad of exile and love, saw the audience provide a spontaneous backing vocal, which he applauded. He then turned his mesmeric voice to London London, another song of exile, but written in English when he was here in 1970. Its chorus - "while my eyes go looking for flying saucers in the skies" - is glaring. He's a great lyricist, but something got lost in translation there. Throughout, Caetano held his audience with his eyes, smiles and theatrical gestures; in return, they greedily demanded encore after encore and danced in the aisles. Above it all his distinctive voice shone through clear, pure, poetic. A voice of freedom.  Grupo Corpo perform at Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020 7863 8000), June 29-July 1. Grupo Giramundo will appear at Riverside Studios, London W6 (020 8237 1111), August 23-26. They will also present Peter and the Wolf at the Ross on Wye international festival (01989 563330), August 19-20. Companhia de Danca Deborah Colker appear at the Barbican, London EC2 (020 7638 8891), July 18-22 as part of the Brasil: Brazil festival. Brazil 500 information line: 020 7399 9265.

webTitle: Lumpy, ugly, mud coloured - so bad it's a classic car

fields.headline: Lumpy, ugly, mud coloured - so bad it's a classic car
fields.standfirst: For motoring's centenary Lord Montagu's museum invites a vote on the vehicles with cachet and those several screws short of a style
fields.trailText: The National Motor Museum is showing cars which would normally never be allowed across its threshold - those voted the worst ever built.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The National Motor Museum is showing cars which would normally never be allowed across its threshold - those voted the worst ever built.

The museum, at Beaulieu in Hampshire, has created an exhibition which brings together 11 cars voted the worst, as well as 15 voted the best of all time. The cars are displayed with labels on their history, but visitors must work out for themselves to which list they belong.

Some, like the 1934 Crossley Burnley, perhaps born of an encounter between a sea-plane and a bin lorry, are so hideous they defy categorisation.

The cars were chosen by motoring commentators and correspondents and the public in time for the millennium, the end of the first century of motoring history. The choice of cars has provoked intense debate among the museum staff.

Lord Montagu, chairman of the museum trust, who drives a Rover in London, a Daimler in Hampshire and a Ford Mondeo around his Beaulieu estate, has few quibbles with the best. And as he surveyed the worst, their lumpy shapes, horrid colours - the Trabant, in pond-slime green, the clear leader here - and tragic attempts at stylish detailing, he found it hard to disagree with the selection.

In front of the Sinclair C5, a monument to creative intelligence overcoming common sense, he said: "I remember driving one of the prototypes. Very awkward driving position, very awkward indeed. Wouldn't like to do it now."

The Trabant etched its place in history when the iron curtain rusted and a procession of east Europeans headed west in a pall of black smoke. "We don't actually have one in the collection," Lord Montagu said. "When the curtain came down we had a chap ring us up from Poland offering us one - he wanted a nice trip, poor chap. Next thing we had a phone call from Munich. Some great German lorry had sat down on it, squashed it flat, nothing left."

Doug Hill, chief engineer at Beaulieu, has bitter memories of two cars on the worst list. "Did my test in an Allegro. Horrible car, horrible to drive, horrible to look at. And the Mayflower, we had one as a family car when I was little, we called it the Dodgy - we used to go on family outings and never knew how far we'd get."

The 1896 Pennington is the oldest and weirdest on the list, more like a sinister Louise Bourgeois sculpture than a car. Lord Montagu is not at all sure that it ever went, and as far as he knows theirs is the only surviving example of the bundle of iron poles and exposed engine bits, sporting two terrifying bicycle saddles directly above the road.

The Volkswagen Beetle appears on the best and worst list. Stephen Vokins, head of the museum's film and video archive explained: "I suppose once you become used to its rather obvious charms, you realise it really hasn't got very much else going for it."

The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, is at Beaulieu, Hampshire, until September.

webTitle: Pregnancy fears as age of puberty drops

fields.headline: Pregnancy fears as age of puberty drops
fields.trailText: One in six girls in Britain is reaching puberty by the age of eight compared to one in 100 a generation ago, according to a study which found that girls are capable of becoming pregnant while at primary school.
fields.body:
One in six girls in Britain is reaching puberty by the age of eight compared to one in 100 a generation ago, according to a study which found that girls are capable of becoming pregnant while at primary school.

The research, which tracked 14,000 children in the former Avon area from birth, also found that one in 14 boys aged eight had pubic hair, an early indicator of puberty, compared with one in 150 of their fathers' generation. This may lead to a fundamental review of the way parents, teachers and policymakers deal with childhood and adolescence.

The rush of hormones that accompanies puberty could lead to earlier first-time sex, despite emotional immaturity and being too inexperienced to make informed decisions.

"Girls are now having sex before their great-great grandmothers had their first period," said Jean Golding, director of the Children of the Nineties study at Bristol University's institute of child health. "Half of all girls in Britain will have entered puberty by the age of 10."

The study, which will be featured in Channel 4's Generation Sex series on June 27 , has shocked experts such as Rosemary Jones, a community paediatrician in Bath.

"To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time in 30 years that anyone has tried to find out what is going on," she said. "Girls are discovering sex before their parents or teachers think it necessary to discuss it with them and they are having periods before they even know what periods are."

The study found that from a sample of 1,150 girls, one in six had started puberty at eight. Further research carried out in Exeter among 9,000 children found that the age of the first period has fallen below 13 in Britain for the first time.The average age is now 12 years 10 months compared to 13 years six months in 1969. Possible reasons for this are diet and general health.

Marcia Herman-Gidden, a paediatrician who made similar discoveries in a survey of 17,000 children in the US in 1997, believes the studies prove that society is not to blame for over-sexualisation of children.

"This is proof that children are programmed to be sexual at a time when society still considers them to be very young," she said. "We have a very different situation now from that which existed in the past and it is fraught with dangers."

webTitle: Royal Opera chief ready to exit after scaling the heights

fields.headline: Royal Opera chief ready to exit after scaling the heights
fields.trailText: The Royal Opera and Ballet is facing the appalling prospect of beginning the hunt for a new chief executive all over again, the poison chalice of the arts world.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
The Royal Opera and Ballet is facing the appalling prospect of beginning the hunt for a new chief executive all over again, the poison chalice of the arts world.

The friendly American, Michael Kaiser, who is regarded as having worked miracles in restoring shattered morale at Covent Garden, central London, has indicated that after one more season he will probably be moving on to a new challenge - almost certainly back in the US. "There's no fight, no rift," a spokesman said yesterday. "Michael was never going to stay forever. He has told us he is willing to stay for at least one more season, and then we'll all see. He isn't contracted to stay for any particular length of time."

He took over at the end of 1998 at the lowest point in the history of the theatre, when Covent Garden had come to the edge of bankruptcy, and lost two chief executives in a year - one in bitter political infighting over her appointment, the other due to exhaustion caused by job stress. The management was hammered by the Commons culture committee, and the grant of almost £80m in lottery funds, towards the £200m rebuilding of the complex, was one of the most unpopular ever made. The building work itself was dogged by disputes, delays, and threats of walkouts.

From day one Mr Kaiser operated a policy of being nice to everyone, front stage, back stage and board room, even politicians and journalists.

He weathered the inevitable storms around the reopening last December, which ranged from a row over seat prices - the dearest seats have become cheaper, but the cheapest seats with a decent view of the stage became much more expensive - to criticism of the allocation of seats at invitation-only previews, to a row over whether the black tie opening gala betrayed the ideal of making Covent Garden the people's opera.

He also kept his cool, and insisted all would be well after inevitable teething problems, throughout the far greater embarrassment of the malfunctioning computerised set changing system, which led to a string of performances, and one entire opera, being cancelled.

Now conditions have settled down - he has almost eliminated an inherited £5m deficit, all the facilities are working and on the whole admired and Antonio Pappano and Ross Stretton chosen as popular new directors for the opera and ballet - the word from insiders is that Mr Kaiser is growing restless.

Some say he is disappointed with his reception in London, and that there have been personality clashes with Covent Garden's acerbic chairman Sir Colin Southgate. Others insist he saw reopening the opera house as the challenge, but never viewed it as a job for life.

If he leaves next spring, as reported, his departure would coincide with that of the formidable Vivien Duffield, who raised £50m towards the rebuilding, was made a dame on Saturday, and is retiring from the board.

The two are said never to have seen eye-to-eye, and are unlikely to be sharing the same leaving cake.

webTitle: Post Office faces strike over foreign mail plan

fields.headline: Post Office faces strike over foreign mail plan
fields.trailText: The Post Office was last night threatened with industrial action over a proposal to use a private company to handle international mail leaving Britain.
fields.body:
The Post Office was last night threatened with industrial action over a proposal to use a private company to handle international mail leaving Britain.

Confidential talks have taken place with the privately-owned Dutch postal service that could result in it sorting and carrying millions of letters posted in Britain to addresses abroad.

A senior manager disclosed that under the plan the Dutch service, now run by the courier company TNT, would handle a proportion of international mail at its own depot.

The proposal was denounced as "backdoor privatisation" by furious union leaders who are to seek an urgent meeting with Post Office directors and will press Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, to halt the scheme.

Details emerged at a sensitive time for the Post Office. It is due to report its first loss for almost 25 years later today. It is also in delicate negotiations over plans to shift 1,500 jobs out of central London's Mount Pleasant sorting office and seek union agreement on staffing a new international complex to open next year at Langley near Heathrow.

Union leaders threatened industrial action to stop a deal that would for the first time give a private firm responsibility for Royal Mail post.

John Keggie, CWU deputy general secretary, said: "We will not allow work to be handed to a competitor. We recognise commercial freedom has put us in a different environment but that does not mean handing over the family silver to a rival."

Discussions between John Mod, managing director of Royal Mail's international division, and the Dutch post office are understood to be at an advanced stage;one insider claimed a draft agreement had been signed.

The British, Dutch and Singapore post offices announced an alliance earlier this year to win new business around the world in the face of fierce German and US competition.

The Post Office yesterday insisted no deal had been signed to involve the Dutch company in the UK postal system.

But an industry source maintained that under the proposal the Dutch TNT Post Group would win a share of the letters leaving Britain once it had proved it could do so more cheaply than Langley.

The Post Office is expected to announce today a deficit of around £250m in the year to the end of March.

Industry sources blame the government's decision to pay state benefits directly into bank and building society accounts - rather than over post office counters - for the slide into the red.

The change is thought to have cost some £400m in revenue last year and meant that the Post Office had to write off £571m of a £1bn investment project for counter services automation.

Though the Post Office would have made money without the write-off, today's figures are expected to show a downward trend in its profits reflecting growing competition as well as the loss of revenue from benefit payments.

There are fears for the future of many post offices, especially those in rural and inner city areas. Only 600 post offices are directly run by the Post Office directly. The remainder are run by sub postmasters, most of whom own the businesses and are paid for the services they provide.

Some 8,000 are said to be making losses and are being subsidised by the Post Office.

fields.headline: Two Koreas, one future
fields.standfirst: Korea: special report
fields.trailText: The image of the two Koreas' two Kims shaking hands on the tarmac in Pyongyang was, for most people, perhaps, a mundane gesture. But for Korea, that small handshake was the political equivalent of a moon landing; a baby-step for the Kims, a giant leap forward for peace on the peninsula.
fields.body:
The image of the two Koreas' two Kims shaking hands on the tarmac in Pyongyang was, for most people, perhaps, a mundane gesture; two leaders in bad suits posturing for the news cameras. Blink, and you missed it. But for Korea, that small handshake was the political equivalent of a moon landing; a baby-step for the Kims, a giant leap forward for peace on the peninsula.

That this historic three-day summit barely registered in the British press makes the event all the more precious to me. I only wish my mother, who was Korean, and grew up in a province that was later divided into North and South Korea, could have lived to see this rapprochement. As recently as two years ago, when she died, such a meeting was impossible; the two nations were deadlocked in mutual suspicion. Famine and need have accelerated North Korea's willingness to reach out to the south, but the convulsive changes Korea has undergone this century have all been swift - though mostly terrible; Japanese invasion, second world war, north-south partitioning, the Korean war. But what is most extraordinary about the first face-to-face meeting of the two Korean leaders is the unfamiliar, but wonderful, feeling of hope it brings.

When I saw thousands of North Koreans wearing bright han-boks and waving silk flowers on the route from the airport I could barely swallow for the lump in my throat. Some western commentators suggested that they were little better than Stalinist robots planted in a crude display, but this is inaccurate - these people are genuinely glad. After 55 years of forced separation from their families, oppression, starvation, torture, poverty and humiliating foreign intervention, North Koreans have reason to welcome the South Korean president.

There is a profound longing for peace in North and South Korea. Reunification will come, and, following this summit, it may be sooner than anyone thought. For most families, however, it will be too late to be reunited with their lost relations. Most of my mother's family in the North are dead by now, but no one knows for certain; no communication of any kind has been possible since 1945.

My mother's family were from Kangwon province, which literally straddles the 38th parallel. They were aristocratic landowners there for 2,000 years. Our lands were artificially divided by the demarcation line, titles and properties stripped from us, first by the Japanese, and later by the communists. When the communists took power, some of our family stayed in the North, wrongly thinking the regime would be swiftly defeated. Of these, some were imprisoned; none were ever seen or heard from again.

When I was in Korea for my first visit in 1987, I stood at the barbed-wire perimeter fence at the DMZ (demilitarised zone), gazing out across the landmine-strewn horizon at "North Korea". This was as close as I could get to meeting my relations there. When my mother left Korea during the war to study abroad she did not know if her cousins and grandparents were alive or dead. On my last visit, I brought back her ashes, and still it wasn't possible to scatter her remains on the hilltop she once described to me as a child. Still, I know my mother would have been moved and amused by the photographs of Kim Jong-il and Kim Dae-jung embracing. What struck me was how vulnerable and tired the North Korean dictator looked. Rather than being the evil red monster with two horns and a tail, here was an ageing, dissipated-looking man who looked as if he'd been on an 45-year bender.

With some five million North Koreans estimated to have died of starvation during the past five years, it must have taken some doing for Kim Jong-il to sleep well, night after night, after his legendary banquets. His rarefied world of self-indulgence must be one of unimaginable loneliness and oddity. In that photograph of the Kims embracing they seem like fraternal twins, representing the opposite extremes of Korean politics.

It may be facile to say that Kim Jong-il is the bad one and Kim Dae-jung is the good one, but there's some truth in this. The fresh, virtuous-looking Kim Dae-jung is a poignant contrast to Kim Jong-il; his entire life has been a strenuous, even dangerous fight for democracy and public service, tortured and arrested by previous military regimes, a Mandela-like figure in Korean politics. Kim has been devoted to overthrowing the kind of oppression that has ensured Kim Jong-il's very survival.

Yet both men displayed an unmistakable warmth towards each other. For the first time I feel optimistic about the possibility of reunification. In the photo they are looking into each other's eyes, as if into a mirror, finally accepting, and even forgiving, the difficult reflection they see.

fields.bodyText: The image of the two Koreas' two Kims shaking hands on the tarmac in Pyongyang was, for most people, perhaps, a mundane gesture; two leaders in bad suits posturing for the news cameras. Blink, and you missed it. But for Korea, that small handshake was the political equivalent of a moon landing; a baby-step for the Kims, a giant leap forward for peace on the peninsula. That this historic three-day summit barely registered in the British press makes the event all the more precious to me. I only wish my mother, who was Korean, and grew up in a province that was later divided into North and South Korea, could have lived to see this rapprochement. As recently as two years ago, when she died, such a meeting was impossible; the two nations were deadlocked in mutual suspicion. Famine and need have accelerated North Korea's willingness to reach out to the south, but the convulsive changes Korea has undergone this century have all been swift - though mostly terrible; Japanese invasion, second world war, north-south partitioning, the Korean war. But what is most extraordinary about the first face-to-face meeting of the two Korean leaders is the unfamiliar, but wonderful, feeling of hope it brings. When I saw thousands of North Koreans wearing bright han-boks and waving silk flowers on the route from the airport I could barely swallow for the lump in my throat. Some western commentators suggested that they were little better than Stalinist robots planted in a crude display, but this is inaccurate - these people are genuinely glad. After 55 years of forced separation from their families, oppression, starvation, torture, poverty and humiliating foreign intervention, North Koreans have reason to welcome the South Korean president. There is a profound longing for peace in North and South Korea. Reunification will come, and, following this summit, it may be sooner than anyone thought. For most families, however, it will be too late to be reunited with their lost relations. Most of my mother's family in the North are dead by now, but no one knows for certain; no communication of any kind has been possible since 1945. My mother's family were from Kangwon province, which literally straddles the 38th parallel. They were aristocratic landowners there for 2,000 years. Our lands were artificially divided by the demarcation line, titles and properties stripped from us, first by the Japanese, and later by the communists. When the communists took power, some of our family stayed in the North, wrongly thinking the regime would be swiftly defeated. Of these, some were imprisoned; none were ever seen or heard from again. When I was in Korea for my first visit in 1987, I stood at the barbed-wire perimeter fence at the DMZ (demilitarised zone), gazing out across the landmine-strewn horizon at "North Korea". This was as close as I could get to meeting my relations there. When my mother left Korea during the war to study abroad she did not know if her cousins and grandparents were alive or dead. On my last visit, I brought back her ashes, and still it wasn't possible to scatter her remains on the hilltop she once described to me as a child. Still, I know my mother would have been moved and amused by the photographs of Kim Jong-il and Kim Dae-jung embracing. What struck me was how vulnerable and tired the North Korean dictator looked. Rather than being the evil red monster with two horns and a tail, here was an ageing, dissipated-looking man who looked as if he'd been on an 45-year bender. With some five million North Koreans estimated to have died of starvation during the past five years, it must have taken some doing for Kim Jong-il to sleep well, night after night, after his legendary banquets. His rarefied world of self-indulgence must be one of unimaginable loneliness and oddity. In that photograph of the Kims embracing they seem like fraternal twins, representing the opposite extremes of Korean politics.
