fields.headline: Silly billy
fields.standfirst: Denis Healey was the brilliant and brutal star of the Callaghan government. Now he's leading the charge against the euro. Sort of.
fields.trailText: Denis Healey was the brilliant and brutal star of the Callaghan government. Now he's leading the charge against the euro. Sort of.
fields.body:
Denis Winston Healey, poet, photographer, highbrow thug, has called people a lot of names over the years. Thatcher: "Virago intacta", "la Pasionaria of privilege" or "That bloody woman". Hurd: "A tattered Talleyrand"; Howe: "a dead sheep". Even Prescott, he once said, had the face of a man "who clubs baby seals". Today, we're just settling for "dear". "Come off it, dear," he says when once he might have hollered "silly bugger". "Hurry up, dear," he says, never before a stranger to the "sod off".

Thank God, then, for the pigeon. We meet on the terrace at the House of Lords where the crumbs of a previous collation are causing some feathered excitement. One pigeon lands briefly on my head. Healey, who has been sitting immobile like an old cat missing a few teeth, bored and indifferent to the mice frolicking at his feet, opens his red-rimmed blue eyes a little wider. "I asked him to come along," he says, eyebrows twitching like antennae. "I said, 'I've got a bird out here who needs going over.' "

Ostensibly, we have met to discuss Labour and the single European currency. Lord Healey, a member of David Owen's New Europe group, left his Sussex garden recently to speak out, along with Nigel Lawson - "of all people" - against joining. He's been on Sky the day before this interview, "though you get paid for that". He's always been pro-Europe, anti-euro, "and my views have just been confirmed by what's happened and I'm always interested when you get someone like Eddie George saying it's a mistake". But he won't be drawn any more than that, won't discuss the ferrets fighting in a bag, apart from to say that Hague stole that phrase from someone, "probably from me".

"It's a boring subject," he says. And as for being involved in the New Europe group and its "hard-hitting" white paper: "I say 'involved'... I just supported the thing which I suppose David probably wrote."

He thought, he adds, that the interview was to be about "this sudden interest in aged obesity". After spells of gout and diabetes, he has recently lost weight. There is still a sizeable stomach under the jacket of his shiny blue suit, but there is a empty envelope of skin between his neck and his chin. "Do you want my clothes off?" he says. I tell him he's attained the status of statesman. He says he hasn't. "A statesman is a dead politician." What are you then? "I'm in the home of the living dead which is betwixt and between. The House of Lords." And he laughs, but his face hardly moves.

He is 82 now and it is eight years since the politician believed by many to be the great Labour leader we never had - "brilliant and brutal" in the words of the Guardian's Hugo Young - gave up his seat as MP for Leeds East. He vacated his last cabinet post, as opposition spokesman for foreign affairs, in 1987. It is 21 years since he was active in government, as chancellor of the exchequer at the time of Margaret Thatcher's 79 election victory. It is even 11 years since he wrote his bestselling autobiography, The Time of My Life, a work which earned him £150,000 and which he refers you back to at intervals as if all activity stopped there. It is a long time to hang out in your hinterland and, Healeys living as long as they do (his father died at 92, his mother at 99), there is more time to come.

Does he enjoy retirement? "I enjoy my retirement, I don't particularly enjoy being retired, if you see what I mean. But I'm quite active. I'm reading Charlotte Brontë at the moment. I have my garden, my photography. I paint a bit, though none of my pictures are worth much. Occasionally I even talk to young ladies who work on newspapers." He enjoys the Lords, thinks Margaret Jay is "a very able woman, very attractive too". He stops a passing Norman Lamont for a chat. "This is just like a club really," he says after Lamont has gone, "much nicer, much less party than the Commons." So he doesn't watch the goings-on next door with his fingers twitching? "No," he says shortly. "The only point of being a politician is to do things, not just to talk about them."

He calls the Blair, Brown, Prescott triumvirate the "Holy Trinity". "They're a perfect mix, really. Each has qualities the other lacks. Prescott is extremely down to earth and very much in touch with how ordinary people think. Blair is a charismatic figure with a silver tongue and..." There is a pause. He seems lost for a moment. "Brown. Brown has a very powerful mind and I think he's a very good chancellor, and a prime minister who doesn't have a good chancellor is finished." He was a "pretty good" chancellor himself, he adds, though everybody in the party hated him "because you have to deny them all the time" and there was that spot of bother with the IMF.

"That was the most tiring time I ever had, negotiating what I thought were the most lenient conditions and then trying to get your cabinet colleagues to agree when they don't regard them as lenient. But it's a very different world now. Very different economy. We are no longer one of the world's three great powers. And of course Gordon hasn't yet had the sort of crisis which the oil crisis produced for me. But..." he adds, and one can't ignore the little smile, "that is always a possibility."

Does he think Brown, unlike Healey, might make leader himself one day? "He doesn't have the face for it."

Politics, he continues, has changed since "those days". "The public meeting is finished so you only really meet politicians now if you go to their surgeries and very few people do that, and otherwise they're just faces on the box so they feel more distant." Do politicians still have hinterlands? "Chris Smith is very interested in the arts. Tony loves travel. He loves culture, too, in a sense, otherwise he wouldn't be so interested in Italy. But it's a busier job now, so much faster..." There are fewer jokes, too, he says, far fewer people being savaged by dead sheep, or nuzzled by old rams.

"Disraeli made brilliant jokes and humour and wit have always played a major role in politics. You see it in Trollope. There are many quotes from him.... they're in my book. But now you don't get people deliberately making people laugh. People get laughed at despite themselves." Maybe the rhetorical putdown has been replaced by the spin? He looks fierce for a moment. Whoever would have guessed Healey would be on message? "You need people like Peter Mandelson with that ability to present things. I hardly know Alastair Campbell but I have a great sympathy for him because he spent some of his childhood at Keighley where I was brought up.

"One thing is still the same," he goes on sternly. "There has always been a tradition of thinking that politicians are nastier than other people. But in my experience - and I have lived in many different worlds, politics, the arts, contact with the church though I'm not a believing Christian - at the top of any profession you have exactly the same kind of jungle war. It's true that if a bishop stabs another in the back you can't see the blood flowing down because he wears a red surplice, but that's the only difference. When people are competing for fame or position, then it's a jungle war."

Next week, Lord Healey and Edna, his wife of 55 years, are off to Greece on a freebie. Healey has to go to a meeting in Thessalonika - "Oh, it'll be about everything that is happening in the world with a lot of Europeans, Americans, Japanese and Arabs, that sort of thing." He's not being paid, which galls a little. "In the old days I used to get £5,000 a time. Not bad, hmm? Though not as good as advertising. I spent half an hour once just sitting there, pretending I wasn't, with somebody else's hands making scrambled egg with smoked salmon for Sainsbury's and I got £50,000." They used his eyebrows on buses once. "Can't remember what for. They're very useful eyebrows. I once shaved them off and my trousers fell down so I had to let them grow again. You don't believe me, do you dear?"

The more he jokes, the less humour seems to emanate from Healey. When asked who "his chums" were, he gets caught up in the word. "Chums? Chums?" he says, as if alienated by the concept. "I don't hang out with people in that sense and never have. I've always been a loner. I'd rather spend time with my family." He missed out on a lot of his children's childhood (two girls and a boy), and can't remember how many grandchildren he has. "Um... er... come on, lad. Four. We've got four."

Lady Healey, he tells me, is writing two books at the moment, one about Emma Darwin, the other about "the wife of that champagne socialist called Denis Healey". He watches my face to see the penny drop. "I don't like champagne actually," he said, "I like whisky and ginger wine." A whisky mac, I say. He looks engaged for the first time, enthusiastic. "That's right. Exactly so. Yes, yes, yes."

When Big Ben strikes the hour, Healey looks at his watch. He isn't, he reminds me, being paid. Not even in euros. He shows me out. We get lost in the kitchens on the way.

fields.headline: No: 1658
fields.standfirst: Joy Luck Street
fields.trailText: Joy Luck Street
fields.body:
What is it?
A new Chinese version of Coronation Street. Manchester becomes Beijing and Granada Television, which will co-produce, gets to pocket £15m.

£15 million? Sounds a lot, just for Corrie.
Not when you consider that Joy Luck Street will go out on around 100 cable channels. It'll be on three times a week and viewing figures should be around the 400m mark.

What about the Rover's Return?
It becomes a Chinese bar selling local Chinese beer.

And the Kabin corner shop?
A local supermarket. Instead of chocolate, ciggies and tinned peaches, there'll be noodles, sacks of spices, the odd pig, perhaps, and fresh lychees.

So does Joy Luck Street have its own Mike Baldwin?
The nearest it gets to the middle-aged capitalist lothario is Gao Cheng, a local solicitor.

Who's the gossip?
Xu Aizhu. Xu is Mandarin for Audrey, we think. And Aizhu obviously means Roberts.

Go on, who else?
There's Xu Xiaoyang.

Two Xus? This is getting confusing.
Not as confusing as when Xu Xiaoyang has to put his initials next to the x when he's filling out forms.

Don't be daft - they don't really use our alphabet. So what does this new Xu do then?
Goes out with Ah Lan, an actress. And Cheng Wan, a market trader.

Xu plays away?
Yes. Which is kind of appropriate, as he used to be a footballer.

For Shanghai Shenhua?
No. For an as yet undisclosed English premiership team. The producers are currently in negotiations with clubs.

They're negotiatiating to determine which club he used to play for? Weird.
Not when you think about it. 400m viewers, that means 400m potential replica shirt buyers.

Do say:
Crispy Duckworths, anyone?

Don't say:
Who ate Minnie Caldwell's cat?

webTitle: Barak caves in to save coalition

fields.headline: Barak caves in to save coalition
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday surrendered to the unruly coalition partner that has been holding his government to ransom, sacrificing his pride to keep the peace process alive.
fields.body:
Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, yesterday surrendered to the unruly coalition partner that has been holding his government to ransom, sacrificing his pride to keep the peace process alive.

Mr Barak's decision to cancel his weekly cabinet meeting was plainly meant to stop the 12-day crisis that has hobbled his government from exploding in his face. By putting off the day of reckoning, he bought time to finesse the deal under which he hopes to win the loyalties of the ultra-orthodox Shas party, which had threatened to leave his coalition.

Mr Barak hopes to unveil the terms of the deal tomorrow, but newspapers carried accounts of the humiliating compromises he has had to swallow: extra funding and greater autonomy for Shas's scandal-ridden religious schools, and the creation of a new broadcasting authority to legalise its Channels of Holiness pirate radio network.

The deal marks a new pinnacle for Shas, which has adroitly blended ultra-orthodox theology with an appeal to the wounded ethnic pride of Jews of Middle Eastern origin. After making a modest parliamentary debut in 1984, the party, with 17 members in the knesset, is the second largest in the ruling coalition.

Israel's secular majority views the last days of frantic manoevrings with disgust, and sees Shas's extreme religiosity as a throwback to the middle ages. But for the 430,000 Shas voters, Mr Barak's cave-in is seen as retribution for the discrimination they have suffered at the hands of a largely European elite.

Some commentators said the crisis was an inevitable result of Israel's electoral system. Mr Barak was directly elected with 56% of the popular vote, but that has not translated into real power when it comes to steering his coalition.

"Israel is in danger of becoming a deadlocked democracy, in the sense of being paralysed to make decisions ahead," said Yaron Ezrahi, a political scientist at Hebrew University.

Such fears could be laid to rest if Mr Barak succeeds in extracting an agreement with the Palestinians before Yasser Arafat declares an independent state on September 13. But with the peace process at a standstill, with acrimonious exchanges on both sides after the return of negotiators from the latest round of talks in Washington yesterday, the chances of a breakthrough look unlikely.

Although Israel is to release three Palestinian prisoners today, Palestinians have proved singularly unimpressed by the goodwill gesture, demanding the release of some 1,650 prisoners and pressing Israel to fulfil a promise to transfer more territories in the West Bank by June 23, which Mr Barak is in no mind to do.

Yesterday, his office issued a gloomy statement on the prospects for peace following a briefing for cabinet ministers. "While Israel is interested in a settlement and is even willing to make difficult decisions, it is not possible to enforce a settlement on the other side," the statement said.

"While Israel is interested in a settlement and is even willing to make difficult decisions, it is not possible to enforce a settlement on the other side," the statement said.

webTitle: Medical breakthrough could end uncertainty over the onset of labour

fields.headline: Medical breakthrough could end uncertainty over the onset of labour
fields.trailText: The frightening uncertainty over the start of labour in pregnancy is set to become a thing of the past, after a breakthrough by British medical engineers.
fields.body:
The frightening uncertainty over the start of labour in pregnancy is set to become a thing of the past, after a breakthrough by British medical engineers.

A joint project between doctors and physicists in Leeds is close to perfecting a do-it-yourself monitor of the changes in electrical impulses that show labour is imminent. A prototype hand-held device has passed trials on women approaching full term, giving accurate forecasts within a two-day period before birth.

Extended trials are under way with the aim of producing a monitor which is reliable for up to a fortnight before the onset of labour.

The longer-term target is an affordable device -about the size of a personal stereo - which would be available over the counter and simple enough to use without help from a doctor or midwife.

Non-invasive, it would record electrical impulses from outside the body. The team behind its development think that it will be another year or two before such a device is ready.

"All our data to date indicates that labour is a predictable event," said Nigel Simpson of Leeds medical school, a body linking Leeds University, the general infirmary and St James's hospitals.

"Giving women more knowledge as to when it is about to happen empowers them."

The system has been developed following a decision by the Leeds specialists to strike out in a new direction from traditional, and often haphazard, attempts at predicting the onset of labour. These have relied on monitoring simpler physical changes in the body or biochemical tests. Both systems have a much greater likelihood of requiring women to see GPs or go into hospital early for what may prove false alarms.

Dr Simpson, who is based at the infirmary, and James Walker of St James's, spent a year looking at electrical data after success monitoring other parts of the body.

"Just as an electrocardiogram works by sensing electrical activity in the heart, this approach measures uterine electrical activity, which changes significantly ahead of the onset of labour," Dr Simpson said.

The prototype monitor uses software which has to be linked to a personal computer - but the project team is confident that a much smaller version is within reach.

Electrocardiograms have come within the reach of lay users in recent years, notably through emergency systems designed for mountain and offshore rescue teams.

Volunteers in the Lake District regularly use machines which are linked by modem to local hospitals to monitor the condition and treatment of heart-attack casualties on the fells before they reach hospital.

fields.headline: Strangers at the gate
fields.standfirst:
A short leap of imagination by Somerset villagers could transform asylum seekers from a threat to a gift

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: A short leap of imagination by Somerset villagers could transform asylum seekers from a threat to a gift
fields.body:
A black face can still turn heads in Nether Stowey. Walk into a pub in this small Somerset village, even when Euro 2000 is on the big screen, and there will be that same momentary silence you will hear in just about any rural bar in Britain as you single-handedly integrate a social space.

A tiny stretch of time when the dart seems to hover at the dart board and beer remains suspended between tap and glass - just long enough so that everyone notices, but short enough that anyone could claim you were imagining it. Not hostile stares, for good-natured conversation soon follows, but the overlong glances from people not used to strangers and for whom a non-white face denotes not just ethnicity but geography. It means "You are not from here."

This is the Mild West - Coleridge country -where hills roll, roads wind and only the bleating of sheep and rustling of leaves disturb the silence on a balmy summer's day. But recently this apparent tranquillity has been disturbed by an attempt to house up to 74 asylum seekers from Kosovo, Sierra Leone and Sudan in a former boarding school in nearby Over Stowey - a tiny hamlet of 314 people.

Planning permission for the centre was refused by Somerset council. The inquiry into that decision, which was held last week, is being viewed as a legal test case for attempts to disperse asylum seekers around the country. It also risks being turned into a moral test case on the rights of asylum seekers to exist at all.

The proposal, which has been made by the Baptist charity Kaleidoscope, has aroused the kind of blatant xenophobia that most thought had been laid to rest with Love Thy Neighbour and the Robinsons golliwog. If some locals are to be believed, the arrival of people fleeing terror in their home countries will cause house prices to tumble, crime to escalate and even compromise the virtue of local young women.

The right has tried to portray these fears as emblematic of the Tory-led assault on asylum seekers - a bastion of essential, monocultural Englishness, according to the Telegraph and the Mail, is about to be "swamped" by unwelcome foreigners thanks to a group of do-gooding liberals. They have created not only a mythic sense of what Over Stowey is, but a demonic sense of who the asylum seekers are too.

These attitudes do not come from nowhere. William Hague has sown the seeds from which this particular strain of bigotry grows and the Labour leadership has so far proved itself too spineless to get its hands dirty and pull his work out at the roots. As a consequence, we have turned into a nation that can stand up for "humanitarianism" when it comes to sending soldiers to the Balkans and Africa but is incapable of dealing with the actual humans who flee the self-same conflicts. We have learned how to export righteousness at the barrel of a gun, we just cannot bring ourselves to distribute it through the Home Office on our own doorstep.

In the church in Over Stowey there is a picture of Msusi Nyanzi - a young boy they have sponsored from Uganda. One wonders what reception he would get if, like Clare Boylan's Black Baby, he turned up one day and asked for his benefactors to provide him with the kind of Christian charity that actually made a difference to their daily lives. Probably the same reaction as the displaced families of Bujumbura, whose pictures stand nearby on the board devoted to the Mothers' Union.

Not that everyone in Over Stowey is a bigot: far from it. Some express concern that the area is not equipped to cope with such large numbers - the nearest pub, shop or post office is more than a mile away from the hostel and the bus to the nearest big town, Bridgwater, comes only twice a week.

They have a point. The location of Quantock Lodge, where the asylum seekers would be housed, is more suitable for a hospice than a hostel. It is set in woodland off the road and a good 15 minutes walk from Over Stowey itself. True, there is a swimming pool, sports pitches and arts centre in the former school - which paradoxically some local people also resent - and Kaleidoscope plans to run a minibus to Bristol, Bridgwater and Nether Stowey. But it remains extremely isolated - possibly ideal for people suffering from traumatic experiences but hopeless for those who want to exercise some independence.

Somehow, however, one gets the feeling that if the asylum seekers were white Zimbabwean farmers on the run from Mugabe, we would not be talking about bus services and walking distances. It is also a very small community in which to place a relatively large group of people. But then Over Stowey has already shown that it can cope with this. The idea that it has been a haven of pure, lily-white Englishness is bogus, not the asylum seekers. The Lodge used to be a private school that took in a large number of Hong Kong Chinese. But they were wealthy and not, at the time, national hate figures.

There is little doubt that the arrival of asylum seekers will change Over Stowey and the surrounding area. The trouble is the automatic presumption that it will change for the worse, the notion that all that 74 people from different parts of the globe can bring to a small, ageing, rural area is crime and destitution, that an area where black people are still to be stared at has nothing to learn about the modern world.

Not everyone in the area believes that. Several local people are strongly in favour of the plans. The debate has pitted the vicar (pro) against the head of the parish council (anti) and split families. There have been petitions and heated meetings.

"It'll be great to have people here," said Suki Ince as she weeded her garden. She says those who oppose the hostel are a vocal minority; they say most of those who back it are outsiders. "Some of the things people have been saying have made me ashamed to be from this village. One person said they'd moved here from London to get away from all that. That kind of thing really surprised me."

When a visitor expressed envy at the fact that transport in the area is bad and yet the asylum seekers will get their own bus, Ince retorted: "Well, great. Then maybe we can use their bus."

Her visitor had not thought of that. And in just one sharp response, the focus had shifted from asylum seekers being people who will definitely take something away to people who had something to add. From a problem to an opportunity.

And then she went back to her weeding - seeking out the problem plants and yanking each one out by the roots.

webTitle: We just don't know what to believe

fields.headline: We just don't know what to believe
fields.standfirst:
The spin doctors' legacy is widespread cynicism

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Like so many other phrases which debase the language, "spin doctor" is an American import and I assume a relatively recent addition to the lexicon of ugly expression. Pierre Salinger, who these days would be said to spin for President Kennedy, was certainly never described in that way.
fields.body:
Like so many other phrases which debase the language, "spin doctor" is an American import and I assume a relatively recent addition to the lexicon of ugly expression. Pierre Salinger, who these days would be said to spin for President Kennedy, was certainly never described in that way. Nor was Bill Moyers who did the job for Lyndon Johnson. My suspicion is that in Britain the description was put about, if not by Peter Mandelson himself, by Labour party press officers of the Mandelson era. For that is the time that talking to the media became an independent operation. Until then it had been an activity which was essentially supplementary to the practice of politics. In the eighties it became an occupation in its own right. New Labour is now paying the price for that change of status.

Until Bernard Ingham moved into the office behind 10 Downing Street's front window, nobody outside a highly limited circle of political correspondents and members of parliament knew the name of the prime minister's press secretary. Such people only existed as extensions of their master. From time to time, they disowned erring ministers, reinterpreted parliamentary statements and confided secrets about the way in which their prime minister's mind was working. But they were never more than an extension of their masters' long shadow. They told a story in which they did not take part.

Even when Sir Bernard took over the job - arriving in Downing Street thanks to the earlier patronage of Barbara Castle and Tony Benn - nobody ever thought that he was a free agent. Indeed he was criticised for being totally Margaret Thatcher's creature - "the sewer, not the sewage" in the immortal phrase of one offended Minister. He was not even one of the full supporting cast on the political stage. Ingham was in the prompt box making sure that the audience, as well as the cast, knew the approved dialogue by heart.

But then "spin" became a trade which was discussed on television by those who practised it. They were so proud of the way in which they massaged the message that they could not resist boasting about their achievements. The New Labour spin machine became - certainly in the opinion of those who drove it and possibly in its judgment of more objective observers - the most effective press operation in the history of democratic politics. And the operators milked the applause. So we saw photographs of them standing, like mafiosi, at the back of the Labour party conference and gesticulating wildly when they feared that the politicians who employed them - people who were actually elected to parliament - had ignored their advice.

Those real politicians must take some of the blame. It was they who elevated presentation above policy and - by giving the spin doctors a veto over policy - encouraged them to have ideas far above their station. And none of them had the sense to realise that if they went on boasting about the way they fixed the news, the people whom they hoped to impress would assume that the news was too crooked to be taken seriously. Last week minister after minister appeared on radio and television to repeat the same sentence - "Tony Blair is opening a new hospital at the end of the week". Knowing that repetition is a sure sign of spin, I took it for granted that the Downing Street press office had been at work. But I assumed that the fact they all parroted was true. However, I guarantee that millions of listeners wondered "Is it really new?" and "Has it been opened just to divert attention from other discontents?" Who really believed that, on the morning after the birth of baby Leo, Tony Blair just happened to come out of No 10 with a coffee mug in his hand? The cynicism is the legacy of the Mandelson era.

Now Alastair Campbell is to withdraw from public relations front line. The electorate's reaction to the announcement was perfectly illustrated by a man who stopped me in the street last Thursday and asked, in all seriousness "Are they really cutting down on spin or is the announcement just more spin of a different kind?" Few people will believe that the spinning is over while Alastair Campbell - soon to be immortalised in a fly-on-the-wall television documentary - is still in Downing Street.

I do not call for his resignation. After all, when I was shadow home secretary I never demanded the head of Kenneth Baker. So my tolerance level is infinite. I simply state the facts. Although he will not be bullying lobby correspondents at the daily briefing, complaining to political editors about their prejudice or calling the chancellor of the exchequer "psychologically flawed", journalists (some with old scores to settle) will not forget him. And innumerable floating voters - who lost their political innocence under New Labour - will believe that the government's real achievements are illusions of success created by "spin doctors". The spin doctors have only themselves to blame.

fields.headline: Teen pop star recovers
fields.trailText: The teenage pop star Billie Piper was yesterday recovering in hospital after collapsing in central London. Billie, 17, foamed at the mouth after keeling over while at Bar 38 in Covent Garden, witnesses said.
fields.body:
The teenage pop star Billie Piper was yesterday recovering in hospital after collapsing in central London. Billie, 17, foamed at the mouth after keeling over while at Bar 38 in Covent Garden, witnesses said.

Her spokesman said she was suffering from a "mild kidney infection" and was being given antibiotics.

The incident on Friday night happened when Piper went out with friends and two of her dancers.

James Dunne, the duty manager at Bar 38, said: "The lady fainted in a group of her own friends and left the building. No assistance was asked for from ourselves."

Piper shot to fame in July 1998 when her debut single Because We Want To entered the charts at number one, making her the youngest solo female singer since Helen Shapiro, in 1961, to top the charts. Her success has been built on her ability to appeal to record buyers aged nine to 14 years.

Her agent Dave Pittman said her condition was not serious and issued a statement, on her behalf, which said: "It all came as a bit of a shock. One minute, I'm having fun with my friends, the next I'm being carried to a car by a bouncer."

Mr Pittman said she would remain in hospital for a couple of days.

Since coming to public attention, illness has forced Piper to pull out of events. After one such cancellation she told an interviewer: "It was just flu and tonsillitis and it came at the wrong time. I fly a lot and I'm always kissing fans and holding their hands. I'm not suggesting they're full of germs but you're bound to pick up everything going.

"There is also a lot to cope with, it's emotionally and physically draining. I spent the first year worrying about what people thought and concentrating on 'how to be a pop star'. I forgot about my own needs."

Last May her mother Mandy told an interviewer of her fears that her daughter would suffer because of the pressures of a pop star lifestyle. She said: "Of course I worry about drugs. I've spoken to her about them a lot. Hopefully she'll never do it. I don't think she will but who knows?

"I've said to her, 'if anybody ever offers you anything before you go on stage, don't you dare take it'. Being a mother you hear about it all and you can't help but panic."

fields.headline: Joy in (part of) the land
fields.standfirst:
But demon drink spoils the show
Football violence: special report
fields.trailText: England's was a necessary victory. It is not sufficient to prove anything - especially on those big questions about the club-country balance and the depth of the talent reservoir. Some think judgment of Kevin Keegan and his tactics are not premature, but the fair-minded will wait till tomorrow. So far Euro 2000 has only shown the limit of most generalisations about victory formulae. Italy indicates
fields.body:
And joy in the land was unconfined - at least in that part of Great Britain east and south of its internal borders and that part of the population not mesmerised by events at Edgbaston or transfixed by the fate of an England squad in the South African highlands.

As for the score, was it not something like the BBC 12m, ITV 6m, a result that again confirms the public's appreciation of the national broadcaster (except that "national" is increasingly problematic)? Alan Shearer's goal may only have suspended the sentence but it was hard to miss the collective exhalation across the bosom of England on Saturday evening.

England's was a necessary victory. It is not sufficient to prove anything - especially on those big questions about the club-country balance and the depth of the talent reservoir. Some think judgment of Kevin Keegan and his tactics are not premature, but the fair-minded will wait till tomorrow. So far Euro 2000 has only shown the limit of most generalisations about victory formulae. Italy indicates what can be done with a strong club scene and France with a weak one.

Until the dust settles and tallies are compared with the Dutch and Belgian police, it will not be possible to say whether the surveillance of known hooligans was any more effective this time round. Let the Tories rant: the party that brought us knee-jerk legislation on dangerous dogs and football licensing has learnt and forgotten nothing. Tony Banks has a sharp axe to grind as cheerleader for England hosting the 2006 world cup, but is probably right about the behaviour of hangers-on out for a drink and a fight in Charleroi and Brussels: it is a problem only contingently related to the sport, intimately to young people and their use of alcohol. England is not an "exceptional" team, winning or losing. There is, however, deep within England's social structure and popular attitudes an exceptional tendency to condone excess off the field.

As for the score, was it not something like the BBC 12m, ITV 6m, a result that again confirms the public's appreciation of the national broadcaster (except that "national" is increasingly problematic)? fields.headline: Winning over women
fields.standfirst:
Beware of inverting Blairite populism
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Since the Women's Institute incident, conventional wisdom rabbits on about Labour's problem with gender. Catchpenny psychologists roll up to tell us why Tony Blair's pleasing non-macho style circa 1997 has turned into something rebarbative, despite baby Leo. The historical fact is that Labour has always (at least since 1918) had a problem with older women and vice versa. Younger women are, if anything, more leftwards inclined than their male peers.
fields.body:
Since the Women's Institute incident, conventional wisdom rabbits on about Labour's problem with gender. Catchpenny psychologists roll up to tell us why Tony Blair's pleasing non-macho style circa 1997 has turned into something rebarbative, despite baby Leo. The historical fact is that Labour has always (at least since 1918) had a problem with older women and vice versa. Younger women are, if anything, more leftwards inclined than their male peers.

By and large women voters are functionalists. Their preferences turn on which party is going to benefit them or their immediate family. Labour has started to fall foul of their practical tests of political acceptability by having failed to cut class sizes and reduce waiting lists as promised. They will now, presumably, vote Tory on the grounds that state services are going to be better looked after by that well-known friend of collective, tax-financed endeavour William Hague.

In her new Fabian pamphlet on Labour and women, Harriet Harman desperately wants to believe that more and better policies for women and children will bring electoral reward. That of course cannot be their justification; it may even run the risk of inverting the populism which so tempts Tony Blair. A higher minimum wage is desirable because it is just (interesting, this weekend, how its former arch-enemy, Stephen Byers, has changed his tune). Similarly more generous maternity pay and a better balance between work and "life" follow from the ambition to make society more civilised. The case for Labour's national childcare strategy, Sure Start and its various initiatives to improve both children's life chances and women's opportunities is best founded on an aspiration of women's emancipation not a voting calculation. Ms Harman's own data shows many women are uncertain about work and its childcare implications.

She stoutly make a case for revisiting the gender balance in Labour's parliamentary representation, even creating a new position of deputy leader reserved for a woman. Such reforms need to be cast as a way of modernising Labour and changing its physiognomy. Ms Harman implies that more women MPs will mean electorate-friendly policy. Does that really follow? The arrival of individual women in top jobs does not guarantee progressive policies. Look at the pallid performance by Ann Taylor and Margaret Beckett on Commons' reform.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Horn of Africa war reprieve
fields.body:
Horn of Africa war reprieve

Ethiopia and Eritrea yesterday signed an agreement to cease hostilities in their more than two-year border war that has left tens of thousands dead in the African countries.

The accord, reached at talks in Algeria, does not bring a definitive end to the fighting but allows for a reprieve as negotiators delineate the border. It calls for peacekeepers deployed in a "security zone" during negotiations. AP, Algiers

German plan to free hostages

Germany is considering a plan to end the Philippine hostage crisis by providing a humanitarian aid package to Islamic rebels who have been holding 21 people captive on the island of Jolo since Easter Sunday, Welt am Sonntag newspaper reported yesterday.

The paper quoted intelligence sources as saying Berlin was ready to supply the package in lieu of agreeing to a $20m ransom demand. Three of the hostages are German. Tony Paterson, Berlin

Nato detonates Kosovo bombs

British bomb experts with the Nato-led Kosovo peacekeeping force yesterday detonated two explosive charges in Pristina. One of them was in a car in front of the Grand, the city's main hotel, and the other was nearby. AP, Pristina

Election official flees Haiti

Haiti's top election official has fled the country in fear of his life after coming under pressure to release flawed election results, diplomatic sources said yesterday.

Leon Manus, the president of Haiti's provisional electoral council, crossed the border to the Dominican Republic on Saturday and planned to reach the US, the sources said. Reuters, Port-au-Prince

fields.headline: Mark Hughes
fields.standfirst: Purveyor of Californian health cures to the credulous
fields.trailText: Mark Hughes, who has died aged 44, apparently of natural causes, was founder of the Herbalife International weight-loss and nutrition company. His body was found at his mansion on the Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu, which he had bought in December for $25m.
fields.body:
Mark Hughes, who has died aged 44, apparently of natural causes, was founder of the Herbalife International weight-loss and nutrition company. His body was found at his mansion on the Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu, which he had bought in December for $25m.

Bulldozing the properties adjoining his previous $20m Beverly Hills mansion had brought him into conflict with neighbours, as had his application for exemption from height restrictions for the $50m "Mediterranean-style villa" he wanted to build in Benedict Canyon.

But Hughes's main troubles concerned the firm he founded in Beverly Hills at the age of 24, Herbalife International, described in 1997 by Forbes business magazine as selling dubious elixirs for weight reduction and nutrition. Herbalife was the subject of complaints almost from the first month, in which it sold $23,000 of powders and potions, building to $2m by the year's end and to $500m annually five years later.

During the next few years the firm was formally criticised at least three times by the United States Food and Drugs Administration, and subject to a CNN television exposé, a senate investigative committee inquiry, denunciations from a medical watchdog organisation and an $850,000 penalty payment imposed by the California attorney general for making false medical claims and marketing an illegal pyramid sales scheme. This recruited 750,000 "distributors" in what Hughes claimed were 48 countries, including Britain.

Through it all Hughes maintained a cherubic smile, and his web site included cheery messages exhorting customers to buy more and promising fortunes. But finding an address or a telephone number for corporate headquarters was impossible.

He said he had founded the firm to "devote his life to improving people's health" because his mother had died when he was 18 from a drug used to lose weight. In fact, her death was caused by an addiction to amphetamine.

As for the "natural" ingredients Hughes claimed were the basis of his products, some were at various times judged to be toxic, and at other times carcinogenic. The PhD whom he promoted as his original scientific adviser had bought his degree from a correspondence school, and the research laboratory the advertisements boasted of was exposed by CNN as a conference room table loaded with books about herbs. Hughes had abandoned his schooling aged 14. He then spent three years in a residence for troubled youths.

At the senate inquiry, Hughes arrived with an entourage and another (genuine) PhD, who had to admit that he had been hired only when Hughes received a subpoena. Hughes hit back at the senators' scientific advisers by saying: "If they're such experts, why are they so fat? I've lost 16 pounds in the last few years on my products."

The FDA formally warned Herbalife for mislabelling, making false health claims, and engendering too many complaints from users. Forbes later reported that with such pyramid schemes, initially impressive sales always faltered, and when this happened to Herbalife in the US, he turned to suckers abroad until over three quarters of his business was in foreign countries.

Last autumn, as the firm's share price fell to $12, Hughes announced he would buy all the outstanding shares for $17 each. He increased this to $17.81 in January after shareholders sued him, but in April withdrew the offer when the shares collapsed to $4. Just before his death they traded at $10.

He was married three times. In 1997 he announced that he and his third wife Suzan, a former Miss Petite America, were separating.

 Mark Reynolds Hughes, health products purveyor, born January 1 1956; died May 21 2000

fields.headline: Work in progress
fields.standfirst: The EU faces a fraught half-year
fields.trailText: The European Union faces an unusually broad range of contentious issues but expectations are low that any one of them will be settled at the summit which convenes in Feira, Portugal, today. The problem is that these divisive matters may still not be sorted out in six months' time, when the French presidency is supposed to culminate in Nice with a treaty to compare with Maastricht.
fields.body:
The European Union faces an unusually broad range of contentious issues but expectations are low that any one of them will be settled at the summit which convenes in Feira, Portugal, today. The problem is that these divisive matters may still not be sorted out in six months' time, when the French presidency is supposed to culminate in Nice with a treaty to compare with Maastricht.

The slow pace of consensus-building and decision-making within the EU has long been notorious. If membership increased without large-scale changes to the architecture it would get worse, to the point of stasis. Doubts have grown through the period of the Portuguese presidency about when first-wave candidates such as Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, let alone the other 10 aspirants can be permitted to join, for the EU's as much as their sake. The slowing pace is the result of many factors, not least the EU's reluctance to extend its already enormously expensive agricultural subsidy system. Since the EU is far from agreed on enlargement-related proposals to expand the use of qualified majority voting, the weighting of votes in the council of ministers and changes to the composition of the commission and parliament, it is hardly surprising that 2005, rather than 2003, is looking more and more like the earliest point of entry for new members.

All the same, these institutional reform issues should, in theory, be settled during the next half year. Likewise, the transformation of the European security and defence identity project into the promised reality of a 60,000-strong rapid reaction force, complementary to but separate from Nato, is scheduled to be completed by the time EU leaders assemble on the Cote d'Azur. France can count on the United Kingdom's help in pushing along this particular initiative, defence being one of the few areas of policy where the two countries engage creatively. But quite how it is all going to work and who is going to pay for it as defence budgets fall (in Germany, perhaps also in the UK) remains unclear.

Single issues such as the proposed Europe-wide withholding tax so detested by chancellor Gordon Brown still have the potential to disrupt summits. But one of the main successes of the Portuguese presidency, from one perspective at least, has been its encouragement of the resurgent debate about "enhanced cooperation", a term of art also called flexibility, subsidiarity and variable geometry. It is becoming increasingly clear that a core group of countries, most of them already more closely linked through membership of the 11-strong euro-zone club, will seek to speed up aspects of integration - whatever hold-outs such as the UK and for now at least, Denmark, may say. The "savings tax" row aside, taxation is generally speaking an area where a joint EU approach is more and more probable. The pressure is growing on the UK to decide in this instance, as with policy on the environment, justice and law and order, and indeed, the euro, whether it wants to keep pace with the majority or slip gradually into a quasi-permanent, second-tier placing.

Not that the path of integration runs smooth for others. Differences in approach between France and Germany, symbolised by the recent speeches of their foreign ministers, Joschka Fischer (enthusiastic) and Hubert Védrine (more cautious), indicate that the old axis is still far from what it was and that the overall vision of what Europe should and will become is still very far from settled. A work in progress as always: but harder going now than ever.

fields.headline: Envoy from cyberspace
fields.trailText: I would like to make a short response to your excellent supplement on online government (Vote with your mouse, June 8). We were pleased that the tone was generally supportive - we know we have a difficult task and have set ourselves ambitious targets.
fields.body:
I would like to make a short response to your excellent supplement on online government (Vote with your mouse, June 8). We were pleased that the tone was generally supportive - we know we have a difficult task and have set ourselves ambitious targets. In fact, these are even more ambitious than those set out in the supplement: in March, Tony Blair announced he was bringing forward the target for 100% of government services online to 2005.

The article makes the point that the visual impact of the government's websites is often poor. We are addressing that urgently - with the appointment of the new media team, under Alex Allan. And they will be ensuring that new, high-quality sites will have the common government brand - UK Online. Later this, a new personalised gateway to the government's online services will be launched. Services currently online include Companies House (online returns and searches); NHS Direct; Foreign Office advice for those travelling abroad; consumer advice; and a comprehensive news service on the Number 10 website.

We are driving forward. The e-government strategy, published in April (www.iagchampions.gov.uk) gives a good picture of the way ahead. It makes it clear that the e-envoy, supported by the government's information age champions, will provide the strong leadership that is needed.

Ian McCartney
Minister of State, Cabinet Office

fields.headline: Think again on RUC bill
fields.trailText: The Patten report on policing in Northern Ireland was ground-breaking in its attempt to build a new policing service on the basis of protecting human rights.
fields.body:
The Patten report on policing in Northern Ireland was ground-breaking in its attempt to build a new policing service on the basis of protecting human rights. Amnesty is greatly disappointed that human rights protection is not at the heart of the draft police (NI) bill, currently in the Commons.

The bill undermines many of the good recommendations made in the report and weakens its central tenet: "Accountability should run through the bloodstream of the whole body of a police service." The proposed legislation repeats the mistakes of the past by placing too much power in the hands of the secretary of state and the chief constable. It raises doubts that the new policing service will be truly accountable to the law and to the community it would serve.

The secretary of state, Peter Mandelson (I am listening, June 16) said that "the key point is to ensure that all officers are bound by the same standards of behaviour". However, the bill states that the new oath of office - to uphold human rights - would only apply to new recruits.

Despite the Patten report's proposal that the powers of the ombudsperson should be increased, the bill significantly curtails them. The ombudsperson would be restricted to investigating specific complaints and would not be able to initiate investigations into clearly identified patterns of human rights violations, such as ill-treatment at interrogation centres. The new policing board will also be limited in its ability to obtain information about police conduct.

The challenge facing parliament now is to provide for a policing service which will conform to international human rights standards, be fully accountable and have the confidence of all sides of the community. The bill, as it stands, does not meet this challenge.

Javier Zuniga
Programme director for UK, Amnesty International

 Brendan O'Leary (Comment, June 14) is a last-century commentator. His attack on the Northern Ireland police bill smacks of past ravings of sectarianism. One of the most remarkable yet unremarked successes of recent years has been the way politicians of all hues have been persuaded to avoid inflamatory rhetoric. In other words to speak in the knowledge they are being listened to by their opponents' supporters as well as their own interests.

Negotiated compromise between opposites will always be messy, yet O'Leary's polemic seems designed to wreck rather than improve. How about a little more reasoning and a little less ranting?

Ken Jones
London

fields.headline: Foul play in Charleroi
fields.trailText: So, this government has thrown away the opportunity for our country to host future football championships (Belgian police hold 170, June 17).
fields.body:
So, this government has thrown away the opportunity for our country to host future football championships (Belgian police hold 170, June 17). It is not enough to say most of the further 500 arrested at the England-Germany match did not appear on lists of trouble-makers and confiscation of passports would not have prevented them travelling. The only way to have prevented that would have been to institute a rigid policy of "no match ticket - no travel" on ferries and flights. Bona fide business travellers and holiday-makers should have been asked to produce evidence of the purpose of their holiday. I know this would have infringed civil liberties, but it is the only way of preserving England's good name.

Phil Sherwood
Weymouth, Dorset

 Presumably the "England supporters" who trashed Brussels were merely continuing William Hague's policies by other means?

Simon Hunter
Brookmans Park, Herts simonhunter@talk21.com

 What a record! Still undefeated by Germany in a competitive match this century.

David Williams
Prudhoe, Northumberland

 So watching paint dry is more exciting than Scottish football (Letters, June 17). What is more exciting than this cliché? Groups of arrogant, xenophobic beer-bellied English fans destroying beautiful cities in a country whose people ask nothing more than to be able to host a tournament of the beautiful game in peace? Or, we could always watch that clip again: you know, the one from another era, whose only relevance now is to remind you that you weren't always the laughing stock of football?

We Scots are happy to support other British nations: it's just that the English have caused enough riots and generally lowered the reputation of British football that being associated with them is not top of our wish lists. My reason at present for wishing a quick demise of that team of has-beens and never-weres is that I like Belgium and Holland. They're nice countries and the quicker the English fans leave, the more chance they have of staying that way.

fields.headline: Becks' cultured right foot
fields.trailText: There are many reasons to explain Britain's poor showing in advanced literacy (How the British lag behind in reading, June 15; Letters, June 16). But one which should not be ignored is the corrosive effect of market philosophy on the idea of culture.
fields.body:
There are many reasons to explain Britain's poor showing in advanced literacy (How the British lag behind in reading, June 15; Letters, June 16). But one which should not be ignored is the corrosive effect of market philosophy on the idea of culture. Matthew Arnold was aware of this problem in the 19th-century, but it has become steadily worse since he castigated the philistinism of the business class for viewing everything in "practical" terms.

Such an attitude discounts the study of literature: after all, how does reading Jane Austen help the economy? Not at all. What it does do is help create a sensibility which does not look at society in purely economic terms. It is a reminder that there are other perceptions, values, apprehensions and judgments other than profit and loss.

It is of course in the interest of the business class to rubbish this attitude, but lately it has been seeking to eradicate it completely by starving the humanities of funds in the universities unless they can demonstrate their usefulness to an economy in which at least one-fifth of children live in poverty and which pays £20,000 a week or more to a footballer whose sole contribution to the common good is his ability to cross the ball. Literacy will never improve if culture is held in contempt and economic values are prized over human ones.

Gary Day
Bedford gday@dingleydell.in2home.co.uk

 Many complex and powerful cultural and socio-economic factors dominate the British approach to TV. As part of our induction programme for reception children, I ask parents to switch off the television whilst hearing their child read. The following is a note I received: "Sorry to tell you that we are having problems getting him to read to us. I've told him to switch off the TV like you said, but he won't." Where does one begin?

F Thomas
Kent

 One-fifth of UK children live on or below the poverty line; I bet they can't wait for reform of the Oxford entrance procedures.

Peter McCourt
West Bridgford, Notts

fields.headline: A twinkle in their eyes
fields.trailText: Your article on the GM vote in east Yorkshire (Villagers back GM crops in referendum, June 17) suggests this was "the biggest official GM test in Britain".
fields.body:
Your article on the GM vote in east Yorkshire (Villagers back GM crops in referendum, June 17) suggests this was "the biggest official GM test in Britain". In a council-organised ballot on local trials in Wivenhoe, in which over 2,000 people voted (a turnout of 38%), 88% voted against the trials.

Stewart Belfield
Wivenhoe, Essex fast.wiv@dial.pipex.com

 At Surrey county council we are well advanced in developing a school bus scheme (US yellow bus plan to cut school traffic, June 10). The yellow bus model has features that wouldn't transfer to the UK, not least its failure to meet UK and European emission standards. But the concept of an escorted bus service, with enhanced safety, providing a reliable and practical alternative to the car is very exciting. We have held detailed talks about a solution tailored to the needs of Surrey, where traffic problems consistently top the list of concerns.

Cllr Nick Skellett
Leader, Surrey county council

 No "fresh blood" policy exists at the BBC World Service. Most of our staff are on continuing contracts and our goal is to increase the level to 75% by March next year. But in a fast-changing media environment, we need the flexibility for some staff to be on non-renewable, fixed-term contracts and for some short-term provision to cover special programmes, maternity leave, training cover etc.

Mark Byford
Director, BBC World Service

 You say (Leader, June 16) that the national missile defence system has problems distinguishing which rocket emissions or "twinkles" are decoys and which are actual missiles with nuclear warheads. Might the answer to this problem of the "twinkle factor" be pixie dust.

Nigel Baldwin
Portsmouth N.Baldwin@btinternet.com

fields.headline: Last orders for real beer
fields.trailText: The news that Bass, one of our oldest brewers, is to be sold to a giant foreign "theme pub" conglomerate should fill us all with dread (Bass falls to Interbrew, June 15).
fields.body:
The news that Bass, one of our oldest brewers, is to be sold to a giant foreign "theme pub" conglomerate should fill us all with dread (Bass falls to Interbrew, June 15). The guest beer legislation, which sought to protect smaller brewers, has been sidestepped by the big brewers (including Bass) selling their pub estates to corporate entities who continue to exclude the smaller brewers.

The Society of Independent Brewers commissioned me to survey beer drinkers' attitudes. We were startled to find that fewer than 1% of beer drinkers preferred "theme pubs". The survey revealed similar results when it came to the kinds of beer respondents liked to drink.

The fact is we are forced to drink watery, mass-produced "pish" through a combination of legislative incompetence, the crushing imperatives of big business and our susceptibility to insidious marketing techniques. As a result of this latest merger we can expect more "brands" in our pubs but they will all taste the same.

Peter Martin
Helios Marketing

fields.headline: Lake louts
fields.trailText: One can only agree with Martin Wainwright (Midnight charity hikers invade Lakes, June 16) that the antics and noise of late night walkers on the Lake District fells are deplorable, disturbing the peace that Wordsworth valued.
fields.body:
One can only agree with Martin Wainwright (Midnight charity hikers invade Lakes, June 16) that the antics and noise of late night walkers on the Lake District fells are deplorable, disturbing the peace that Wordsworth valued. Only recently, I read of a party held on Skiddaw in the late evening. Besides lighting a big bonfire, the revellers got very drunk, sang loudly, fired off guns, set fire to the vegetation, and didn't return until after midnight. Scandalous! Fortunately, most of their names are known. They include a Lord and Lady Sunderlin, R Southey, J Boswell, and one W Wordsworth. This happened on August 21 1815. I hope the National Trust is doing something about it.

Bill Sharrod
West Cumbria Field Centre

fields.headline: The taxman cometh in Pakistan
fields.standfirst: Pakistan: special report
fields.trailText: Pakistan's military rulers yesterday warned that they would enforce a new, broad tax regime despite widespread opposition in a country where tax evasion has become a national pastime.
fields.body:
Pakistan's military rulers yesterday warned that they would enforce a new, broad tax regime despite widespread opposition in a country where tax evasion has become a national pastime.

Wealthy farmers, many of whom still run their businesses under a feudal system, will have to pay tax this year for the first time.

Just 1.8m of Pakistan's 135m population pays tax.

Already the generals are locked in a bitter row with shopkeepers and traders who led a strike earlier this month against a survey of their well-hidden incomes and the imposition of a retail sales tax.

The powerful Islamic religious parties backed the strike and threaten to undermine the military's efforts to reform the economy and unlock international aid.

"No country can prosper whose citizens acquire wealth and income non-transparently," said the finance minister, Shaukat Aziz, in a television address as he announced the budget for the coming year. "Every citizen must share the cost of governance by paying a share of his income," added Mr Aziz, a widely-respected banker and former Citibank executive.

But he stopped short of setting a rate for the new agricultural tax, saying that would be decided by Pakistan's four provincial governments.

Since seizing power in a coup last October, the army head and chief executive of the government, General Pervez Musharraf, has had to put an economic recovery at the top of his agenda.

Pakistan's sickly economy came close to sliding into bankruptcy last year, and more than half the government's spending is still swallowed up in interest payments on its colossal foreign debt.

Defence spending takes up the next largest slice, leaving little room for development work. As a result the number of people living below the poverty line has more than doubled in the past decade to 44m.

Widening the tax burden would help meet the demands of lenders such as the International Monetary Fund, which has frozen credit since the coup. But it is certain to ignite opposition across the country.

Traders and shopkeepers closed down their businesses for two weeks in protest at the proposed new taxes, arguing that they would be forced to pay bribes to corrupt tax officials.

Although most of them have now returned to work after the military met some of their demands, the confrontation has been postponed but not resolved.

The influential Islamic party, Jamaat-i-Islami, has also come out against the new taxes.

"This budget will increase the misery of the common man," said Ghafoor Ahmed, a Jamaat leader, yesterday. "The government will face opposition from the agricultural community.

"Life has become more costly and the government is giving no security of jobs or of property. There is no welfare state. Most of the money is spent on debt servicing and defence, not on health or education or welfare. We should stop taking these foreign loans."

Gen Musharraf may not be able to risk angering the Islamists. Already he has backed down on changes to Pakistan's much-criticised blasphemy law because of opposition from the Islamic parties, and he is now coming under pressure to switch the weekly holiday from Sunday back to Friday.

And under the terms of a supreme court ruling announced early this year, Gen Musharraf must make Pakistan's economy completely free from interest charges under an Islamic banking system by next year.

In the budget, the military also raised defence spending by 11% to 159.6bn rupees (£2bn) for this year. That still falls well short of India's defence budget, which New Delhi has increased by 28% to £8.4bn.

"We do not want an arms race with India but it is necessary to maintain a credible defence," said Mr Aziz.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Offenders' names deleted
fields.body:
Offenders' names deleted

Details of 140,000 young offenders have been wiped off the national police computer. The blunder was described as "a weeding error" and the home secretary Jack Straw has ordered an inquiry. The Home Office insisted that there was a hard copy of all the information and that there would be no risk of people with criminal histories appearing to have clean records.

Unions fight racism at work

The TUC is launching a hotline for victims of racism in the workplace. It is the latest campaign from the unions following the murder of Stephen Lawrence whose mother Doreen will help launch the helpline. The TUC general secretary, John Monks, said: "Every worker should have the right to equal treatment and respect to get a job."

Threat to native woodlands

Britain's bluebell woods may soon disappear under the bulldozer, bigger farms or because of climate change, a report warns today. The Woodland Trust says 2% of Britain is now covered by ancient wood, half the area of the 30s.

Man held after student's death

A man was arrested yesterday in connection with the murder of a fellow student at Lancaster University. The woman, 44, was found with serious injuries at Furness College halls of residence.

Two share £7.3m

Two tickets shared Saturday's national lottery jackpot of £7.3m with numbers 4, 22, 24, 25, 40, 43. The bonus was 6. The Thunderball numbers were 3, 4, 11, 18, 31 plus Thunderball 2.

fields.headline: Hunt for stolen war children
fields.standfirst: An El Salvador priest is striving to unite families split by kidnap
fields.trailText: Ismelda Lainez dreamed of owning a pair of shoes and she loved long dresses. But at just six years old she was also angry and serious. When government troops bombed her home in Isle of Monte Cristo, northern El Salvador, she refused to run for shelter.
fields.byline: Lucy Jones  in Isle of Monte Cristo, El Salvador
fields.body:
Ismelda Lainez dreamed of owning a pair of shoes and she loved long dresses. But at just six years old she was also angry and serious. When government troops bombed her home in Isle of Monte Cristo, northern El Salvador, she refused to run for shelter.

Ismelda's family has no idea what she loves or hates these days. They last saw her in 1984 just before she vanished from a guerrilla-run hospital during a government attack. "When I buy clothes for my other children I become very sad remembering her request. I cry when I think of her," said her father, Jose Lainez, 44, a farm labourer.

There are 540 registered cases of children who went missing during El Salvador's 12-year civil war, which started in 1979. While 10 children have been found to have died, the Association for the Search of Disappeared Children in San Salvador has found more than 100 living with adoptive families in countries such as Britain, and it believes there are many more.

Government troops initially snatched the children from villages held by the rebel leftwing Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front in an attempt to force people into submission, according to the association and some retired army officials who have spoken out since the end of the civil war. But the kidnappers quickly realised that money could be made by putting the children up for adoption to foreign couples wishing to give a home to a "war orphan".

In the early 1980s, many Europeans and Americans travelled to the capital, San Salvador, to adopt children. They paid around £15,000 for a child and the official adoption papers, often unaware that the real parents were alive.

At least 6,000 children are thought to have left the country this way during the 12-year war. Many more are thought to have been secretly moved through Guatemala, smuggled out by illegal adoption rings.

After the conflict ended in early 1992, five families whose children went missing during la guinda de mayo - a nine-day battle in the guerrilla-controlled central Chalatenango district in which 54 children disappeared - asked the government to help find them, to no avail.

The government's inaction prompted Father Jon de Cortina, a chain-smoking priest from the Basque region in Spain, to set up the association. The first five children he found were living in orphanages in El Salvador; the next two were living in Germany, which led the association to widen its search to overseas.

Almost all of the 100 or so adopted children found by the association in Europe and the US have since visited relatives in El Salvador. "We do not intend these youngsters to come back and live with their natural families," Fr de Cortina said. "But they know they're not British, Swiss or from Belgium. We want them to know who they are and have an idea of their true identity. It's a very important human right."

However, for the parents who adopted the children, the news that their sons or daughters still have family in El Salvador comes as a huge shock.

"At first, I thought this was not my son they were talking about. I had no idea what Peter's thoughts would be, but he wanted to go the next day," said Kathleen Cassidy, who lives with her adopted 15-year-old son, Peter, in New Jersey.

Once reunited, the El Salvadorian parents struggle to stay in touch by trading photographs, or through telephone calls and letters; often their children do not speak Spanish and the parents themselves are illiterate.

But for those children who are still missing, the search goes on. Uncovering information is difficult, however; the army refuses to open its files and parties from across the political spectrum prefer not to discuss the issue.

There are some signs that the state may slowly be coming to grips with its past. El Salvador's human-rights ombudsman recently adopted a resolution that pinned the responsibility for the problem of the missing children on the armed forces.

It was the first time that any part of El Salvador's government had recognised that the forced disappearances took place during the war.

"We'll keep looking. We believe there to be many more children out there," said Fr de Cortina. "Sooner or later these children are going to realise there's something within him or herself that isn't clear; it's like having a psychological handicap. Knowing that they weren't abandoned, and [that they] have a family in El Salvador can help these children enter adulthood."

When government troops bombed her home in Isle of Monte Cristo, northern El Salvador, she refused to run for shelter. Ismelda's family has no idea what she loves or hates these days. I cry when I think of her," said her father, Jose Lainez, 44, a farm labourer. There are 540 registered cases of children who went missing during El Salvador's 12-year civil war, which started in 1979. While 10 children have been found to have died, the Association for the Search of Disappeared Children in San Salvador has found more than 100 living with adoptive families in countries such as Britain, and it believes there are many more. Government troops initially snatched the children from villages held by the rebel leftwing Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front in an attempt to force people into submission, according to the association and some retired army officials who have spoken out since the end of the civil war. But the kidnappers quickly realised that money could be made by putting the children up for adoption to foreign couples wishing to give a home to a "war orphan". In the early 1980s, many Europeans and Americans travelled to the capital, San Salvador, to adopt children. They paid around £15,000 for a child and the official adoption papers, often unaware that the real parents were alive. At least 6,000 children are thought to have left the country this way during the 12-year war. Many more are thought to have been secretly moved through Guatemala, smuggled out by illegal adoption rings. After the conflict ended in early 1992, five families whose children went missing during la guinda de mayo - a nine-day battle in the guerrilla-controlled central Chalatenango district in which 54 children disappeared - asked the government to help find them, to no avail. The government's inaction prompted Father Jon de Cortina, a chain-smoking priest from the Basque region in Spain, to set up the association. The first five children he found were living in orphanages in El Salvador; the next two were living in Germany, which led the association to widen its search to overseas. Almost all of the 100 or so adopted children found by the association in Europe and the US have since visited relatives in El Salvador. "We do not intend these youngsters to come back and live with their natural families," Fr de Cortina said. "But they know they're not British, Swiss or from Belgium. We want them to know who they are and have an idea of their true identity. It's a very important human right." However, for the parents who adopted the children, the news that their sons or daughters still have family in El Salvador comes as a huge shock. "At first, I thought this was not my son they were talking about. I had no idea what Peter's thoughts would be, but he wanted to go the next day," said Kathleen Cassidy, who lives with her adopted 15-year-old son, Peter, in New Jersey. Once reunited, the El Salvadorian parents struggle to stay in touch by trading photographs, or through telephone calls and letters; often their children do not speak Spanish and the parents themselves are illiterate. But for those children who are still missing, the search goes on. Uncovering information is difficult, however; the army refuses to open its files and parties from across the political spectrum prefer not to discuss the issue. There are some signs that the state may slowly be coming to grips with its past. El Salvador's human-rights ombudsman recently adopted a resolution that pinned the responsibility for the problem of the missing children on the armed forces. It was the first time that any part of El Salvador's government had recognised that the forced disappearances took place during the war. "We'll keep looking. We believe there to be many more children out there," said Fr de Cortina. "Sooner or later these children are going to realise there's something within him or herself that isn't clear; it's like having a psychological handicap. Knowing that they weren't abandoned, and [that they] have a family in El Salvador can help these children enter adulthood."
