fields.headline: Save the children
fields.standfirst: Most parents know smacking doesn't work, even while they're doing it. The government should take a bold lead and ban it
fields.trailText: Most parents know smacking doesn't work, even while they're doing it. The government should take a bold lead and ban it
fields.body:
The government faces a dilemma. It is required to change the law on smacking to provide children with greater protection from harm. A decision by the European court of human rights leaves it no choice. It ruled in 1998 on the case of a step father who had severely and repeatedly beaten his stepson with a pole but had been found not guilty by an English jury because of the old Victorian defence of "reasonable chastisement".

Labour ministers reacted robustly to the ruling, affirming that smacking had its place. That was partly because they fear public opinion will not countenance further restrictions on parents' right to discipline their children. When 88% of adults believe it is sometimes necessary to smack a naughty child, the government's freedom for manoeuvre seems slim. Yet the opinion data need to be read closely.

The government's own survey has shown that the vast majority of adults, 87%, think children should not be hit with any kind of implement. Almost all agree that children should not be hit on the head (98%), and that children under two should not be smacked at all (76%). Armed with such support, it would seem that government could at least outlaw such practices without fear of rebuff.

To ban the use of implements would also serve to reduce the legal uncertainty that has left parents unclear what level of punishment is permitted and what can lead to a criminal conviction. For while adults who have beaten a child with electrical flex, a belt or riding crop have recently been acquitted of any offence, others who have used a belt or hit on the thigh with a wooden spoon have been convicted.

The question is whether government could confidently go further and ban all kinds of physical punishment. The public's support for parents who feel it necessary to smack might suggest not. Yet 80% of adults also believe that smacking is not effective. So, while some parents smack because they think it works, others smack despite believing that it does not.

Are they right? A new study for the Institute of Public Policy Research by Professor Christina Lyon of the University of Liverpool reviews the research and suggests that smacking is not only ineffective but makes children's behaviour worse. The evidence is remarkably consistent in finding physical punishment to be a significant factor in the development of violent attitudes and behaviour both in childhood and in adult life. Smacking fails, in practice, to promote positive behaviour or self-discipline. Using the "what works" yardstick, the guiding principle of those working on crime reduction, smacking would earn a negative score.

Supporters of smacking insist that parents know the difference between a reasonable smack, which they believe is effective, and excessive violence. But the reality is that parents are seen to slip all too easily from one to the other; whether through lack of self-control or, like the courts, being unclear what level of punishment is "reasonable". Parents charged with abusing their children regularly claim in court that they were "only disciplining" their child.

Britain is not alone in having this debate. Eight European governments have banned all forms of physical punishment. In each case, they have done so ahead of public opinion, on the basis of professional advice. But law reform was not thrust on a sceptical public in isolation. It was accompanied by extensive guidance and support to parents on constructive alternative ways to guide their children's behaviour.

Where a ban has been in place long enough for its effect to be monitored, the impact has been shown to be positive. Parental practice has shifted towards non-physical means of disciplining their children and they have not been prosecuted for minor assaults. Early identification of children at risk of abuse has risen. The behaviour of children and adolescents has not deteriorated. In Sweden, it has at least coincided with some remarkable improvements, such as decline in teenage alcohol consumption. Most significantly for government, public opinion has swung from support for smacking, to opposition - 78% of Swedish adults now oppose smacking.

National surveys regularly ask the opinion of adults, rarely of young people themselves. No one likes to be hit, and pollsters may assume children would prefer parents to find alternatives. Recent research for the National Children's Bureau did indeed confirm that expectation. But it also revealed a greater level of unhappiness among young children than parents may realise. When you get smacked, it hurts deep inside. And children reported parents hitting them in a corner where no one else could see, detecting their parents' uncertainty about the acceptability of the punishment they were giving.

So smacking is neither effective nor safe. The majority of parents, while using it, know that it does not work. Children care more deeply than we realised and want their parents to find alternatives. The government genuinely wants to protect children, and to improve their behaviour. Meanwhile, other governments faced with this challenge have changed the law to ban all physical punishment and public support has followed. Does a Labour government, seeking re-election, have the courage to lead public opinion, or only to follow?

Sarah Spencer is director of the citizenship and governance programme at the Institute for Public Policy Research. Loving Smack or Lawful Assault by Christina Lyon is out today

s.spencer@ippr.org.uk

webTitle: Sails but no sales on France's oil spill coast

fields.headline: Sails but no sales on France's oil spill coast
fields.trailText: Tourists arriving at the Interlude camp site near the Atlantic port of La Rochelle are faced with what looks like an outdoor modern art exhibition.
fields.body:
Tourists arriving at the Interlude camp site near the Atlantic port of La Rochelle are faced with what looks like an outdoor modern art exhibition.

Odd-shaped, sand-coloured sails, with yacht-style rigging, have been scattered through the seaside site alongside the local pines.

"They really represent missing trees," the owner, Jean-François Mainaud, said.

"Three hundred of the 1,000 trees on the camp-site were swept away in the December storm. The sails will compensate for the lost shade, but unfortunately there is not much we can do about a more damaging image problem."

Even more than the storm, the site on the Ile de Ré, one of France's top Atlantic vacation destinations, is suffering from the oil slick from the sunken tanker, Erika, even though it is more than 100 miles from where the ship went down in the worst storm in living memory last Christmas.

"Only a few drops of oil reached La Rochelle but for foreigners the Atlantic coastline is all one piece, whether it's Britanny or Aquitaine," the Ile de Ré tourist director, Catherine Senand, said.

The Ile de Ré is in Charente-Maritime département, which is squeezed between the better-known Vendée to the north and Bordeaux's wine areas to the south. It has long been a favourite of the British, who account for 5% of the 3.5m summer holidaymakers strung along 100 miles of beach and more than 400 camping sites.

But adverse publicity over Erika and the destructive winter storm has cut bookings across an accommodation range dominated by camping sites that are now investing in hundreds of sails to create shade.

"The French know the local geography better and we will be packed out in July and August but we haven't stopped the drift of British, Germans and Dutch whom we depend on in spring and autumn," said Thiery Bouet, the Charente-Maritime tourist director.

Anxiety is likely to increase over the next few days following an official decision to close at least 11 beaches in Britanny and the Vendée because the damage caused by Erika has not yet been cleared up.

Concern over an oil slick which has not yet sullied the Charente-Maritime has at least deflected attention from lasting damage caused by the December 27 storm, in which 90mph winds killed more than 70 people across France and felled 10m trees.

The zone around the fortified port of La Rochelle took the full blow, tearing off roofs, causing floods, beaching more than 350 boats, destroying sand dunes and carrying so much salt air inland that trees which appeared untouched by the wind have withered and died.

"Much of the damage has been repaired with the help of workers sent from all over Europe but there is a still a titanic job ahead to clear devastated forests," the département's council chairman, Claude Belot, said.

The worst shock was to the Charente-Maritime's £120m-a-year oyster industry, where one sixth of the 60,000-tonne harvest was destroyed. Growers, some of whom lost two years' production, are awaiting £11m compensation.

France's passion for oysters has seen a marked decline since the oil slick, caused by fears about quality.

Marc Texier, a third-generation grower on the Ile d'Oléron, south of La Rochelle, said the crisis could hasten the drift of growers away from a food industry started by the Romans that employs 7,000 workers.

"It takes four years to raise oysters for the market and growers are lucky if they receive the minimum wage (about £600 a month) for a 70-hour week.

"Seeing so much work swept away by the storm will dishearten many who can't afford to repair damage to warehouses," Mr Texier said.

fields.headline: The best inquisition scene
fields.standfirst: Final destination
fields.trailText: Final destination
fields.body:
Having seen the majority of their classmates killed off in a plane crash - as foreseen by Alex Browning (Devon Sawa) - Alex and his fellow students Carter Horton (Kerr Smith), Billy Hitchcock (Sean William Scott) and Clear Rivers (Ali Larter) discuss the strange deaths of every other survivor. Convinced their deaths are part of a pattern, they grill Alex over the identity of the next victim while driving around town.

Carter, behind the wheel, is irate.

"Out of us, who's next to see it?"

Billy pipes up.

"Please tell me I'm going to get to see the Jets win a Superbowl."

"It's me, isn't it?" insists Carter. "That's why you're not saying."

Billy mutters to himself.

"I knew I should have hit on Tammy in the pool that time."

"He didn't say anything," exclaims Clear. "Just drive."

Carter's voice cracks.

"YOU HAVE A RESPONSIBILITY TO TELL ME!"

"Finally, Alex answers.

"It's going to make it easier to know?"

"Hey, you get off on having control over me. Now you let me decide how to deal with it."

"It doesn't matter who's next," Alex snaps. "Because we're all on the same list."

He stares out of the car window.

"All of us."

See also: Marathon Man, The Pit And The Pendulum, The Name Of The Rose

Don't see also: Red Dawn

Pointless trivia: Ali Larter took part in a 1996 hoax for American Esquire, posing as a Hollywood starlet called Allegra Coleman for an "expose" on PR-led film journalism.

More pointless trivia: Decon Sawa is quoted as being "totally into techno-rap"

fields.headline: The agony and the Edgbaston
fields.standfirst: Unpredictable bounce ensures predictable result as West Indian height and pace prevail
fields.trailText: Unpredictable bounce ensures predictable result as West Indian height and pace prevail. Mike Selvey reports.
fields.body:
The game of snakes and ladders continues. No sooner had England climbed the rungs against Zimbabwe than they came slithering down a giant anaconda at Edgbaston.

The debriefing meeting yesterday in the team's hotel - round about the time the fourth day's play should have been starting - must have made unpleasant listening.

England came out of the match with few plus points, although Nasser Hussain's assertion that those extended no further than Darren Gough is harsh on Mike Atherton, who for two hours on Saturday batted against Courtney Walsh and in particular Curtly Ambrose about as well as was humanly possible in the conditions. Nick Knight too top-scored in both innings, although as five West Indians managed more in their single innings than he had in both of England's it is best not to pursue that too far.

Already there have been the usual knee-jerk calls for wholesale changes, which is just nonsense. This is one match, at a venue which consistently poses unique problems.

Last summer in Birmingham, for instance, New Zealand lost inside three days and went on to win the series. And five years ago West Indies won the opening match of the summer at Headingley by nine wickets, but England came back and won the next at Lord's by 72 runs.

Came the following match at Edgbaston and, on a pitch little short of scandalous, England suffered greater traumas than ever they did over the past few days, losing by an innings and 64 runs before lunch on the third day - bowled out for 147 and 89 in 74.2 overs. Their response was to go to Old Trafford and square the series again.

Both teams know the one-off nature of test cricket at Edgbaston. As this match was drawing to its conclusion, Viv Richards was asked whether a losing side should be changed. His response was that, unless the conditions demand it, you should offer those who lost a match the chance to redeem themselves in the next. Only if they fail do you then consider moving on.

It is sound thinking and it would fly in the face of a policy of continuity started last winter if, say, Mark Ramprakash was not given an extended chance to learn the opener's role or Graeme Hick was jettisoned because of his pair in this game.

In the scheme of things, this was a match that England were never going to win after it became apparent what type of surface had been prepared. Once there is variable bounce then it is the tall bowlers, who deliver at pace but do not compromise on accuracy, who will prosper. Walsh and Ambrose, in other words.

In the first innings, when it was damp and the movement was lateral off the seam, they pursued a relentless line just outside off stump and a rigid length to a ring of close catchers. In the second innings, where the variable bounce was the key factor, they bowled straight and the dismissals reflected as much.

Whatever the conditions, however, there is no great secret to the success: the more straight throws the greater the chance of a coconut. England's batsmen did play some poor shots at times, and others received balls that were unplayable or batted as if expecting one. Each performance needs to be placed in context.

Consider Hussain, who in the second innings managed successive boundaries to third man off Ambrose from near identical deliveries by splicing the first through the hands of first slip as the ball rose sharply and toe-ending the second as it shot along the deck. It is hard to be pragmatic in such circumstances.

And look at Atherton, who had been given absolutely nothing hittable for two hours and knows that when a bad ball comes from a change bowler he has no option but to go for it irrespective of the variable bounce. He chopped on to his stumps. You do not condemn batsmen who encounter truly great bowlers on a surface as capricious as this.

Chastise the bowling, though, because, Gough and perhaps Andy Flintoff apart, it did not come close to matching West Indies' for accuracy, skill or sense of purpose. It allowed the tourists to escape from 136 for four, when Brian Lara's wicket fell and England were still in the match, to make 397.

And reserve contempt for a groundsman who yet again has produced a pitch that failed abysmally to meet the requirements of international cricket. This one was not dry at the start, apparently because of the wet weather on Wednesday. Well, poppycock: the pitch should have been dry already and ready to play a day early. One suspects it is kept damp deliberately to prevent it cracking too early.

The Warwickshire club are culpable and must be told that matches will be taken elsewhere if they cannot do better that this. Along with the game, a full house was lost yesterday and with it upwards of £500,000. English cricket can afford neither.

fields.bodyText: The game of snakes and ladders continues. No sooner had England climbed the rungs against Zimbabwe than they came slithering down a giant anaconda at Edgbaston. The debriefing meeting yesterday in the team's hotel - round about the time the fourth day's play should have been starting - must have made unpleasant listening. England came out of the match with few plus points, although Nasser Hussain's assertion that those extended no further than Darren Gough is harsh on Mike Atherton, who for two hours on Saturday batted against Courtney Walsh and in particular Curtly Ambrose about as well as was humanly possible in the conditions. Nick Knight too top-scored in both innings, although as five West Indians managed more in their single innings than he had in both of England's it is best not to pursue that too far. Already there have been the usual knee-jerk calls for wholesale changes, which is just nonsense. This is one match, at a venue which consistently poses unique problems. Last summer in Birmingham, for instance, New Zealand lost inside three days and went on to win the series. And five years ago West Indies won the opening match of the summer at Headingley by nine wickets, but England came back and won the next at Lord's by 72 runs. Came the following match at Edgbaston and, on a pitch little short of scandalous, England suffered greater traumas than ever they did over the past few days, losing by an innings and 64 runs before lunch on the third day - bowled out for 147 and 89 in 74.2 overs. Their response was to go to Old Trafford and square the series again. Both teams know the one-off nature of test cricket at Edgbaston. As this match was drawing to its conclusion, Viv Richards was asked whether a losing side should be changed. His response was that, unless the conditions demand it, you should offer those who lost a match the chance to redeem themselves in the next. Only if they fail do you then consider moving on. It is sound thinking and it would fly in the face of a policy of continuity started last winter if, say, Mark Ramprakash was not given an extended chance to learn the opener's role or Graeme Hick was jettisoned because of his pair in this game. In the scheme of things, this was a match that England were never going to win after it became apparent what type of surface had been prepared. Once there is variable bounce then it is the tall bowlers, who deliver at pace but do not compromise on accuracy, who will prosper. Walsh and Ambrose, in other words. In the first innings, when it was damp and the movement was lateral off the seam, they pursued a relentless line just outside off stump and a rigid length to a ring of close catchers. In the second innings, where the variable bounce was the key factor, they bowled straight and the dismissals reflected as much. Whatever the conditions, however, there is no great secret to the success: the more straight throws the greater the chance of a coconut. England's batsmen did play some poor shots at times, and others received balls that were unplayable or batted as if expecting one. Each performance needs to be placed in context. Consider Hussain, who in the second innings managed successive boundaries to third man off Ambrose from near identical deliveries by splicing the first through the hands of first slip as the ball rose sharply and toe-ending the second as it shot along the deck. It is hard to be pragmatic in such circumstances. And look at Atherton, who had been given absolutely nothing hittable for two hours and knows that when a bad ball comes from a change bowler he has no option but to go for it irrespective of the variable bounce. He chopped on to his stumps. You do not condemn batsmen who encounter truly great bowlers on a surface as capricious as this. Chastise the bowling, though, because, Gough and perhaps Andy Flintoff apart, it did not come close to matching West Indies' for accuracy, skill or sense of purpose. It allowed the tourists to escape from 136 for four, when Brian Lara's wicket fell and England were still in the match, to make 397. And reserve contempt for a groundsman who yet again has produced a pitch that failed abysmally to meet the requirements of international cricket. This one was not dry at the start, apparently because of the wet weather on Wednesday. Well, poppycock: the pitch should have been dry already and ready to play a day early. One suspects it is kept damp deliberately to prevent it cracking too early. The Warwickshire club are culpable and must be told that matches will be taken elsewhere if they cannot do better that this. Along with the game, a full house was lost yesterday and with it upwards of £500,000. English cricket can afford neither.
